webTitle: FA Cup: Tranmere v Southampton

fields.headline: Cup heroes back Aldridge to keep job
fields.trailText:
Tranmere v Southampton
John Aldridge received a vote of confidence as Tranmere look to claim their seventh Premiership scalp in recent seasons.
fields.body:
Tranmere should not sack John Aldridge if his team of Cup giantkillers are relegated from the First Division this season. So says Rovers' on-loan defender Richard Jobson who along with his team-mates, celebrated Saturday's FA Cup fifth-round draw at Premiership Southampton.

Tonight's replay at Prenton Park could take Tranmere's Premiership victims to seven in recent seasons and set up an enticing sixth-round meeting against Aldridge's old team Liverpool. But the prospect of relegation gives the former striker sleepless nights.

However, Jobson, outstanding on Saturday, believes that Aldridge is still the man for the job. "He has done wonders for Tranmere in the nearly five years he's been in charge. There's no point in looking at the situation over the past month or two. You've got to look at the overall picture. He definitely is the right man for the job. That's not in question."

Aldridge has injury worries ahead of today's game. Clint Hill is ruled out for a month and Dave Challinor is doubtful.

Southampton are down to bare bones, with Matt Oakley and Kevin Davies out injured, Tahar El Khalej away winning his 100th Moroccan cap and Dan Petrescu cup-tied.

Wycombe are almost sure to throw 19-year-old Ben Townsend into the fray in tonight's other FA Cup replay at Wimbledon, with the winners away to Leicester.

Lawrie Sanchez's return to his old club has been marred by an ankle injury sustained by right-back Mark Rogers in Saturday's controversial 2-2 draw. Gerard Lavin, another right-back on loan from Bristol City, is also injured.

Wimbledon's spirits, undermined by Saturday's draw, may be dealt another blow.

Financial pressures at the cash-strapped club could see yet another of their best players departing. Manchester City have been linked with a move for the Dons' Norwegian international midfielder Trond Andersen.

Meanwhile the team's veteran defender Alan Kimble will have a late fitness test before tonight's game.

webTitle: Highbury brawl to come under FA scrutiny

fields.headline: Highbury brawl to come under FA scrutiny
fields.trailText: The FA confirmed yesterday that it would investigate the mass fracas which broke out between Arsenal and Chelsea players during Sunday's FA Cup tie at Highbury.
fields.body:
The Football Association confirmed yesterday that it would investigate the mass fracas which broke out between Arsenal and Chelsea players during Sunday's FA Cup tie at Highbury.

Chelsea's defender Celestine Babayaro may also be in hot water as two incidents involving him but missed by the game's officials will also be considered. "The referee Graham Barber has sent in his match report and has asked us to look at an incident which could be alleged to be a mass confrontation," said the FA's spokesman Adrian Bevington.

"He has confirmed that he did not see a couple of incidents involving Celestine Babayaro. The FA will take a look at these incidents and consider whether to send a tape of them to the video advisory panel for their views."

Arsenal, who have had their fair share of disciplinary trouble, and Chelsea face fines of up to £250,000 if found guilty and individuals, not least Babayaro, may also be cited for misconduct once there has been an official review.

Babayaro could be banned for three matches if found guilty of violent conduct in either incident. The Nigerian has been accused of deliberately treading on Fredrik Ljungberg's ankle and also appeared to flick out a boot, tripping up Dennis Bergkamp.

The FA has also asked to look at the video of a mass brawl during Saturday's 1-1 draw between Crystal Palace and Norwich. Both clubs have already been found guilty of similar charges this season.

Dave Bassett has withdrawn from the race for the QPR manager's job after talks with the club. The winner from a shortlist of Steve Bruce, Iain Dowie, Steve Coppell, Ian Holloway and Graham Rix should be announced tomorrow.

Charlton's Shaun Newton, with more than 200 games for the club, has been transfer-listed at his own request due to a lack of first-team football. "I understand his position and have reluctantly agreed to his request," said the manager Alan Curbishley.

Blackburn Rovers have been in talks with Benfica's Ukraine midfielder Sergei Kandaurov.

Brighton have rejected a club-record offer of £1.5m from Wigan Athletic for their striker Bobby Zamora.

webTitle: Manchester United 1 - 1 Valencia

fields.headline: Manchester United 1 - 1 Valencia
fields.standfirst:
Group A
Richard Williams' view
David Lacey's match report
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Manchester United: 1-Fabien Barthez; 2-Gary Neville, 6-Jaap Stam, 24-Wes Brown, 27-Mikael Silvestre; 7-David Beckham, 18-Paul Scholes, 16-Roy Keane, 11-Ryan Giggs; 10-Teddy Sheringham, 9-Andy Cole. Subs: Rachubka, Irwin, Butt, Phil Neville, Yorke, Solskjaer, Chadwick.

Valencia: 1-Santiago Canizares; 20-Jocelyn Angloma, 12-Fabian Ayala, 2-Mauricio Pellegrino, 15-Amedeo Carboni; 10-Miguel Angel Angulo, 6-Gaizka Mendieta, 19-Ruben Baraja, 18-Kily Gonzalez; 35-Pablo Aimar, 7-John Carew. Subs: Palop, Deschamps, Djukic, Zahovic, Alonso, Vicente, Albelda.

Referee: Hellmut Krug (Germany)

1 No injury worries for United as they attempt to capitalise on their week-long break against a Valencia side playing on the back of a 10-hour journey from the Canary Islands, the location of the Spanish side's last league game. United kick-off and spray the ball wide to the right.
2 Silvestre plays in Cole 20 yards out, Cole rolls it on to Scholes in the area, and Scholes lays it off for Sheringham to miss a close-range chance.
4 Cole attempts to get around the back but Angloma runs him off the ball.
5 Giggs crosses from the left, high into the six-yard box but Sheringham is deemed to have fouled Canizares in the Valencia goal.
6 Good chance for Kily as he shoots over from 15 yards after being played in by Aimar.
8 Stam stops Aimar dead 30 yards out.
9 Neville, his goal against Aston Villa last month fresh in his mind, skips down the right past Kily and fires in a right-foot shot across the face of goal.
12 GOAL: Manchester United 1 - 0 Valencia Giggs finds Cole 20 yards out, Cole returns it, Canizares thinks that Giggs is about to shoot and shapes up just as Giggs passes to the on-running Cole again for the United striker to slide the ball home with his right foot at the near post.
17 Valencia free-kick after Beckham tussles with Kily near the centre circle. Baraca takes into the area, cleared for Kily to have a crack from distance; over the bar
18 Substitution Butt on for Giggs, who has tweaked his hamstring.
19 Sheringham wide on the left releases Cole through the middle. Cole gets behind Pellegrino depite an unnlucky bounce but shoots straight at Canizares. Possibly a better chance than the one that led to his goal.
24 United pinned back in their own half as Valencia get themselves together.
25 Great sweeping move by Valencia brings the ball out from their own half to the edge of the United area. Baraca finds Mendieta, who immediately releases Aimar into space with only Barthez to beat from an angle, but he shoots well wide of the far post
28 Baraca lobs the ball over the top to Carew in space on the far right side of the United area; Silvestre comes sliding in to disposess.
30 Aimar very unlucky to be caught offside when he would have been away on goal.
33 Butt gives away a free-kick 35 yards out; Valencia immediately win another 25 yards out and square-on to goal but Mendieta fails to to hit the target.
36 Beckham momentarily distracted wide on the right when he spots the linesman's stupendous moustache.
38 Sheringham floored by a knee in the back from Ayala; bizarrely, Sheringham is penalised.
39 United show signs of sitting back - bags of space opening up on the left for the home team but no one too willing to use it. Doesn't help having Giggs off the field.
40 Kily plays it out left from the edge of the area for Carboni to cross; wins a corner. Comes to nothing. Continued Valencia pressure before United break through the middle. Ends with Butt having a go from distance - straight at Canizares.
43 Valencia free-kick just outside the United area. Aimar thumps it and Barthez claims on the half-volley.
45 Another free-kick for Valencia in United's half; comes to nothing. Lots of movement from Valencia in response to United giving the ball away too much. Half-time.

46 Valencia get the second half underway. Scholes and Cole work the ball down the left before Cole is caught offside.
48 Silvestre starts to push up on the left in an attempt to fill the hole left by Giggs. 49 Booking Butt for chopping down Mendieta.
50 Kily does well to get past Beckham and Keane to the left of the United area. He plays a one-two and shoots for Barthez to save.
51 Keane pulls the ball back for Butt to shoot from 20 yards out; deflected clear.
53 Carboni plays a one-two with Aimar deep on the left for Valencia, but his great cross across the face of goal finds no one.
54 Valencia corner. Mendieta takes, Pellegrino heads down for Butt to clear; played back in for Barthez to claim.
59 Sweeping move involving Sheringham and Keane in the middle of the park allows Silvestre to get away and cross from near the by-line.
62 Stam gets in a cross from the by-line but Valencia clear.
63 Booking / substitution Beckham / Solskjaer on for Sheringham.
65 Substitution Sanchez on for Angulo.
66 United now effectively playing with only one up front and a five-man midfield.
68 Keane slices at a shot from a Solskjaer cross on the left.
69 Solskjaer burgles Angloma in the middle of the pitch; United get the edge of the area but the pitch lets them down and Valencia clear. Lots of huff and puff this half but nothing to raise the blood pressure.
71 Solskjaer races down the left, gets away from Angloma and crosses across the face of goal after Cole fails to get a touch.
74 Booking Baraca after he has a go at Beckham for a challenge in which the United player in fact got a foot on the ball, despite going in heavily. Lots of nattering at the ref from Valencia players, so the ref feels obliged to have a word with Beckham.
76 Substitution Vicente on for Kily.
78 Beckham avoids rising to the challenge after Carboni hacked him down and earned himself a booking.
80 Neville does well to get the better of Vicente near the by-line and cross through the six-yard box; Cole unable to get a touch.
86 Baraca denied an equaliser when he gets his head to a cross and Scholes clears off the line.
87 OWN GOAL: Manchester United 1 - 1 Valencia Bummer for United; Wes Brown deflected in from a Vicente close-range effort.
89 Abelda on for Aimar.
90 Not a lot to play for now as both teams try to make sure they don't lose. Pretty dull stuff for the entire match in fact, but full credit to Valencia for plugging away and forcing a point in a game that never really took off.
Full-time: Manchester United 1 - 1 Valencia.

webTitle: Come on City - or Bush's number could be up

fields.headline: Come on City - or Bush's number could be up
fields.trailText: Tottenham's vaguely New Age, year-that-ends-in-one philosophy isn't half of it. The numerological possibilities for football know no bounds.
fields.body:
Professional football is not an area in which you might expect to find adherents of New Age philosophies. Yet when it comes to numerology the game is a torch-bearer. Certainly other sports dabble in the belief that numbers shape our destiny. The NBA star Dennis Rodman, for example, argued relentlessly for the right to have 69 on the back of his vest, presumably because of the clarity and direction associated with figures divisible by three.

In cricket, meanwhile, the score 111 is considered unlucky and causes umpire David Shepherd to hop up and down in a bid to fight off its evil effects. According to ancient lore 111 is a Nelson, because the hero of Trafalgar had one eye, one arm and one leg. Study of pictures of the admiral, however, tends to support the opinion that he was actually fully equipped when it came to lower limbs. The ill-favoured number then should clearly be 112. It is an error that has undoubtedly cost England hundreds of Test match victories.

But while cricket and basketball may hold sincere views on the mystical power of numbers they are clearly not as enmeshed in numerological wisdom as football folk. Which is why last week (and this week and no doubt for several months to come) we were assailed on all sides by fans, players and pundits eager to alert us to the paranormal effects that A Year That Ends In One has in N17, London.

There are two things that everybody knows about Tottenham Hotspur. The first is that at White Hart Lane the punters love elegant, attacking football. While this fondness for entertainment is in many ways admirable, I can't help thinking it betrays a lack of originality. I mean, is there a set of supporters in the world that don't like elegant, attractive football?

In the 60s, for example, Internazionale achieved unprecedented domestic and European success under Helenio Herrera, high priest of catenaccio . But does every high-scoring game at the San Siro these days provoke the Milanese equivalent of Richard Littlejohn to bellow, "In case you haven't noticed, Mr Tardelli, Inter fans are connoisseurs of brutally uncompromising negative football - 4-3 versus Perugia! It's just not the nerazzurri way. And it never will be"?

Somehow I doubt it. The second thing everybody knows about Spurs is that they always fancy their chances of winning something in A Year That Ends In One. This is obviously more imaginative. It's no myth either, for the facts bear it out.

Tottenham have claimed eight major trophies in years ending with a single. It is easy to knock these things, of course, for as the wise old man remarked, "It takes 27 facial muscles to smile, but only two fingers to register contempt."

And no doubt some readers will be snorting and muttering, "So what? On the basis of the past decade Manchester United might expect to win something whenever the year ends in a number."

I am not so sceptical. My only complaint is that A Year That Ends In One is too much in the limelight. Personally I would like to see some other amazing facts given a regular airing.

Perhaps we might be told more often that Huddersfield Town are at their most potent when the decade begins with a two, that if the Queen outlives the Duke of Edinburgh it could bring Cup glory back to Ewood Park, Rovers generally being at their swashbuckling best when an elderly widow sits on the throne, or that a top-four league finish by Middlesbrough usually heralds a world war.

And then there is Sunderland's mysterious record in the Cup. They won it in 1937 and 1973. Which means that since the demise of 1873's victors, The Wanderers, the Wearsiders reign supreme in the competition in years when the last two digits multiplied together make 21. Based on this stunning piece of knowledge I expect that the club will soon take a leaf out of Man United's book and reserve their hotel rooms in London 36 years in advance.

People might also like to ponder the following worrying juxtaposition. In September 1901 President William McKinley is assassinated. The following spring Manchester City are relegated from Division One. In April 1963 Manchester City go down from top flight. Seven months later John F Kennedy is shot. It is possible to read too much into these things, of course, but in my view Joe Royle would be well advised to start campaigning for tighter gun controls in the US, while George Bush should divert some overseas aid in the direction of Maine Road.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

Which means that since the demise of 1873's victors, The Wanderers, the Wearsiders reign supreme in the competition in years when the last two digits multiplied together make 21. Based on this stunning piece of knowledge I expect that the club will soon take a leaf out of Man United's book and reserve their hotel rooms in London 36 years in advance. People might also like to ponder the following worrying juxtaposition. In September 1901 President William McKinley is assassinated. The following spring Manchester City are relegated from Division One. In April 1963 Manchester City go down from top flight. Seven months later John F Kennedy is shot. It is possible to read too much into these things, of course, but in my view Joe Royle would be well advised to start campaigning for tighter gun controls in the US, while George Bush should divert some overseas aid in the direction of Maine Road.  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: Champions League preview: Man Utd v Valencia

fields.headline: United plan show of strength as Ferguson looks for a headstart
fields.trailText: David Lacey on how Sir Alex Ferguson will try to reap the benefit of early qualification for the quarter-finals tonight.
fields.body:
If it were done when 'tis done, then 'twere well it were done quickly. Sir Alex Ferguson may be disinclined to invoke Macbeth before his players face Valencia at Old Trafford tonight but the benefit of early qualification for the quarter-finals of the Champions League should be obvious enough.

A win would assure Manchester United of a place in the last eight with two games to spare, providing a bigger breathing space in which to prepare for the knockout stage.

The season is panning out well for Ferguson's dream of winning the European Cup a second time before he retires. Out of the FA Cup, United have enjoyed a weekend off between meetings with Valencia and a victory tonight would ease the pressure for the visit to Athens to play Panathinaikos a fortnight tomorrow.

Not that beating Valencia is a formality. While a draw would not disappoint Hector Cuper and his side, defeat would expose them to a late surge from the Greeks or Sturm Graz. So it will be in Cuper's interest to renew last week's attempts to curb the influence on the wings of David Beckham and Ryan Giggs.

Here Valencia half-succeeded. While Beckham found his attempts to move forward for the best angle of cross stifled by Amedeo Carboni, the 35-year-old Jocelyn Angloma could not match Giggs for speed.

In Valencia, United were largely content to play out their second successive scoreless draw at the Mestalla stadium. Tonight they will be more ambitious, which means Roy Keane and Paul Scholes getting forward to help Teddy Sheringham and Andy Cole.

Much will depend on Giggs's ability to get behind defenders consistently. That said, memories of Real Madrid's 3-2 win at Old Trafford, when they knocked out the holders in last season's quarter-finals, remain sufficiently stark for Ferguson to demand a degree of caution.

"The incentive to get into the quarter-finals is something that will drive us on," the United manager said yesterday, "but we will have to try and understand what tactics our opponents may use.

"I hope we have improved from last year and I think that if we were playing Real at home again we would play differently from a defensive point of view. Against Real we got caught on the counter-attack too many times."

Since Valencia are natural counterpunchers United will trust that Keane retains his present omnipotent form while Sheringham and Cole find the opportunities they were denied in Valencia.

Manchester United (probable, 4-4-2): Barthez; G Neville, Stam, Brown, Silvestre; Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Cole, Sheringham.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Simon
fields.trailText: What did I say about New Zealand? Didn't I say don't bother with it? Didn't I tell you it's nothing but wind and rain and hills full of bored looking sheep? And then you go and book a flight there. Are you nuts? Do youself a huge favour - for God's sake stay in Sydney for Mardi Gras rather than freeze in some shack in NZ. Really, one day you'll thank me for this.
fields.body:
Milly, Milly, Milly,

What did I say about New Zealand? Didn't I say don't bother with it? Didn't I tell you it's nothing but wind and rain and hills full of bored looking sheep? And then you go and book a flight there. Are you nuts?

You've obviously fallen for the charms of that snake-in-the-grass Sam, and he's not letting on how wet and boring it all is. Why do you think the travel agent man had trouble getting you a flight? Why do you think no-one else wants to fly there? It might be something to do with there being nothing of any interest to do when you get there, or it could just be cos it's wet and cold for nine months of the year and you've just missed the other three.

Do youself a huge favour - even if you ain't gonna schlep over to Perth, for God's sake stay in Sydney for Mardi Gras rather than freeze in some shack in NZ. Really, one day you'll thank me for this.

Simon

webTitle: British tourists die in Tasmania bus plunge

fields.headline: British tourists die in Tasmania bus plunge
fields.standfirst: Dirt track deaths of wildlife watchers bring safety calls
fields.trailText: Tour operators claim that some of the Cradle Mountain national park's narrow gravel roads are inadequate for the 140,000 holidaymakers who visit the region each year, and say that more needs to be done to protect the safety of the growing number of wilderness tourists.
fields.body:
Three British tourists were among four people killed when a bus taking holiday-makers on a nocturnal wildlife trip in Tasmania plunged off a narrow dirt track and rolled down an embankment.

Two of the dead were a couple from Scotland. The third British victim was Judith Franklin, 63, from Little Abington, near Cambridge. Her 67-year-old husband, Colin, was treated in hospital for minor injuries.

All 14 others in the minibus, including the guide and 23-year-old driver, were injured in the crash on Sunday night in the Cradle Mountain national park, north west Tasmania. Hobart police said three Australians and three Britons remained in hospital last night. One British woman was in a critical condition.

The party, including tourists from the US and New Zealand, was on a guided search for Tasmanian devils, Bennett's wallabies and wombats that make up the region's unique nocturnal wildlife.

Their bus pulled to one side of the road to let a national parks vehicle pass.

Colin and Judith Franklin's son, Stephen, spoke to his father on the telephone after the accident. "He remembers the bus pulling over and then the front wheel just started to slide," he said.

Inspector Matthew Richman of Hobart police said: "The bus appears to have toppled from the road and rolled down some 33 metres, coming to rest upside down against a tree."

Parks and wildlife spokesman Hank Schinkel said the ranger in the other vehicle noticed the Mazda minibus had disappeared from view, and raised the alarm when he returned to find it crashed.

Inspector Richman said police had yet to determine the precise cause of the accident, which happened on a dry road in clear weather, but confirmed there was no collision involved and no mechanical failure.

Rod Stendrup, general manager of Cradle Mountain lodge, which organised the evening tour of the world heritage-listed national park, said the accident was "very distressing".

He said the night tours were a long-established attraction and his staff knew the roads well. "Unfortunately something went wrong last night. It's quite a narrow section of road and it drops off very sharply. The bus, from what I understand, stopped to let a car go the other way and the edge of the road just crumbled and it rolled over."

Mr Stendrup said the dirt road was wide enough for two vehicles to pass slowly. Inspector Richman said it was too early to say whether the edge of the dirt road had collapsed, causing the bus to overturn. The busy tourist track was shut for most of yesterday as police accident investigators and a coroner examined the site of the accident, three miles from the Cradle Mountain visitor centre.

Police admitted the rescue effort was hampered by a lack of light on the remote road until a generator arrived several hours after rescue crews reached the bus.

Tour operators claimed that some of the national park's narrow gravel roads were inadequate for the 140,000 holidaymakers who visit the region each year and said more needed to be done to protect the safety of the growing number of wilderness tourists. "There have certainly been increased numbers in the [Cradle Mountain national] park in the last couple of years and because of that there's a lot more traffic," said Chris Purtell of Tasmanian Expeditions. "Unfortunately, sometimes it takes something as tragic as this for action to be taken."

webTitle: Family doctors 'failing to meet needs of carers'

fields.headline: Family doctors 'failing to meet needs of carers'
fields.trailText: Family doctors are failing to meet the health needs of the UK's 5.7m carers and are unlikely to meet the government's revised April 2002 target for identifying carers in their locality, according to a survey seen exclusively by SocietyGuardian.
fields.body:
Family doctors are failing to meet the health needs of the UK's 5.7m carers and are unlikely to meet the government's revised April 2002 target for identifying carers in their locality, according to a survey seen exclusively by SocietyGuardian.

The survey report, Primary Care Support to Carers, from the Carers National Association's (CNA) north of England region, found that the NHS is slow to respond to government initiatives to recognise and support carers compared with social services departments and voluntary agencies. The charity believes the findings are indicative of the entire country.

The report - based on questionnaire responses from 23 organisations supporting carers in the north of England - comes a day before the CNA launches its election manifesto and ahead of the implementation of the Carers and Disabled Children Act 2000. The Act comes into force in April and gives local authorities powers to provide services directly to carers.

Technology problems and GPs' perceptions that they will not be able to meet carers' needs have been blamed on the poor response in identifying carers, says the report. The report also found that some carers are wary of being tagged by GPs, fearing the information may be used to judge their ability to care.

Identifying carers - "tagging" - was introduced under the Department of Health's national priorities guidance in 1998, which required GPs to identify carers by April 2000 in a bid to ensure that carers receive adequate support. The deadline was extended due to concerns over the Data Protection Act, information technology and confidentiality.

While some health agencies were embracing the new guidance - through carers clinics, staff awareness training and other moves - most were not, says the report.

It calls for:
 the Department of Health to issue prompt guidance to health authorities, primary care groups (PCGs) and primary care trusts on how to identify carers to meet the 2002 deadline;
 PCGs to involve carers in decision-making; to set out action plans to address carers needs; and fund initiatives to identify and support carers;
 the NHS Executive regional offices and health authorities to monitor PCG progress on carers; and ensure that postgraduate training and education addresses the needs of carers
 carers' organisations to ensure that PCGs are kept informed of policy developments affecting carers; assisted in involving carers in decision-making;
 carers' organisations to help PCGs find practical ways of identifying and supporting carers and understanding their needs.

"This study demonstrates that positive developments are taking place by primary care staff and primary care groups to improve the identification and support of carers," said CNA chief executive Diana Whitworth. "However the progress is piecemeal with differences within areas as well as between areas."

Both the British Medical Association (BMA) and the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) admit it is unlikely GPs will meet the government's target.

Dr Paul Davies, vice chairperson of the RCGP, said: "Most GPs are not making this a major priority, there's so many national guidances and imperatives, that meeting all of them, given the workforce situation we have, is an impossibility."

And Dr Andrew Dearden, chairperson of the BMA's committee on community care, said: "What is needed is a schools campaign, a publicity campaign and to get social services, the NHS and the Benefits Agency all talking to each other because it doesn't matter who identifies carers but that they are identified."

webTitle: From: Lynn (18 Feb)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Lynn
fields.trailText: I have just been catching up with your travels. I emailed you a few weeks ago to say that, inspired by your example, we booked two weeks in India. It was an incredible experience. I am grateful to you for being my inspiration and convincing me that 51 (had 52nd birthday in Varanasi) is not too old.
fields.body:
Sue -

I have just been catching up with your travels. I emailed you a few weeks ago to say that, inspired by your example, we booked two weeks in India. Now we are looking back on it, it was an incredible experience.

We started in Delhi, got the train to Agra (Taj Mahal exceeded all expectations), train to Jhansi, four hour drive to Khajuraho (discovered sole rule of the road which is that the heaviest vehicle gets priority). Amazing erotic sculptures. Flew to Varanasi and took the obligatory dawn boat ride. Then, the best bit, met Jen (she emailed you about Juhu beach, she has been working in Mumbai during her gap year). We walked the length of the ghats, travelled by second class sleeper 15 hours to Calcutta (as soon as we arrived I made her trade in our return tickets for AC2), and took a three day boat trip to the Sunderbans, hoping to see tigers. We were the only westerners on the boat trip, and I very quickly had to learn how to eat with my right hand as there were no concessions for Europeans.

The whole trip was unforgettable - my husband and I are still recovering from it! Jen has now gone on to Thailand, but has said she will come home at the end of May as she knows she has to get some money together before going to uni. Her time away has turned her into a mature, confident and capable person, and we now have a relationship of equals rather than mother and daughter, particularly as she had to hold my hand in Calcutta so I did not get lost or run over.

Don't feel you have to reply to this; I am just grateful to you for being my inspiration and convincing me that 51 (had 52nd birthday in Varanasi) is not too old.

Hi Sam,

I see that you're off to Byron - it's fab there. Have a look at the Belongil Beach House - great hostel, bit of a walk along the beach but worth it for the fab cafe attached to it. You took my advice on dolphins so trust me on this one! It's also worth hiring a bike and cycling up to the lighthouse - requires a bit of effort but it is worth it as you may get to see whales coming up the coast.

Byron rocks, and if you want to stay somewhere a bit off the wall try the Arts Factory. Also has a good outdoor cinema. Word of warning - don't learn to dive here, I tried and nearly drowned. They try and rush you through a three day course - it isn't long enough. enjoy.

I'm very jealous. Keep the news coming.

Jane.

webTitle: Downturn in profits will see US charities suffer

fields.headline: Downturn in profits will see US charities suffer
fields.trailText: Charities are set to suffer financially after several major US charitable foundations reported a downturn in asset income - the first decline in 10 years - caused by a collapse in hi-tech share prices.
fields.body:
Charities are set to suffer financially after several major US charitable foundations reported a downturn in asset income - the first decline in 10 years - caused by a collapse in hi-tech share prices.

The foundations are expected to wind down the level of grants and awards in the wake of the downturn.

Fifty-five per cent of the 142 foundations in the study, to be published in the Chronicle of Philanthropy this week, said they expected their giving to stay static or drop this year. A similar percentage said their assets had shrunk in the past 12 months.

The Chronicle says: "Large grants and new long-term awards could be the first to be jettisoned as foundations adjust their spending to slower growth or losses in asset values."

This is seen as a worrying sign for the US charitable sector as foundations are usually considered a bedrock of support in times of economic downturn because of their steady asset base. However, some high profile foundations have themselves lost income in the fallout from dot.com failures.

The assets of the David and Lucile Packard Foundation dropped by 25% last year - most of its investments were in Hewlett-Packard, the business and home computer hardware company, and its subsidiary, technology firm Agilent.

The Paul G Allen Foundation - set up by billionaire Microsoft founder Paul Allen - also saw its assets drop by 39%.

The overall decline of the biggest foundations' assets was 0.3% but this figure is skewed by the success of the two largest foundations, William H Gates and the Lilly Endowment.

The William H Gates Foundation set up by chairman of Microsoft, Bill Gates, donated $34m in cash and $200m in software last year.

The overall decline of the biggest foundations' assets was 0.3% but this figure is skewed by the success of the two largest foundations, William H Gates and the Lilly Endowment. The William H Gates Foundation set up by chairman of Microsoft, Bill Gates, donated $34m in cash and $200m in software last year.

Dear Sue,

I don't know what your plans are for Bali, but I would recommend going to Tirta Gangga, on the eastern side of the island, near Amlapura. webTitle: Blair accuses 'lazy' critics on the left of self-mutilation

fields.headline: Blair accuses 'lazy' critics on the left of self-mutilation
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair today warns leftwing critics of his "third way" ambition to reconcile market economics with social justice that their willingness to join forces with the right amounts to "a curious form of self-mutilation".
fields.body:
Tony Blair today warns leftwing critics of his "third way" ambition to reconcile market economics with social justice that their willingness to join forces with the right amounts to "a curious form of self-mutilation".

Mr Blair uses an article in the monthly magazine, Prospect, to set out his stall in ways which will infuriate enemies as diverse as Tony Benn, Ken Livingstone and Lord Hattersley.

"Constructive criticism is healthy, lazy negativism is not," he warns his unnamed opponents.

The prime minister claims that his third way "was always intended to renew and modernise progressive politics, not find a soggy compromise between left and right.

"Ideas are the key; and the tide of ideas is flowing in our direction," Mr Blair says, days before he meets the new hope of the right, US president George Bush. In his article he claims that the third way reflects the global centre-left's response to the collapse of communism and - in the west - the growing understanding of markets.

Yet when planning and public ownership receded "it seemed easier for the left to opt out of serious economics". That was "a position of wholly unnecessary defeatism and weakness.

"For the right to attack (us) is eminently sensible" since a revitalised centre-left will marginalise the right, "but for the left itself to join in is a curious form of self-mutilation".

In a fresh display of impatience with internal Labour attacks the prime minister also takes a swipe at opponents of the new technologies, includuing genetically-modified (GM) crops, as "extreme greens who are anti-science fundamentalists".

Instead he lists "the challenge of harnessing the new technologies to create wealth and meet human need" as the first of six major issues which progressive governments must tackle.

The other five are: transforming education to create "a culture of high expectation" for all; tackling inequality; modernising government beyond the old one-size-fits-all model; overcoming democratic alienation; and engaging in international cooperation as "a matter of morality and enlightened self-interest".

webTitle: Extract from Did Things Get Better? (II)

fields.headline: Things got a little fairer
fields.standfirst:
Our second extract from a new book assessing Labour's performance in government shows that it has helped the worst-off the most
Extract one: Well, did things get better?
Extract three: environment
Extract four: crime
Extract five: health
Polly Toynbee and David Walker pick their top 10 politics books
fields.trailText: Our second extract from a new book assessing Labour's performance in government shows that it has helped the worst-off the most.
fields.body:
A month after he took office, Tony Blair walked up a newly disinfected stairway on the Aylesbury estate in the urban wastelands of Peckham, south London. There he made his great promise to the poor: "No forgotten people and no no-hope areas." He staked his success on leaving behind "a fairer country".

Is it? The distribution of income, let alone wealth, is probably no more equitable; if anything the gap between top and bottom has widened. But the poorest households have benefited disproportion ately from the government's changes in taxes and social benefits, as the chart shows.

Labour's inheritance was certainly grim. While Labour was out of office 8m more people became poor on official definitions. While average incomes rose by 40%, those of the poorest stayed static. A third of all UK children were born into poverty.

To plumb the depths, Labour commissioned a domesday book of poverty, measuring every ward in England for a mighty index of deprivation - this will become a benchmark for all successive administrations. Ministers certainly tried. Though poverty was not something Labour talked about much in public, from the start battalions of hyper-active ministers set about attacking urban conditions with myriad programmes.

Employment, education and health action zones were given extra money, criss-crossing one another until researchers found there were no control zones where nothing was happening against which to judge their success. The social exclusion unit set up at the very heart of Whitehall pumped out projects with stiff targets for halving teenage pregnancy, school exclusion, truancy and rough sleepers, aimed at cutting off the paths into poverty. Initiatives flowed out, each allocated lump sums: the media soon lost count and then lost interest.

If this government is not primarily identified with abolishing poverty, it is mainly its own fault for sending out such mixed messages. The cut in lone parent benefits demanded by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, early in the government's life was followed by an equally politically misleading cut in disability benefits.

The sums were trifling, but the cabinet wanted to be seen to be "reforming" social security. Yet despite Tory rhetoric, the social security bill was not some huge drain on resources, at just 13% of GDP compared with an average of 19% across the European Union. Plummeting unemployment saw the bill fall slightly from £100bn to £99bn. It would have fallen further but for large increases willed by Labour: in income support (up a real 72% for children), child benefit (up 25%) and pensions (up 30% for the poorest).

Greatly increased in-work benefits would have seen the total bill for social supports rise further but these were hidden away in the accounts of the Inland Revenue, re-badged as tax credits. Their effects were real enough: working families tax credit brought an average £24 a week extra to low-paid families, child tax credits brought a further £520 a year.

Labour's £5bn windfall tax on the privatised utilities financed far more than the New Deal, aimed initially at 250,000 unemployed under-25s. Independent studies say many young people would have found work anyway, but 160,000 got into jobs at least six months sooner than they would have done without the programme. The New Deal for over-25s doubled the number into jobs at a very reasonable cost of £4,000 each. New Deals for lone par ents, the over-50s and disabled people followed.

Destiny starts at birth, Labour said. Before they are two years old, children from the top social classes are already 14% ahead of the bottom classes in terms of development. The first generation born under Labour's programmes ought to break that cycle of deprivation. Sure Start (costing £580m) is designed to catch depressed mothers and failing families in the poorest areas with support at home and in nurseries. American research showed how intensive help for two nursery years saved seven times the sums spent later on social security and crime for those children.

During the past four years, all four-year-olds were given nursery places, with three-year-olds to follow. The national childcare strategy promises 1m after-school, homework and holiday schemes. Connexions, for 11-25-year-olds, offers a further safety net. But Connexions gets going in earnest only this year.

Back on the Aylesbury estate, just one of 2,000 worst estates, how much change have residents yet seen? Policy no longer forgets them. More money has arrived through the various zones. Crime is down, though few realise it. The local primary school has had excellent results recently. Pensioners and families have more money in their household budgets, more people have jobs. The New Deal for communities has given the estate £56m - but, as elsewhere, the money sits in the bank while a local committee makes plans.

It all takes time and it all started two years too late. Few residents claim signs of improvement yet. The air is thick with promises, delivery yet to come.

webTitle: A month of woe, but Labour lead soars to 15%

fields.headline: A month of woe, but Labour lead soars to 15%
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Labour's lead over the Conservatives has leapt to 15 points - an increase of five points in the last month - according to the February Guardian/ICM poll published today, placing new pressure on Tony Blair to consider calling an early general election on April 5.
fields.body:
Labour's lead over the Conservatives has leapt to 15 points - an increase of five points in the last month - according to the February Guardian/ICM poll published today, placing new pressure on Tony Blair to consider calling an early general election on April 5.

Although the smart money in Downing Street will remain on May 3, the strong lead gives added impetus to go to the polls sooner rather than later. Results in line with the poll would deliver a second land slide victory for Mr Blair almost on the scale of the 1997 historic win - if he can get the potential Labour vote to the polling stations on the day.

The detailed results of the ICM poll neatly encapsulate the dilemma facing the prime minister. While the Labour lead is at its highest level for more than a year, it also shows that the numbers of those who say they are certain to vote has dropped three points since last month.

The poll underlines Labour fears that it is "stay-at-homes" who pose the main threat to the scale of its second-term victory, on the basis that the more likely a landslide appears, the fewer people will bother to take part in what they see as a foregone conclusion. Ministers must also privately doubt if this political momentum can be sustained for a further 10 weeks in the run-up to a May 3 election.

The poll shows that despite a month of indifferent headlines for Mr Blair, including the Mandelson resignation and the dome sale, Labour is actually up three points to 47% and the Tories are down two points to 32%, suggesting that the formidable economic feel good factor is responsible more than anything for fuelling this renewed resurgence in the government's fortunes. Labour's dominance on the economy is underscored by the poll finding that 33% regard it as the best party to manage the economy, double the 16% who believe the Tories would be more competent on an issue that was traditionally one of their strengths.

The 15-point lead, which is larger than the margin by which Labour won the 1997 general election, is all the more impressive because ICM customarily records a lower share of the vote for Labour than other opinion polls, as it adjusts for a "shy Tory" factor.

The poll also shows that the overwhelming majority, 64%, believe that Mr Blair was right to ask for the resignation of Mr Mandelson. Only 14% of voters say he was wrong.

It reveals that the government has firmly nailed any lingering reputation Labour had as the party of public spending. The voters regard both main parties as equally likely to raise taxes. In February 1997, when the question was last asked, 49% said they expected that Labour would spend more than the Tories if elected. That figure has now fallen to only 24% of voters and in fact a slightly higher proportion, 29%, believe that the Tories would spend more than Labour if they won. A further 25% believe public spending will be at roughly the same level whichever party gets in.

The main switch in opinion has been the growth of scepticism about Labour's future spending plans, with the "don't knows" growing from 6% in February 1997 to 22% now. This indicates how' expectations of a big boost in public spending during a second-term Labour government have receded. As for the Tories, 38% expect them to increase public spending if elected and only 23% to cut current levels. On tax Labour is now seen as little different from the Conservatives. Both parties are expected to raise taxes if they are elected, with only 20% saying they believe the Tories would cut the overall tax burden.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,000 adults by telephone from February 16-18. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: The lord chancellor

fields.headline: The lord chancellor
fields.trailText: February 20 2001: Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, is set to respond to criticism of his role as a fundraiser for the Labour party by answering a question in the House of Lords. But what is it that he is supposed to do, and who is he? Derek Brown explains.
fields.body:
Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, is set to respond to criticism of his role as a fundraiser for the Labour party by answering a question in the House of Lords. But what is it that he is supposed to do, and who is he? Derek Brown explains.

What does the lord chancellor do?
Lots of things. As a politician, he is a senior member of the Labour cabinet. As a lawyer, he is top dog: the head of the legal profession, with the power to appoint judges and Queen's Counsel. As a parliamentarian, he acts as speaker of the House of Lords, and gets to sit on the Woolsack.

Who is lord chancellor?
Alexander Andrew Mackay Irvine. Lord Irvine of Lairg to you and me. 'Derry' to his pals.

Why is he in the news?
Because, as a Labour man, he wrote to lawyers who are known Labour supporters, inviting them to a dinner - and suggesting that they donate at least £200 to the party. Thus proving that there is no such thing as a free meal.

Why is that a problem?
The Tories are making great play of the lord chancellor being supposed - in his legal role - to be impartial and non-political. They say that lawyers receiving the dinner invitation could have felt under pressure to donate funds, because of Lord Irvine's ability, through his power of patronage, to advance their careers.

Isn't that a silly way to promote lawyers?
The Law Society thinks so. It has called for an independent appointments body to select judges and QCs. It would include lay people as well as lawyers. Others go further: a report from the Economic and Social Research Council last year called for the office of lord chancellor to be abolished, and replaced with a minister of justice accountable to the Commons.

Didn't Labour once advocate the same thing?
Yes, but that was in the dim and distant past - before 1997.

And Lord Irvine's view?
Is that the lord chancellor is a bulwark of the constitution; an essential link between executive, parliament, and judiciary.

How much does the job pay?
The salary is the best in government; more even than the prime minister gets. To be precise, £173,875. Top barristers would sniff, but lesser mortals wouldn't sneeze at it.

webTitle: Leader: Do not dismiss Derry

fields.headline: Do not dismiss Derry
fields.standfirst:
Get rid of his job instead

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: February 20 2001, leader: Get rid of his job instead
fields.body:
Derry Irvine may be a first-class lawyer, but when it comes to politics he definitely belongs in the B-team. His political tin ear has been one of the more consistent features of this Labour government.

He got things off to a quick start with his authorisation of £650,000 of redecoration expenses for the lord chancellor's official residence - including Pugin wallpaper priced at £350 a roll - and compounded the error by snobbishly suggesting he could hardly kit out his quarters with any old rubbish from B & Q. He was soon comparing himself to Cardinal Wolsey, not realising how badly that would play with an electorate already suspicious of the arrogance of politicians. And more recently he provoked cries of cronyism and discrimination after hiring a chum to fill a top job that had never been advertised.

So no one will be surprised that the mighty lord chancellor has once again put his stockinged foot in it. His error this time is to have walked into the sleazy minefield that is party funding. It now emerges that Lord Irvine signed a letter inviting lawyers to a Labour bash earlier this month where they would be squeezed for donations. Mega-brain Irvine was too dim to realise the glaring inappropriateness of his actions. He did not see what everyone else would: that he was seeking funds from people whose careers he can make or break.

As the head of the judiciary, a lord chancellor exercises personal control over the promotion of lawyers and judges. It is he who can, at the wave of a pen, transform a mere barrister into a queen's counsel. Yet, happy that his action broke no law, he could not see the problem. He did not foresee the obvious headlines that would greet his move: cash for wigs.

Yet political clumsiness is not a resigning offence; nor is hosting an ill-judged event which breaks no law. So Derry Irvine will be safe - but the same should not be true of his job.

For the noble peer's actions have exposed not only his own limitations as a politician, but also the absurd contradictions of the office he occupies. It is a post which does not just risk conflicts of interest - it makes them almost inevitable. A lord chancellor wears at least three hats (in addition to the pantomimic piece of headgear he wears for special occasions). He is, simultaneously, a top-ranking member of the cabinet, speaker of the second chamber and head of the judiciary.

In other words, three branches of government - executive, legislature and judiciary - strenuously kept separate in other democracies, are fused together in Britain in the body of one man. The fact that he is unelected, and unaccountable to an elected chamber, only adds to the indefensibility of the post. And now we know, thanks to Lord Irvine, that lord chancellors often wear another hat: they can be fund-raisers for their party. The charitable might say this latest row is not Derry Irvine's fault. The problem is not the arrogance of the man; it is the arrogance of the job.

There is a simple way to clear up this mess. It is time to shut the lord chancellor's department and replace it with a ministry of justice headed by a member of the House of Commons. fields.bodyText: Derry Irvine may be a first-class lawyer, but when it comes to politics he definitely belongs in the B-team. His political tin ear has been one of the more consistent features of this Labour government. He got things off to a quick start with his authorisation of £650,000 of redecoration expenses for the lord chancellor's official residence - including Pugin wallpaper priced at £350 a roll - and compounded the error by snobbishly suggesting he could hardly kit out his quarters with any old rubbish from B & Q. He was soon comparing himself to Cardinal Wolsey, not realising how badly that would play with an electorate already suspicious of the arrogance of politicians. And more recently he provoked cries of cronyism and discrimination after hiring a chum to fill a top job that had never been advertised. So no one will be surprised that the mighty lord chancellor has once again put his stockinged foot in it. His error this time is to have walked into the sleazy minefield that is party funding. It now emerges that Lord Irvine signed a letter inviting lawyers to a Labour bash earlier this month where they would be squeezed for donations. Mega-brain Irvine was too dim to realise the glaring inappropriateness of his actions. He did not see what everyone else would: that he was seeking funds from people whose careers he can make or break. As the head of the judiciary, a lord chancellor exercises personal control over the promotion of lawyers and judges. It is he who can, at the wave of a pen, transform a mere barrister into a queen's counsel. Yet, happy that his action broke no law, he could not see the problem. He did not foresee the obvious headlines that would greet his move: cash for wigs. Yet political clumsiness is not a resigning offence; nor is hosting an ill-judged event which breaks no law. So Derry Irvine will be safe - but the same should not be true of his job. For the noble peer's actions have exposed not only his own limitations as a politician, but also the absurd contradictions of the office he occupies. It is a post which does not just risk conflicts of interest - it makes them almost inevitable. A lord chancellor wears at least three hats (in addition to the pantomimic piece of headgear he wears for special occasions). He is, simultaneously, a top-ranking member of the cabinet, speaker of the second chamber and head of the judiciary. In other words, three branches of government - executive, legislature and judiciary - strenuously kept separate in other democracies, are fused together in Britain in the body of one man. The fact that he is unelected, and unaccountable to an elected chamber, only adds to the indefensibility of the post. And now we know, thanks to Lord Irvine, that lord chancellors often wear another hat: they can be fund-raisers for their party. The charitable might say this latest row is not Derry Irvine's fault. webTitle: Blair dismisses calls to sack 'naive' Irvine

fields.headline: Blair dismisses calls to sack 'naive' Irvine
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night rejected "with contempt" Conservative calls for the resignation of the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, for his role in sending a fund-raising letter to lawyers on behalf of the Labour party.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night rejected "with contempt" Conservative calls for the resignation of the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, for his role in sending a fund-raising letter to lawyers on behalf of the Labour party.

But pressure mounted from critics in the Labour and Liberal Democrat ranks - along with the Law Society and other supporters of legal modernisation - who seized on the controversy to argue for reform of the lord chancellor's dual role as a politician who also heads the judicial system and appoints QCs and judges.

Robert Stevens, master of Pembroke College, Oxford, said that the affair underlined "the fact that you can't have the same person as head of the judiciary, a cabinet minister and responsible for all preferments".

A member of a committee of legal peers and academics which has called for a independent body to oversee appointments, Mr Stevens added: "If Tony Blair is committed to modernisation he needs to have a head of the judiciary who is not a politician and he needs to have a judicial appointments committee.

"Then if your minister of justice wants to have a party and shake people down for money, that's fine."

Lord Lester, a human rights QC and Liberal Democrat peer, called Lord Irvine's letter "politically naive."

He said: "As the Book of Matthew teaches us, no man should serve two masters and Derry [Irvine] serves at least two masters if not three or four.

"His politically naive decision may be important in highlighting the need to reform his domain when he's been busy reforming everybody else's." But he dismissed Conservative calls for the lord chancellor's resignation and accused the Tories of "making capital out of his unwisdom".

In the hope of reviving the sleaze issue ahead of the general election with what they dubbed the "cash for wigs" affair, the Tories demanded the names of all lawyers attending the controversial free dinner.

They also wrote to Lord Neill, the chairman of the committee on standards in public life, seeking an investigation.

When it emerged last week that Lord Irvine had solicited "at least £200" donations from lawyers attending the fundraising dinner with Cherie Booth QC, senior Tory lawyers privately joined the widespread condemnation: the action was foolish, but not warranting his resignation from the cabinet, they agreed.

But yesterday they performed a u-turn, ostensibly because Downing Street had given what Tory chairman, Michael Ancram, himself a barrister, called "a contemptuous brush-off" to concerns voiced about Lord Irvine's patronage powers to appoint the very lawyers at the dinner to be QCs or judges.

Lord Lester branded "constitutionally illiterate" a statement from the prime minister's spokesman that there was no difference between the lord chancellor hosting a fundraising dinner and the prime minister acting as host.

Attempts to raise the issue in the Lords yesterday were rebuffed. And Mr Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, accused the media and the Tories of using the row to "avoid real debate on policy and the issues that matter to people".

The resignation call would be treated by Mr Blair "with the contempt it deserves", he said.

Undeterred, Mr Ancram issued a direct challenge to Mr Blair, once a pupil in Lord Irvine's chambers.

He wrote: "I believe that Lord Irvine's actions in soliciting money from lawyers have breached the trust placed in him and brought the integrity of the lord chancellor's office into question.

"As you have failed to provide any satisfactory reply to the allegations and failed to acknowledge any appearance of impropriety on the lord chancellor's part, I am now calling on you now to consider Lord Irvine's position as head of the judiciary."

The Scottish National party backed the Tories. Lord Lester voiced concerns, also expressed by Labour QCs such as Bob Marshall-Andrews, about Lord Irvine's dual functions as a powerful cabinet policy maker and arbitrator (he played a key role in Peter Mandelson's fall) as well as impartial head of the judiciary.

The roles should be separated into a justice department and an appointments panel, reformers say.

Talk about it
Should Lord Irvine resign?

webTitle: Luton axes 100 jobs as part of  £4m savings

fields.headline: Luton axes 100 jobs as part of  £4m savings
fields.trailText: Nearly 100 academic and managerial jobs at Luton University are to be axed in a £4m cost-cutting exercise to compensate for falling student numbers.
fields.body:
Nearly 100 academic and managerial jobs at Luton University are to be axed in a £4m cost-cutting exercise to compensate for falling student numbers.

The lecturers' union Natfhe protested today but blamed the crisis on inadequate government funding for the new universities which it says receive only half as much income for teaching as the old universities.

The university is cutting back courses including history, maths, technology and English, where student numbers are down, and concentrating resources instead on more popular subjects such as business, computing and media studies. Luton also intends to place less emphasis on recruiting full-time undergraduate students - whose numbers are down - and more on part-time, postgraduate and overseas students.

The union is currently in talks with university management to try to avoid compulsory redundancies and re-deploy the threatened staff to other academic departments.

Vice Chancellor Dai John stressed final job losses would be much lower as staff were re-deployed. The action was a necessary response to the changing pattern of higher education, including a marked shift in demand towards the more vocational rather than the traditionally academic subjects.

"The amended course portfolio will underpin the university's growth for the future while allowing a reduction in expenditure of some £4m this year to help offset the funding lost through lower recruitment in some areas."

Jenny Golden, Natfhe's regional official said: "This crisis is due mainly to the mixed messages that the new universities receive from the government. On the one hand they are told to improve access to higher education while, on the other, receiving only half the teaching income of the old universities for doing so. This funding disparity means that universities like Luton have to be especially sensitive to the profitability of their courses."

She added that a lot of Luton's students came from the local ethnic and working-class populations. "Inadequate student financial support means that many of these students have to consider carefully whether they can afford to study full-time. If they do, they frequently choose a course on the basis of its employment potential rather than pure academic interest."

webTitle: Four universities tie for number one in first graduate pop chart

fields.headline: Four universities tie for number one in first graduate pop chart
fields.trailText: Which universities produce the most graduate popstars? Four institutions emerge as contenders for first place from our first survey of bands formed during campus life . But we plan to finalise the rankings at the end of the week. Any nominations, by email please. lee.elliotmajor@guardian.co.uk
fields.body:
It all started with a boast from University College London. The university's head publicist said that the band Coldplay had met as undergraduate students at UCL and were tipped as likely winners at the Brits Awards. He claimed that this was the latest in a long tradition of student band successes including Elastica, Suede and Basement Jaxx.

But how did UCL's record in producing famous musicians compare with other universities across the country? A straw poll of university press managers, alumni officers and student union reps attracted an unprecedented response.

Some were clearly themselves clutching at straws ("Brad Pitt once practised guitar here" came the reply from Thames Valley University, while in clear desperation the University of Oxford listed the rock combo, Ugly Rumours, led a former student called Tony Blair.)

But other responses were impressive: some institutions could list a glittering array of alumni who became pop stars in the 70s, 80s and 90s, as well as up and coming bands making waves in the current music scene.

The survey also uncovered an intriguing trend for musicologists: more and more bands appear to be forming during university rather than as an alternative to higher education.

So, in the spirit of performance indicators and league tables, we constructed the Guardian's first ever ranking of the hippest academic institutions in the country - based on the numbers of past students who have gone on to make fame and fortune in the music world.

The government is currently developing employability indicators rating graduate job prospects at different universities, but it is unlikely that this particular form of the job creation has been considered. Yet in terms of generating wealth and inward investment, and promoting the country's image abroad, successful bands can be industries in themselves. (Think of former LSE student Mick Jagger for example.) And such success stories could be exploited to help the government lure thousands of extra students onto university campuses - looking for pop stardom while completing their degree course.

The formula we came up with for the rankings was very simple: universities score 10 points for every pop star alumni, 20 points for bands formed while at university. But where musicians were judged to be embarrassingly unhip, universities were penalised points. Bonus points were awarded for special circumstances. Cardiff University for example was awarded extra points for producing Richey Edwards - the missing member of Manic Street Preachers. Pop stars who failed to complete degrees, meanwhile, also attracted extra points.

As the results show, no clear winner emerged. But three universities - Cardiff, Manchester, and London Guildhall - all managed to equal UCL's score at the top of the table. Perhaps London Guildhall shows the most consistent performance over time: producing 60's pop icon Ray Davies, 80's star, Adam Ant, and the 90's indie band, Echobelly. With a sad triumvirate of Kris Kristoffersen, Paul Gambacinni and Ugly Rumours, Oxford meanwhile for once lies at the bottom of an academic league table.

We don't for one minute pretend that this is the definitive list of academic chart toppers. For one thing different universities claim to have produced the same bands in some cases. And the survey drew no response from Scottish or Northern Irish institutions.

But why do so many bands form at university? This is perhaps a simple consequence of the move to a mass higher education system. Our popstars are generally more educated now than ever before. Radiohead is the quintessential modern band: all four members met at public school and then went on to university.

In TV terms this exercise could be billed as top of the pops meets university challenge. But what about this for TV series proposal: 'university popstars' - the search for five students picked from 100's of hopefuls to form an all graduate band?

webTitle: 'Golden triangle' universities win third of research funds

fields.headline: 'Golden triangle' universities win third of research funds
fields.trailText: The four large research universities in the South East know as the 'golden triangle' have won the lion's share of the government latest funds for research facilities in the English academic sector.
fields.body:
The four large research universities in the South East know as the 'golden triangle' have won the lion's share of the government latest funds for research facilities in the English academic sector.

University College London, Imperial College London, Cambridge and Oxford University have won £170m for new buildings and equipment - just under 30% of the £600m allocated to academic institutions in total. These four are the only universities winning over £40m in grants, which will be available from April 2002 and must be spent by March 2004.

The London and south east regions received the most funds from the scheme, £180m and £100m respectively.

The allocation of funds through the Science Research Investment Fund marks an abrupt departure from the bidding competitions of previous government schemes.

The Higher Education Funding Council is distributing the funds by a formula. Half the allocation is based on institutions' research grants won through the Research Assessment Exercise. The other half is based on the total research income received by the institution last year. Only income in scientific areas is counted, not income in the humanities, language-based disciplines, design and creative arts.

Universities will be asked how they plan to use the money though. The plans must be submitted by 31 May 2001. The grants must make up no more than 75% of the total cost of a project, except where programmes include projects with more than one university collaborating.

fields.bodyText: The four large research universities in the South East know as the 'golden triangle' have won the lion's share of the government latest funds for research facilities in the English academic sector. University College London, Imperial College London, Cambridge and Oxford University have won £170m for new buildings and equipment - just under 30% of the £600m allocated to academic institutions in total. These four are the only universities winning over £40m in grants, which will be available from April 2002 and must be spent by March 2004. The London and south east regions received the most funds from the scheme, £180m and £100m respectively. The allocation of funds through the Science Research Investment Fund marks an abrupt departure from the bidding competitions of previous government schemes. The Higher Education Funding Council is distributing the funds by a formula. Half the allocation is based on institutions' research grants won through the Research Assessment Exercise. The other half is based on the total research income received by the institution last year. Only income in scientific areas is counted, not income in the humanities, language-based disciplines, design and creative arts. Universities will be asked how they plan to use the money though. The plans must be submitted by 31 May 2001. The grants must make up no more than 75% of the total cost of a project, except where programmes include projects with more than one university collaborating. webTitle: £1bn pumped into university science

fields.headline: £1bn pumped into university science
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The government will today seek to secure Britain's base at the forefront of the genetics revolution by announcing the distribution of more than £1bn for funding science in universities.
fields.body:
The government will today seek to secure Britain's base at the forefront of the genetics revolution by announcing the distribution of more than £1bn for funding science in universities.

The industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will reveal that a large part of the cash designed to improve university infrastructures and research bases will be targeted at the biotech industry.

A large tranche of the money is to be handed to universities in the north-west in a bid to nurture a Manchester to Liverpool biotech corridor. Eighteen new biotech companies have been formed or moved to the region in the past year and the government hopes the new cash for local universities and hospital research can play a decisive role in creating a long term future for the north-west economy.

The government last year suffered a political backlash when it was agreed that the £500m synchrotron investment should go to Oxford instead of the north-west. The move infuriated north-west Labour MPs, but the government insisted it was given no choice by the company.

The facility, called a synchrotron radiation source, generates a high-energy X-ray beam capable of probing the structure of proteins, aiding the design of better drugs.

Although the allocation of today's cash, agreed in outline in the summer spending review, has been subject to peer review by academics and researchers, ministers are delighted at the money going to the north-west.

In the past six months there has been a shift within Whitehall in favour of strong regional economic policies. The shift was confirmed in a speech by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in Manchester last month.

The science minister and Mr Byers, drawing on US experience, regard universities as being at the heart of Britain's future productive capacity.

In last week's white paper on the knowledge economy, the government argued universities could no longer be seen as either solely creators of knowledge or trainers of young minds, but also as "agents of economic growth". Ministers still regard universities as failing to realise their full potential as hubs of growth. The government is setting up university innovations centres - in essence, research partnerships between business interests and the university sector.

But ministers believe that the new flow of cash to universities will help to develop clusters of skills, and that the north-west in particular can build on its established base of pharmaceutical and chemical sectors.

With only 1% of the world's population, the UK is responsible still for 4.5% of the world's spending on science. Yet UK companies apply for fewer US and EU patents than any of Britain's main competitors except Italy.

webTitle: Women academics still lag behind on pay

fields.headline: Women academics still lag behind on pay
fields.trailText: Average pay for full-time female academic staff in UK higher education trails 17% behind that of their male colleagues, according to newly published government figures.
fields.body:
Average pay for full-time female academic staff in UK higher education trails 17% behind that of their male colleagues, according to newly published government figures.

While male academics earned on average £669 gross a week in 2000, female academics earned £113 a week less.

David Triesman, general secretary of the Association of University Teachers, said that in the past decade the gender pay gap in higher education had narrowed by 10 percentage points. "But the continued gulf in earnings is a serious impediment to achieving equality."

Today details of the Equality Challenge initiative mounted by university heads will be outlined at a conference in London by Professor Janet Finch, Vice-Chancellor of Keele University, who chairs the initiative.

Professor Finch said: "Equality for staff in the sector is vital for the staff and the students, the new Equality Framework is a hugely important development for higher education's progress towards equal opportunities," she said.

But Mr Triesman commented: "Although the pay gap has closed during the last decade on average male academic staff earn £113 per week more than female counterparts, enough money to pay the rent or feed a family. It is difficult to see how universities can discuss equality without first tackling this fundamental barrier."

Diana Warwick, chief executive of Universities UK, formerly the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals, said today's conference would bring together leading experts in the UK and demonstrate vice-chancellors' commitment to equal opportunities.

Details of the Equality Challenge conference at www.universitiesuk.ac.uk

webTitle: Dozens of universities failing to reach enrolment targets

fields.headline: Missing persons
fields.standfirst: Dozens of universities are failing to reach enrolment targets, reports  Donald MacLeod
fields.trailText: Dozens of universities are failing to reach enrolment targets, reports Donald MacLeod
fields.body:
Signs that the government's drive to boost student numbers is faltering are emerging as Labour moves into the election. A total of 51 universities and colleges in England missed their student targets by more than 2% this academic year and 2001 applications for many institutions, particularly the new universities, are looking worse.

Applications in England are lagging behind those in Scotland, prompting political opponents to claim that the abolition of grants and the introduction of fees is deterring the potential students from disadvantaged backgrounds and ethnic minorities that Labour is pledged to attract into higher education. At least one large London institution has concluded that application levels are not going to recover and it will have to concentrate efforts on retaining as many of its students as possible rather than promoting recruitment.

Next week the funding councils are due to reveal student numbers for each university and higher education college - those which have missed their targets by more than 4% will lose funds for the coming year.

Scotland has already passed Tony Blair's goal of half of all young people taking part in higher education. Here the funding council is placing a cap on full-time undergraduate numbers and promoting part-time courses in an effort to widen participation to families and neighbourhoods who have traditionally not been included.

The proportion of 17- to 30-year-olds north of the Border participating in higher education stands at 58%. The prime minister reiterated last month that he wanted a 50% university participation rate for the under-30s in the country as a whole by 2010.

Since the Cubie report, Scottish students no longer pay upfront tuition fees. In the rest of the UK, fees will only be paid by half of students, insists the government, but evidence of spiralling student debt given to the Commons education committee has added to the belief that the least- well-off students are being put off. Professor Trevor Watkins, deputy vice-chancellor of South Bank University, said: "The price has gone up and you would expect demand to go down whatever the government might say."

Applications for engineering, built environment, science and business were "substantially down" and, like other new universities, South Bank appears to have lost out to older, more prestigious institutions which dropped their A-level offers last summer. Watkins said the university was doing well in attracting part-time, overseas and European students but was now concentrating on improving the retention of existing students. This would involve better support for students to enable them to succeed without lowering standards, but financial problems were often involved, he said.

Tony Blair said that in Labour's first three years the number of university students increased by 34,000 full-time equivalents. "Over the next few years, we aim for over 74,000 more."

Tim Boswell, former Conservative higher education minister, is trying to probe whether overseas and European student figures are making recruitment look better than it is. "It is pretty clear there is not the bonanza in student numbers the government is seeking to claim."

Within the overall problem of recruitment, science and engineering courses continue to struggle. Even Imperial College London underrecruited last year by more than 2%. Rector Sir Richard Sykes said that it was impossible to increase the proportion of students from state schools, as the government wished, because the pool of students taking science A-levels continued to decline every year.

"It is pointless, asking the universities to do more - the main problem is elsewhere," he said.

Institutions that missed their maximum allowable student number by more than 2% for 2000-01.
