webTitle: Potential rise in funding for PhD students

fields.headline: Star gazers spy cash on horizon
fields.standfirst: Flexible funding, more of it, and earlier -  Alok Jha reports on a potential postgrad windfall
fields.trailText: Flexible funding, more of it, and earlier - Alok Jha reports on a potential postgrad windfall
fields.body:
Grants for PhD students in particle physics and astronomy could rise to £9,000 a year by 2002 - a year earlier than first expected. The proposal comes as part of new plans by the government's Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council (PPARC) to change the way it allocates money to PhD students.

In a consultation paper published last month, the council says that it plans to "accelerate the move to higher student stipends" first announced in July 2000 in the Department of Trade and Industry's white paper on science and innovation. Under the proposed new funding scheme, students will be paid £8,000 a year from October 2001 and £9,000 a year from October 2002. The stipends aim to cover students' living costs.

Following the government's com prehensive spending review last year, stipends for all PhD students funded by the seven science research councils will increase over the next three years from the current figure of £6,620 a year outside London. They will rise to £6,800 this academic year and then to £7,500 in 2001-02, £8,000 in 2002-03 and finally £9,000 by 2003-04. The DfEE has subsequently announced similar increases for PhD students in the arts and humanities at English universities.

However, the PPARC now plans to accelerate this timetable for the 175 students it supports every year. According to Pat Jones, secretary of the council's education and training committee, the increased stipends will cost the research council £233,000 in 2001-02, £691,000 in 2002-03 and £925,000 in 2003-04. The money will come directly from the research council's baseline funding.

A recent study of career paths of PhDs across the sciences showed that PPARC studentships attracted the highest proportion of students with first-class or upper-second degrees.

The council is also re-evaluating how it allocates money to departments on behalf of PhD students. It currently funds studentships to university departments using a panel of referees. A number of studentships are awarded to a department and the council pays the university fees, a research training support grant and money for fieldwork and attending conferences. Further money, which includes the annual stipend, is paid direct to the student.

Now the PPARC is considering a move to an arrangement similar to a scheme that the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council will introduce from October this year. The EPSRC's "doctoral training account" will allow universities the flexibility to set stipends that are higher than the minimum set by the research council itself. It will also allow institutions to vary the length of studentships and move funds across departments and across years.

The mechanism would allow departments to pay higher stipends to exceptional students, for example by using the money for three studentships to fund two students. Departments will not, however, be allowed to reduce stipends to below the standard research council level.

The PPARC's own version of the scheme would determine a department's allocation of studentships, as before, following the judgment of a team of academics. The quota of studentships would then be turned into a sum of money, which the department would use to manage all of its postgraduate-level training. The council estimates that departments would get an average of £13,500 per student per year, based on previous years' spending figures.

The aim of the scheme is to "give departments a degree of flexibility in the management of studentships and to allow some movement of funding across the various elements provided for in the training grant," says a report by the council. The PPARC will not allow departments to set their own stipend levels but it will allow them more options with timing of the take-up of studentships.

"Universities would be free to start a studentship at any time. There would be no PPARC nominations exercise every summer," says the report. The council also says that it will consider requests for extended support into a fourth year for some students in "certain clearly defined circumstances". It says, however, that it would not allow "a wholesale move away from three-year PhDs and would take steps to encourage PhD submissions at or close to the three- year point".

The final decisions about whether or not the council will go ahead with any of the proposals will take into account the views of the astronomy and particle physics academic communities. The PPARC's board will then discuss the issue at its meeting in May. If the plans are passed, the training grants scheme would begin in October 2002.

Alok Jha works for Research Fortnight.

fields.trailText: Teaching staff can find their career effectively over if they don't fulfil their department's RAE requirements. Lee Elliot Major on a cruel lottery
fields.body:
Dr Robert Jones knew his time was up two years ago. It was no surprise when the 56-year-old lecturer was eventually asked to meet the university's dean of research and head of department. There were no questions or explanations. Jones (not his real name) was told that he would not be included in the department's submission to the Research Assessment Exercise, and was urged to move on to a teaching only contract.

"I knew it was coming," he says. "I had spent a considerable time on two articles for a book, but the book fell through." At first he worked frenetically trying to recover something from the situation, trying to produce redrafts. But it quickly became apparent that he could not produce the quota of four published articles in the two remaining years left before the deadline for the assessment.

"Come the day, come the hour, you are faced with nemesis," he says. "If you don't make it into the RAE you are dead in the water - academic life is essentially over." He says he is being punished for taking risks with his research, when he could have quite easily trotted out four "tedious, predictable articles". Over an entire lifetime, an academic might produce two or three highly original research papers, he says, but to be entered into the RAE a researcher must produce a paper every year.

"It is not as if, crudely put, I am a nobody in the area," he says. "I found the whole experience thoroughly demoralising and demotivating. For all the moralising of these places, they don't mind giving you a mugging if they can get away with it. Of course, it is all done in the best possible taste but a mugging is a mugging, however politely the boot goes in."

Jones is just one of countless victims of the RAE. For five years since the last assessment, university managers have been focusing on one date on their academic planners: 31 March 2001. This is the deadline for submissions to RAE 2001. This is the date by which research reputations will be won or lost. And often individual academics find themselves -sacrificed as universities manoeuvre to maximise their chances of high research ratings, and classify the highest possible proportion of academics as "research active".

Even publishing the full quota of four articles in the five years before the deadline is no guarantee that an academic has a place in a department's prestigious submission to the exercise. As Dr Jane Brown found out, much to her distress, sometimes your research just doesn't fit into the university's plans.

After a year of protracted discussions Brown, a 50-year-old lecturer, finally won her battle for a permanent academic position - something she was entitled to after six years on fixed-term contracts. The university appointments committee first turned down the request, then acquiesced.

But with the decision came a nasty surprise. "One person [on the committee] said I would damage the university's RAE submission, which I found deeply insulting and very distressing," says Brown. "Although I had the right number of publications I was told I didn't fit into the package of the RAE submission. "I found the whole experience undermining to my confidence and belief - even though I know I am good at what I do. It is very undermining having an institution questioning your worth."

The two stories could have been told by any number of academics. They may have failed to produce the right number of papers; their research area may have been judged out of bounds; they may have concentrated on teaching duties; or they may be approaching retirement. But the humiliation is always the same: they are told that they cannot take part in the RAE, and pressurised to retire or transfer to non-research contracts.

Local representatives of the Association of University Teachers call it the "gatekeeping" problem. Complaints have come from staff at universities as far afield as Stirling, Lancaster, Edinburgh, Keele, Exeter, Cardiff, Reading, and Liverpool. For all the government's vows to raise the status of teaching in academia, the RAE victims reveal that the harsh reality is that research still rules the university world. And despite talk of better staff management, institutions still seem stuck in the middle ages when it comes to dealing with their academic employees.

Determining the allocation of £1bn of grants a year, the RAE wields an enormous influence over the sector. A five-star, top rating in the exercise represents the ultimate sign of academic kudos - and is used to secure other research grants, and fee-paying international students. Departments also strive to classify the highest possible proportion of staff as "research active" to prove the depth of their research strengths.

A typical example is Lancaster University, which announced that it aims only to have departments with ratings of 4 and above. A plan was developed to identify staff likely to be included, and examine what could be done about the rest of the staff, with a view to removing them from the total figure to be declared for the assessment.

"Over the past year a succession of members have come for advice," says John Wakeford, secretary of the local AUT branch. "Many are women academics who have worked for several years on annual renewable contracts. They seem to have been offered permanency if they accept appointments on the inferior, "other related" scale, losing their right to sabbatical leave.

"Others are senior people in their 50s and 60s who have devoted themselves to teaching and writing textbooks as well as research - or have published in areas that just didn't fit into the particular theme a department was putting forward. Various things were raised with them - ill-health retirement, premature retirement, teaching only contracts."

According to Wakeford, most were devastated. They felt they were being told that their life's work had been defined as second-rate: "The actual assessment process is carried out meticulously by the funding council, and based on decisions by groups of academic peers. But our main concern is the damage done to the careers and self-respect of many dedicated academics by some universities' short-sighted and insensitive response."

Lecturers' names have been changed

webTitle: Which are the top universities in the eyes of employers?

fields.headline: Just the job for us
fields.standfirst: We've all scoured the performance tables. But when it comes to recruitment, which British universities really put stars in employers' eyes? Cliff Pettifor finds out
fields.trailText: We've all scoured the performance tables. But when it comes to recruitment, which British universities really put stars in employers' eyes? Cliff Pettifor finds out
fields.body:
Your degree is a passport - but will you get it stamped by the right university? Despite the government's glib talk of "top" universities, the Performance Indicator Project's annual poll of employers throws up more upsets than the FA Cup.

We asked employers to name universities they considered above or below average. Out of more than 250 major recruiters taking part, 41 were seeking graduates in civil engineering and construction, and they gave Oxford Brookes as many votes as its older neighbour Oxford University, Tony Blair's alma mater.

Other new universities do even better. One major employer compliments Plymouth for "the way it cares for its students and what happens to them". That is one of five nominations for "above average" provision, placing it 17th equal in the rankings for civil engineering.

Nottingham Trent got six votes for and one against, giving an overall score of five, which placed it in 19th position. Portsmouth, with six votes for, and two against - an overall score of 4 - lies 23rd. At the other end of the table is South Bank, with its -5 total coming from five recruiters naming it "below average".

Loughborough is not a member of the Russell Group of universities - the so-called "premier division" - but it tops the civil engineering table with 13 positive votes, equivalent to almost one employer in three favouring its graduates.

New universities get recruiters' respect in other areas of engineering. Among 59 employers of electrical engineers in the survey, four listed Plymouth favourably and three listed Portsmouth. But credit goes to Brunel, another non-Russell institution. Edged out of top place by Imperial (19 votes) and Umist (18 votes), its score of 16 accounts for over 6% of all votes; in 1996 it earned just 2%.

Other "risers" in this category include Heriot-Watt, Nottingham and Belfast. For general engineering, Umist won 27 votes (the equivalent of almost half of those recruiting), to head the list. Nottingham Trent with an overall five votes (six for, one against) is top "new boy".

The so-called "top" universities have employer-appeal too. In law, Oxford and Cambridge share first spot, each with 11 votes for and none against from a poll including 22 active recruiters. Bristol, Durham, Warwick, LSE and Southampton all figure prominently in survey respondents' lists of "above average" departments.

Russell Group members also dominate in maths. Again Cambridge and Oxford top the list, followed by Warwick, Durham and Nottingham.

Many recruiters in the business and management section of the surveys are able and willing to award negative votes, highlighting what they consider a "below average" standard of graduates. More than a quarter of their votes show employers' experience of inadequate provision. Seventy-one business and management recruiters voted. Graduates from three former polytechnics, De Montfort, Leeds Metropolitan and Brighton with six votes overall, and Kingston, with five, all achieve the top 25 status of 97 ranked universities. That is something that three "older" universities, Liverpool, Glasgow, and King's College London, fail to achieve. Leeds Metropolitan, 28th in last year's table, has risen to 19th.

Cambridge's 18 positive votes from 58 recruiters in the sciences suggest that, other qualities and qualifications being equal, its graduates will be favoured by almost one in three recruiters. Yet the university's five-year record shows a slight decrease.

This allows a comparison with other less prestigious institutions. For example, Keele's share of votes and its consequent ranking has risen over the same period, as has Plymouth's. This ex-polytechnic can boast a 2% increase in vote share and a recently acquired top 20 standing in science. Its 6:0 record equals Warwick and betters Liverpool.

The 80 companies recruiting in computing and information technology in the survey year are among the most satisfied with the employability of new graduates. Eighty-three per cent of specialists in the subject area described it as "good" or "fairly good". Only 9% of the 385 votes cast were for "below average provision". Relative newcomers receiving impressive and increasing portions of the favourable reaction include De Montfort (7:0) and Sheffield Hallam (6:0).

Aston and Brunel are two other institutions, rarely defined as part of the elite, whose output impresses a grow ing number of employers. Their 10:0 and 9:0 totals easily outscore those of Nottingham, Glasgow, University College London, Southampton, Leeds and many others.

But don't get the impression that the so-called "top universities" aren't good. Like Man United, they are, and employers' votes confirm it. But in many subjects, students should question assumptions and look further than the apparently limited select group of providers.

Remember, if an applicant's A-levels aren't enough to "buy" them a place at what they are told is a "top university", the preferences voiced by future employers might offer a valid, or even better, alternative.

Chris Pettifor is a lecturer involved in Performance Indicator Project's surveys. These are published for education professionals as Signposts to Employability 2001 (£25, extra copies £5.50), and for students and employers as Choose-a-Uni 2001 (£14, extra copies £11). Orders and details: Performance Indicator Project, c/o Harlaxton College, Grantham, Lincs NG32 1AG in writing; or email: cpettifor@ueharlax.ac.uk

webTitle: Which universities produce pop stars?

fields.headline: Wanna be a pop star?
fields.standfirst: For budding student chart-toppers, the advice is simple: go to Manchester.  Angelique Chrisafis finds out just what it takes to make it big
fields.trailText: For budding student chart-toppers, the advice is simple: go to Manchester. Angelique Chrisafis finds out just what it takes to make it big
fields.body:
It was student band acoustic night at a Manchester beer hall. A duo called Little Plato stood on a stage by the gents' toilets. The guitarist swung his fringe and hit a chord. The singer sang "I'll always be a fool, but that's cool with me . . . yah." The amp screeched, stray dogs outside started yelping and someone in the audience blew a fart on their harmonica. Nine acts later, a drunk would wander in off the street and sing Wonderwall. The audience loved it.

Manchester, according to record companies and pop music lecturers, is the place student musicians are making for. Its student exports include the Chemical Brothers, James and D:ream. Now heading for big record deals are Gecko Levy, Embryonic, Spybase and Shatner.

Manchester reflects the changes in Britain's student band scene. Computer students are downloading illegal music software, making it easier for bands to record for next to nothing. The entrepreneurial streak among skint undergraduates means most are teaming up with marketing students, setting up gig websites, releasing singles on the net and raking in cash from their bands.

Across venues in the city, most student bands say they specifically applied to universities in Manchester to network on the music scene. But other locations are producing good acts which formed as students, including Necessary Elvis from Leeds, Portobello from Sheffield and a list of bands from Bath, Liverpool and London heading for the finals of Live and Uncut's national unsigned band competition later this year.

According to the record industry, around 10% of student bands nationwide will make the big time. But the greatest change on the student scene is that successful bands, espe cially hip-hop and dance acts, are not just emerging from the bedrooms of classics students. Students on new rock music and technology courses at further education colleges and universities like Salford, which specialises in pop, are making it in large numbers. These are often highly talented students who have already sessioned on albums but who come to college specifically to form bands.

In Manchester, the pop students run in parallel to the part-time biology or English student bands - they gig the same circuit but they hardly interact. A trawl of venues reveals from both sides just what it takes to make it as a student band.

First, there's the management issue. With the proliferation of flyers and promotional websites, unless band members want to spend all day leafleting and flunk their degrees, they may need help.

Alex MacHorton, 22, a third-year economics undergraduate at Manchester University, has never picked up an instrument but manages Madee, an alternative indie band made up of maths and physics undergraduates. "With an economics background, I bring in a business approach. The band are great at what they do, but they are not always organised. I take the bureaucracy off them, so they have more time to write," he says.

MacHorton, like John Dang, the band's singer, has his own e-business. Dang, in his third year, just turned down a £42,000 banking job because he thinks the band can really make it. "The next six months are crucial, it's make or break," he says. What about finals? "That's just study. I'll knock off a 2:1."

On the London circuit, the highly rated The Glass Heroes, made up of City University business students and recent Oxford graduates, recruited a friend who had just started a management consultancy job to manage them. Bernie Smith, 26, said: "The band are 22 and 23. They were not getting as much notice as they wanted from record companies so they brought me in to promote them." The singer, Julian Ridgway, said he wished the band had recruited a manager earlier.

One thing a manager can do is keep a tab on costs. For students who aren't doing a music course at a specialist college, the cost of playing in a band is around £2,800 a year. CD home copying and promotional demos can cost £500 over three terms, flyers can reach £150. Recording in a studio costs £300 a day, plus £500 a year for instrument repairs and maintenance and £100 on the all-important entry to competitions.

The band Madee estimate they will make £1,200 this year through music. Planned gigs will bring in £800 and 200 bottles of beer and they plan to sell their EP at £3 a go, making £400. Profits are split six ways to include the manager. Other Manchester University bands, like Loose Canon, run band nights and produce their own singles for 50p and sell them for £1, without a manager. They make friends in other bands, and wear promotional stickers of their gig nights as they perform across the city. "It's all about branding ourselves and our night," Marc Davies, the guitarist, said.

Quite a few others, including the Manchester band, Extinguish Her, are financed by parents. Matt Collins, a Manchester student band reviewer, plays in a band back home in Belfast and spends all his loans on flights.

The advice across the spit and sawdust of the clubs is that if being in a band is the only thing you want to do in the long term, get a pop qualification. Dawn Maskrey, 30, has just graduated as a mature student from North Trafford College in Manchester with a BTech in music performance. Her band, Embryonic, one of the best student bands in Manchester, has played Manchester's crucial In the City unsigned bands festival - deemed "Urban Glastonbury". They have a CD and DVD out.

"I was a singer, I had done vocals on The Smiths' Big Mouth Strikes Again and I was doing quite a lot of dance tracks, but I didn't want to be a lone singer. I wanted a band behind me so I came to college to meet them. I also felt I needed a qualification, so I could fall back on teaching if music didn't work out," she said.

"The course changed me. It made me less into myself and more giving to others. I know enough about music now to make it in any area of the industry without having to turn to teaching." She devotes five days a week to the band. At night, she leaflets other gigs with the band's flyers.

North Trafford College is one of 23 colleges in the country that run contemporary music courses as part of the Access to Music organisation. The course requirement is to form a band. Session musicians teach; record bosses, promoters, reviewers and DJs come to lecture. The course is at Beehive Mill recording studios in the heart of clubland, among other professional artists and musicians. Two of North Trafford's hip-hop students, Akosua Mensah and Serina Wain, were nominated for best unsigned act at this year's Mobo awards.

On the other side of Manchester, Salford University is the centre of pop degrees in Britain. It is in its 12th year of a BA honours in popular music and recording, and its graduates - including a drummer for Gomez and two of Pete Waterman's co-producers for Steps - have fed the Manchester music scene. Sheila Whitely, Britain's first professor of pop, said the course has 550 applicants for 50 places each year. They learn acoustics, performance, theory, recording and the technology of mixing and mastering. "Our course is also vital for networking. With 12 years' worth of graduates in the music industry, we provide a very effective network for student bands."

Advice that emerges from all the bands is that the scene is just as full of hope and insecurity as student acting or journalism. Most student bands feel over the hill. It takes until the age of 24 or 25 to begin to stand a chance of emerging professionally after you have devoted three years to a degree, while other teen bands with a foot in the door can make it much faster. "I'm getting older too . . . ooh," crones one student singer at the acoustic night.

Where the top bands come from...

The Guardian pop music rankings table all started with a boast from University College London. The university's head publicist said that the band, Coldplay, had met as undergraduate students at UCL and were tipped as likely winners at the Brits Awards. He claimed that this was the latest in a long tradition of student band successes including Elastica, Suede and Basement Jaxx.

How did other universities compare? Some were clearly themselves clutching at straws ("Brad Pitt once practised guitar here" came the reply from Thames Valley University, while in clear desperation Oxford listed the rock combo, Ugly Rumours (led by a former student called Tony Blair).

But other responses were impressive, too. So, in the spirit of performance indicators and league tables, we constructed the Guardian's first ever ranking of the hippest academic institutions in the country - based on the numbers of past students who have gone on to make fame and fortune in the music world.

Universities score 10 points for every pop star alumnus, and 20 points for bands formed while at university. Embarrassingly unhip acts attracted penalty points but Cardiff was awarded extra points for producing Richey Edwards - the missing member of Manic Street Preachers. Stars who failed to complete degrees also attracted extra arbitrary points.

London Guildhall shows the most consistent performance, producing 60s pop icon Ray Davies, 80s star Adam Ant, and the 90s indie band, Echobelly. With a sad trium-virate of Kris Kristoffersen, Paul Gambacinni, and Ugly Rumours, Oxford meanwhile lies, for once, at the bottom of an academic league table.

Lee Elliot Major

Kris Kristoffersen; DJ Paul; Ugly Rumours (Tony Blair's band); Manager of Coldplay
fields.bodyText: It was student band acoustic night at a Manchester beer hall. A duo called Little Plato stood on a stage by the gents' toilets. The guitarist swung his fringe and hit a chord. The singer sang "I'll always be a fool, but that's cool with me . . . yah." The amp screeched, stray dogs outside started yelping and someone in the audience blew a fart on their harmonica. Nine acts later, a drunk would wander in off the street and sing Wonderwall. The audience loved it. Manchester, according to record companies and pop music lecturers, is the place student musicians are making for. Its student exports include the Chemical Brothers, James and D:ream. Now heading for big record deals are Gecko Levy, Embryonic, Spybase and Shatner. Manchester reflects the changes in Britain's student band scene. Computer students are downloading illegal music software, making it easier for bands to record for next to nothing. The entrepreneurial streak among skint undergraduates means most are teaming up with marketing students, setting up gig websites, releasing singles on the net and raking in cash from their bands. Across venues in the city, most student bands say they specifically applied to universities in Manchester to network on the music scene. But other locations are producing good acts which formed as students, including Necessary Elvis from Leeds, Portobello from Sheffield and a list of bands from Bath, Liverpool and London heading for the finals of Live and Uncut's national unsigned band competition later this year. According to the record industry, around 10% of student bands nationwide will make the big time. But the greatest change on the student scene is that successful bands, espe cially hip-hop and dance acts, are not just emerging from the bedrooms of classics students. Students on new rock music and technology courses at further education colleges and universities like Salford, which specialises in pop, are making it in large numbers. These are often highly talented students who have already sessioned on albums but who come to college specifically to form bands. In Manchester, the pop students run in parallel to the part-time biology or English student bands - they gig the same circuit but they hardly interact. A trawl of venues reveals from both sides just what it takes to make it as a student band. First, there's the management issue. With the proliferation of flyers and promotional websites, unless band members want to spend all day leafleting and flunk their degrees, they may need help. Alex MacHorton, 22, a third-year economics undergraduate at Manchester University, has never picked up an instrument but manages Madee, an alternative indie band made up of maths and physics undergraduates. "With an economics background, I bring in a business approach. The band are great at what they do, but they are not always organised. I take the bureaucracy off them, so they have more time to write," he says. MacHorton, like John Dang, the band's singer, has his own e-business. Dang, in his third year, just turned down a £42,000 banking job because he thinks the band can really make it. "The next six months are crucial, it's make or break," he says. What about finals? "That's just study. I'll knock off a 2:1." On the London circuit, the highly rated The Glass Heroes, made up of City University business students and recent Oxford graduates, recruited a friend who had just started a management consultancy job to manage them. Bernie Smith, 26, said: "The band are 22 and 23. They were not getting as much notice as they wanted from record companies so they brought me in to promote them." The singer, Julian Ridgway, said he wished the band had recruited a manager earlier. One thing a manager can do is keep a tab on costs. For students who aren't doing a music course at a specialist college, the cost of playing in a band is around £2,800 a year. CD home copying and promotional demos can cost £500 over three terms, flyers can reach £150. Recording in a studio costs £300 a day, plus £500 a year for instrument repairs and maintenance and £100 on the all-important entry to competitions. The band Madee estimate they will make £1,200 this year through music. Planned gigs will bring in £800 and 200 bottles of beer and they plan to sell their EP at £3 a go, making £400. Profits are split six ways to include the manager. Other Manchester University bands, like Loose Canon, run band nights and produce their own singles for 50p and sell them for £1, without a manager. They make friends in other bands, and wear promotional stickers of their gig nights as they perform across the city. "It's all about branding ourselves and our night," Marc Davies, the guitarist, said. Quite a few others, including the Manchester band, Extinguish Her, are financed by parents. Matt Collins, a Manchester student band reviewer, plays in a band back home in Belfast and spends all his loans on flights. The advice across the spit and sawdust of the clubs is that if being in a band is the only thing you want to do in the long term, get a pop qualification. Dawn Maskrey, 30, has just graduated as a mature student from North Trafford College in Manchester with a BTech in music performance. Her band, Embryonic, one of the best student bands in Manchester, has played Manchester's crucial In the City unsigned bands festival - deemed "Urban Glastonbury". They have a CD and DVD out. "I was a singer, I had done vocals on The Smiths' Big Mouth Strikes Again and I was doing quite a lot of dance tracks, but I didn't want to be a lone singer. I wanted a band behind me so I came to college to meet them. I also felt I needed a qualification, so I could fall back on teaching if music didn't work out," she said. "The course changed me. It made me less into myself and more giving to others. I know enough about music now to make it in any area of the industry without having to turn to teaching." She devotes five days a week to the band. At night, she leaflets other gigs with the band's flyers. North Trafford College is one of 23 colleges in the country that run contemporary music courses as part of the Access to Music organisation. The course requirement is to form a band. Session musicians teach; record bosses, promoters, reviewers and DJs come to lecture. The course is at Beehive Mill recording studios in the heart of clubland, among other professional artists and musicians. Two of North Trafford's hip-hop students, Akosua Mensah and Serina Wain, were nominated for best unsigned act at this year's Mobo awards. On the other side of Manchester, Salford University is the centre of pop degrees in Britain. It is in its 12th year of a BA honours in popular music and recording, and its graduates - including a drummer for Gomez and two of Pete Waterman's co-producers for Steps - have fed the Manchester music scene. Sheila Whitely, Britain's first professor of pop, said the course has 550 applicants for 50 places each year. They learn acoustics, performance, theory, recording and the technology of mixing and mastering. "Our course is also vital for networking. With 12 years' worth of graduates in the music industry, we provide a very effective network for student bands." Advice that emerges from all the bands is that the scene is just as full of hope and insecurity as student acting or journalism. Most student bands feel over the hill. It takes until the age of 24 or 25 to begin to stand a chance of emerging professionally after you have devoted three years to a degree, while other teen bands with a foot in the door can make it much faster. "I'm getting older too . . . ooh," crones one student singer at the acoustic night. Where the top bands come from... The Guardian pop music rankings table all started with a boast from University College London. The university's head publicist said that the band, Coldplay, had met as undergraduate students at UCL and were tipped as likely winners at the Brits Awards. He claimed that this was the latest in a long tradition of student band successes including Elastica, Suede and Basement Jaxx. How did other universities compare? Some were clearly themselves clutching at straws ("Brad Pitt once practised guitar here" came the reply from Thames Valley University, while in clear desperation Oxford listed the rock combo, Ugly Rumours (led by a former student called Tony Blair). But other responses were impressive, too. So, in the spirit of performance indicators and league tables, we constructed the Guardian's first ever ranking of the hippest academic institutions in the country - based on the numbers of past students who have gone on to make fame and fortune in the music world. Universities score 10 points for every pop star alumnus, and 20 points for bands formed while at university. Embarrassingly unhip acts attracted penalty points but Cardiff was awarded extra points for producing Richey Edwards - the missing member of Manic Street Preachers. Stars who failed to complete degrees also attracted extra arbitrary points. London Guildhall shows the most consistent performance, producing 60s pop icon Ray Davies, 80s star Adam Ant, and the 90s indie band, Echobelly. With a sad trium-virate of Kris Kristoffersen, Paul Gambacinni, and Ugly Rumours, Oxford meanwhile lies, for once, at the bottom of an academic league table. webTitle: Higher browsing

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: higher news
fields.body:
The third degree

 David Blunkett's bombshell that there would be no top-up fees in a second Labour term delighted the NUS and other campaigners. But are celebrations premature? Sure, it was an unambiguous pledge - almost as clear as "Read my lips, no selection". But given that half the secondary schools in England will soon be allowed to select a percentage of their pupils, the more cynical vice-chancellors are probably building fees into their financial planning as we speak.

Bristol University's jolly contribution to was to announce a major study into the world's most comon sexually transmitted bacterial infection. The Chlamydia screening studies project is being undertaken with Birmingham University over the next two years. If detected it can be simply treated with antibiotics but, as most women and many men have no symptoms, it tends to get passed on and cause long-term complications. Happy Valentine's Day.

Southampton University's Wolfson Unit for marine technology took a discreet bow as Ellen MacArthur sailed home to an ecstatic welcome. Her Kingfisher boat was designed in its tanks and wind tunnels and she was closely involved in the process herself. Ideal honorary degree, perhaps?

Stories? Gossip? Contact us: donald.macleod@theguardian.com or lee.elliotmajor@theguardian.com

News

New e-uni gets its backing

Universities and colleges are right behind the "ambitious and radical" plan for an inclusive e-university, and 91 private sector companies have shown interest, the Higher Education Funding Council for England said today.

Rather than picking a consortium of prestigious universities to develop the concept, the council opted for a small operating company taking courses from any university that meets its standards.

Announcing the appointment of consultant Nick Winton as acting head of the venture, Sir Brian Fender, the council's chief executive, said: "The whole sector now needs to move rapidly to establish the e-University as a major player in the rapidly expanding market for online education."

Meanwhile, a major rival, Fathom, set up by Columbia University in the US and backed by the London School of Economics and a group of London museums, is reported to be having difficulty attracting students and investors.

www.hefce.ac.uk/partners/euniv/

Research news

Researching researchers

Science minister David Sainsbury last week formally launched the quinquennial review of the government's six grant-awarding research councils. The review will examine the role and performance of the councils, which each year allocate £1bn of grants to universities and research institutes.

'Good idea' centres

A cadre of university innovation centres and technical institutes is to be created in the UK following the government's white paper on enterprise, skills and innovation. The centres will aim to "boost research and development, innovation and technology transfer and provide the regions with skills in ICT and high technology". The government also proposes that students "learn in ways which encourage them to be more creative and enterprising".

Universe

MBA, comrade?

The march of global higher education capitalism takes another step this Thursday when 13 Russian students are presented with their Open University Business School MBAs. Each student has paid $10,000 in course fees to complete their MBA, a huge commitment compounded by the value of the rouble rising from six to 30 per dollar during their studies. The school also has international programmes throughout central and eastern Europe, and in various Asian and African countries.

Cuba libre

Ever the good neighbour, Fidel Castro has offered six years of free medical education and training in Cuba to hundreds of low-income minority students from the US. Will President Bush be grateful . . .?

webTitle: Designer to the stars goes back to school

fields.headline: Designer to the stars goes back to school
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Sir Paul Smith, designer to the stars and owner of a £170m clothing empire, has agreed to help design a new uniform for the school as part of a scheme operated by the Sorrell Foundation, which aims to encourage children's creativity.
fields.body:
Generations of schoolchildren reluctant to wear their painfully untrendy uniforms have been told that school is not a fashion parade. But that argument is unlikely to hold much water at Aldercar junior school outside Nottingham.

Sir Paul Smith, designer to the stars and owner of a £170m clothing empire, has agreed to help design a new uniform for the school as part of a scheme operated by the Sorrell Foundation, which aims to encourage children's creativity.

But the clothier credited with reinventing menswear in the 1980s faces arguably the most daunting challenge of his career. Not only has he promised to bring Aldercar's traditional-style uniform up to speed with the classic-with-a-twist suits for which he is famed. He is also tackling that seemingly most lost of fashion causes: the dinner ladies' outfits.

"Even aspects like stopping collars sticking into necks, or preventing ties coming loose, is a challenge I'm looking forward to," said Sir Paul, who grew up in Nottingham and opened his first boutique in the town in 1970.

The project is one of several at schools around the country, with the aim of improving pupils' quality of life. Children at Aldercar met Sir Paul and were encouraged to contribute their own ideas. The head, Tony Cooper, is hopeful that the designs will be adopted.

"We reintroduced uniform wearing in 1995, but it's the same style I was wearing as a child," he said yesterday. "Some of the main ideas are for a different summer uniform and a special one for older children."

Aldercar parents horrified at the prospect of needing to buy a winter and summer wardrobe designed by a man famed for his £400-plus suits were assured that pricing of the uniforms would be kept to an "acceptable" level.

fields.headline: School report
fields.standfirst: Foldaway kitchen
fields.trailText: Foldaway kitchen
fields.body:
www.hope-education.co.uk, tel: 08702 433400

Price: £199.95

Age/ability range: 3+ yrs

The manufacturer says: "Ideal where space is at a premium, the units are at three different heights. They simply all fold into one another, making this design compact and unique. Packed with play potential, it will allow several children access at any one time, encouraging personal and social development through role play."

Maria Rosen, Reception Teacher, Marlborough County Primary School, Macclesfield, says: "The children loved it. They used it in groups of four in free play and rigged up a washing line with numbered pegs; played with food and saucers; and made shopping lists of items they would need to cook with. There were no manufacturer's guidelines, though it only took me a couple of minutes to familiarise myself with it. It helped to develop the children's life skills, as well as counting and cooperation. Considering the cost of the product, I would have thought an iron might have been included to go with the board and maybe some saucepans and food items. Luckily we had plenty of our own. The taps had to be screwed into the middle section which took a bit of time. However, it is an extremely useful and enjoyable resource which the school will definitely make good use of."

fields.headline: Book reviews
fields.trailText: Lindsey Fraser looks at The Smallpox Slayer, by Alan Brown, and After Juliet, by Sharman Macdonald, part of the Royal National Theatre's Connections series
fields.body:
The Smallpox Slayer, by Alan Brown

(Hodder Children's Books, www.madaboutbooks.com, tel: 01235 400400, £3.99)

Age 8-12 yrs

This exploration of the life and work of Edward Jenner - the man behind the concept of vaccination - is timely, given the MMR controversy. The narrative bobs between dramatic description of his rudimentary medical techniques, social documentary and extracts from letters and papers exchanged between medical practitioners across the world. There were no health watchdogs in 1796, so a man appalled by horrifically high mortality rates - 25% of children died from smallpox - could experiment fairly freely. His theory later proved adrift, but the practice was almost spot on. A story worth telling.

After Juliet, by Sharman Macdonald

(Nelson Thornes/ Faber/ Royal National Theatre, £6)

Age: 11-19 yrs

Plays for young people are hard to come by and it was the unfulfilled demand that inspired the Royal National Theatre, with funding from BT, to invite established playwrights to contribute scripts. These were distributed amongst schools, some of which attended workshops with the writers. The result is an inspired series, Connections, featuring such writers as Liz Lochhead and Alan Ayckbourn, amongst others. Macdonald's play is an intriguing sequel to the original Shakespeare. There is also a dedicated website (www.connections plays.co.uk). Check there to confirm appropriate age-range for individual plays.

webTitle: What can be done to help limit truancy?

fields.headline: I'll skip this one
fields.standfirst: Every day 50,000 children bunk off school. Truancy patrols are helping to limit the scale of the problem. But what of the pupils whose parents condone it? By  Esther Addley
fields.trailText: Every day 50,000 children bunk off school. Truancy patrols are helping to limit the scale of the problem. But what of the pupils whose parents condone it? By Esther Addley
fields.body:
It is not, I am realising, as easy as it looks. We are standing in the frozen meals section of Marks & Spencer's food hall, shooting furtive glances at a tall, attractive young girl in heavy make-up. "What do you reckon?" someone asks. "Only one way to find out." We troop across to the girl, who is shopping with her mother. "Excuse me, but can I ask - are you still at school?"

It is 11am on a wintry Friday in Islington, north London, and the shops are surprisingly busy. Older women pull baskets behind them, home-makers stock up on the weekly shop. And everywhere there are children: babies in pushchairs, 10-year-olds kicking along the street behind their grandparents, young girls who at first glance look 14 but who might easily be five years older.

It is the most difficult part of the job, says PC Jim Dodd from the schools and community office at Islington police. "Quite often we stop people who are 19 or 20. I just say to them, you'll be glad you look so young when you are older." He's much better on boys, he says. With girls he often gets it wrong.

Dodd and Sandra Rose, an educational welfare officer for the council, are familiar figures in this part of the borough. Every few weeks they patrol the market, checking for children who should be at school but are not. The shopkeepers and stall-holders know them, as do a good number of the kids they come across. All children who look of school age, whether on their own or with their parents, are stopped and asked why they are not in class.

It's a non-confrontational approach: their names and details are taken, and they are told that a call will be put into the school "just to check that everything is all right". But the presence of the uniformed officer lends an air of authority to the patrol, says Dodd. "I usually say to people when we stop them, 'don't worry, you're not in any trouble', though that's not necessarily true."

Every day of the year, 50,000 children skip school. It is a problem that has preoccupied politicians and educationists for decades, the faceless menace of "truanting", blamed for low educational achievement and anti-social behaviour, and for nurturing a generation of petty criminals.

This assumption is far from incorrect. Jack Straw recently remarked that he had never met a young offender who hadn't been involved in truanting, and one survey found that three-quarters of truants admitted to having committed at least one offence. Several councils have seen petty crime rates drop markedly with the introduction of proactive anti-truanting measures, notably Newham in east London, where car crime fell by 70% in the north of the borough on the days when the streets were being patrolled.

But as councils and police forces have become more coordinated in tackling the problem, particularly in organising "sweeps" to pick up truants, a more complicated picture of non-attendance has emerged than the cliched image of gangs of disaffected teenagers roaming the streets, bent on crime. In particular, it has become clear that many children bunk off school with the full knowledge of their parents. Almost two-thirds of the children stopped by a recent patrol in Salford were accompanied by parents or other carers. "The extent of parentally condoned truancy we would not have seen without the truancy sweeps," says Phil Hamerton, head of social inclusion for the education department at Manchester City Council. "We were quite surprised if not shocked by that, and that's a very important learning point. It's affected our strategy - our campaigning is now aimed partly at the parents." The council now runs sweeps once a week in some parts of the city.

Sure enough, most of the children stopped by Dodd and Rose are with a mother or a brother or a grandparent. "She's not playing truant, I can assure you of that," says the mother of one 13-year-old girl. "She knows better than that." She says her daughter wasn't feeling well during the night, though the girl is wearing short trousers and sandals and is laden with shopping bags from Iceland. "If she's not well enough to be at school, she's not well enough to be out shopping," says Rose, trotting out a well-worn phrase. webTitle: If you ask me...

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My daughter has been offered a place at an excellent secondary school. As we are Muslim I have asked if she would be allowed to wear a headscarf. The reply was no. Can they discriminate against my daughter in this way?
fields.trailText: Leading experts answer your problems
fields.body:
If you are from an ethnic minority, the school is completely outside the law in what it says. You can use the Race Relations Act to deal with this, because the school is laying down conditions which because of your culture or faith you cannot comply with. We've taken up a number of cases of this type, although we've never gone to court because the school has always given way - as I expect it will in this case. My advice would be to start by talking it over with the school. If you're from an ethnic minority you probably only have to point out that the school is acting unlawfully. Try not to be confrontational, at least initially. Don't assume the school will continue to be difficult once they realise how strong your case is.

Chris Myant
Commission for Racial Equality

The law allows Muslims to practise their faith without hitch or hindrance, and if anyone is preventing a Muslim girl from wearing a headscarf that's a denial of her basic religious rights. The headscarf is a symbol of modesty which it's incumbent on all women who read the Koran to wear. You need to start by pointing this out to the school, and if they seem unwilling to change their ideas you probably need to talk to someone at the LEA. If that doesn't work, I'd suggest approaching the DfEE - in the past the department has taken up similar cases strongly and I'm sure they would in your case. They aren't going to look favourably on any school that tries to deny any pupil her right to follow her faith.

Dr Syed Pasha
The National Muslim Education Council of the UK

The governing body must comply with the law on sex and race discrimination. Muslims are a religious rather than a racial group, so the Race Relations Act does not directly apply. However, it could be argued that the dress code indirectly discriminates because it will affect some racial groups more than others. The DfEE issued guidance last year to remind schools that dress code should not discriminate against different sexes, religions or races. You could point this out in a letter to the chair of governors and ask him or her to reconsider the decision. You may also wish to explain that a no-headscarves ruling will disproportionately affect certain racial groups.

Margaret McGowan
The Advisory Centre for Education

Coming next

We plan to take our children, aged five and nine, travelling for six months to a year. We're sure they're going to learn a lot, but how far should we go to safeguard their conventional education, too?

Do you have a problem with your child's education? Is something bothering you about his or her school? Each week we ask leading experts to advise on a specific issue. Please send in your "problem" marked "If you ask me" to Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or fax them to 020 7239 9933 or e-mail to education.letters@theguardian.com

webTitle: Can the government impose academic order on the chaos of early adolescence?

fields.headline: Young at heart
fields.standfirst: Most children leave primary school keen as mustard. One year on, too many are rude, badly behaved and bored. But can the government really impose academic order on the chaos of early adolescence?  Luisa Dillner  reports
fields.trailText: Most children leave primary school keen as mustard. One year on, too many are rude, badly behaved and bored. But can the government really impose academic order on the chaos of early adolescence? Luisa Dillner reports
fields.body:
It's not easy being a 12- to 14-year-old - and teaching young people of that age is harder still. Something happens to teenagers once the thrill of going to big school wears off, and the government doesn't like it. The Department for Education's green paper, Building on Success, published last week, says that "Pupils make far too little progress during these years. Attitudinal surveys show motivation falling and disaffection rising."

The seeds of later failure (especially in boys) are sown in these years, warns the government, so teaching standards and expectations for this age group must be raised.

Perhaps there is a limited armoury at the education department, but it has gone for the key stage 3 exam as its main weapon. To focus the minds of pupils and teachers, it proposes moving the exam from the age of 14 to 13 (from year 9 to 8).

The department suggests "catch-up" lessons for children who fall behind in English and maths, and offering some children accelerated progress to GCSEs. Convinced that numeracy and literacy strategies in primary schools have been successful, the government is already piloting their use in 205 secondary schools in 17 different local education authorities. The message is clear. All those 12- to 14-year-olds who thought the first three years of secondary school were about jostling for peer group position, struggling with their adolescence and having their imaginations fired by new subjects must think again. On the chaos of early adolescence the government wants to impose academic order.

The phenomenon of underachieving in the 12-14 age group is too well documented for the government to ignore. The Ofsted report published this month was emphatic that commitment and academic achievement falls away in years 8 and 9. More disturbingly, it noted the rise in bad behaviour and disaffection.

But is it possible to raise standards with primary school methods and a Sats exam for 13-year-olds? Is it simplistic to suppose that increasing the pace of learning will suddenly engage teenagers? Could it be that early adolescence is when social as much as school pressures affect academic achievement? A time when biology, emotional maturity and a tenuous hold on self-esteem are competing demands on the young person's attention span?

"There's an amazing mismatch between what children of this age are supposed to be doing according to the national curriculum and what their natural inclination would have them do," says Reva Klein, author of Defying Disaffection: How schools are winning the hearts and minds of reluctant learners (Trentham Books, £19.95). "They don't want to be sitting down and talked at, they want to be doing and discovering things."

Emotionally these are difficult ages, says Klein. "They have a lot going on in their minds, and it's hard for them to concentrate, to feel secure and able to communicate on different levels and to use the appropriate decorum that a school expects.

"They feel terribly singular and isolated, that they are the only people who feel things. They are at an age when they want to separate from their parents but feel anxious about it. They don't want to follow authority. They bring the bad stuff from home to school and the bad stuff from school back to home. It's a horrible time."

Klein believes the reactions to this terrible time vary between genders. "Whereas boys tend to act out their disaffection by playing the clown or truanting, girls drop out in their minds. I know I did when I was a teenager. I hated school. Girls keep their heads down and pretend they are invisible. Although there is a trend now for girls to act out in worrying ways."

Adrienne Katz is director of Young Voice, an organisation formed to listen and respond to the needs of young people, and the author of a report called The Leading Lads. She, too, doubts that any government plans to further regulate these years through academic programmes will tackle the problem. "It's social and to do with relationships - teenagers have a sense that no one listens to them, that no one knows them as people. School exaggerates this."

Her report found that truancy was often linked to teenagers feeling vulnerable at school, particularly from bullying. "Girls suffer because they are being treated like babies when they want more adult rights," says Katz. "Adults are slow to catch up with this need. Education seems out of kilter with the rate at which girls develop. There is a sharp increase in girls saying they need to be treated less like children between the ages of 13 and 14. Boys can have a big increase in suicidal feelings at this time. In adjusting to a new environment, it can be 18 months before they can attend to learning. They are so caught up in which group they should join or whether they're being made to look an idiot."

Dr Madeleine Portwood, senior educational psychologist at Durham LEA, says there is good evidence that disaffection with school at the age of 13 makes children more vulnerable to truancy. "Instead of being shown up for not doing good work, some children would rather be shown up for not behaving - they are more likely to get adulation from their peer group. There is a notion that we have problems because there's a culture that it's not cool to be good at school, but this seems far too simplistic."

Portwood does not believe that bringing the key stage 3 exams forward is a solution. "It's not the measurement that's the problem: it is what schools are doing to motivate children. At key stage 3 disaffected children benefit from being offered subjects they feel they can be good at - you want to be sure that an earlier exam doesn't compromise access to other subjects. Lots of children who drop out like games - it improves social skills and teaches team play in a secure environment."

Andrew Nixon, head of Fortismere School, a comprehensive in Muswell Hill, London, thinks the government is too narrow in its focus: "There's an unhealthy preoccupation with this narrow range of English, maths and science. You have to encourage children at this age to feel they are good at something, so we teach drama and put lots of emphasis on sport and creative arts, so that all children have that chance."

The lack of key stage exams in the first few years of secondary means teachers can be more creative. "Some of the best teaching takes place in these years because they are not overregulated," Nixon says. "All children respond to imaginative teaching. Most of our youngsters have no difficulty being on task and responding well.

"Children do regress in year 7 com pared with year 6 at top junior, but we are talking about a narrow range of competencies, in English, science and maths. But that is because they have been exposed to technology workshops, specialist teaching . . . lots of new things."

Patrick Lawton, a 14-year-old at Fortismere School, enjoys the wider curriculum. "I like the practical subjects where you're not just sitting down and writing. I enjoy technology where you're making something that you can take home and be proud of."

He is not convinced that Sats would be a motivational force in year 8. "We spent quite a bit of last year [year 9] preparing for Sats, and we didn't learn that much in the second part of the year because we were just revising. It's much easier to be motivated by enjoying something than by being set exams."

He likes secondary school because it brings more freedom and the teachers treat him as an adult. "Rather than shout at you, they will tell you that if you don't work you are the one that will lose out at the end of the day." But isn't it uncool to study? "It's cool to do well but not that well. It depends on who you are and how other people see you."

At Aldenham School, a public school for boys in Hertfordshire, the head, Richard Harman, also believes that to motivate teenagers you must treat them as individuals.

"You have to treat each child with respect. Because we are a small school it's easier for us to make our children feel they each have a talent. Boys are competitive, particularly in the short term, and if you handle it well you can turn it to your advantage. We have a short-term reward system that is easily understandable - we give 'golds' that reward good behaviour almost instantly. Motivating and keeping in place a firm structure, with clear discipline as well, is what can turn a boy around."

Promoting citizenship in schools - giving children a say in how things are run, may be another way of making teenagers feel involved and motivated. David Christy, senior lecturer in educational studies at the University of Strathclyde, says that in Scotland headteachers must now indicate in their school development plans how they will consult children. Some secondary schools have programmes in which all new children are consulted on setting standards of how they would like to be treated by peers and teachers. "Scottish schools are also looking at reducing the number of specialist lessons by combining some subjects and teaching, for example, broader topics such as environmental studies," says Christy.

Some teachers would argue that middle schools addressed the problems of this age group much more clearly than ordinary secondaries. Introduced in the 1970s and with children from 9-13 or 8-12, they were meant to iron out the problems of being a young teenager. "Middle schools were a good idea," says Brian Schram, the headteacher of Southwood Middle School in Milton Keynes. "The ages of 8-13 are a time when children go from more concrete to abstract thought and become more streetwise. We try to develop their independence but also their interactivity with other children."

Consultation on the government's proposals is likely to be heated. Dr Portwood is clear on who should be most consulted: "We need to listen to adolescents rather than prescribe what's good for them."

David Christy, senior lecturer in educational studies at the University of Strathclyde, says that in Scotland headteachers must now indicate in their school development plans how they will consult children. Some secondary schools have programmes in which all new children are consulted on setting standards of how they would like to be treated by peers and teachers. "Scottish schools are also looking at reducing the number of specialist lessons by combining some subjects and teaching, for example, broader topics such as environmental studies," says Christy. Some teachers would argue that middle schools addressed the problems of this age group much more clearly than ordinary secondaries. Introduced in the 1970s and with children from 9-13 or 8-12, they were meant to iron out the problems of being a young teenager. "Middle schools were a good idea," says Brian Schram, the headteacher of Southwood Middle School in Milton Keynes. "The ages of 8-13 are a time when children go from more concrete to abstract thought and become more streetwise. We try to develop their independence but also their interactivity with other children." Consultation on the government's proposals is likely to be heated. Dr Portwood is clear on who should be most consulted: "We need to listen to adolescents rather than prescribe what's good for them."

webTitle: On the Web: How plants grow | Charles Dickens

fields.headline: On the Web
fields.trailText: How plants grow | Charles Dickens
fields.body:
How plants grow

Lesson ideas
www.clickteaching.com/science/ks2_plants.shtml
Suitable for: KS2 teachers

Lesson ideas for investigating the effects of light, air, water and temperature on plant growth. "Parts of the Flowering Plant" is a worksheet which tests knowledge of the parts of a flower. Not suitable as a teaching tool but can be used for assessment at the end of a lesson.

Illustrated plants
tqjunior.thinkquest.org/3715
Suitable for: KS1 & KS2 teachers, KS2 pupils

Includes a clear, colourful picture of a plant, including roots, with all parts labelled. "What is a flower?" includes all essential vocabulary for national curriculum study with good colour illustrations. The other pages are equally well presented and offer great opportunities for further investigation of the topic.Very useful.

A revision aid
www.primaryresources.co.uk/science/plants.htm
Suitable for: KS2 teachers

Teachers notes are provided on the parts of a plant and what plants need to grow. Select "The Parts of a Flower" for a useful black and white illustration with practical information followed by a worksheet with all necessary spellings. A useful revision aid for Sats.

Leaves in autumn
photoscience.la.asu.edu/photosyn/education/colorchange.html
Suitable for: KS2 pupils & teachers

This United States site examines the question "Why do leaves change colour in the fall?" The information is clear and is accompanied by colour illustrations.

Videos
www.brainpop.com/science/plantsandanimals/pollination/
Suitable for: KS2 teachers & pupils

This superb site offers a choice of cartoon videos which explain a wide variety of scientific concepts, including photosynthesis and pollination. The commentary is rather fast but just manageable for children and is easily re-run. Movies start with an interactive quiz and cover several types of pollination, including wind. The parts of the flower are named and their role in reproduction explained.

Compiled by Jim Merrett

Charles Dickens

Dickens and his world
www.landow.stg.brown.edu/victorian/dickens/dickensov.html
Suitable for: KS3/4/teachers

Covers biography, works, economic contexts, political history, social history, religion and science, both in general and specifically linked to Dickens' own thoughts and experiences. Teacher direction is preferable.

A literary tour
www.Greenwichpast.com/vip/writers/dickens-greenwich-tour.htm
Suitable for: KS3/teachers

Created to celebrate the historical significance of Greenwich in 2000, this site offers a tour, with links to related passages in Dickens' novels. Provides an interesting introduction to the author and his works.

Dickens detectives
www.west.net/~cybrary/Dickens
Suitable for: KS2/3

This wonderful Californian site is an inventive and fun way to approach the great man. Students are presented with five "cases", to uncover the life and times of Dickens. Teachers would need to explore this first to ensure whether they need to provide additional resources, but then, just let them go!

The biography maker
www.bham.wednet.edu/bio/biomaker.htm
Suitable for: KS2/3

Another wonderful site. Students are guided through the process of writing a biography, in a fun and interactive way using the Biography Maker. Along the way, four key issues are covered: questioning; learning; synthesis; and storytelling. Some areas require additional classroom resources.

It's good to talk
www.talkingto.co.uk/talkingto/ttcd/index.asp
Suitable for: KS3/4

Allows students to "talk" to famous figures, including Dickens. Students don't actually submit questions, but can access responses written by leading experts on Dickens on a range of areas.

Who wants to be a Dickensian?
www.triv.net/html/Literature/dickens1.htm
Suitable for: KS3/4

This quiz site is loosely based upon the TV series, Who Wants to be a Millionaire, (without the money, unfortunately). Whilst not the most cerebral of sites, it's a good way to learn and a chance to test your trivial knowledge of Dickens.

Compiled by Amanda Grimwood

fields.trailText: Learning for Life Volume 1 | 1,000 Questions for GCSE Modern World History
fields.body:
Learning for Life Volume 1
(Grampian Police, tel: 01224 709975, edliaise@ifb.co.uk )
Price: £58.75 for single user
Age: 5-11 yrs

Supports the PSHE curriculum, particularly topics on vandalism, bullying and drugs sense. The content is split for three age bands and is well thought out, with strong curriculum relevance. It has clear progression within topics, eg bullying. Children work through key ideas such as coping strategies, friendship skills etc. Children can use it easily with minimum adult help. Teachers' resources help with planning and providing more information. Printable worksheets useful for teachers and staff Inset days and for informing parents.

1,000 Questions for GCSE Modern World History
(Heinemann, £64.61 incl. VAT )
Age: KS4

With 1,000 topic-based questions this program supports all the main topics of modern history and all examination boards. It is a helpful revision tool, with each of the eight topics having three levels of difficulty: foundation, core and advanced. It follows a basic question and answer format. The final question demands that the student works out the answer from a series of clues. Teachers can edit questions to suit their classes and can print out tests. This program could prove a useful addition to a history department's library of CD-roms.

You can read full evaluations of these programs at www.teem.org.uk

webTitle: The school I'd like competition: Great Ormond Street Hospital

fields.headline: A school refuge
fields.standfirst: Claire Phipps  visits Great Ormond Street Hospital, which is taking part in our competition
fields.trailText: The school I'd like: Claire Phipps visits Great Ormond Street Hospital, which is taking part in our competition
fields.body:
It's a rare school, in these times of teacher shortages, that finds itself with a surplus of applicants for every vacancy it advertises. But then this is an unusual school in many ways. For example: "I must be the only head who doesn't know all my children," says headteacher Yvonne Hill, as she shows visitors around the classroom. Or another one: in how many schools would teachers be expected to supervise a session on making paper chameleons for a rainforest display and keep watch over a pupil's IV drip?

The Children's Hospital School at Great Ormond Street is about as child-centred an institution as you'd be likely to find. Government targets mean little (although the school is still subject to Ofsted inspections and must give a nod to the national curriculum) when your pupils have needs as individual as these children. From long-term patients to recurring regulars and even the siblings of those in the wards upstairs, the school has to be able to take them in at a moment's notice - and lose them again, for whatever reason, just as quickly.

"The recurring and long-stay children are our priority," explains Hill. "Motivation can be difficult when you have children who are sick and disaffected. But we need to encourage them to come down to the school; no one is compelled to come."

A key means of attracting reticent children (those who can't or won't leave their beds are tutored in the wards) is through ICT. John Sosna, the school's ICT co-ordinator, believes that it is one element of "normal" schooling that most are eager to continue with. Children unable to come down , such as those in dialysis wards, have laptops that link them to the classroom. (And no, in case you're wondering, there are never enough to go round.)

"Most kids are very into IT, whether it's developing a web page or making a movie," says Sosna. "It's something that really engages them." In a school such as this, though, ICT can have uses beyond its cross-curricular benefits. Long-term patients use email to keep in contact with their home schools; a videoconference link with the science labs at Haberdashers' Aske's school extends the hospital classroom beyond its rather cramped confines.

That lack of space is something the children would like to change. But the school has to take a rather unique approach to such long-term projects as The School I'd Like competition.

"You never know who's going to walk through the door from one day to the next," Sosna points out. "You'll have a core of children to work on projects, but each lesson also needs to be a whole, so they have something to take away with them andfeel that they have achieved something."

And what they achieve is up to the children. A list of "expected" names is chalked on a board - these children may turn up or they may not; they could appear for 10 minutes and then be called away for treatment. No medical procedures are carried out here - it's a refuge from a life in hospital, a place where children do the things they ought to be doing.

And yes, that does include exams. Older children, who might find themselves admitted just before a crucial GCSE period, bring in their own work or make contact with the home school to keep up. Or they could, of course, take a break from school and concentrate on getting well again. As Hill says: "Everything is dictated by them."

To enter the competition: email education@theguardian.com or write to Education Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER for an entry form.

The prizes: The winner in each of the three categories (primary; years 7-9; years 10-13) will receive £10,000 of Toshiba ICT equipment and Microsoft software for their school. If you would like to see your school featured here, please contact the above address.

webTitle: So you want to learn...game show research

fields.headline: So you want to learn...
fields.standfirst: Game show research
fields.trailText: Game show research
fields.body:
Nice to see you, to see you... Sorry?

Come on, you must know it. Know what?

Anthea, give us a twirl! Have you been drinking?

Course not. But you should know it all. What?

Brucie's patter. I haven't a clue what you're on about.

Call yourself a game show researcher. I am a game show researcher!

And you don't know the Forsyth oeuvre. It's a flower, isn't it, "forsythover". We had that on Countdown.

Ye gods! What do you do all day? Game show researchers do a variety of tasks, ranging from compiling questions for quizzes to interviewing and auditioning contestants for gameshows.

Sounds a doddle. Huh! It takes a great deal of time, finding out material for quizzes and gameshows, including audio and visual material, which throws up all sorts of copyright probs.

Where do you work? On the sets. We're usually based in a production office. Quite a lot are self-employed

What are the desired qualities? We need excellent communication and social skills, and the ability or relate to many different people. An awful lot of patience comes in handy and bags of enthusiasm for interviewing prospective contestants. And we've got to be able to put them at their ease.

Anything else? An ability to work under pressure as production companies may need to have strict deadlines, because some gameshows are filmed in blocks. And, as most of the work is solitary, researchers need to be self starting and easily motivated, and able to multitask as well, as there may be a number of things that need to be done all at once. Not forgetting good keyboard and computer literacy skills to research material from reference or archive sources.

What are the entry requirements? Nothing formal is required other than being able to demonstrate some of the skills and qualities mentioned above. However, most researchers have degree-level academic qualifications. Previous employment gained in magazine or newspaper journalism may be an advantage.

Any age requirements? There are no upper age limits. Most researchers start in their mid twenties and many will move into other jobs in the industry. Employers often try researchers on short contracts before offering them experience on different programmes.

What kind of training do you get? Many researchers start off down the journalist's route, so will have already a lot of experience in how to interview and research information.

The organisation Ft2 run an 18-month researcher training scheme, but it is aimed at factual researchers, rather than games show researchers. This offers attachments to a production company, and additional training in other important areas such as legal copyright.

What are the opportunities like? It's a very competitive profession and you're not very likely to be employed for the same employer year after year.

And future prospects? As researchers work so closely within the programme-making process, experience in this field can be an excellent springboard to a variety of other broadcasting jobs.

FT2
www.ft2.org.uk

Skillset
Telephone 0207 534 5300 www.skillset.org
