webTitle: Victims complaints of bullying upheld at Basildon college

fields.headline: College bullies
fields.standfirst: Victims' complaints are upheld, report  Simon Midgley and  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Victims' complaints are upheld, report Simon Midgley and Peter Kingston
fields.body:
Aculture of bullying has prevailed in Basildon College while managers looked the other way, an investigation has concluded.

The bullying went further than the principal, Chris Chapman, who resigned last week, according to a report by the Further Education Funding Council.

Chapman, the college's principal since September 1997, was suspended in March 2000 following staff allegations that a culture of fear and intimidation existed in the college.

The claims of bullying and harassment came in the wake of the funding council inspection report which gave the college eight (out of 10) grade 4s (the second lowest grading classification) for curricula and cross-college provision. Professor David Melville, the funding council's chief executive described the report as the third worst inspection report ever.

A six-strong funding council team investigated eight allegations of bullying and harrassment. These included: blaming teaching staff for the poor inspection, while saying the inspectors had blundered in giving a grade 4 for management; keeping staff fearful for jobs from constant disciplinary threats; and telling staff that if they weren't working 60 hours a week they weren't performing properly.

"The investigation team were persuaded that, at least in certain sections of the college, there is a culture of bullying and it was not limited to the principal alone.

"There is also a 'keep your head down' culture among a number of managers, especially senior managers. This is very often found where there is bullying."

After indications that the inspection in October 1999 had not gone well, some 20 college employees were threatened with disciplinary procedures. These charges were later dropped, but around 15 lecturers resigned from the college because they could not put up with what they felt to be the intimidatory nature of the management culture.

In the wake of the inspection report and the receipt of more than 50 complaints from college lecturers and managers about senior management's leadership style, which it was alleged, created a culture of fear, Professor Melville dispatched an investigatory team to the college.

The chairman, vice chairman and many of the college's board of governors subsequently resigned and have been replaced by new governors.

In August the college is due to merge with Thurrock college. Acting principal, John Gould, said: "The resignation of Chris Chapman means that we can now draw a line under the old college . . . the governors are only prepared to discuss the future.

"The governing body, the management and staff are working hard to make the impending merger a success."

Two members of the lecturers' union Natfhe have outstanding personal injury claims against the college. Natfhe said members felt vindicated but also outraged "it has taken almost a year for this outcome to be reached and even now no disciplinary action has been instigated."

webTitle: Rostrum

fields.headline: Fries with that
fields.standfirst: The burger sector needs decent training too, says  Sylvia Merris-McDonald
fields.trailText: The burger sector needs decent training too, says Sylvia Merris-McDonald
fields.body:
The launch of the joint DfEE/DTI white paper on enterprise, skills and innovation last week provides an insight into the government's thinking on work-based training and workforce development.

There are also strong indications that government wants to have a positive dialogue with training providers to develop capacity and achieve continuous improvement in quality. This view will be re-enforced with the publication of a DfEE consultation paper "Getting the best from each other".

But with less than six weeks to go before local Learning and Skills Councils take over the role of Training and Enterprise Councils there are still concerns about some aspects of the new funding regime.

It is inevitable that large-scale restructuring will produce winners and losers. The move from 72 TECs to 47 local Learning and Skills Councils stimulated intensive negotiations with government officials and their agencies to ensure that the new arrangements do not disadvantage work-based training providers . The Association of Learning Providers (ALP) is encouraged that after many years the modern apprentice sector is starting to get funding that fits the bill. What is needed now is for the service industry to be examined similarly, particularly given employment growth in this sector.

Whilst the majority of providers accept there is still a lot of work to do in the longterm, many believe there should be an acceptable level of short-term funding in place for 2001-02. However expectations have probably been raised too high and assumptions have been made that everything will happen from day one. It is worth reminding everybody that the Learning and Skills Council only comes into being on 1 April 2001.

Our members are currently negotiating with TEC-seconded staff to sort out some of the funding anomalies - for example, those caused by using 1999 as the base year for "profiling". This seriously affects those providers who have grown in the last year. It's also bad news for those who received low "on-programme" payments and are losing out on expected outcome payments. This hopefully will be solved by so-called "cushioning" arrangements.

Another area of concern is the proposed phasing out of what is termed "other training" by September 2002. This will have particular effect on those engaged in the service sectors, such as customer service, retail and fast food.

Within the buoyant UK economy many young people who do not prosper within the education system choose to enter the labour market directly at 16 or 17. "Other training" often provides a first step back into learning for this group, especially as full-blown apprenticeship schemes often put them off the whole idea. Other training acts as a gateway to further learning.

Other training also provides the first steps on the qualification ladder for slightly older workers who have few or no qualifications. This is particularly true for many 19- to 24-year-olds who have entered the labour market directly without going through further learning. It represents the key programme for this group and is often the catalyst for further educational achievement.

The assertion that all work-based learners will be part of an extended Gateway programme or Foundation Modern Apprenticeship frameworks covering more occupational areas is simplistic and misses vital issues.

One is the rejection of key skills by many employers, who believe these should be the responsibility of the education system. This view is held by some major household names who can boast excellent training records.

The Association of Learning Providers is convinced of the value of other training in work-based learning, and will be asking the DfEE to reconsider their decision. Despite these concerns, most training providers, particularly those represented by the association, are optimistic. The development of the Learning and Skills Council, with its greater awareness of work-based learning and the integration of vocational training means that providers are generally looking forward to steady progress during this period of radical change.

Sylvia Merris-McDonald is press and communications officer for Association of Learning Providers, an alliance of national training associations and training providers who, between them, deliver 80% of work-based, vocational learning across the UK.

webTitle: Furthermore

fields.headline: Tell us another one...
fields.standfirst: Francis Beckett looks into the performance related future
fields.trailText: Francis Beckett looks into the performance related future
fields.body:
One further education college gives performance pay on the basis of lecturers' scores for "contribution to cheerful atmosphere in college" and "loyalty" and "customer care" among other things. Another college gives the performance bonus to one teacher from each department who "has done really well". Now the colleges and the government want a national scheme for performance pay. How will you get your bonus in 2010? . . .

The summons to the chief executive's office came just as Harry Wilkins was packing to go home. It had been a long, hard day and he thought, just for a moment, of pretending the message hadn't reached him, for he was very tired. But he needed that bonus. His children's birthdays were coming up, and the family needed a holiday badly.

As he knocked at the door, he pasted a huge grin on his face. "Come in," called Mr Grimley in a voice like thunder, and Harry threw open the door and dropped to his knees in the deep pile carpet, which already - he saw with disgust - had dents in the unmistakable shape of Lucy Smith's elegant knees.

"Well?" said Grimley, putting his fingers together and tilting his huge leather chair back. Harry, shuffling forward on his knees, hands together in supplication, the grin somehow still stuck to his face, caught a glimpse through the office window of his colleague Arthur Smith doing cartwheels exactly in Mr Grimley's line of sight. Harry said desperately:

"There was an Englishman, an Irishman and a Scotsman."

Grimley leaned forward, peered over the top of his spectacles, and said: "We do not wish to know that. Kindly leave the stage."

Harry's voice was edged with desperation now. "Mr Grimley, would you like to hear about the way in which I satisfied my GNVQ customers today? Or about the ways in which I was able to improve the learning experience for my A-level customers?"

"Leave" said Grimley in a terrible voice.

The staff room was depressingly familiar. Sally Bright was wearing her Kiss Me Quick overalls, and from one dim corner came the rhythmic flashing of Charlie Entwhistle's battery operated tie. Harry should have gone home. Just a few minutes rest, he thought, and sat down in one of the two threadbare armchairs. At once there was a loud trumpeting noise, and he knew, with a sinking heart, that he had sat on Charlie Entwhistle's whoopee cushion, again.

The door was flung open and a booming voice shouted out: "What-ho, boyos, top of the morning to yez. Are we not lucky to be working in such a splendid place, doing such an inspiring job? Why don't we all recall three ways in which we have increased customer satisfaction today, thanks to our beloved college's dedication to Total Quality Management?"

"Drop it, Brendan," said Harry wearily. "He's not here."

"Oh." Brendan looked round the room. He sat in the other armchair, and they looked at each other, gloomily.

In the end none of them got the bonus. It went to the staff representative on the board of governors. She had the wit to suggest that the governors should pay the chief executive a 100% increase, to bring his annual salary to the round half million.

webTitle: Is the new learning regime founded on mistaken assumptions?

fields.headline: No stopping now
fields.standfirst: Is the new learning regime founded on mistaken assumptions, asks  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Is the new learning regime founded on mistaken assumptions, asks Peter Kingston
fields.body:
Some government schemes are focus-group proof. They have so much riding on them that their presentation could suddenly cause entire front loungefuls of middle Englanders to snort their Rich Tea bickies up their noses and they wouldn't be changed.

The government's post-16 reforms now have that unstoppable momentum. Whatever else may happen in this pre-election phony war, it is a dead cert that on April 2 there will be a big Learning and Skills Council and 47 mini clones.

The Institute of Public Policy Research is no mere focus group. Even so, this thinktank which snuggles closest to the ear of government cannot expect the critical debate it is hosting today on the post-16 landscape to get any shrift at all from ministers.

The seminar hosted by the IPPR at its offices off the Strand promises to throw up robust proposals on what should happen to higher and further education. Important as the issues are, it does look to be cutting things comically fine to be suggesting, in effect, a return to the drawing board just two months before the new £6bn system is unveiled.

But, as Professor Howard Glennister of the London School of Economics, and a key speaker said, there are no illusions about getting into the manifesto this time around.

"I'd like to go back to the drawing board, but that's the academic view."

His fellow lead-speaker and LSE colleague, Dr Nicholas Barr, shrugs with scholarly sang-froid at the notion that the debate might be incongruously timed. That is not the academic's concern, even for one used to pitching in with policy advice at the highest level. He's currently advising the Hungarian government on a proposed student loans system.

And he's certainly used to telling the highest circles at home what they don't want to hear. He advised a recent seminar at 11 Downing Street that it is not possible with any precision to measure the connection between education and economic growth. In other words it is not possible to find a scientific measure for the spillover benefits to society of educating individuals.

The corollary is that no one can calculate what share of the cost of an individual's tertiary education the taxpayer should stump up for.

And yet in its post-16 reforms, government does appear to insist that the spillover fruits of education can be measured. Time and again ministers talk about Britain suffering a skills deficit which can be measured. Furthermore our national economic game can be substantially raised if only that gap can be filled by further education. This underpins the drive for widening participation and all the targets to which education ministers are now apparently addicted.

More than one voice today will give an opinion that these targets and their premise, if not plucked out of the air, are dodgy; not least Peter Robinson, the IPPR's senior economist and co-organiser of this series of post-16 seminars. According to those who share Robinson's views, the targets are arbitrary: 60% of 21-year-olds and 50% of adults to have level 3 qualifications by 2002 etc.

He says bluntly that the National Skills Taskforce's assertion that by the end of the decade two-thirds of employment will be at level 3 is wrong. This illustrates the failure of planners to understand the economy.

Ministers like to cite the level 3 deficit between Britain and its EU partners, France and Germany.

Switzerland, Austria and Denmark, says Robinson, share with Germany a similar apprenticeship-based training system and relatively high proportions of the workforce with intermediate qualifications. Switzerland, Austria and Denmark, however, show productivity levels no higher than those in Britain.

Today's seminar, entitled Discerning Consumers in a Learning Market, will debate the proposal that the whole of post-compulsory school age education, including higher education, should operate as a market.

"Can we really have post-secondary school education in these separate watertight compartments?" asks Howard Glennister.

"Does it make sense to have two separate funding regimes. I don't think it does make sense."

Glennister believes that in the separation of the sectors clear opportunities are not available to people to make the best decisions.

The boundary between sectors is getting increasingly fuzzy on the ground. Ministers hope that foundation degrees can only melt the barrier down further. Glennister argues, though, that real choice for everyone cannot be possible without two basic conditions: equal information and equal funding.

Despite the bulging web data on higher education institutions, many working class young people, he says, just don't have the information, at least not in an effective mode, to consider university.

"Some people may go into further education because they know about it and don't go into higher education because they don't."

He argues not just for a level playing field where all institutions can charge fees, and there is an income-contingent student loan system. Why not give all 18-, or 21- year-olds, a capital sum which could be used for education or for starting up a business.

Years of scrutinising markets have led Barr to conclude that information is paramount in deciding the relative roles they and the state should play in service provision.

The state should have the lead role in schools, as it should with health care, because the punters in each case can't get or use the necessary information to make good choices.

Tertiary education is more akin to food, where consumers can be relied on to make choices. In Barr's view post-16 education should be left to the market, with the state insuring that all consumers have the means to participate.

"The difference between food and health care has bugger all to do with ideology. Food conforms with the conditions you need for a market to work efficiently and health doesn't."

Labour has been embracing markets, too warmly for some supporters. In the 1999 white paper Learning to Succeed there was a clearly expressed desire for a learning market driven by the needs of the learner.

But how does this square with the triple layers of planning in the new system?

fields.standfirst: Danny Foster
fields.trailText: Danny Foster
fields.body:
Born: May 3, 1979

Occupation: Singer. Member of what is for the moment the most famous quintet in the country. A trained nursery nurse plucked to fame by "Nasty Nigel" and his two co-judges on ITV's Popstars.

College: City & Islington college

Attended: 1996-1998

Studied: Diploma in Nursery Nursing; was aiming to do a primary BEd.

A tutor recalls: "Danny was a really able student, with plenty of merits and distinctions. He worked well with children of all abilities, and especially enjoyed working with children with special needs. We are all thrilled at his success on Popstars."

Danny recalls: "They were absolutely brilliant at college. It was wicked."

webTitle: New course to help Asperger's sufferers cope with work

fields.headline: Social skills
fields.standfirst: John Crace on a course to help Asperger's sufferers cope with work
fields.trailText: John Crace on a course to help Asperger's sufferers cope with work
fields.body:
Last week a boy of 12 was found guilty of killing his baby brother. The boy suffered from Asperger's syndrome, a form of autism, and the prosecution accepted a plea of manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility as his condition left him prone to violent rages. Thankfully, such severe cases are rare, but even in its mildest forms Asperger's still exacts a heavy price on sufferers.

Asperger's syndrome was first identified in Germany in the 1940s, but only became widely understood and diagnosed in the English-speaking world about 10 years ago. It is now estimated that as many as one in 200 people, most of them male, may suffer from either autism or Asperger's.

The social and emotional cues - the intonation of speech and facial expressions - that most people decode instinctively in their daily interactions remain a mystery to Asperger's sufferers. So while many may have high IQs and be technically and logically extremely proficient, they lack the ability to relate to other people. To the outside world they are geeks, nerds, self-centred or obsessives; stamp collectors, even.

In some careers, this may not matter. Geniuses such as Wittgenstein and Einstein are believed to have had Asperger's, while some have speculated a similar diagnosis for Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft. But in other professions, the syndrome can be a massive problem.

"We come across people who fail to get promotion at work because they lack the social skills," says Dr Simon Baron-Cohen, co-director of the Autism Research Centre at Cambridge University. "Those with Asperger's find it hard to have a casual chat over a cup of coffee. Some may also lack the people skills for management; they tend to be perfectionists who are so focused on the details that they don't make mistakes and they find it hard to accept human error in others."

Social skills are often as important in the workplace as technical or professional qualifications, and up till now there has been no help available for Asperger's sufferers. This may be about to change as Dr Baron-Cohen is currently developing an interactive CD-rom to enable Asperger's and autism sufferers to understand and identify other people's emotions and expressions.

Dr Baron-Cohen is well aware of the inherent paradox of using computer technology to teach emotions to the potentially technologically obsessed, but he feels it is a medium they understand, and will therefore use, and one that is best suited to repetitive tasks.

"In real life facial expressions may be transient. These individuals aren't learning them through normal channels and may need to study them in great detail," he points out. "A computer can repeat the same thing endlessly."

The CD-rom, with a working title Teaching Mindreading aims to be useful for all age groups across the whole spectrum of autism, from those with learning difficulties to those with average or even talented intelligence. "There will be courses pitched at each developmental level," Baron-Cohen continues. "When you first log on, either the parent, teacher or the individual will be asked to fill in some personal details , such as their age to guide them to a suitable starting level. From there they can progress at their own rate."

The core of the programme will be a database of facial expressions. Dr Baron-Cohen and his team in Cambridge have identified over 1,000 words in the English language which describe human emotions; these are being photographed with both adults and children expressing them. Each emotion has been assigned to the age groups at which it is commonly understood.

The programme also matches the words to audio files, as tone of voice can be hard to decode emotionally. Finally the CD-rom will provide multiple examples of contexts that give rise to each emotion. Dr Baron-Cohen recognises that what he is doing is only a first step to providing sufferers with social skills. "The information on the CD-rom will hopefully make them better at picking up emotional cues in others," he says,

"Applying such knowledge in the real world may still need the feedback of live social skills teaching. The CD-rom will be valued for its use both as a solitary teaching tool and in group lessons. It is still in development and we welcome any suggestions from teachers, parents and those with autism and Asperger's about what they would want to see included."

Suggestions about the project can be made at www.autismsoftware.co.uk

webTitle: Investigations continue at Barnsley college

fields.headline: Barnsley crisis deepens
fields.standfirst: Investigators probe a complex web of business dealings. By  Francis Beckett
fields.trailText: Investigators probe a complex web of business dealings. By Francis Beckett
fields.body:
Another college chief is to be parachuted in to take control of crisis-torn Barnsley College as investigations continue into a possible £6m funding overclaim as well as its chief executive's complex business dealings.

Last year the college denied any impropriety, but the National Audit Office and the Further Education Funding Council are all trying to unravel the complicated web of companies in which Barnsley's chief executive, David Eade, has been involved over the past decade.

One company was devoted to publishing a surfing magazine. Another bought paintings.

Detectives and the audit office are scrutinising the college's relationship with Progress Training, which was set up in 1990 and collapsed in October. The college's official line has been that it was a private company to which the college subcontracted some work.

But Eade, 57, whose £101,000 salary makes him the second highest paid principal in further education, was a director of the company until July 28 1999, when he resigned under pressure from the funding council. The company was set up and owned by Barnsley College Educational Trust, which was set up by the Barnsley College Corporation and of which Eade was chairman. No one can name any other clients apart from Barnsley College. Most of its work was done by college staff on secondment.

Liquidated on the same day was Focus Trading Ltd, whose role was "to develop and sell education-related services", and Barnsley College Holdings Ltd, holding company for the other two. Eade had been a director of all three, which together owe well over £200,000 to Barnsley College. Their only other creditors are the bank and Inland Revenue.

Eade, who is on sick leave following an operation, was also the director of another company with financial links to Progress Training, Frontline UK Ltd, where two fellow directors were his stepson and stepdaughter, Christopher and Sarah Nelson. Its main activity was a magazine about surfing, on which the Nelsons are thought to be very keen. A note to Frontline's 1998 accounts states that it was given a loan of £21,000 by Progress Training.

Investigators will want the college to flesh out its contracts with Progress Training. They will want to see the open learning packages purchased for £21,000 in 1996. Progress Training also bought paintings from local artist Ashley Jackson for £20,000. Jackson, who thought he was dealing with the college, donated further paintings. It was not until the company went into liquidation that he realised the paintings would be sold by the liquidator. He has had to buy back his work.

In 1995, finance director Michelle Squires wrote to the company: "The college will require consultancy ser vices to assist in the planning, initiation and implementation of overseas links . . . The college will require 100 consultancy days for the above services . . . for which a fee of £33,600 will be paid."

The college said it was unable to pay last year's full pay agreement to its staff. Those lecturers who refused to give up their old contracts were not given any pay award last year.

This week Natfhe branch secretary Paul Heggie said: "The staff here have worked very hard for the college, and made it much better at getting local people into further education. Staff and the community should not carry the can for the actions of senior management. We need a new start, and we need help from the funding council."

webTitle: The ease of electronic distance learning

fields.headline: Net that degree
fields.standfirst: Whether you're in an office or a remote hamlet, if you're fishing for commercial skills nothing is easier than electronic distance learning, says  Stephen Hoare
fields.trailText: Whether you're in an office or a remote hamlet, if you're fishing for commercial skills nothing is easier than electronic distance learning, says Stephen Hoare
fields.body:
Like White Fang, e-learning is a creature of the wild open spaces. It is no accident that the only two virtual universities in the world - Athabasca in Canada and in Finland are far from civilisation. Learning online is ideal when you have a high penetration of the net and a widely dispersed population.

Learning online has also become a viable alternative to much of what goes on in the classroom. With its click icons, decision trees and seemingly inexhaustible banks of interactive self-checking exercises, it is an ideal medium for instructional teaching. There is an entire industry of software designers, publishers and consultants - players such as IBM, Smartforce and Pearson - busy developing web-based training packages for people who just want facts and no frills.

Not surprisingly, e-learning has had an enormous impact on the world of business, where it meets the needs of time-poor executives. According to Ettie McCormack, training manager for Unisys: "It's a cultural change. Managers can't be out of the office for five days and run their operations from a classroom. Self-study is part of the job, and it can be done from a laptop at home or in an airport lounge or just closing the office door for a while."

Universities are experiencing similar pressures. e-Learning has been adopted widely by business schools, where it is taking over from the postal service as the delivery mechanism for distance learning. For postgraduate degrees and continuing professional development, e-learning is the obvious answer to widening participation.

Anglia Polytechnic University puts its MA (Ed) and its National Professional Qualification for Headship (NPQH) online to make studying more attractive for professionals holding down busy and demanding jobs. Professor Stephen Heppell says: "Some of our students were spending four hours travelling for three hours of tuition. And they couldn't all make a regular time commitment. Designing an online course helped inclusion and gave us much-needed flexibility."

Prof Heppell's online MA has much more than the interactive self-study that is the basis of most business courses. Typically for university-level e-learning, it features asynchronous (students do not all have to log on at the same time) chatroom communication which involves intensive question and answer sessions.

He argues that it is better for learning and teaching than the conventionally taught MA. Research into student interaction in seminars revealed that the people who dominated the discussion were among the least intelligent.

"We found the 'oracy stars' were well down the list. The ones who had been sitting quietly had been waiting for the conversation to reach a level of intelligence where they felt able to join in. Online learning is less confrontational. People find it easier to reflect on what is being said and come back after more reading and research."

It is also easier to monitor students' performance because, online, their absence would be noticed more quickly. "If you don't type you're not there," says Prof Heppell. "It flags up a problem."

But the professor warns that e-learning is not a cost-cutting panacea and, far from cutting swathes through the teaching profession, the chatroom and the virtual classroom put academic staff on their mettle. "You need staff who know their subject inside out who can provide light-touch diagnosis - it's the skill of managing online learning. The mistake people make is that online learning is for geeks who are more into HTML (the tool for designing web pages) than subject knowledge."

Heppell reflects the prevailing view of e-learning academics when he says that online delivery systems need to be part of the mix of offerings that universities must develop to meet the needs of students.

Even at a campus university staff do not always have the opportunity to meet and discuss issues face-to-face and learning does not only take place in the lecture theatre or in the tutorial. Cranfield School of Management, for example, issues its MBA students with laptops and e-learning software when they join the course.

MBA lecturer Richard Kwiatkowski says: "Lotus notes, database and e-mail provide access to a lot of information. But while the e-learning is a short cut to research, skills like leadership or business strategy can only be taught in the classroom. You learn as a team and you build on the synergy of the team."

That said, e-learning is set to make a big impact at all levels of the university system and the race is on to develop the technology. Leading the field, the Higher Education Funding Council of England is negotiating with several private-sector partners to help it develop the e-university. As an online platform, the e-university will provide courses from undergraduate level up and will embrace all subjects - not just the obvious ones such as business and IT but the arts as well.

With a launch date set for March 2002, the e-university will provide the framework and the expertise to help UK universities who lack resources to develop their own e-learning solutions to a wider market - namely overseas distance learners.

So far the government has provided £62m to fund the project, which will receive as much again in matched funding from the private sector. The aim is to build an online flagship for UK plc and beat off the threat of serious market competition for overseas students from US and European universities.

Stephen Marston, director of institutions for the council, says: "The e-university is a new way of bringing together universities, colleges and other partners to develop new online programmes and services. Globally there is enormous potential for online courses, and if we don't do this the UK will be missing a big opportunity."

webTitle: Sharon battling against time in coalition talks

fields.headline: Sharon battling against time in coalition talks
fields.trailText: Israeli prime minister-elect Ariel Sharon is fast losing patience with the lumbering negotiations over forming a government of national unity.
fields.body:
Israeli prime minister-elect Ariel Sharon is fast losing patience with the lumbering negotiations over forming a government of national unity.

Since winning the prime ministerial election on February 6, Sharon and his leading lieutenants in the rightwing Likud bloc have been locked in endless, acrimonious coalition discussions with the Labour party.

After two weeks of public backbiting, the political crisis is now reaching a head, with Sharon threatening to break off discussions with the Labour party unless a deal is done by Monday.

Labour leader Ehud Barak is trying to reconcile his ambition to become defence minister in Sharon's administration, with the promise he made after losing the prime ministership that he would withdraw from politics.

Even more bizarrely, Barak remains prime minister until Sharon can somehow assemble a majority in the chronically fractious Knesset (parliament). Should he fail to do so, the country faces yet more elections, for parliament and prime minister.

The new deadline has so far done little to concentrate minds on either side. Barak, according to political commentators, is making more rather than fewer demands. He is insisting that the coalition must not include small, far-right Knesset factions, and that he and other putative Labour ministers must have unfettered control over their departments.

With Barak as defence minister and former prime minister Shimon Peres almost certain to become foreign minister, such an implied veto would severely restrict Sharon's scope for imposing radical change on Israel's diplomatic and security policies.

In the latest Byzantine manoeuvre, Barak has apparently done a deal with his own Labour faction. He has promised his likely successor as party chairman, Knesset speaker Avraham Burg, that if he becomes defence minister, he will not mount any future challenge for the leadership.

What makes the picture murkier, is Burg's unpopularity in the Knesset Labour caucus. They see the formation of a national unity government as a means of delaying a leadership race, and thus denying Burg the job.

Adding to Sharon's difficulties, according to knowledgeable observers, is the lurking presence of former Likud leader and prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu.

Netanyahu, who was comprehensively defeated by Barak in the 1999 prime ministerial election, is itching to make a comeback. Israeli commentators say he'd love a Sharon coalition to fall apart, provoking fresh elections in which he could challenge for the Likud nomination.

Meanwhile, as Sharon struggles to fill the vacuum in Israeli politics, another and in some ways more worrying hiatus is appearing in the Palestinian territories, where Yasser Arafat's authority and his rag-tag apparatus of government - the Palestinian National Authority (PNA) - are both crumbling.

During the eight years of the Oslo peace process, Arafat was firmly in the driving seat of Palestinian politics. He was able to sideline or simply ignore the alternative power structures that had grown up during his long years of exile.

Now, with Oslo dead and buried, the various arms of the Palestine Liberation Organisation of which Arafat is titular head, are finding new independent vigour. So too are the anti-Oslo factions, both Islamist and secular, for whom the PNA has been at best an irrelevance and at worst a betrayal.

webTitle: The Way You See It

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: Arsenal v Chelsea: your verdict
fields.body:
Arsenal v Chelsea: your verdict

Has The Way You See It been abducted by Daily Mail readers? Read the reaction to the mass fracas at Highbury on Sunday and judge for yourself.

"The latest boxing match between the two sides and the events prior to that were more distasteful than the tussle between Man Utd and Arsenal when they were deducted points in a league match a few years ago," blasts Cf Hui - although thankfully he doesn't call for anyone to be put away for a very long time.

Instead he argues: "A fine means nothing to these wealthy clubs. I think Arsenal should be kicked out of the FA Cup, not that that's going to happen." Not a Chelsea fan by any chance are you, Mr Hui?

Another reader not happy with the off-the-ball antics at Highbury last weekend is MC Leese. "Having been present at an Arsenal match the other day, I was very surprised to see the artistic way that aggression happened without the referee seeing it," he says.

"There's no need for players of that quality to behave little better than thugs. Ranieri too seemed excessively aggressive; waving his arms and pacing up and down. I was very disappointed."

Why David Lacey is wrong about Igor and Macca

This week it's the turn of David Lacey to receive flak for his opinions. (Well, Richard Williams is away.) And the reason for your fury? Mr Lacey's comments about Igors Stepanovs.

"After all the years that David Lacey has been watching football, I'm surprised he's still a totally inept judge of a decent footballer. And he still hasn't found a way to disguise his contempt for Arsenal," says Adam Rose.

"His only justifiable reason to call Igors Stepanovs ponderous would have been to set up his contrived little joke about Luzhny 'the horse' and Stepanovs 'the cart'.

"Stepanovs was exemplary against Chelsea," he continues. "He was always in the right place, made no mistakes and played with confidence and assurance throughout. At this rate, it will not be long before most football writers are acknowledging him as the true heir to Tony Adams.

"Lacey, however, will still be rooting myopically around in the dungeons of his dream-world, scanning the videos of Arsenal games for fleeting moments of mediocrity on which he can build another puerile and unjustified attack.

"If he despises Arsenal so much, why on earth do you force him to watch them?"

And Adam isn't the only reader out to stick up for Stepanovs. Regular Arsenal watcher Howard Davies reckons the Latvian's performance against Chelsea was "excellent".

"He was definitely the man of the match," he continues. "When he was unable to play in Lyon mid-week, we looked weak.

"Our recent defensive form has been placed at the hands of Seaman and Adams. But while Seaman has been playing well, Adams has not been up to his usual standard. Stepanovs, you will find however, has been present in these games and has been our most influential player in defence.

"In summary, please don't read the price tags, watch the player. Arsene Wenger tends to have a habit of picking up good players on the cheap. It only takes one intelligent journalist to watch the match and report on a player accurately, soon all the other monkeys start clapping their hands and stamping their feet, applauding the next Jaap Stam."

Meanwhile, Lacey's view that Steve McManaman would be wasted on the left for England isn't shared by everyone either.

"How can you say that Macca would be wasted on the left for England?" asks Craig Allison. "I am a Real Madrid season-ticket holder, and this season McManaman (playing on the left) has been nothing short of outstanding.

"He is a much improved player than when he left Liverpool and he is the blatantly obvious solution to fill the problematic England left side. The biggest compliment you can pay to him is that he looks totally at home around the likes of Figo, Raúl and Roberto Carlos and the Real fans recognise that - I have witnessed several standing ovations in honour of him!

"When you compare him to the other players in line for this position there is no competition - especially in a game against Spain, where he will know his opponents very well. He simply must start!"

York City fans: we're not racists

Finally, many York fans are unhappy with David Hopps's match report about their game against Exeter.

"I was angered to read that David Hopps thinks that it would be a fitting end for York to go down after failing to join the kick out racism campaign," says Craig Smallbone. "Our chairman Douglas Craig received countless letters and calls from City fans saying the club should back the campaign.

"Despite our terrible form and mismanagement at board level, City fans have continued to back the team. Why is it that Hopps chose to blame the club for the bigotry of our chairman?" he adds.

Craig's view is shared by Tom Dyson, who says: "The majority of fans of York wanted Craig to sign up and tried in vain to get Mr Craig OBE to sign up. We are disgusted by our chairman's response to criticism - likening groups such as the Black Lawyers Association or the Black Police Officers Association to all white, supremacy groups.

"Unfortunately this lazy piece of journalism would make people who read it antagonistic to the whole club and they would probably think it would be fitting for the club to go down. Why could the journalist not have researched a little further into this matter and highlighted how our club is on the edge of oblivion due to negligent management at both board and coach level?"

"Unfortunately this lazy piece of journalism would make people who read it antagonistic to the whole club and they would probably think it would be fitting for the club to go down. Why could the journalist not have researched a little further into this matter and highlighted how our club is on the edge of oblivion due to negligent management at both board and coach level?"

webTitle: BSkyB promotes digital TV

fields.headline: BSkyB pushes digital TV through London
fields.trailText: 4pm: BSkyB is to offer free digital TV upgrades of aerials on communal housing blocks in several London boroughs, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
BSkyB has launched a radical digital TV initiative with several London boroughs, in a bid to ensure all its customers haveupgraded for the proposed analogue switch-off deadline of 2006.

The satellite broadcaster has teamed up with authorities in Enfield and Newham to replace communal aerials in housing blocks with state-of-the-art equipment that can pick up digital broadcasts.

"There are around 3m UK homes owned by local authorities and housing associations that need an upgrade to get digital TV," said a spokesman for BSkyB.

The culture select committee last week raised the issue of making digital TV available to all UK homes before switching off the analogue signal around 2006.

The signal is used to provide BBC, ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5 programmes to the majority of the population.

"There was a lot of discussion about making digital TV available to every home in the UK but we need to know how to deal with homes with communal aerials.

"BSkyB believes a system like this is the best option," added the spokesman.

The 80,000 residents who benefit from the free upgrade will not be obliged to subscribe to pay-TV services.

However, the spokesman said the company was "confident" the customers would sign up to Sky Digital, which has more than 4m subscribers.

BSkyB confirmed it is in negotiations with other local authorities and housing associations across the country, although the installation work will take up to three years.

webTitle: Tories promise extra cash for under-fives

fields.headline: Tories promise extra cash for under-fives
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo yesterday took the pre-election battle over tax to Gordon Brown's home turf when he pledged an extra £200 a year for parents of children under the age of five.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo yesterday took the pre-election battle over tax to Gordon Brown's home turf when he pledged an extra £200 a year for parents of children under the age of five.

In a daring attempt to steal the chancellor's thunder, Mr Portillo promised to set aside an extra £400m to boost Labour's cherished children's tax credit which comes into force in April.

Under his plan, families with a child under the age of five will receive an additional tax break of £200 a year, which works out at just under £4 a week. The pledge will stand even if the chancellor increases the credit's starting rate in the Budget from £442 a year to £520, as proposed by the Treasury.

In a speech to the Centre for Policy Studies, Mr Portillo said he believed it would be best to give extra help to families with the youngest children. "When children are not yet at school, they make the greatest demands in terms of expense, time and nervous energy."

The children's tax credit, launched amid great fanfare by the chancellor last month, is designed to top up the pay of less well off parents.

Standard rate taxpayers who earn less than £32,000 will receive an extra £442 a year from April. The payments are reduced for higher earners and any parent receiving more than £41,000 receives nothing extra.

Mr Portillo indicated that he would open up the tax credit to the better off.

The shadow chancellor, who will announce further details next week, said that it was "absurd and indefensible" to prevent the better off from receiving the credit.

"Gordon Brown has arranged that a couple each earning £30,000 will receive the credit but a couple with a smaller joint income, with one earner receiving just over £40,000 will receive no tax credit," he said.

The announcement by the shadow chancellor was the latest in a series of tax concessions unveiled by the Tories in the past few weeks.

Central office hopes to appeal to floating voters by targeting tax cuts at middle income earners.

Mr Portillo has pledged to introduce £8bn worth of tax cuts in the run-up to the general election, which will be paid for by cuts in public services.

In his speech yesterday, Mr Portillo insisted that there was a moral case for low taxation. "We will remind the country that it was through the pursuit of low-tax policies that the British economy was transformed from the sick man of Europe to a picture of health."

Labour last night claimed Mr Portillo's announcement was another Tory u-turn. Andrew Smith, shadow chief secretary, said: "Just a few weeks ago, Michael Portillo told the Daily Mail that the children's tax credit was a 'stealth tax on marriage'. A month ago, David Willetts described the children's tax credit as a 'gimmick'. Today their policy is in chaos and confusion."

Mr Smith said that the Tory figures did not add up because he claimed that the party was committed to introducing £16bn of cuts.

His criticism was echoed by the Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman, Matthew Taylor, who said: "People know you can't get something for nothing - you can only cut taxes by cutting schools, hospitals and pensions."

webTitle: Sun girl joins Smash Hits

fields.headline: Sun girl joins Smash Hits
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: Emma Jones, deputy to Sun showbiz editor Dominic Mohan, is taking the helm at Smash Hits, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Emma Jones, deputy to the Sun's showbusiness editor Dominic Mohan, will be the next editor of Emap's Smash Hits.

Ms Jones, who joined the Sun from the Mail on Sunday last year, is young and good looking with a sharp news sense - everything Smash Hits looks for in an editor.

The appointment continues the tradition of giving the top job to a young, attractive female editor who will bring publicity and personality to the title as well as journalistic talent.

Kate Thornton, who was appointed editor at only 22, has been the highest-profile editor of the magazine to date.

She was superseded by John McKie, who has left the magazine to join Q.

Ms Jones was poached by the Sun from the Mail on Sunday after a series of scoops on the Sunday paper.

These included a rambling interview with former Rolling Stone Ronnie Wood about his alcohol addiction and the story of Billie Piper collapsing in a bar.

While at the Sunday Mirror, Ms Jones broke the story of Liam Gallagher's Lost weekend - an article referring to his "disappearance" from wife Patsy Kensit.

Apart from her obvious familiarity with the world of pop, Ms Jones also boasts a hands-on knowledge of classical music, having done a stint as the PA of violinist Nigel Kennedy.

She could be just the shot in the arm Smash Hits needs.

It lost 8.2% of its circulation in the last ABCs, as the beleaguered pop magazines sector took a battering.

webTitle: Eccentricities continue at London Fashion Week

fields.headline: Eccentricities continue at London Fashion Week
fields.standfirst:
The Betty Jackson and Antoni & Alison shows were today's highlights

Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: The Betty Jackson and Antoni & Alison shows were today's highlights.
fields.body:
Betty Jackson caught the mood of the season with a sensational catwalk show at London Fashion Week today.

The Marks & Spencer design consultant mixed a combination of soft-layered chiffons with harder leather accessories for her event at the Natural History Museum.

Ms Jackson, who designs for M&S's Autograph label, brought out her strength as a designer with a well-known combination of classical tailoring and soft lines.

Hundreds packed into the tents to see the collection of mainly black clothing designs interspersed with a number of raspberry and lime green creations.

Camel-coloured jersey sweaters were combined with leather gauntlets and collars to make unusual, yet very classical, outfits.

Earlier in the day, British duo Antoni Burakowski and Alison Roberts took a satirical look at the fashion world in a hilarious show, held on the third day of the fashion fest.

Their production - mixing photographic imagery, music and wearable outfits - proved extremely popular with the dedicated fashionistas running from show to show.

The exhibition, entitled At Last I've Found You I Was Almost Going Mad, was a collection of the pair's famous T-shirt designs, sweaters, tunic dresses and tartan skirts all in a very high-street style.

The creations were all based on a parody of the fashion business with many T-shirts emblazoned with statements such as "I'm so unhappy", "Nobody understands me" or "I feel ill".

The film, projected on a screen alongside the stage in the lecture theatre at the Victoria and Albert Museum in central London, carried through the same themes with images of spilt milk on an alpine scenery and "help me" spelt out in peas on a table cloth.

The clothes ranged from brightly coloured satin striped skirts, gingham blouses and tartan tunics to mini tee-shirts with the trademark Antoni & Alison logos and knitted polo neck sweaters with intricate sequinned designs.

Designer Antoni explained the pair's very British style and the sense of humour displayed in their work today.

He said: "People laugh at our work but we take it incredibly seriously... We know it's often perceived as being funny; this isn't a problem as sometimes we feel that we are setting ourselves up to be some kind of stand-up comedians... We juxtaposed the pictures and clothes because we are photographers as well as designers and we find it interesting to see the two ideas come together."

webTitle: Comet marketing chief defects to Argos

fields.headline: Comet marketing chief defects to Argos
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: Argos has poached Comet Group's top marketer Paul Geddes to be its new marketing chief, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Argos has poached Comet Group's top marketer Paul Geddes to be its new marketing chief.

Mr Geddes replaces Siobhan Chatburn, who quit as Argos director of marketing at the end of January after only four months in the job.

A date has not yet been set for Mr Geddes' arrival at the high-street and catalogue retailer.

Mr Geddes joined Kingfisher-owned electrical chain Comet as marketing and development director in July 1999.

Before that he was head of marketing at Kingfisher sister company Superdrug and had previously held a number of senior marketing roles at Procter & Gamble.

Ms Chatburn joined Argos from Blockbuster in September but left the company after four months, weeks after the arrival of managing director Kate Swann.

Acting managing director Peter Jones had recruited Ms Chatburn but he was replaced last month by Ms Swann, who joined from Homebase.
