webTitle: Questions mount over practicalities of Labour's new regional proposals

fields.headline: Questions mount over practicalities of Labour's new regional proposals
fields.trailText: Analysis: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, has set out his party's priorities for local government in a second Labour term, and the watchword is "devolution", writes Simon Parker
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, has set out his party's priorities for local government in a second Labour term, and the watchword is "devolution".

Mr Brown told an audience of councillors at Labour's spring conference in Glasgow that: "In a second term, to achieve our goals of full employment, better public services and ending child poverty, we need to devolve power from the centre to regions and local communities."

Behind the chancellor's rhetoric, two big policy ideas have emerged: more power for the regions, and local public service agreements (PSAs).

Mr Brown's enthusiasm for the latter seems hard to overstate. He told the conference that 150 PSAs would be created over the next two years and that they would provide: "Flexibility and finance in return for reform and results... I want people to see what we do together as a Labour commitment to the renaissance of local government in our country."

If any further endorsement of the policy were needed, the chancellor's chief adviser, Ed Balls, is said to be frustrated that the media does not yet understand how "radical" the agreements are.

PSAs are actually rather more mundane than Mr Balls suggests. Essentially, the agreements mean councils signing up to tough service targets in return for more freedom to deliver them. The treasury is enthusiastic because the agreements give ministers the chance to direct local council efforts towards the big national priorities of education and social services.

The first six agreements were signed earlier this month, but the freedoms gained by councils were very limited. They included:

 A 'light touch' best value inspection regime - offering authorities a degree of freedom from the regular, intensive audit commission investigations they currently undergo.
 More freedom to spend the heavily ringfenced school standards fund, used at present to fund specific government education programmes.
 New powers to pool their budgets with police and health professionals to tackle the problems of drugs and crime.

More powers will almost certainly become available as the PSA programme evolves. With 150 councils trying to prise new freedoms from Whitehall's hands, the government may be forced to concede more, particularly if some of those authorities start collectively bargaining with the treasury to create a "menu" of new flexibilities.

The regional agenda could have a far more radical effect. The chancellor's new-found interest, coupled with deputy prime minister John Prescott's enthusiasm for devolution, means directly elected regional government could be a major issue in a second Labour term.

In one of his most strident public expressions of support for regional assemblies, Mr Prescott told the conference: "Regional chambers are a start to decentralisation in the English regions. Our next step must be to deepen regional accountability. I believe the time is right to take the next steps, to publish a green paper on empowering our regions to strengthen the accountability of regional chambers and where people vote for it, to move to directly elected regional assemblies."

Reports suggest Tony Blair has given the go-ahead for a green paper, and that the document is likely to suggest ways in which referendums for regional government could be triggered.

If this is true, it raises a whole host of questions. Labour's 1997 election manifesto promised to create a tier of unitary authorities beneath regional government, effectively abolishing county and district councils. Ministers were clear that they did not want three tiers of local government. This position could prove a serious obstacle in the minds of some councillors, while Mr Prescott is back-pedaling, saying in parliament that unitaries need not be a precondition for devolution.

There is also the question of what kind of regional parliament ministers will choose. In the north-east, for example, there have been heated discussions over whether to support a minimalist, strategic regional authority, or to go for an assembly with powers rivalling the Welsh assembly - the option favoured by the Campaign for a North East Assembly.

The green paper may not get the chance to provide answers. Both Mr Prescott and the chancellor are promoting the regional agenda at present, but Mr Brown has made it clear that he sees regional devolution being driven by economic rejuvenation, rather than by any desire to create a new tier of democracy. Even if the deputy prime minister gets his way, the party leadership could still kick the green paper into the long grass.

If that happens, it is hard to see how the government will be able to deliver more devolution. City mayors and Westminster-style council cabinets have not yet been linked with more power for local government, and neither has best value.

The government's proposed reforms of local government finance include more control over business rates and new powers to encourage regeneration, but they also limit education spending freedoms through new per-pupil school spending guidelines.

The chancellor will need regional government, or a few more big policy ideas, if he is to close the gap between his conference rhetoric and his government's policy reality.

webTitle: China 're-educates' cult members

fields.headline: China 're-educates' cult members
fields.trailText: China has admitted making extensive use of a much-criticised form of imprisonment without trial in its efforts to suppress the banned Falun Gong spiritual sect.
fields.body:
China has admitted making extensive use of a much-criticised form of imprisonment without trial in its efforts to suppress the banned Falun Gong spiritual sect.

The practice of sending people to labour camps for "re-education" has been condemned by human rights groups abroad. They say Beijing may also be employing it to clear the streets of undesirables during its bid to stage the 2008 Olympic Games.

A team from the International Olympic Committee (IOC) visits the city today to assess the bid. The police are on heightened alert against demonstrations, after another alleged Falun Gong supporter committed suicide in public on Friday.

A thousand women followers of Falun Gong have been "successfully re-educated" at a "re-education through labour institute" in Liaoning province, the official People's Daily reported at the weekend.

It said the "tutors" at the Masanjia camp provided "loving care", helping the inmates to overcome their resistance to reform. Claims by the Falun Gong organisation abroad that many members had been tortured by Masanjia were denied.

The figures quoted for one camp in one province give an idea of the magnitude of the operation against the Falun Gong. The People's Daily said more than 300 inmates had returned home from Masanjia after finishing their "re-education terms". Another 300 had their terms reduced or were serving them "outside the facility".

The process of labour re-education appears similar to the "thought reform" methods used in Chinese labour camps during the Mao Zedong era.

In a typical case in Masanjia, a "former cult leader", Li Lina, says the prison "even provided the latest articles of Li Hongzhi and organised former practitioners to debate them".

The use of repentant inmates to persuade more stubborn prisoners to change their beliefs was a characteristic feature of the "thought reform" process.

Mr Li, the Falun Gong's spiritual "master", who issues his pronouncements from the US, has denounced unnamed Falun Gong members for working for the authorities after being persuaded to recant.

The Human Rights in China group in the US calculates that up to 2m people are picked up under some form of "administrative custody" every year, at least 5% of them children.

The system, used in the past mainly against marginalised groups - typically those without jobs or papers or fixed abode - allows detention of up to two years without trial.

In a letter to the IOC, the co-chairman of Human Rights in China, Robert Bernstein, says that it "cannot risk further shame by abetting Beijing's abuse of citizens." He urges the IOC to "insist that China pledge not to use these camps to make Beijing more presentable for the games".

Falun Gong sources abroad have published claims of alleged torture in the detention camps leading to more than 140 deaths since the Falun Gong was banned in July 1999.

Beijing routinely denies that torture occurs, while admitting that Falun Gong members have died in detention.

"You have to ask how they died," a Chinese diplomat, Zhang Yuanyuan, told the BBC last week. "So there are some who are old, sick and they commit suicide.

"They throw themselves against the wall and got themselves fatally injured, and they refused to eat, refused to take medicine, refused medical attention, and people also died of natural causes."

Falun Gong confirms that members frequently resort to hunger strike as a form of protest, and say that this is dealt with brutality.

It publicised the case of Li Mei who died in Hefei detention centre on February 1 after going on hunger strike. Her family were allegedly not allowed to examine her body.

An Amnesty International report says the crackdown fits a pattern in which the government demands quick results from local officials who then use torture to obtain recantations or confessions.

It says that out of the 120 alleged Falun Gong deaths it has looked at, 17 "jumped" to their death, according to official reports, and 15 "fell" while in detention.

It says there is evidence that force feeding was carried out by people with no medical training, resulting in damage to the windpipe and other reportedly fatal complications.

China rejected the report as based on "rumours and hearsay".

webTitle: Teacher's murder highlights familiar failings

fields.headline: Teacher's murder highlights familiar failings
fields.standfirst: John Gittings reports from Shanghai on an everyday injustice
fields.trailText: Shanghai dispatch: John Gittings reports from Shanghai on an everyday injustice.
fields.body:
The miserable death of a university graduate in one of China's poorer provinces has been attracting unusual attention. The story is a simple one of casual violence, but it involves elements of everyday injustice familiar to millions of ordinary Chinese.

Qi Peiyu, a 27-year-old graduate from Shanghai, drowned in front of his helpless wife after an unequal fight with four local bullies in his home province of Anhui. The police admit there was a struggle, but believe that he may have drowned himself afterwards. As the Guangzhou Daily asks in an ironic headline, "Did the victim kill himself?"

At 3pm on a dull day early this month [February], Qi put down an English book he was studying, and took his wife Yang Xiu for their regular walk along a curved river embankment. They were overtaken by a car that forced them to one side and suddenly stopped. The driver got out, shouting at the top of his voice "I want to piss", and urinated immediately in front of them.

Qi had been a primary school teacher for several years, but he graduated from Shanghai's Tongji University in political science - with Marxism-Leninism as his special field. He looked at the man and made a sharp comment: "Your behaviour is really uncivilised". The man - who was drunk - threw a punch and was joined by three comrades from the same car.

After being badly beaten, Qi and his wife escaped down the inner slope and struggled across a field to clamber up again where the embankment curved round. But the car drove round to trap them. As he was beaten once more, Qi urged Yang Xiu to flee. While she fled, she saw her husband being hit with an iron bar and pushed into the water.

No Chinese who has read the story this far will be surprised at the following facts unearthed by investigative reporters from several enterprising newspapers:  The four men, all in their 30s, had been to a party given by a local government cadre. They were driving what looked like an official car - though it was now privately owned.

 Several villagers, including eyewitnesses to the scene, are reluctant to give evidence. "These people will kill you just for a word," says one of them. "They've got good roots here."

 The local authorities have tried to prevent journalists from gathering information about the case.

 The four attackers admit they pursued Qi after the first tussle but say they failed to find him, and that he either stumbled to his death or committed suicide.

 The local police find this explanation plausible.

Life in rural China is usually quite placid: farming communities have to avoid internal conflict if they are to survive their hard struggle with nature. But there has always been a raw edge of violence, associated with those who possess or seize power. In the bad old days, the local bullies worked for the landlords (and, during the war, for the Japanese army or their puppet rulers).

The tradition revived in the lawless years of the Cultural Revolution (1966-76) when local thugs were the hired hands of rival factions. Since the post-Mao Zedong reforms, they work for despotic and corrupt cadres in an economic climate where the rewards have become greater.

While new habits and expectations have formed elsewhere, the poorer parts of China stagnate or slip further backwards. Senior officials in Beijing and in provincial capitals acknowledge the widening gap but seem unable to bridge it. In this context, Qi Peiyu can be seen as representative of the new more "civilised" China - which may be why his case has attracted so much press attention.

Qi also showed the kind of diligence that is much admired: he was a poor country lad who borrowed money from his family to go to college. But if he had not learnt about "civilised behaviour" in Shanghai, might he not still be alive?

No Chinese who has read the story this far will be surprised at the following facts unearthed by investigative reporters from several enterprising newspapers:  The four men, all in their 30s, had been to a party given by a local government cadre. They were driving what looked like an official car - though it was now privately owned.  Several villagers, including eyewitnesses to the scene, are reluctant to give evidence. "These people will kill you just for a word," says one of them. "They've got good roots here."  The local authorities have tried to prevent journalists from gathering information about the case.  The four attackers admit they pursued Qi after the first tussle but say they failed to find him, and that he either stumbled to his death or committed suicide.  The local police find this explanation plausible. Life in rural China is usually quite placid: farming communities have to avoid internal conflict if they are to survive their hard struggle with nature. But there has always been a raw edge of violence, associated with those who possess or seize power. In the bad old days, the local bullies worked for the landlords (and, during the war, for the Japanese army or their puppet rulers). The tradition revived in the lawless years of the Cultural Revolution (1966-76) when local thugs were the hired hands of rival factions. Since the post-Mao Zedong reforms, they work for despotic and corrupt cadres in an economic climate where the rewards have become greater. While new habits and expectations have formed elsewhere, the poorer parts of China stagnate or slip further backwards. Senior officials in Beijing and in provincial capitals acknowledge the widening gap but seem unable to bridge it. In this context, Qi Peiyu can be seen as representative of the new more "civilised" China - which may be why his case has attracted so much press attention. Qi also showed the kind of diligence that is much admired: he was a poor country lad who borrowed money from his family to go to college. But if he had not learnt about "civilised behaviour" in Shanghai, might he not still be alive? Other articles More articles by John Gittings

webTitle: Chelsea stars in Ranieri 'mutiny'

fields.headline: Chelsea stars in Ranieri 'mutiny'
fields.trailText: Chelsea players were allegedly involved in a half-time confrontation with coach Claudio Ranieri against Arsenal at Highbury on Sunday.
fields.body:
Chelsea players were allegedly involved in a half-time confrontation with coach Claudio Ranieri against Arsenal at Highbury on Sunday.

According to newspaper reports, there was a heated exchange of opinions over the Italian's tactics, with some senior players criticising his plans to make half-time substitutions. The Blues were holding Arsenal to a 0-0 scoreline at half-time on Sunday, but went on to lose 3-1.

The players reportedly accused Ranieri of changing the system for no real reason, bringing on Eidur Gudjohnsen and Jesper Gronkjaer for Gianfranco Zola and Sam Dalla Bona. The papers claim that the arguments were so loud that they could be heard in the Arsenal changing room.

Gustavo Poyet said: "It was difficult to understand the reasons why the coach wanted to change things, although we weren't playing well, we were stopping Arsenal from playing their normal game."

This is not the first time this season that Ranieri's tactics have been called into question. He was forced to change his formation half-way through the recent league encounter with Arsenal after an abortive attempt to play Frank Leboeuf at full-back.

Ranieri also sacrificed winger Gronkjaer against Man Utd two weeks ago, despite the Dane having caused havoc in the United defence all afternoon.

Captain Dennis Wise said recently of the changes: "Sometimes it is quite difficult to keep adjusting to different positions but that is what the coach asks us to do. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't. We have to get on with it."

webTitle: Winter gardens and springlike hopes for city's future

fields.headline: Winter gardens and springlike hopes for city's future
fields.trailText: One of the the biggest urban greenhouses to be built in Britain is to span part of the centre of Sheffield by the end of the year, as part of the first winter gardens to be commissioned for more than 100 years. Martin Wainwright reports
fields.body:
One of the the biggest urban greenhouses to be built in Britain is to span part of the centre of Sheffield by the end of the year, as part of the first winter gardens to be commissioned for more than 100 years.

Filled with sago palms, bamboo and - the city council hopes - tourists, the heated glass arcades form the heart of a £120m regeneration scheme unveiled yesterday.

"This is an urban renaissance with people at its heart," said the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, launching the Sheffield Masterplan. "It is not just a list of projects. It is about a commitment to regaining Sheffield's status as one of Europe's leading cities."

Buoyed up by the Boeing aircraft company's new research partnership with Sheffield university, and by poaching Alison Nimmo, the woman who led Manchester's post-IRA bomb rebuilding, as the scheme's director, the city is the main pilot for the government's new concept of urban regeneration companies. Headed by Sir Peter Middleton, the Sheffield-born chairman of Barclays bank, a seven-year partnership between the city council and local business is backing the almost complete transformation of the Victorian centre.

New hotels, offices and galleries linked to the Tate and the Victoria and Albert museum form the commercial spine of the scheme. But its heart is an uncomplicated determination to make the once-dirty central streets a pleasant place. Praising the completed first phase, a fountain garden and cultural square bounded by Sheffield's two theatres, Mr Prescott remembered a similar unlikely oasis from his past.

"When I was a boy growing up in Rotherham, we had a place in the town centre known as Sunshine Corner, where people used to go," he said. On the same lines, parts of the new £15m Millennium Galleries in Sheffield, flanking the winter gardens site, will be given over to concerts and events, alongside John Ruskin's personal art collection, donated to the city on the writer's death, and visiting exhibitions.

Ms Nimmo, whose work in Manchester is given much of the credit for triggering the city's recent revival, said that "celebrating the public realm" was crucial to the Sheffield plan.

Although the regeneration company, Sheffield One, is not pinning its hopes on the winter gardens' 70ft high gothic arches, or any other single project, high quality squares, seats, plants and sculpture are common to all its planning proposals.

The architects of the Millennium Galleries worked on Lord's cricket ground's celebrated "spacepod" press stand and the new parliamentary building at Westminster.

The galleries' formal link with the V&A forms the London museum's first regional out-station and the building has also been chosen to host the National Portrait Gallery's BP portrait award exhibition in the autumn.

webTitle: Irvine to face House of Lords grilling

fields.headline: Irvine to face House of Lords grilling
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The lord chancellor will respond tomorrow to criticism of his role by personally answering a question on the issue.
fields.body:
The lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, will respond tomorrow to criticism of his role as a fundraiser for Labour by personally answering a question on the issue in the House of Lords.

The response tomorrow to the question tabled by Liberal Democrat peer Lord McNally will be Lord Irvine's first public comment on the outcry over a letter he wrote to Labour-supporting lawyers, asking them to donate at least £200 each to the party.

It comes amid growing pressure for reform of the lord chancellor's position, removing the power to appoint judges and QCs from someone with a key political role.

It had been expected that the lord chancellor would avoid putting himself open to direct questioning on the party fundraising issue by having the question answered by the attorney general, Lord Williams, or the leader of the house, Baroness Jay.

But his department today confirmed that he would respond himself when Lord McNally asks "whether the role of lord chancellor is compatible with that of a party fundraiser".

Meanwhile, Cabinet Office minister Mo Mowlam claimed that splits were emerging in the Tory party over chairman Michael Ancram's call for Lord Irvine to resign over the so-called "cash for wigs" affair.

She pointed to comments made by the shadow lord chancellor, Lord Kingsland, who declined to add his voice to Mr Ancram's demand for Lord Irvine's head.

Lord Kingsland defended the Labour peer's record in appointing judges and QCs, saying he had always acted with "absolute probity".

But by allowing himself to be drawn into party politics and not replying to his critics, Lord Irvine had forced the Conservatives to demand his resignation, he said.

Ms Mowlam said: "Lord Kingsland made it clear ... that he didn't see this as a resigning matter. He said that Lord Irvine 'has behaved with the utmost probity in selecting judges'."

Lord Kingsland also rejected proposals - backed by the influential Law Society - to split the lord chancellor's judicial and political roles.

The Law Society has proposed a new independent judicial appointments commission, to ensure that "fears of patronage cease to be an issue", and the suggestion has won the backing of the left-leaning Institute of Public Policy Research thinktank.

The lord chancellor's department said today that Lord Irvine had already advertised the position of first commissioner for judicial appointments, who will provide independent monitoring of the selection procedure for new judges.

However, this falls short of the Law Society's preferred option - reported to have won some support within the government - of removing the power to appoint judges from Lord Irvine altogether.

webTitle: Virtual pets for mobile users

fields.headline: Virtual pets for mobile users
fields.standfirst: Click here for a picture of a Sea-Monkey
fields.trailText:
1pm: Motorola has teamed up with a games developer to create articifical pets to live on its internet-enabled phone, reports Julia Day.
Click here for a picture of a Sea-Monkey
fields.body:
If you thought the Tamagotchi virtual pet craze was dead, you were mistaken.

The idea of virtual pets is alive and well and coming to a mobile phone near you.

Motorola is to offer its mobile phone users pets that live on their handsets.

In a deal with games developer Creature Labs, Motorola will market games that are played on web-enabled mobile phones connected to GPRS and third generation networks.

The first game available will be called Sea-Monkey.

The game begins with the birth of the creature, then the mobile phone user must nurture it through various stages of life, ensuring its happiness and health.

Each player has a virtual tank in which the Sea-Monkey lives.

The mobile phone user must care for the environmental condition of the tank, for example, by providing different plants for the Sea-Monkey to play with.

The pet must also be fed.

The more interaction a player has with their pets, the more bonuses are accredited.

Bonuses can be swapped for plants or machinery to keep the tank clean.

Motorola considers the wireless games market to be a major area for development.

If mobile phone users can be persuaded to connect to their phone networks more often, revenues for the companies involved grow.

The games will reside on a server connected to the mobile phone operator's network and not to the individual handset.

This means players have to connect to the network to check on their pet.

The new generation of phone networks will allow an "always on" connection to the internet, allowing instant interactivity with the pets.

At the moment, users have to log on every time they use WAP services.

Creature Labs chief executive Chris McKee said: "We're really pleased to have formed a partnership with Motorola to exploit the exciting games opportunities represented by next generation wireless devices."

fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are still reeling from the news that Kym from Popstars has snogged Ritchie from Five
fields.trailText: Eric Cantona has turned down a £4m-a-year job as coach of Olympiakos because he wants to succeed Sir Alex Ferguson as manager of Manchester United, reports the Star. The paper quotes a "Greek source" who says: "The club wanted Cantona because he is such a big name and it would have been a great coup to get him out of retirement. He was offered £4m but he was just not interested. He told the club that he was still interested in managing Manchester United and that was the only club he would get back into football for."

The paper quotes a "Greek source" who says: "The club wanted Cantona because he is such a big name and it would have been a great coup to get him out of retirement. He was offered £4m but he was just not interested. He told the club that he was still interested in managing Manchester United and that was the only club he would get back into football for."

Tottenham have opened talks with 19-year-old River Plate striker Javier Saviola over a £3.5m move, claims the Express. Saviola, nicknamed "The Little Rabbit", has scored 23 goals in 39 appearances this season.

Newcastle will tie up a £800,000 deal for Sheffield United defender Wayne Quinn later today, claims the Star. And Bobby Robson is also interested in signing Helsingborgs' Brazilian striker Alvaro Santos, according to Planet Football.

Sunderland are giving a trial to 21-year-old Brann winger Alex Valencia, reports Planet Football. Teamtalk go much further: they claim Peter Reid has agreed a £800,000 deal for Valencia and the transfer will be completed as soon as he agrees personal terms.

Middlesbrough have admitted they are keen on Paris St-Germain striker Christian. Head coach Terry Venables told Teamtalk: "We have looked at Christian and he is a good player."

Blackburn have warned Newcastle off making a £3m-plus-Stephen Glass bid for Irish international Damien Duff. Rovers manager Graeme Souness told the Star: "Duff is not for sale. There's no chance I'd be prepared to let him go."

Former Sheffield Wednesday manager Paul Jewell is the shock name on the two-man shortlist for the vacant QPR manager's job, reports the Mirror. But the paper reports that Steve Bruce is still favourite to get the job.

webTitle: Testy westerners

fields.headline: Testy westerners
fields.standfirst: All is quiet on the Quebec separatist front, but in the west of Canada the natives are revolting, says Anne McIlroy
fields.trailText: All is quiet on the Quebec separatist front, but in the west of Canada the natives are revolting, says Anne McIlroy in Ottawa.
fields.body:
Just as Canadians are breathing easier about the threat of losing Quebec, a growing number of westerners are talking about splitting their provinces from the rest of the country.

Last month, the Alberta Independence party held its founding meeting and a fledgling Saskatchewan separatist party met to plan its own convention this summer.

Disgruntled westerners have been getting front-page treatment in the country's newspapers, although the separatists are fringe groups and have only several hundred supporters.

"I'm finished with Canada," said one Saskatchewan farmer at a weekend rally, where he and other western separatists talked about designing a new flag.

Angry comments like this are greeted with bewilderment rather than fear in the rest of the country. For decades, worried English-speaking Canadians have puzzled over what the Quebec-speaking majority in Quebec wants.

Now easterners are asking the same thing about their neighbours in Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia, although they don't take them all that seriously.

That may be the problem. When asked why they are angry, many westerners attending the separatist conventions talked about a lack of respect from central Canada, rather than specific grievances.

Historically, Ontario and Quebec has had the wealth and population to dominate the national government and for years the mantra of unhappy westerners has been "the west wants in".

The federal election this fall crystallised their frustration. For years, westerners have supported a protest party called Reform that championed their interests and became the official opposition after the 1997 federal election.

But last year, Reform changed its name to the Canadian Alliance and watered down its conservative policies in an effort to appeal to voters in the rest of the country. It didn't work.

The Canadian Alliance was all but locked out of eastern Canada in the fall election, but dominated in the west. Once again, the House of Commons is fractured along the east-west divide.

It didn't help that prime minister Jean Chrétien insulted westerners during the campaign, joking that he was more comfortable with eastern Canadians, or that he mused in a recent interview about using "tough love" on the region.

One of his cabinet ministers criticized the Canadian Alliance as being racist and bigoted, an attack that many westerners took personally.

The truth is, while a separate nation of westerners is as likely as pigs learning to fly, the resentment and unhappiness of the radical few is shared by many, especially in Alberta.

"This western alienation talk is real and we had better pay attention to what's being said. It is being talked about at kitchen tables and in coffee shops," Canadian Alliance MP Myron Thompson told the Globe and Mail, Canada's oldest national newspaper.

Even if they don't want separation, Mr Thompson says many westerners want more autonomy from Ottawa, much as Quebeckers do. Prominent western intellectuals recently called on Alberta premier Ralph Klein to opt out of the national health care program and pension plan.

The growing anger in the west comes as the Quebec separatist movement appears to be entering a period of dormancy.

Polls show support for independence is low, so low that Quebec premier Lucien Bouchard, the man who came close to winning the 1995 referendum on sovereignty, has decided to quit to work in the private sector.

webTitle: German Jews sue over Nazi net content

fields.headline: German Jews sue over Nazi net content
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Germany's main Jewish group plans to take internet service providers to court if they provide German citizens with access to Nazi and far-right websites.
fields.body:
Germany's main Jewish group plans to take internet service providers to court if they provide German citizens with access to Nazi and far-right websites.

The vice-president of the Central Council for Jews, Michel Friedman, said yesterday he wants to see the German government act to enforce laws that prohibit the publication of anti-semitic and racist content, even if the sites concerned are hosted outside Germany.

Mr Friedman hopes a lawsuit from the Central Council for Jews will prompt the German government to take the kind of action that the French government did when it took the US internet company Yahoo! to court over a site that auctioned Nazi memorabilia.

The French government argued that as French citizens had access to a site, Yahoo! was breaching national law even though the site was hosted in the US and was not specifically directed at French users.

Yahoo! complied with the French ruling, but has filed a suit in a California court to challenge the jurisdiction of the French court. The existence of hate groups online is protected under US freedom of speech laws.

German courts ruled in December that a foreign internet service provider is subject to German law if its sites can be accessed within the country.

"This is difficult to defend on the subject matter; no one wants to support Nazi sites," said Mike Pullen, an internet lawyer with London firm DLA. "But this is a worrying principle. Who's next? What if the French government decides it doesn't like Greenpeace campaigning about nuclear weapons?"

webTitle: Tornado sweeps up Labour peer

fields.headline: Tornado sweeps up Labour peer
fields.trailText: Lord Alli yesterday joined the board of Tornado Group, a little known company dealing in the distribution of digital media.
fields.body:
Lord Alli yesterday joined the board of Tornado Group, a little known company dealing in the distribution of digital media.

The non-executive role is the second taken by Lord Alli, above, since he left Carlton Productions at the end of last year. Two weeks ago the Labour peer joined a consortium bidding for the third and final digital radio multiplex in London.

Lord Alli, 36, rose to prominence as managing director of independent production company Planet 24, best known for Channel 4's Big Breakfast. Carlton paid £15m for the business.

After leaving Carlton, where he will be best remembered for reviving Crossroads, Lord Alli said he wanted more time to devote to the House of Lords as well as collecting a number of non-executive posts.

Tornado was founded in late 1999 and floated on the Alternative Investment Market in March last year. It aims to provide secure infrastructure for the storage and download of digital products such as music and games. It has signed deals with EMI and Bertelsmann for secure downloading of internet music files.

The company reported a loss of £5.8m in its first year, reflecting the investment in developing its technology. Shares in the company, placed at 150p during the height of the internet boom doubled on their debut. They fell 9p to 84.5p yesterday.

The Digital Radio Group, where Lord Alli is chairman, is a consortium intending to launch eight radio stations.

webTitle: Analysis: Gordon Brown is right to keep his powder dry

fields.headline: Gordon Brown is right to keep his powder dry
fields.standfirst:
By avoiding a pre-election giveaway despite his £17bn budget surplus, the chancellor is creating the conditions for major spending in a second Labour term, writes economics correspondent Mark Atkinson

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText:
By avoiding a pre-election giveaway despite his £17bn budget surplus, the chancellor is creating the conditions for major spending in a second Labour term, writes economics correspondent Mark Atkinson.
Special report: Budget 2001
fields.body:
Two weeks before the Budget, Gordon Brown is like a man who has just won the lottery but doesn't want anyone to know. Despite figures out this morning showing a burgeoning public sector surplus, the chancellor was saying nothing about his good fortune for fear of attracting attention from special interest groups. Any previous Labour administration would have been jumping for joy at being awash with cash. But not Mr Brown, who was probably working quietly on his speech in Number 11.

Cynics will spy a trap. Mr Brown is staying silent to maximise the impact of his pre-election giveaway, they will say. In reality, however, we can expect nothing of the kind. Any tax cuts or spending increases announced on March 7 will be modest, probably no more than £2bn - a figure dwarfed by the £17bn surplus accumulated in the first 10 months of the financial year.

To his critics Mr Brown is being plain stingy, trapped by his rigid adherence to neo-liberal dogma about keeping control of public spending to avoid crowding out the more efficient private sector. But they are wrong.

Sure, lack of cash is not a constraint. The chancellor could easily sprinkle a few billion pounds here and a few billion pounds there, bringing short-term relief to hard-pressed public services such as schools, hospitals and the railways, which are still suffering from decades of underinvestment despite rapidly accelerating public spending growth. But, in the long term, such a strategy does not make sense.

First, it would immediately incur the wrath of the Bank of England which, instead of continuing to cut interest rates, would begin raising them to offset increased inflationary pressure. Higher interest rates would send the pound back up against the euro on the foreign exchanges just when it is beginning to fall, helping to rebalance the economy away from still rampant consumer spending towards manufacturing.

Quite apart from the dangers of overstimulating an economy close to full employment, there is the risk that the health of the public finances is no more than a mirage, the result of a cyclical boom which will vanish when the economy eventually turns down. Then, as in the early 1990s, the chancellor of the day will face the difficult task of repairing the damage. Higher taxes and spending cuts will be the result.

By being patient, by waiting to see if the bounty filling the Treasury is real, Mr Brown will be in the enviable position in Labour's second term of being able to follow up the downpayment made on improved public services in the first with lots more cash. Instead of spending £10bn today, it could be £20bn or £30bn tomorrow. That surely is worth waiting for.

webTitle: Oftel investigates mobile pricing

fields.headline: Oftel investigates mobile pricing
fields.trailText: 10.45am: The explosion in text messaging has sparked a competition enquiry from telecoms watchdog Oftel, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The explosion in mobile phone text messaging has sparked a competition enquiry from telecoms watchdog Oftel.

Oftel is investigating the price controls it set in 1998 to prevent the excessive "termination charges" levied on customers who phoned the BT Wireless and Vodafone networks.

For example, on a standard BT Wireless contract, a call to a rival network would cost 50p a minute at peak times compared with 18p a minute for a call to a BT phone.

With text messages, no distinction is made between networks, with BT charging a flat rate of 12p per message irrespective of the receiving network.

The regulator today said text messages are seen as a far cheaper alternative to phone calls, and it will decide if this is encouraging competitive pricing in termination charges.

"If people think it is too expensive to call other mobiles, they might get round it by sending a text message because it might be cheaper," said a spokeswoman for Oftel.

Text messaging is now the preferred method of communication of teenagers trying to beat excessive phone charges.

But it is also a hugely popular mode of communication with busy executives.

In December, a record 750m text messages were sent in the UK alone, with 6bn messages exchanged during the whole of last year.

"We will look at short messaging services to see whether this is having an impact on the way people are using mobile phones.

"It may be putting a competitive pressure on termination charges because people are choosing a different way of communicating," added the Oftel spokeswoman.

Oftel will remove the price controls on BT and Vodafone if it finds the mobile phone market is competitive enough to keep prices down without the regulator's intervention.

webTitle: Foxed by the riddle of the Svenx

fields.headline: Foxed by the riddle of the Svenx
fields.standfirst:
Eriksson is charming, laconic and discreet - and we don't have a clue who he will pick
Graphic: David Lacey helps Sven with his squad
Graphic: Lacey's picks part 2
fields.trailText: Eriksson is charming, laconic and discreet - and we don't have a clue who he will pick. Expect plenty of joyful speculation, rumour and opinion.
fields.body:
In the past, by now, a full four days before he made his announcement, we would have a good idea about whom an England manager was going to name in his squad. Generally back then, there was always a place for whoever was gathering a head of steam in the headlines.

If Don Revie or Graham Taylor were still in charge, then West Ham's entire current midfield would be a shoo-in for Friday's squad. And they wouldn't be the only Hammers representation. Following last weekend's eulogies, alongside them would be their team-mate Stuart Pearce, there to act as chaperon, mother hen and guide to the kind of obscure punk records he was collecting before they were born. After all, his claim was being vigorously pursued by the Daily Telegraph yesterday morning, and in the past that might have been enough.

Plus, we would have known because by now someone would have got a leak. A canny journalist, aware of the intoxicating but ultimately frustrating power of having a piece of information that everybody wants but can't be revealed, would have flattered some of it out of the manager, and run it claiming the highest of sources.

Besides, we could guess which names would be in it anyway. Frightened of failure, scared of what ruthlessly funny computer-generated caricature the tabloids had ready to run in the event of defeat, we could guarantee the manager would pick the same old lags, in the forlorn hope they might "do one last job" for him.

But with Sven-Goran Eriksson, we haven't a clue. Maybe this is the first product of having a foreigner manage England: we cannot read his mind. And being a newcomer from another culture, he has yet to forge a gossipy relationship with the press, so no one has been able to extract more than a polite, quite possibly ironic, platitude.

Judiciously playing on the language barrier, his statements since he took over back in January have been no more than occasional and always open-ended. One minute he values youth, he says, as long as it is tempered with experience. The next, he reminds us of the importance of experience, so long as it has youth alongside it.

But oh, how we've tried; we have done everything we can to extract some sort of line on his thinking. We have dispatched comedy DJs pretending to be Kevin Keegan to try to catch him off guard, we have put him on the panel with the BBC boys during a live European match, we have even sent him to be savaged by the slobbering sycophant Sir David Frost. And what concrete information have we gleaned? Simply that there is every chance that the captain in England's last game is in with a chance of being the cap tain in this. Four days to go and he remains enigmatic, distanced, aloof. Welcome to the Svenx.

In fact, rather than indulging our collective need for speculation, what Eriksson has been doing since his appointment is observing.

Even though his assistant Tord Grip is seen more often at football grounds these days than Wagon Wheels, the new England man clearly wants to add the evidence of his own eyes to the information to be gleaned from his assistant's dossiers.

He has been to 22 matches in the past month, geographically scouring the country, from West Ham to Sunderland (though not yet to the Dell, so we can probably rule out a dramatic recall for Matt le Tissier from Southampton's reserves). Twenty-two matches in less than 30 days: just as well he doesn't have to pay the inflated prices most visiting fans have to or he would already have eaten into the vast stipend the FA have choked up for his services. More than 3,500 miles he has clocked up in his patriotic Rover 75, supplied by his employers. Apparently he has loved the opportunity to see so many games in the flesh, a chance denied a club manager who has to restrict much of his scouting to the video machine.

And what will he have learned? At Manchester City against Coventry, the major lesson was how to prevent himself from nodding off as the cameras were trained relentlessly on him. At Leeds against Liverpool, it was how not to look too alarmed as players from two of the clubs from which he is expecting to draw a significant part of his talent appeared incapable of passing the ball to their own team-mates. And at Real Madrid against Lazio, he must have marvelled at what he has left behind.

Still, he will have seen virtually every player available to him in the Premiership, from the certains (David Beckham, Paul Scholes and Sol Campbell) through the possibles (Michael Carrick, Jamie Carragher and Paul Robinson) to the I-wouldn't-put-the-mortgage-on-it-if-I-were-yous (Gavin McCann, Spencer Prior and Dean Windass). Some players scuffed their chance to shine. Kevin Phillips, carelessly, did so twice. But still, whom he will pick remains his secret.

Which, for four days, means hours of joyful speculation, rumour and opinion. The romantics among us will hope he will treat the game against Spain as the start of Year Zero, a new dawn of Wes Brown and the Cole boys, Ashley and Joe. We will point out that since they are the best players around anyway, what barrier is youth?

The pragmatists will be hoping that names like Gareth Southgate's or Teddy Sheringham's are not dismissed simply on grounds of age. And some recidivists believe that - with a World Cup campaign to be rescued from near disaster - nothing can better the grizzled experience of Martin Keown, Paul Ince and David Seaman.

This is the cleverest thing about the information vacuum that Eriksson's build-up has produced: suddenly, from nowhere, we look spoiled for choice.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: CD-Rom aims to rival lads' mags

fields.headline: CD-Rom aims to rival lads' mags
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Pure Communications has launched a CD-Rom-based magazine for 18- to 34-year-old lads, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Pure Communications believes the future of lads' magazines may be in multimedia.

Pure has launched a CD-Rom-based magazine called Enter, edited by former Later deputy Sam Delaney, which it is describing as "a TFI men's lifestyle Edinburgh Nights".

The magazine centres around a "virtual city" that users access from their CD-Rom.

It apes the familiar lads' mag format, featuring interviews with Charlie Seiga, and the inevitable totty slot in the shape of Grimleys star Amanda Holden.

But more oddly, the first issue features an interview with Gerry Adams on what he likes about Britishness, from PG Wodehouse to Enid Blyton.

Mr Delaney said the magazine aimed to be "like going to a great party and not quite knowing which room to visit first".

He continued: "You can see celebrities, play games, watch classic comedy and even go shopping."

Enter, which will be sold on newsstands from Thursday February 22, is aimed at men aged 18-35.

The launch follows a dismal set of ABCs for the men's lifestyle magazine sector.

Esquire's circulation fell by 39% year on year, Emap's Sky plunged 35.2% year on year while Later lost 22% of its circulation.

webTitle: Microsoft prepares Stinger for market

fields.headline: Microsoft prepares Stinger for market
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Microsoft has set the scene for a battle to establish the operating system for the next generation of mobile phones, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
Microsoft yesterday set the scene for what is likely to be a fierce struggle to establish the standard operating system for the next generation of mobile phones.

The company announced deals with handset manufacturers Mitsubishi and Birmingham-based Sendo in addition to an earlier agreement with Samsung. Microsoft will hold trials of its system, called Stinger, with networks including Vodafone in Britain, Deutsche Telekom's T-Mobile, Telstra in Australia and Spain's Telefonica Movile.

Microsoft described the agreements as a "significant leap forward" in its attempt to break into wireless.

Although a relative latecomer in the mobile phone market, Microsoft's ubiquity in the PC market means it is likely to provide a formidable threat.

It is lining up against Psion, the British handheld computer group which is the lead shareholder in the Symbian operating platform, US business Palm and the i-Mode platform developed by NTT DoCoMo of Japan.

Symbian yesterday announced a separate agreement to supply its operating software to next generation "smartphones" for Siemens, now the second largest mobile phone manufacturer in Europe. The deal prevented the Microsoft announcement from denting Psion shares, which closed 6p higher at 192p.

Alive to the fact that access to the internet is moving away from the desk to mobile phones and television sets, Microsoft has been hurriedly adapting its software for different platforms.

The Psion-led Symbian consortium took an early lead in the mobile market with a set of investors including four of the world's top five handset manufacturers: Nokia, Motorola, Ericsson and Matsushita.

Microsoft's agreement with Sendo is to develop handsets bearing the branding of the network operator, the mobile equivalent of own-label. Microsoft hopes it can erode the market share of some of the larger manufacturers by stealth - in doing so displaying a willingness to adapt its usual more aggressive approach to market. Sendo makes phones for Virgin Mobile.

Microsoft presented the system at the GSM World Congress in Cannes, the annual mobile phone conference.

The company hopes the first of its phones will go one sale before the end of the year taking advantage of GPRS technology, the interim between the current standards and the third-generation phone networks.

The phones will offer large colour screens, email, faster mobile internet access than the current Wap phones as well as a diary, database of contacts, music and video. It also provides secure corporate web access. Microsoft's Stinger platform is built on a version of the Windows CE 3.0 operating system.

GPRS, which has been dubbed 2.5G, is expected to provide a significant change in the use of wireless internet, providing much faster speeds. It will introduce "always on" technology, unlike WAP which requires users to log on every time they want to go online.

The first Microsoft phones were about 30% smaller than the present average phone, the company said.
fields.bodyText: Microsoft yesterday set the scene for what is likely to be a fierce struggle to establish the standard operating system for the next generation of mobile phones. The company announced deals with handset manufacturers Mitsubishi and Birmingham-based Sendo in addition to an earlier agreement with Samsung. Microsoft will hold trials of its system, called Stinger, with networks including Vodafone in Britain, Deutsche Telekom's T-Mobile, Telstra in Australia and Spain's Telefonica Movile. Microsoft described the agreements as a "significant leap forward" in its attempt to break into wireless. Although a relative latecomer in the mobile phone market, Microsoft's ubiquity in the PC market means it is likely to provide a formidable threat. It is lining up against Psion, the British handheld computer group which is the lead shareholder in the Symbian operating platform, US business Palm and the i-Mode platform developed by NTT DoCoMo of Japan. Symbian yesterday announced a separate agreement to supply its operating software to next generation "smartphones" for Siemens, now the second largest mobile phone manufacturer in Europe. webTitle: In brief: Hannibal has biggest ever UK opening weekend for 18 film

fields.headline: Hannibal has biggest ever UK opening weekend for 18 film
fields.standfirst: Plus: Woody Allen pushes to beat strike; Stanley Kramer dies at 87; "Arnold the barbarian" rampages on; Bryan Singer starts work on X-Men 2
fields.trailText: Plus: Woody Allen pushes to beat strike; Stanley Kramer dies at 87; "Arnold the barbarian" rampages on; Bryan Singer starts work on X-Men 2
fields.body:
 Hannibal, featuring Sir Anthony Hopkins reprising his role as the evil Hannibal Lecter, has achieved the biggest opening weekend ever recorded in the UK for an 18 certificate film, netting £6.4m in its first three days and doubling the previous record, held by Snatch.

 Even Woody Allen, normally a law unto himself, is being pressured by the fast-looming actors' strike. Renowned for setting the cameras rolling each autumn without fail, Allen has pulled forward the schedule on his new comedy to beat the June deadline.

 Veteran producer-director Stanley Kramer has died, aged 87, writes Ananova. Renowned for working on message films like Judgement at Nuremberg and The Wild Ones, he was also involved with High Noon (as producer) and It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World. Nominated for the Best Director Oscar three times, he was eventually presented with the Irving G Thalberg Memorial Award in 1962. He succumbed to pneumonia and died yesterday.

 This week's issue of the National Enquirer leaps into the fray to cast further doubt on the marriage of the man Premiere magazine has dubbed "Arnold the barbarian". Wife Maria Shriver is, according to the sleaze-obsessed rag, fed up with Arnold Schwarzenegger's philandering ways and the exposé details supposed liaisons with a leading lady, a stewardess, a stand-in, a makeup artist and others. True lies or what?

 Although Bryan Singer's film of Confessions of a Dangerous Mind, based on the autobiography of The Gong Show host Chris Barris, has been cancelled because of funding problems, the X-Men director will not be short of work. Coming Attractions reports that he has confirmed that he is to direct X-Men 2. The superhero sequel is due to begin filming towards the end of the year and Singer is currently working on the script.

webTitle: EasyEverything creates ad sales house

fields.headline: EasyEverything creates ad sales house
fields.trailText: 12pm: The chain of internet cafes has teamed up with advertising giant WPP to sell ads in its stores, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
EasyEverything, the chain of internet cafes set up by Stelios Haji-Ioannou, has created a 50-50 joint venture with advertising giant WPP to sell advertising in its stores.

The company, to be called EasyEverything Media Sales, will be responsible for all online and in-store advertising in the 21 giant internet cafes across the world.

The deal allows WPP's clients access to advertise on EasyEverything's computer screens and its two free websites, bezel and channel advertising.

"Consumers want more from the internet and we are making EasyEverything live up to its name," said Mr Haji-Ioannou.

"With this ability to sell more advertising, the cost of surfing for the consumer will come down, remaining faithful to the principles of the easy brand."

EasyEverything is planning to expand its global chain of cafes and is introducing all the latest Microsoft software as well as webcams and internet telephones.

EasyEverything Media Sales will employ 20 staff.

webTitle: Wheels: The Mitsubishi Shogun Pinin

fields.headline: Haughty but nice
fields.standfirst: The Pinin might not be as big as it thinks it is - but it's still robust enough to take you home across a cow field
fields.trailText: The Pinin might not be as big as it thinks it is - but it's still robust enough to take you home across a cow field, says Giles Smith.
fields.body:
Mitsubishi's tag-line for the Shogun Pinin - a compact sports utility vehicle that has been around for a while with three doors, and now comes in a spanking new version with five - is "small in the city, big in the country". A bit like folk music and pub lunches, perhaps.

The idea seems to have been to create a vehicle that won't look stupid in a built-up area with the sounds of Puff Daddy thumping around inside it (or, indeed, with Puff Daddy himself thumping around inside it), but which at the same time is genuinely robust enough to get you home across a cow field, should that ever prove necessary.

So here it is, then, with its blistered fenders and rap-star wheel arches and its haughty driving position and sheep-proof paintwork. It's not trying to be all things to everyone; it's trying to be two things to someone. And it pretty much pulls it off.

The car's name, Mitsubishi would argue, points to another dual advantage: the style injection that comes from such things as seat cloth from the Italian design company Pininfarina (hence Pinin); plus what Mitsubishi refers to as "the heritage and reputation of the Shogun", the car's considerably older and much fatter brother.

Let those who would scoff at the use of these grandly formal notions in the vicinity of a mere Japanese motor car read the list of awards won by the Shogun in its pomp, not least the Caravan Club Tower of the Year prize and the Practical Caravan Magazine Readers' Top Towing Car Award for 1990. Cool or what? And already in its brief life as a three-door, the Pinin has been voted Scottish Leisure Vehicle of the Year 2000. Still want to argue about heritage and reputation?

The Pinin is a large lump of metal, but it's positively dainty beside the standard Shogun, which is one of the most comically giant cars on the road, an amphibious personnel carrier thinly disguised as a family runabout. One year at the Badminton Horse Trials, which Mitsubishi have been known to sponsor, they backed two of them together to make a fence. Whatever your feelings about sports utility vehicles, you would rather have been in the Shogun than on the horse.

In a couple of respects, the Pinin may be thought to be suffering from a big-brother complex. It has giant handles bolted just inside the driver and passenger doors, as if hauling yourself in and out was as tough as scrambling into the cab of a lorry. And it has a vast door-pull on the boot, as if this was a meat locker you were opening rather than a standard Japanese back door. These touches feel like the equivalent of elevator shoes - as if the car can't quite resign itself to being the kid.

Publicity photographs for the Pinin imagine it functioning across a fetchingly broad spectrum of uses, and with women at the wheel. Mitsubishi claim they have designed the Pinin with women in mind. Not just any women - "women who know what they want". But cornering the market may not be as simple as that. What if it turns out that what some of these women know they want is a Toyota Rav 4?

Whatever, in one photo, we see a woman in shiny shoes, standing by a bruisingly ostentatious gold Pinin outside Harrods, as a green-liveried flunky ferries a hamper in the direction of her boot; in another, we see a woman in black boots, loading into a silver Pinin the contents of a Tesco's trolley; and in another, a driver, who may be a man or a woman in any kind of footwear, tilting a blue Pinin through approximately 70 degrees in what appears to be a torrential mudslide in the middle of a thicket.

These lives could be yours in a Pinin. Or you could be the owner of the wetsuit and oxygen tank that pops up in the boot of a Pinin in yet another shot. Whatever the case, the assumption seems to be that you're an active sort of person. Even when doing nothing braver than the weekly shop, your potential for more reckless kinds of hobby shines through in your choice of a Pinin.

Also, you are necessarily the kind of person who requires two stick-shifts - one to operate the gears in the conventional manner, the other to work the Pinin's unique-to-its-class four-wheel-drive system. This has four modes, which are roughly as follows: "normal", for urban conditions; "slightly hairy", for managing slippery roads; "extremely hairy", for negotiating ice floes and terrain that has recently been subjected to an earthquake; and "David Attenborough", for pursuing gorillas in their natural habitat over a 12-month period.

One can say without fear of contradiction that this is the only compact SUV on the road right right now that goes all the way up to "David Attenborough". Most of them, if we're being frank, stop at "Charlie Dimmock" (for going to a garden centre and coming back with something fairly heavy in the back). For that alone, one must give thanks.

webTitle: Smith's winterwonderland

fields.headline: Smith's winterwonderland
fields.standfirst: Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: "Here we come, Val d'Isere," declared the absolutely fabulous tones of Jennifer Saunders, as the models entered Paul Smith's winter wonderland of Christmas trees and fake snow.
fields.body:
"Here we come, Val d'Isere," declared the absolutely fabulous tones of Jennifer Saunders, as the models entered Paul Smith's winter wonderland of Christmas trees and fake snow.

For next winter Smith, Britain's most successful fashion designer, harked back to old-fashioned winter glamour. With their coloured coats, rosy cheeks and bonnets trimmed with pom-poms, the models looked like ice skaters from a children's book. Even the infamous Christmas jumper made an appearance, in a glittery snowflake pattern.

The mood was more apres-ski - after all, even the most dedicated follower of fashion doesn't want to ski in a corset dress, however prettily trimmed with red ribbon. Sporty, high-waisted trousers were tucked into sock boots in ribbed wool - cosy and sexy, but high-heeled and definitely not waterproof.

There were curvy shift dresses in black or coffee lace over flesh-coloured slips. A sheer lace blouse in black or fuchsia pink with bows at the elbow, in the style loved by Marie Antoinette, was worn bra-less but should be sold with a modesty-saving camisole.

The fake fur coats looked bulky; more suitable for a Moscow tram ride than a ski-lift. More desirable were a sky blue coat with mandarin collar and high back, kick pleat, and a pistachio wool pea coat.

webTitle: Dressed to thrill: London fashion vamps it up

fields.headline: Dressed to thrill: London fashion vamps it up
fields.standfirst: Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: After a low key start, London Fashion Week got glamorous yesterday.
fields.body:
After a low key start, London Fashion Week got glamorous yesterday. Early in the day, Maria Chen had produced the kind of show the city is famous for - offbeat clothes, an hour late in a freezing cold hall. But with the help of a small army of celebrity friends, designers Matthew Williamson and Julien Macdonald showed the paparazzi that London fashion can vamp it up with the best of them.

The Williamson show, held in the cavernous, white-walled Saatchi Gallery in north London, boasted a stellar front row, although not all showed perfect manners to their designer host. Helena Christiansen wore Matthew Williamson, as did TV presenter Cat Deeley and model Jools Oliver, but Jerry Hall lent her support to Clements Ribeiro and Minnie Driver plumped for Burberry.

The collection was titled Wonderland, and there were plenty of outfits for Alice: the white leather French maid's pinny, worn over stripy tights had more than a hint of the Lewis Carroll surreal, as did the black lace mini dress with sequinned playing card motifs and dangling furry dice - not to mention the cream batwing T-shirt with Drink Me written in diamante. But a nude sequinned dress with a pastel skirt looked most suitable for Tinkerbell.

The undoubted success of the collection was marred by a speaker falling into the audience, injuring a journalist.

Julien Macdonald broadcast his catwalk show live from the Grosvener House Hotel on sponsor website icShowbiz.com. By Macdonald's standards, this was a demure collection: there were a few trademark "oops, someone's ripped most of my dress off" teeny numbers in gold-spangled net and pink leopard-printed chiffon, but the tuxedo-style satin trouser suits were sleek and elegant.

Nice to see Macdonald exploring options for after-dark dressing that don't involve flashing your knickers. As the show ended, the catwalk and audience, which included Kylie Minogue and Mick Jagger, were buried under a glitter storm. Hey, that's icShowbiz.com.

webTitle: Coke to cash in on Harry Potter

fields.headline: Coke to cash in on Harry Potter
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Coca-Cola has signed a £103m deal to be the sole marketing partner for the Harry Potter film, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
It has been the biggest sensation in the history of children's publishing.

And now the biggest drink brand in the world is set to cash in on the success of Harry Potter with a record-breaking deal to launch the movie.

Coca-Cola has signed a £103m, multi-year deal to be the sole global marketing partner of the Harry Potter film when it opens.

The scale of the deal has staggered the industry.

The marketing budget is almost enough to pay for the movie and it would certainly be enough to make 30 Billy Elliott films.

Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone will launch in November and cost Warner Bros £110m to make.

Coca-Cola and Warner Bros hope the joint marketing push will create the blockbuster sales both companies need.

Despite the size of the deal, Harry Potter will not be turned into a spokesman for Coca-Cola.

Author JK Rowling is insistent she does not want to taint the stories' magic and innocence with aggressive commercialisation.

Usually children's and family movies are accompanied by huge ad pushes in fast-food outlets such as McDonald's and Burger King.

Films such as Pokemon and The Grinch were involved with huge toy giveaways.

Similarly, the Harry Potter film will be accompanied by joint promotions with supermarkets and an advertising blitz.

But the main focus of the global marketing push will be the promotion of literacy programmes around the world.

The marketing plans will run across the flagship Coca-Cola brand and US brands owned by the Minute Maid Company, including the Hi-C and Minute Maid juice drinks.

"This important partnership with Warner Bros and the release of Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone marks one of the largest global entertainment initiatives ever undertaken by the Coca-Cola Company," said Steve Jones, Coca-Cola Company senior vice-president and chief marketing officer.

"Both Harry Potter and Coca-Cola reach deep into the heart of local communities around the world to add a little bit of magic to people's everyday lives.

"Bringing the two together creates a opportunity for us to develop programmes that will not only touch people emotionally, but allow us to affect their lives in a tangible, meaningful way," said Mr Jones.

webTitle: Snooker body prepares for rights battle

fields.headline: Snooker body prepares for rights battle
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Snooker's governing body has teamed up with a consultancy to contest media rights to the sport, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Snooker's governing body is preparing the ground for a potentially damaging battle over the future of the sport, after teaming up with a media rights consultancy.

The World Professional Billiard and Snooker Association has appointed Media Content to help it through a looming clash with the Sportsmasters Network.

The latter is forming a rival professional snooker tour and has already recruited several top players.

The new tour could threaten the WPBSA's stranglehold on media coverage of the event.

The body hopes the recruitment of Media Content will increase snooker coverage in Europe and Asia.

"With the appointment of Media Content, World Snooker is clearly demonstrating it is building the right team to put its strategic vision into practice," said Jim McKenzie, chief executive of World Snooker.

TSN set up the rival body because it believed snooker is a global money-spinner that has not achieved its commercial potential under the WPBSA.

The company intends to make snooker a huge hit over the internet, with pay-as-you-play online snooker games and webcasts of major tournaments.

But Media Content is a seasoned professional in the broadcasting rights world.

It has brokered deals with sports giants such Manchester United and the New Zealand All Blacks.

"We are delighted to be appointed by the official body for World Snooker.

"We look forward to assisting it in the development and implementation of a media strategy that will provide long-term benefits to all snooker players worldwide," said Jean-Paul de la Fuente, chief executive of Media Content.

webTitle: Straw raises crime victims' cash sums

fields.headline: Straw raises crime victims' cash sums
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Crime victims are to get more cash to compensate for their suffering after an overhaul of the criminal injuries system, the government confirmed last night, although the lawyer for one victim described the increases as "disappointing".
fields.body:
Crime victims are to get more cash to compensate for their suffering after an overhaul of the criminal injuries system, the government confirmed last night, although the lawyer for one victim described the increases as "disappointing".

Pay-outs from the criminal injuries compensation scheme contrast starkly with the amounts awarded by the civil courts, which often run into six figures.

The minimum award for rape victims will be increased from £7,500 to £11,000 and people who suffer multiple injuries will receive higher sums.

Gay couples will have the same rights as heterosexuals for the first time, becoming eligible to claim a cash pay-out if their partner is killed.

Earlier this month nursery nurse Lisa Potts, who received the George Medal for shielding children from a machete-wielding attacker, was told she would get just £49,000 for the 11 serious wounds she received.

Three weeks ago another victim of the machete attack, eight-year-old Francesca Quintyne, had her compensation tripled to £23,000 by an appeals panel.

Francesca's lawyer, Tom Jones, said the new figures would mean an increase in her award of only about £4,000. "If it wasn't so upsetting it would be laughable. The headline figure of the package looks impressive but the detail is disappointing."

Mr Jones said a woman seeking compensation for serious facial scarring in the civil courts could expect to receive between £24,000 and £48,000.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, said the package will cost an estimated £20m a year on top of the scheme's £200m annual budget.

The system pays a fixed amount, or tariff, for each type of wound but has been criticised because each victim can only be compensated for three injuries, no matter how many they receive.

The full tariff is granted for the most serious wound, 10% for the second most serious and 5% for the third. Last night Mr Straw said the formula would increase to 100%, 30% and 15%, but people who have suffered multiple injuries will still only be able to claim for three of them.

The home secretary added: "I want victims of crime to have a greater confidence that we are looking after their interests and listening to their concerns."

webTitle: Germans to send beef to N Korea

fields.headline: Germans to send beef to N Korea
fields.trailText: German and North Korean officials are discussing a plan to ship surplus German beef arising from the BSE crisis to famine-stricken North Korea.
fields.body:
German and North Korean officials are discussing a plan to ship surplus German beef arising from the BSE crisis to famine-stricken North Korea.

In an interview published yesterday the German agriculture minister, Renate Künast, said she was ready to approve the idea, provided that the meat was shared fairly among the population and international humanitarian organisations were given untrammelled access to the country.

The German government has agreed to an EU scheme to buy and slaughter 400,000 head of cattle to prop up beef prices.

The sale of beef fell sharply after it was discovered at the end of last year that mad cow disease had entered German herds.

Meat from the cull will be tested for BSE before being approved for export. Since BSE tests are not 100% reliable the beef intended for North Korea will carry a higher risk of infection than meat from countries unaffected by the disease.

Pyongyang's willingness to have it was conveyed in a letter from its diplomatic mission in Berlin congratulating Ms Künast on her appointment.

Ms Künast, a Green, joined the cabinet last month after her predecessor resigned after being criticised for his handling of the BSE crisis.

The charitable organisation Cap Anamur said last week that North Korea had asked for the meat from 200,000 head of cattle. The German development ministry having talks with NGOs about the suitability of beef for starving North Koreans.
