webTitle: Driving to death at Daytona

fields.headline: Driving to death at Daytona
fields.standfirst: America's fastest-growing sport, stock-car racing, has claimed its fourth victim this year, says Julian Borger
fields.trailText: America's fastest-growing sport, stock-car racing, has claimed its fourth victim this year, says Julian Borger in Washington.
fields.body:
An unlikely US sporting icon died this week. At 49, Dale Earnhardt was twice the age of most sports stars and he met his death driving a souped-up Chevrolet at 170 mph into a concrete wall. Moreover, he was a hero much of America was entirely unaware of until he was gone.

Sunday's crash offered yet another demonstration of America's vastness. Earnhardt was the best-known driver in the National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing, NASCAR.

If you ask most big-city Americans on the east or west coast just what NASCAR is, they would have only a hazy idea. The majority would have had a problem identifying Earnhardt in a line-up.

But NASCAR is the fastest growing sport in America. Over six million people lined up for long hours to see the races last year, and an estimated 70 million watched on television.

Product endorsements by leading drivers like Earnhardt were among the most sought after in merchandising. Licensed merchandise sales grew by 1,400 per cent over the past decade.

It is the sport of the southeast and increasingly the Midwest, pitting home grown heroes against each other in brand-name street cars fortified with a little bit of extra engineering. They race bumper-to bent-bumper in a high-speed traffic jam around huge racetracks.

The races are gaining new middle-class recruits, but NASCAR is overwhelmingly the sport of poor white America.

It started in Georgia in the Prohibition era, when bootleggers would tune up their cars so they could outrun the police when they raced rural moonshine to the speakeasies of Atlanta. On their days off, they would race their cars against each other on dirt tracks for bragging rights.

A streak of the rebellious South still runs through NASCAR. When Earnhardt was killed at Daytona Beach, some of his fans raised his likeness superimposed on the Southern Cross, the battle flag of the Confederacy.

It is not clear where NASCAR will go from here. Its extraordinary growth and now Earnhardt's death have placed it under national public scrutiny, which may be somewhat less forgiving of its rough edges.

Earnhardt was the fourth NASCAR driver to die in a year. A record like that in any other sport would invite commissions of inquiry and calls for reform or even abolition.

Questions would be asked, for example, about why, when Earnhardt's car skidded off the Daytona track, it hit a concrete wall and not something a little more forgiving.

Softer walls had been tried but apparently took too much clearing up when someone ploughed into one, to which Earnhardt responded in an interview with the Orlando Sentinel the week before he died: "I'd rather they spend 20 minutes cleaning up that mess than cleaning me off the wall."

There were also questions yesterday about why the sport had not made obligatory a head and neck brace designed to protect drivers from the sort of fracture at the base of the skull from which Earnhardt died.

So far, the deaths have been absorbed. It is Middle America's version of gladiatorial combat, and after last year's big Daytona race was too uneventful, the organisers stacked more cars together at closer quarters for more thrills and spills.

Earnhardt was adored because he was a competitive driver who was not too timid to scrape the paint off a competitor's car while jockeying for position.

Now that he's gone it will be instructive to find out if his death provides the occasion for some introspection or if it only serves to accelerate NASCAR's relentless rise.

Its extraordinary growth and now Earnhardt's death have placed it under national public scrutiny, which may be somewhat less forgiving of its rough edges. Earnhardt was the fourth NASCAR driver to die in a year. A record like that in any other sport would invite commissions of inquiry and calls for reform or even abolition. Questions would be asked, for example, about why, when Earnhardt's car skidded off the Daytona track, it hit a concrete wall and not something a little more forgiving. Softer walls had been tried but apparently took too much clearing up when someone ploughed into one, to which Earnhardt responded in an interview with the Orlando Sentinel the week before he died: "I'd rather they spend 20 minutes cleaning up that mess than cleaning me off the wall." There were also questions yesterday about why the sport had not made obligatory a head and neck brace designed to protect drivers from the sort of fracture at the base of the skull from which Earnhardt died. So far, the deaths have been absorbed. It is Middle America's version of gladiatorial combat, and after last year's big Daytona race was too uneventful, the organisers stacked more cars together at closer quarters for more thrills and spills. Earnhardt was adored because he was a competitive driver who was not too timid to scrape the paint off a competitor's car while jockeying for position. Now that he's gone it will be instructive to find out if his death provides the occasion for some introspection or if it only serves to accelerate NASCAR's relentless rise. webTitle: BBC courts viewers with undercover series

fields.headline: BBC courts viewers with undercover series
fields.trailText:
Roger Cook has a young pretender. The BBC is pinning its hopes on a lean 34-year-old to reinvent the genre of televised crook-bashing, writes Matt Wells.
Feb 8: BBC confronts current affairs deficit
fields.body:
Roger Cook, the portly pioneer of doorstep journalism, has a young pretender. The BBC is pinning its hopes on a lean 34-year-old to reinvent the genre of televised crook-bashing.

Paul Kenyon takes on conmen and fraudsters for the corporation's latest attempt to popularise its current affairs output. The four-part series, Kenyon Confronts, is already being described as the new MacIntyre Undercover - the BBC's successful but controversial investigation programme.

The new series is part of a strategy by BBC1 controller, Lorraine Heggessey. Since Panorama was moved to Sunday night, it struggles to attract 3m viewers - two years ago an edition about mobile phone health risks, hosted by Mr Kenyon, attracted 7m.

Mr Kenyon, who will continue to work for Panorama, said there was still a place for the BBC's flagship current affairs series: "This is nothing to do with Panorama losing viewers. We are trying to bring current affairs to a new, younger audience."

The first edition, which is shown next Monday, exposes the organisers of "marriage-for-residency" scams. In one memorable scene in a register office, a registrar asks the guests if they know of a reason why a couple cannot be married. Mr Kenyon stands up to say the groom wants to marry the woman simply so he can remain in Britain legally.

Secret filming features in some of the programmes, but Mr Kenyon rejected comparisons with MacIntyre Undercover. "I would say it is closer to the better Cook Report programmes, but moved on from there. Hopefully, we updated it: our show is pacier and more quirky. They are hard-hitting investigations."

Mr Kenyon, a former researcher for the Liberal Democrat MP Simon Hughes, is best known for his BBC2 series Raising the Roof, which exposed dodgy building contractors. The new programme is made by the same team.

Stewart Lansley, the executive producer, said the series tackles serious issues. "We would describe the programmes as traditional, hard-hitting investigations. We gather the evidence and film then expose and confront the perpetrators. But we do it in a new format. The style is popular and we use lots of stunts; Paul is very witty and works on his own investigations rather than just turning up at the end."

But he insisted the programme could not be accused of trivialising current affairs. "We are not selling out: we can robustly defend our approach within a current affairs perspective."

The other programmes in the series expose the bogus claims of some Harley Street doctors, the exploitation of Britons who buy property in Spain and insurance scams.

The new series faces stiff competition. Some BBC insiders are disappointed with the scheduling of Kenyon Confronts. The series will go out in a "graveyard slot" of Mondays at 7.30pm, against ITV's Coronation Street.

ITV is understood to be surprised that the BBC series has not been placed against one of the more vulnerable parts of the commercial channel's line-up, such as the regular peak-time regional slots or a potentially vulnerable drama such as Peak Practice.

webTitle: Historic Charlie Chaplin outtakes discovered

fields.headline: Historic Charlie Chaplin outtakes discovered
fields.trailText: The footage of the legendary screen comic, which includes film of the development of some of his most famous routines, is now being restored
fields.body:
A whole cache of lost Charlie Chaplin outtakes, which the pioneering comic had ordered to be destroyed, have been found, some dating back as far as 1916.

Ananova reports that Frank Scheider, associate professor of communications at the University of Arkansas, made the discovery after viewing over 70 hours of previously unavailable Chaplin footage.

Most of the 400 reels are outtakes shot when Chaplin was making his films which show the gradual conceptualising of some of his most famous routines. There is also screen test material and footage that the actor-director felt did not make the grade. King, Queen, Joker, a film made in 1921 by Chaplin's elder brother Syd, was also unearthed.

Professor Scheide said: "Chaplin experimented by doing variations of his comic business on the set, and then he reviewed the footage - almost like a screen test - to see what worked and what could be changed for greater comic effect. Looking at these outtakes, you can actually see how some of his most famous routines evolved."

In reassuringly familiar "Auntie's Bloomers"-style, one section of the footage features Chaplin and co-stars on 1917's The Immigrant bursting into involuntary fits of uncontrollable laughter between takes.

The reels are currently being restored at the National Film and Television Archive and the British Film Institute in London.

webTitle: Napster backers tackle Fifa

fields.headline: Napster backers tackle Fifa
fields.standfirst: Media Guardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The backers of rogue internet site Napster are taking on the Fifa football organisation, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The backers of rogue internet site Napster are taking on the Fifa football organisation, just one week after a bruising courtroom battle with the world's biggest record companies.

NetCapital, the company which founded the Napster file-sharing service, has agreed to take over a legal battle between US website footofgod.com and Fifa, the body that runs the World Cup.

Fifa has slapped a court ban on the site because it shows clips of vintage World Cup goals - such as Gary Lineker's equaliser against Germany in Italia '90 - that are owned by the football organisation.

Footofgod founder Kadima Lonji has sold the site to Netcapital's SportsClub.com operation, which delivers live or recorded sports action over the internet.

"It is perfect that the guys who own Napster are involved - we all know what they are good at.

"I did not get any money for the company so they will take it over and try to do the right thing," said Mr Lonji.

Napster last week lost a court case brought by four of the world's five leading record companies.

The companies successfully argued the site breached copyright laws by distributing recordings without the owners' permission.

Napster was founded by Shawn Fanning and his uncle John Fanning, who is head of technology investment at NetCapital.

"Huge amounts of fans have written in, complaining that the site has gone. This situation has to be resolved," added Mr Lonji.

However, Swiss company ISL Worldwide is weeks away from launching a Fifa-sanctioned version of the footofgod site.

The sports media firm has acquired the internet rights to all World Cup footage and will launch its site, to be called fifaworldcup.com, in the next few weeks.

"As far as we are concerned, we have the rights to the next World Cup and the video archives for previous tournaments.

"Footofgod contained archive footage - which is a very sensitive area - and I doubt if the site will be able to open again," said an ISL spokesman.

The footofgod site, which is now closed, directs all enquiries to SportsClub's offices.

At the time of closure, footofgod was attracting up to 20,000 football fanatics per day.

They logged on to see football classics such as Maradona's famous solo goal for Argentina against England in the 1986 World Cup.

Fifa and NetCapital were not available for comment.

webTitle: TeleCity holds high hopes despite tripled losses

fields.headline: TeleCity holds high hopes despite tripled losses
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The internet infrastructure company has insisted the European market for its internet hosting services will grow dramatically, reports Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
TeleCity, the internet infrastructure company, yesterday insisted that the European market for its internet hosting services would grow dramatically despite reporting a three-fold increase in losses during the last year.

The company, which joined the stock market last June, said the market for hosting services is forecast to grow from €1bn (£600m) in 2000 to €12.5bn by 2004, according to one estimate.

"The key driver is the rapidly expanding use of the internet by consumers and, more importantly, by businesses," said a company spokesman.

TeleCity, which provides facilities for housing and servicing hardware and high-performance internet connections, posted a pre-tax loss of £12.7m for the year to the end of December 2000, against £3.5m in 1999, as the company focused on rapid growth and sales. The company said it has £47m in cash to fund its development.

The shares, which have underperformed the software and computer services sector by 13% since the company joined the market, fell a further 12.5p to 595p, compared to a peak of £23.45 last September.

Despite increasing losses, TeleCity pointed to strong revenue growth, up 318% to £14.1m over the year.

The company, which currently has 10 operational sites in Europe and plans to have over 30 by 2002, expects to be profitable by the end of 2002.

Mike Kelly, TeleCity chief executive, said: "We are very pleased with the current position and are very confident for the year."

Analysts seemed positive yesterday, saying the results put the company back on track after missing last quarter's revenue forecasts by 20%.

One analyst, however, said the company faces tough challenges this year as it attempts to aggressively push up revenues, expand its services and geographical reach, at the same time trying to become profitable. "There is a risk that they will miss their figures," he said.

The company, which employs 310 people, does not plan to expand through acquisition at the moment.

webTitle: Tories pledge to expand private healthcare

fields.headline: Tories pledge to expand private healthcare
fields.trailText: The Conservative party will provide a massive publicly funded expansion of the private healthcare sector alongside the NHS if it wins the next general election, it emerged today. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
The Conservative party will provide a massive publicly funded expansion of the private healthcare sector alongside the NHS if it wins the next general election, it emerged today.

In a keynote policy speech, the shadow health secretary, Dr Liam Fox, said the Tories would reintroduce competition into the health service by encouraging the NHS to purchase more care in private hospitals.

While the NHS would continue to be free and centrally funded through taxation, the Tories would end its "archetypal state-run monopoly" by helping create a thriving non-state sector.

Under the Tories' scheme, health authorities and GPs would be expected to send patients to the best quality and value-for-money care providers - regardless of whether they are private or NHS.

"I believe the time has come for the NHS to worry less about providing all the care itself, and instead to focus on ensuring that the treatment which it does undertake reaches the required standards," said Dr Fox.

He also announced proposals to give away nearly £500m in tax breaks to firms and individuals in an attempt to stimulate the private health insurance market and increase the overall amount of healthcare.

The Conservatives had "absolute commitment" to reviving the health service, was committed to its principles, had ruled out charges for NHS care and was committed to matching Labour spending on health.

But he added: "We shall spend the money differently and better, with particular emphasis on improving the quality of treatment.

"In parallel with this, we will encourage the development of a much bigger independent sector, to supplement the work of the NHS."

webTitle: Plan for network of drugs courts to prevent addicts returning to crime

fields.headline: Plan for network of drugs courts to prevent addicts returning to crime
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is to step up the war against drugs by setting up a nationwide network of courts to prevent addicts returning to a life of crime. Nicholas Watt reports
fields.body:
Tony Blair is to step up the war against drugs by setting up a nationwide network of courts to prevent addicts returning to a life of crime.

In an attempt to woo Tory voters ahead of the election, the government is to increase the testing of all drug suspects. Specially trained magistrates will also be given powers to force anyone convicted of drugs-related offences to undergo treatment to help them kick the habit.

The initiative, which follows the prime minister's weekend pledge to establish a national register of drug offenders, comes amid mounting concern at the rising cost of drugs-related crimes, which is thought to amount to £2.5bn a year.

Almost two-thirds of criminals (61%) test positive for one or more drugs. Home Office figures also show that 12,250 suspects arrested each week have taken heroin, crack or cocaine in the previous two days.

Under the proposals, drugs offenders would be dealt with by specially trained magistrates who would regularly monitor offenders as they serve their sentence.

webTitle: Consultants hit at private work plan

fields.headline: Consultants hit at private work plan
fields.trailText: NHS hospital consultants last night accused the government of railroading through a plan to stop them working in the private sector as a cynical pre-election stunt after months of dithering by Alan Milburn, the health secretary. John Carvel reports
fields.body:
NHS hospital consultants last night accused the government of railroading through a plan to stop them working in the private sector as a cynical pre-election stunt after months of dithering by Alan Milburn, the health secretary.

The British Medical Association said that ministers were "playing politics with Britain's 25,000 consultants to the detriment of patients and the NHS".

The government is expected tomorrow to publish proposals for a new consultants' contract. They will incorporate an idea floated in the NHS plan in July to make newly qualified consultants work exclusively for the NHS "for perhaps the first seven years of their career".

The move follows a private meeting between Mr Milburn and the BMA last week at which the doctors' representatives are understood to have harangued the minister over his treatment of them.

It looked last night as if Mr Milburn has decided Labour will lose nothing in the forthcoming election campaign by taking on a profession whose image has been dented by recent scandals.

But Peter Hawker, chairman of the BMAs consultants committee, hinted that doctors would respond by challenging the credibility of Mr Milburn's NHS reforms. "He should not assume consultants will be endlessly cooperative when the call on their goodwill is entirely one-sided," Dr Hawker said.

The row centres on the first comprehensive reform of the national consultants' contract since 1948.

Ministers want to provide better rewards for consultants who are fully committed to NHS work, in return for a stronger system of appraisal and clearer lines of accountability.

Dr Hawker said: "We have been seeking to negotiate privately and in good faith ... (but) the Department of Health has consistently failed to produce any concrete proposals.

"Planned negotiating meetings have been cancelled in the absence of any papers and we now fear there is no realistic prospect of meaningful progress before the general election is called."

The proposals being published tomorrow were no substitute for proper negotiation, he said.

"Consultants will be deeply cynical of the government's motives for doing so. In the rush to engage in megaphone negotiations, the government is making the serious mistake of underestimating the very real anger of consultants," Dr Hawker added.

A spokeswoman for the Department of Health said: "We are slightly surprised by their stance because we had a very cordial meeting with them last week. But in a way we would expect this in the run up to any negotiations."

The NHS Confederation, representing the employers' side in the negotiations, said that the BMA's intervention was "ill-timed and intemperate".

Stephen Thornton, the confederation's chief executive, said: "Shortly before the government publishes its proposals is not the time for damaging megaphone diplomacy ... The new contract must enable NHS management to properly manage its staff, including doctors.

"Recent scandals and reports of failing clinical quality have made this imperative."

webTitle: Maggie O'Kane tracks down Radovan Karadzic

fields.headline: Hunting Radovan
fields.standfirst:
For five years Nato's spies have been tracking him through the remote mountains of south-eastern Bosnia. So why is Radovan Karadzic, Europe's most wanted war criminal, still at large? Maggie O' Kane picks up his scent

Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: For five years Nato's spies have been tracking him through the remote mountains of south-eastern Bosnia. So why is Radovan Karadzic, Europe's most wanted war criminal, still at large?
fields.body:
He inhabits a wasteland of snow, mountain cabins and churches. A wild empty space of silence on the Vucevo mountain range, where icicles two metres long hang like spiky white beards at the entrance to the mountain tunnels. It was here that the White Eagles, the last bitter fighters against Tito, survived for almost 15 years. "Radovan," says his mother, Yovanka Karadzic, "Has gone back to his own people - the people he protected."

Dr Karadzic, 53, Serbian nationalist, psychiatrist and poet is the man the International War Crimes Tribunal in the Hague describes as number one on its list. "There's not a day goes by when when his name doesn't come up," says Graham Blewitt, the deputy prosecutor. In the last six years 40 indicted war criminals have arrived at the international court in the Hague.

Today 35 of them, mostly Bosnian Serbs, are detained at Schveningen prison facing trial or awaiting sentence, but there is still no sign of Karadzic. Without him, the Hague is Nuremburg without Rudolf Hess or Albert Speer. When it comes to the architects of Bosnia's destruction, those still alive are Slobodan Milosevic, Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic, their general, Karadzic is the only one within Nato's reach in Bosnia.

Karadzic's Kingdom is an area between the villages and towns of Rudo, Cajnice, Visegrad and Foca. Most of the time he is in the mountains - where the Serbian Orthodox church gives shelter to their own - just as the Catholics did with the Nazi fugitives in South America.

He is watched the old fashioned way. Spies recruited by the Allied Military Intelligence Bureau run by a US intelligence colonel at the international base at Butmir camp in Sarajevo. The American-led intelligence operation is code-named Amber Star. Two years ago the hunters went as far as sending US special operations to Germany in preparation for a swoop on Karadzic, but it was abandoned when senior US military officials found the operation too perilous.

In his home town of Pale, his wife and daughter Sonja have moved out of the family house where a lonely, friendly doberman wanders up and down inside the gates. They are watched round the clock by Nato spies, doing their best to avoid the cameras by moving from flat to flat in the town. Radio St John and TV Astra, once owned by his daughter Sonja, are up for sale and there are rumours that they are running out of money; that the old supporters who benefit from dirty dealings in black market cigarettes, whisky and petrol won't keep the old man fed and protected in the mountains forever.

Nature protects him. In winter, the few cars that make it up the mountains skid along the roads, perilously close to ravines. The only traffic is the trucks of the illegal loggers stripping the mountain forests. Karadzic does not have to try too hard to evade Nato soldiers: just 300 troops out of a force of 21,324 are in the area where he is hiding. "Round here you get the impression that picking up these guys isn't the first priority," says Lieutenant Andreas Kerl, at the German base near Foca. "Nobody really mentions him."

The US ambassador to Sarajevo, Thomas Miller, uses the phrase "that's operational" a lot when asked about Karadzic and says this could be a "very short interview". But he looks genuinely frustrated at the accusation that the Americans are doing nothing to catch him. "We're working on this ... we're doing a lot. I hope sometime I can sit down over a coffee with you and explain just what we're doing."

The problem is that Miller's coffee-drinking days in Sarajevo are coming to an end and his successor, a George W Bush appointee, is not expected to be hot on war criminals.

"We're worried about the way things are going," says one of Sarajevo's most experienced diplomats. "This is going to be a good year for Radovan. I think we missed the chance to lift him and now there is no longer the political will."

It is mostly former policemen from the old Bosnian police force who are paid to watch and photograph Karadzic skimming across the mountain tops. At times, they say, he has used an old orange Zastava, occasionally a military Jeep. They have watched him set up camp in a 19th-century granite church in the village of Rudo; identified his bodyguards from black-and-white photos as the same men who have looked after him since 1992 (he has 80 and at any one time there are no more than 20 men around him); seen him call briefly on the good monks of the Pivski Manasteri or the church at Cajnice where the village merges across the Montenegrin border.

At home in Niksic, in Montenegro, his 78-year-old mother is chain-smoking through a thin, brown plastic cigarette holder, her compromise following three strokes and angina. She is not keen on compromise: "I'd rather Radovan put a bullet in his own head than handed himself over to the Hague," she says. "God will judge him, not the Hague, and what I know of my son is that he wouldn't squash an ant." She smooths out the folds of her lace tablecloth as she talks. The mother of one of the world's most wanted men twinkles gruffly through the interview teasing, prodding.

"I never went to school a day in my life, but God was good to me and gave me four sons and a daughter. Of them all, he was the most talented. We recognised that in him early and worked hard to get him to university. He didn't want to be a politician but the people needed him and he couldn't refuse them. Handsome isn't he?"

On her mantlepiece is a framed photograph of Karadzic. The same Karadzic who established the Omarska detention camp as part of his masterplan to "ethnically cleanse" the Muslims of Bosnia. In his book, the Tenth Circle of Hell, one survivor of Omarska, Rezak Hukanovic, recalls: "Thirst, hunger, gang rapes, exhaustion, skulls shattered, sexual organs torn out, stomachs ripped open by the soldier assassins of Radovan Karadzic. The torturers who ordered an old man to make love to a young woman in public. And the father forced to witness the torture of his son."

Karadzic's defence is that it all spiralled out of his control. Such brutality was never authorised by him. "Radovan knew about rights and conventions and those things. He spent all his money on books," says his mother, lighting yet another cigarette. "That is why they choose him to be leader."

Two years ago a Serbian film director was granted an audience with the man feared by the world's strongest army. He wrote of the encounter in the Belgrade magazine, Profile: "The visitors always come at night to see him. He sits and drinks red wine. He's pretty relaxed, like he was sitting in some restaurant. When he got up to embrace me I felt the holster under his shirt. At his hand are the TV controls, a table full of books, including the Bible and there's also a computer. He kept flicking from one channel to another."

So will he spend his life running in the mountains? Why not, his mother shrugs: "His people will protect him. Would you like coffee - we have espresso? He is well, you know. Mentally he is absolutely fine." Three hours drive from his mother's home is the town of Rudo and the tiny Orthodox church which was one of Karadzic's lodgings last year according to those who watch him.

In these townspeople smile knowingly at the foreign visitor and ask why it is only the Serbs that are hunted for the Hague. They tell you that their problems as Serbs are part of an international plot against them that has to do with oil. And they ask a more troubling question: "Why, if all the stuff about the camps and Srebrenica is true, has nobody arrested Karadzic?" The lack of an arrest is being interpreted as a lack of a case to answer. As the time passes history is already been rewritten, memory lost.

When I went looking for Karadzic I stopped off at the Partizan Hall in Foca, at the top of a steep street called Smaoborska. Eight years ago, in the July 1992, I remember the door of the hall opening briefly on a hot afternoon and a glimpse of dozens of women held inside. Later that summer we heard how they had been systematically raped by Karadzic's men. Last year three men from their town were convicted in the Hague of using rape as a weapon of war, but Foca is still in denial.

Now, the international forces, the international police, the outside world is like Zoran Mandic, the police chief in Foca, pretending that life is getting back to normal. "Of the town's 20,000 Muslims who fled, 680 have come back and things are getting back to normal," he tells me. A German officer laughs at the claim: "We have had only 15 Muslims return out of 20,000, and all of them are over 50," he says. The Muslims of Foca are not ready to come home.

In 1996, Britain and the SAS began to get serious and swooped on alleged war criminals in their zones of control. But the indicted war criminals escaped from the British zone to the French zone, where the French troops ignored them until 1998 when Chirac also decided to get serious. The American body-bag phobia had meant that, while the US will pay bounty hunters and provide intelligence, they won't send troops to snatch criminals themselves.

Now some of those seized by bounty hunters are challenging their arrests in the Hague and even these techniques are being put on hold. These days the new US administration is backing off, the French are relieved and a British government preparing for an election is wary of high-profile cock-ups. "Let's just say everyone is getting the impression that the gears are being shifted down," says one Hague investigator working in Bosnia.

In Omarska they are also in denial. Stojanke Plavsic, 69, leans on her gate, and looks across at the mineshaft, past the white house where the worst of the torture took place: "Here, nothing happened here. Didn't hear anything. It was a couple of kilometres down the road you're looking for. Go and ask the police."

In the police station, they offer flat Fanta and brandy. "We weren't here then,"says one. "Anyway it was just a refugee camp - a transit camp."

Outside, an ice-cream van twinkles by, making delivers of La Barchetta to the local cafes, and just beyond them are the rusting railway carriages that brought in the Muslims. Women and children for transit - the men for beating and sometimes death. The memory is barely a whisper now.

Karadzic's continued freedom and the collective memory loss may suit international politics now. President Bush has made no secret that he wants out of Bosnia as quickly as possible. Ambassador Thomas Miller, the keenest hunter of war criminals will be replaced in June with someone more in keeping with the new administration. Later this month the Polish/American colonel who has headed up the intelligence operation to find him for two years is leaving Sarajevo. The French, never very enthusiastic about picking up war criminals in their zone, can relax. And Karadzic can relax.

Ambassador Miller in Sarajevo likes to wave his hands in the air like the good attorney in Olive Stone's movie, JFK: "Let justice be done though the heavans might fall." But in Bosnia Karadzic is free, history is disappearing, memories are stolen. And it has only been nine years.

fields.headline: Quick - smash up a hotel room
fields.standfirst:
Why is Britain's music press collapsing? Could it be because today's stars are simply too dull for words? Garry Mulholland, who has written for most of the magazines, looks for clues

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Is Britain's music press collapsing because today's stars are too dull for words? Garry Mulholland investigates.
fields.body:
Music journalism has always had a tendency to wrap itself in irony. But, just at the moment, the joke is on us. Just as Cameron Crowe's film Almost Famous has raised the profile of the humble music hack to hitherto unimagined heights, the British music press is in crisis.

Just before the end of last year, two of Britain's most significant music titles, Melody Maker and Select, were suddenly discontinued (the former after 75 years). If you're looking for something to blame, try the false dawn that was Britpop. As Alexis Petridis, the last editor of Select, explains: "The research told us that, no matter how many features we did on Destiny's Child, people still thought it was a magazine about Oasis. We were forever associated with a music in decline."

Melody Maker, in turn, had tried to turn around a long, slow decline by becoming an all-colour glossy and putting a young and frothy Smash Hits-type spin on guitar bands. The result was a sales disaster. Meanwhile, sales of the New Musical Express (Melody Maker's stronger stablemate at publisher IPC) and Q (published by Select's owners Emap) are also in decline, according to current figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulation.

The music press as a whole appears to be falling in esteem, influence and commercial appeal. Of course, there are other factors in this bleak scenario apart from the failure of Oasis and Blur to lead us all into a new golden age of pop culture. Pop is now a staple for a whole set of competing media, from tabloid exposés and broadsheet analysis to TV gossip shows and the explosion of internet and digital radio activity.

As Steve Sutherland of IPC points out: "There are now more exciting ways of accessing information than just sitting down with a pile of magazines. When I was a nipper, if you wanted to find out when your favourite band was touring, you raced down to the local newsagent of a Thursday and bought the music magazines. You wouldn't find out anywhere else, and if you wanted to know more, the mags were the sexiest way of doing it.

"Now they're probably the least sexy way of doing it. You don't have to read a hundred words on 'sonic cathedrals', take someone's word for it and buy the album only to find out it's a pile of shit. You can read about it, get excited, go to a website, hear it, buy it and have it delivered to your door the next day. It's the fulfilment of the music fan's dream."

This utopian vision of pop's multimedia future is perhaps tempered by the fact that Sutherland is the NME's brand director, overseeing the mag's spread into digital radio, television and the internet. And the view that people are no longer interested in just reading about music is challenged by one recent success story.

Emap's Mojo, ostensibly a retro rock "heritage" publication, continues to steadily improve its annual sales, despite flying in the face of perceived publishing wisdom on niche marketing, our short attention spans and our supposed refusal to buy anything that doesn't have a semi-naked model or actress on the cover. And Mojo hasn't exploited the internet yet, though it is now setting up its own website.

If anyone has been threatened by the closure of Melody Maker and Select, it is new bands, particularly those judged as too "alternative" for daytime radio. Julie Bland is co-owner of the independent music PR company 9PR, whose roster includes the bright young likes of Starsailor, Ed Harcourt, Zoot Woman, Lowgold, Doves and Boards of Canada - all critically acclaimed, all (with the exception of Doves and Starsailor) virtually unheard by the general public.

For these bands, early press is vital, and the outlets are disappearing. "With Select we've lost the bridge between the NME and the likes of Q and Mojo," Bland says. "Melody Maker was important for breaking new bands, although not as important as the NME. Mags like Q, Mojo and Uncut won't generally get on board with an artist until they've had a certain amount of success. We're all relying on the NME and, increasingly, the broadsheets."

But then, how much of this crisis is actually down to the bands? Mojo editor Paul Trynka, Sutherland and Petridis all bemoan the lack of rock'n'roll personalities - of decent copy, basically - in the current crop of British rock acts. Petridis is especially withering: "Current music is so boring - or at least, the people making it are. We want the same things out of music as we used to but you have to look to the past to get it. We want proper stars, and Mojo offers you proper stars like Jimi Hendrix and the Ramones. At the moment it's like 1975 all over again. You've got big stars like Oasis and Richard Ashcroft who've gone and bought big houses in the country and made awful records about how terrible it is to be rich and famous. Who cares? Hopefully, some pissed-off 16-year-old is currently in his bedroom with a guitar doing something extraordinary."

Almost Famous, in its rose-tinted, good-natured way, has also reminded today's crop of pop hacks of the naive openness of the music biz back in the 1960s and 1970s. Petridis says: "Access to bands is controlled very, very tightly now. You don't get to go round the band's house, shoot up heroin with them and throw up on their doorstep, as Nick Kent did with Keith Richards. You could never get away with stuff like Lester Bangs's infamous interviews with Lou Reed, where the journalist tells him he's useless and they basically scream at each other for two hours. You'd just be ushered out of the room by the press officer."

Sutherland, who as a 20-year veteran of music journalism was a product of the fashion for florid, highly subjective writing that was booted into touch in the late 1980s, pooh-poohs this kind of nostalgia. "How can I put this politely? Part of my job is to go through the old NME and Maker archives. And yes, I look at them and get a bit misty-eyed. But, truth be told, the whole self-indulgent Almost Famous school of writing seems rather innocent and idealistic. To wish those days back doesn't make sense."

Yet again, there are smaller success stories that challenge all this. The Wire celebrates its 20th anniversary next year after having recently been bought out by its own staff - a move, according to long-serving editor Rob Young, that involves no risk at all. How has this magazine, which rejects pop stars entirely and concentrates almost exclusively on experimental, non-mainstream global music, thrived? According to Young, "we provide the kind of coverage you might have found in the NME or Melody Maker back in the 1970s, before it had been taken over by celebrity."

A lso surviving in unlikely circumstances are the team at black music mag Echoes, which celebrated its 25th anniversary last month, and remains eclectic, opinionated and supremely unaffected by red-herring trends. However, Chris Wells, who has edited Echoes since 1994, is no nostalgist, and echoes Sutherland's pragmatic attitude to keeping the readers sweet.

"The days when our old contributor Stuart Cosgrove interviewed the IRA for the NME and asked them what their favourite northern soul records were are over. You have to identify the music fan and give them what they want, rather than grouping a whole bunch of cultural things together and expecting them to be interested. The idea of a general music magazine is just too wishy-washy. If you're into football, the arts, literature, how many hours are left in the day to read about music you're not necessarily interested in?"

In this spirit, Emap is taking the brave step of launching a new music title into this rather depressing climate. Kingsize is aimed at "16- to 34-year-old ex-Kerrrang! readers" who are into rock-rap bands such as the currently huge Limp Bizkit. This gives them around three dozen bands to cover, maybe a third of which actually sell in Britain. For those of us who like to be told something about the world that we don't already know, the outlook is bleak. The micro-niche is upon us.

But, just in case things change, if you know of an angry 16-year-old doing extraordinary things in their bedroom with a word processor, tell them there's a chair out here marked "Bangs/Kent" waiting for them.

webTitle: Big Breakfast deal with britart.com

fields.headline: C4 serves up art for breakfast
fields.trailText: 8.30am: C4's ailing Big Breakfast is enlisting the help of online gallery britart.com, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Channel 4's ailing Big Breakfast is enlisting the help of artists such as David Hockney and Andy Warhol in its quest to bolster ratings.

Over the coming months, the walls behind Big Breakfast presenters Paul Tonkinson and Donna Air will feature works by UK artists.

Names will include Patrick Hughes, Billy Childish, Andy Warhol, Peter Blake and Eduardo Paolozzi.

Viewing figures have sunk to a low of 300,000 since Johnny Vaughan and Denise van Outen quit the show in January.

Online art gallery Britart will supply the works, which will change every two weeks.

Viewers can then log on to www.britart.com to buy any artwork they see on the programme.

The company offers a money-back guarantee allowing buyers to try the work purchased on their walls for 14 days.

If they decide they don't like it, they can send it back for a full refund.

Britart signed the deal after a Josie McCoy portrait of EastEnders character Pauline Fowler was shown on the Big Breakfast last week.

It generated 10,000 hits for the website after the show.

"There is a huge amount of talent out there that goes unnoticed.

"For us, the chance to showcase some of the fantastic work from the Britart site on the Big Breakfast was an opportunity not to be missed," said Britart marketing director Richard Murphy.

webTitle: DaimlerChrysler loses trademark case

fields.headline: DaimlerChrysler loses trademark case
fields.trailText: 8.30am: A judge has dismissed DaimlerChrysler's claim a London shop infringes its Mercedes trademark, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
DaimlerChrysler has been granted leave to appeal against a high court decision that a London shop called Merc is not infringing the trademark of its Mercedes-Benz cars.

The clothing and footwear shop on London's Carnaby Street has been trading since 1967 and prides itself on being "a mecca of 60s chic".

It is frequented by rock stars including Liam Gallagher and ex-Stone Roses guitarist Mani.

But DaimlerChrysler claimed, under section 10.3 of the Trademarks Act 1994, that Merc owner Javid Alavi was infringing its registered UK and EC trademarks Mercedes and Mercedes-Benz.

One of the main thrusts of its case was the Merc shop was connected with skinheads, mods and casuals, with whom DaimlerChrysler did not want to be associated.

It was also alleged the Merc website contained links to distasteful skinhead sites, which contained links to sites that were even more unsavoury.

But high court judge Mr Justice Pumfrey dismissed DaimlerChrysler's claims.

He said there was no confusion between the shop and the car's nickname.

Nor, he said, was there any "passing off", a term used to describe a company taking advantage of another's mark for its own benefit.

Mr Justice Pumfrey said: "It is not sufficient to see the word Merc, note that this is the word which one uses to refer to Mercedes cars, see the disagreeable website and register it as disagreeable, if nothing actually rubs off on... DaimlerChrysler."

To make a successful infringement claim, the trademark owner has to show the defendant's use of the mark "takes unfair advantage of, or is detrimental to, the distinctive character or the repute of the trademark".

A spokeswoman for DaimlerChrysler said the company has been granted leave to appeal against the decision.

webTitle: Online adspend 'set to double'

fields.headline: Online adspend 'set to double'
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Research indicates online adspend will more than double this year to £210m, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Online advertising will more than double this year as the number of people with internet access continues to increase, according to research by the media agency Optimedia.

The research suggests advertisers will spend £210m online this year - more than twice the £100m spent in 2000.

It strongly contradicts the more pessimistic estimates being issued by rival forecasters.

Optimedia says the rise will come mainly from traditional advertisers turning to the web for the first time.

"Lots of people are predicting a crisis in internet advertising, but we think that's based on the collapse of the dot.coms - and they are by no means the biggest online advertisers," said Optimedia marketing director Sandra Collins.

"We're seeing year-on-year growth of 300% from our clients and many of our traditional clients such as L'Oreal and MFI are only just starting to dip their toes in the water.

"I think we can expect a lot of growth to come from them."

Optimedia predicts internet adspend will rise to £710m by 2005.

The company says this will be driven by improvements in the quality of internet adverts and a rapid growth in the number of people who use the internet regularly.

Optimedia forecasts internet penetration in the UK will rise from 13.9m web users at the end of last year to 20m by the end of 2001 and 32.5m by the end of 2005.

And, according to the research, more people will access the internet via their TV sets.

TV is expected to become almost as popular as computers for accessing the web.

Even the expected economic downturn is unlikely to leave a serious dent in advertising growth rates, according to Optimedia.

Internet advertising allows companies to track exactly how many people have clicked on to their adverts.

Optimedia believes this accountability will make the web more attractive than traditional media when advertising budgets are squeezed.

webTitle: Barbie to join games market

fields.headline: Barbie to join games market
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Hot on the heels of the Barbie movie come Barbie electronic games, writes Julia Day.
Feb 13: Barbie lands movie role
fields.body:
Hot on the heels of Barbie the movie come Barbie electronic games.

In the UK, Barbie manufacturer Mattel is looking at launching a range of hand-held Barbie-branded electronic games later this year.

Mattel is pursuing a strategy of expanding the toy company's core brands into new product categories and sees Barbie as a prime candidate for expansion.

"We are constantly looking at different sectors and areas to expand the Barbie name in to.

"It is one of the most successful licenses for girls," says a Mattel spokeswoman.

"We are looking at electronic games and may bring some out later this year," she said.

The company has also started to target girls in their teens by launching clothing that is less obviously Barbie-branded.

"There is a move away from pink clothing featuring Barbie's image to more subtle approaches like the letter B on a zip or button and trendier fabrics such as denim," said the spokeswoman.

As part of the brand's rejuvenation, a Barbie straight-to-video movie, Barbie in the Nutcracker, is due for release in October.

The film will be supported with a toy promotion in McDonald's restaurants, a book, eight Nutcracker-themed dolls and sleepwear.

An hour-long television special is under discussion.

In the US, Mattel is embarking on a massive licensing push to launch Barbie-branded cosmetics, toiletries, clothing for teenagers and home furnishings.

Some toiletries and bedlinen are already available in the UK.

In the late 90s, Barbie sales plunged, contributing to the resignation of chief executive Jill Barad last year.

But the company gave the brand a makeover in 2000 and sales have increased by 5% to just over £1bn.

webTitle: Daily Star apology to Geri Halliwell

fields.headline: When sorry's not enough...
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Daily Star's front-page apology to Geri Halliwell may not be enough, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The grovelling full-page apology made to Geri Halliwell on the front page of the Daily Star may not be enough to stop the paper having to pay out five-figure damages to the popstar.

It has emerged that, in addition to the apology - the most prominent ever made in a newspaper - the former Spice Girl will also receive a "five figure" sum in damages.

"We're delighted, because normally newspaper editors would rather be boiled in oil than admit they are wrong," said Jonathan Coad of law firm Schilling and Lom, who acted on behalf of Ms Halliwell.

He is still negotiating the damages with the Star but says he is delighted with the outcome as no newspaper had ever printed a full-page apology on its front page.

But media lawyers branded the splash apology a "worrying" precedent, which could pressure newspapers to turn over their whole front pages to apologies.

The Mail on Sunday published an apology to Brooke Shields in May 1998 on its front page after a reporter wrongly claimed she had been searched for drugs at an airport.

The Sun also published a front-page apology to Sir Elton John after wrongly accusing him of using rent boys.

However, neither tabloids handed over the entire front page.

The apology followed a story on Friday, accompanied by photographs of Ms Halliwell with John Leahy, marketing and creative director at EMI.

A headline above photographs of the pair hugging, read: "So Geri much in love".

Nigel Tait, the managing partner at Peter Carter Ruck & Partners, which specialises in libel, says the apology "is consistent with the Express Group's policy of being kind to superstars.

"It always helps newspapers to have a famous person on the cover.

"It also sends out a message that Mr Desmond wants to be kind to superstars," he said.

Mark Stephens, a partner at law firm Stephens Innocent, said: "Front-page apologies are enormously rare.

"This sets a precedent which is worrying."

Another top media lawyer, who did not wish to be named, said: "One has to ask the question whether this was on the front page because of the relationship between Mr Desmond and the Spice Girls."

The deal was arranged between Schilling & Lom, acting for Geri Halliwell and John Leahy, and lawyers acting for Northern & Shell.

He is still negotiating the damages with the Star but says he is delighted with the outcome as no newspaper had ever printed a full-page apology on its front page. But media lawyers branded the splash apology a "worrying" precedent, which could pressure newspapers to turn over their whole front pages to apologies. The Mail on Sunday published an apology to Brooke Shields in May 1998 on its front page after a reporter wrongly claimed she had been searched for drugs at an airport. The Sun also published a front-page apology to Sir Elton John after wrongly accusing him of using rent boys. However, neither tabloids handed over the entire front page. The apology followed a story on Friday, accompanied by photographs of Ms Halliwell with John Leahy, marketing and creative director at EMI. A headline above photographs of the pair hugging, read: "So Geri much in love". Nigel Tait, the managing partner at Peter Carter Ruck & Partners, which specialises in libel, says the apology "is consistent with the Express Group's policy of being kind to superstars. "It always helps newspapers to have a famous person on the cover. "It also sends out a message that Mr Desmond wants to be kind to superstars," he said. Mark Stephens, a partner at law firm Stephens Innocent, said: "Front-page apologies are enormously rare. "This sets a precedent which is worrying." Another top media lawyer, who did not wish to be named, said: "One has to ask the question whether this was on the front page because of the relationship between Mr Desmond and the Spice Girls." The deal was arranged between Schilling & Lom, acting for Geri Halliwell and John Leahy, and lawyers acting for Northern & Shell.

webTitle: Leader: Sunday People's editor's stand does self-regulation no good

fields.headline: The press and the People
fields.standfirst:
Editor's stand does self-regulation no good

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Newspapers make mistakes, just as hospitals, railway companies and politicians make mistakes. When other people make mistakes, newspapers are often pretty unforgiving, demanding inquiries and resignations.
fields.body:
Newspapers make mistakes, just as hospitals, railway companies and politicians make mistakes. When other people make mistakes, newspapers are often pretty unforgiving, demanding inquiries and resignations. When newspapers make mistakes, all too often there is a wall of silence or a sullen refusal to explain or apologise.

Readers of the Sunday People will have searched in vain for an apology - or even a convincing explanation - for how that paper published forged local authority report forms which purported to show that one of James Bulger's killers had attacked another youth in his secure unit. Last week three judges dismissed the stories as baseless and rejected a last-ditch appeal by James Bulger's father to keep the killers locked up. The main evidence on which the appeal was based was the Sunday People's stories.

It may be that the People has yet to find a satisfactory explanation for its story. It claims to have launched an inquiry into the error. But in the absence of an explanation or apology it launched into a blistering attack on the "misguided, muddled and inexperienced" Lord Woolf and the appeal judges, whom the paper accused of being "desperate, out of touch" and of having brought the entire legal system into disrepute. Its columnist, David Mellor, who once lectured the press on ethical standards, waded in in support, calling the judges "a dictatorship of bewigged fools".

The editor of the People, Neil Wallis, sits not only on the code committee of the Press Complaints Commission, but also on the main body of the PCC. He is supposed to embody all the benefits of self-regulation which were supposedly celebrated by the lavish party thrown by Lord Wakeham the previous week. Mr Wallis would do the cause of self-rgulation better if he displayed a little more openness and humility and a little less aggressive grandstanding in the face of damning evidence of error.

webTitle: dot.coms and dot.gones

fields.headline: It's all over for ZapitOver
fields.trailText: 5.45pm: Rapid-delivery service ZapitOver has folded after failing to find further investment, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Another day, another dot.com demise.

Today it was the turn of ZapitOver, the London-focused rapid-delivery service, which threw in the towel after failing to find further investment.

In a statement on ZapitOver's website, the founders bid farewell to its customers and instigated a clearance sale, offering most items at half price.

"After months of toil in the rapid-delivery market we've finally reached the end.

"We've watched all our competitors go bust and soldiered on but, due to lack of investment, we have to close," said the statement.

The site will eventually close at the end of the month with the loss of 10 jobs.

ZapitOver was the brainchild of Will Sankey, former media planning and buying director of BMP DDB, and Elliot Ronald, a former management consultant from Ernst & Young.

It was originally set up as a Wap service, called WapitOver.

After Wap failed to take off, it became clear it was necessary to take the service onto other channels, such as the web and the telephone.

The name ZapitOver was chosen as a more generic name in December last year.

ZapitOver's reinvention was short-lived, as crucial funding was required to take the business forward.

The demise of competitors Urban Fetch, BagsOfTime.com and Koobuycity did nothing to aid investor confidence in ZapitOver's business model.

This centred on delivering convenience goods in London within the hour.

A spokesman for ZapitOver said: "Not only did the dot.com climate go cold but investor confidence was severely dented after what happened to our competitors."

To survive for another six months, the site was asking for just £250,000.

Another problem was demand for such a latent service.

ZapitOver needed at least 100 deliveries a day to break even but only managed to average around 40 a day.

ZapitOver was set up at the end of August last year as a joint venture between 86 Ltd, a digital consultancy, and Deliverance, an existing London-based food delivery service.

It is thought ZapitOver's assets, such as its technology platform and server, will now be bought up by 86 Ltd.

webTitle: Opec warns of supply cuts

fields.headline: Opec warns of supply cuts
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Opec leaders warned yesterday that the oil exporters' cartel was poised to agree more supply cuts at its next meeting, adding to the turmoil in a market already alarmed by the weekend air strikes on Iraq.
fields.body:
Opec leaders warned yesterday that the oil exporters' cartel was poised to agree more supply cuts at its next meeting, adding to the turmoil in a market already alarmed by the weekend air strikes on Iraq.

The cartel's secretary general, Ali Rodriguez said the supply restrictions could be up to a million barrels a day "in the worst case scenario".

North sea oil prices surged above $27(£18) a barrel, closing up 42 cents at $27.32 a barrel, as the markets digested Mr Rodriguez's comments and the impact of the US and British strikes.

"Basically we're up on the back of the Iraqi bombings," said one London trader at the International Petroleum Exchange (IPE). "At the moment there is not really that much to worry about, but obviously if it escalates out there we'll have to relook at that."

The market's big worry is that the raid could provoke a regional oil embargo but there seems little danger so far of a coordinated response from the Arab states.

"While we would argue that the actual impact on oil supplies will be minimal, the news is certainly going to have unsettled the markets," said Lawrence Eagles, commodities expert with the GNI brokerage.

But hawks within the oil producers' cartel may find it easier to make the case for deep cuts at their next meeting on March 16th. Opec, which controls 40% of the 77m barrels of oil used each day, has a target price bank of $22-28 per barrel for a basket of its crudes.

Its reference price stood at $24.90 on Friday according to the Opec secretariat, but the cartel fears slowing demand as the northern hemisphere winter ends could push prices lower.

Asked whether Opec had already decided to announce a further reduction in output next month, Mr Rodriguez replied: "Not yet, but in any case there is an inclination, almost a conviction, that we have to cut production because normally in the second quarter there is a sharp drop in demand and, of course, prices."

Mr Rodriguez said global oil demand normally falls by 2m barrels per day from March to June, although Opec's supply cut of 1.5m barrels per day in February meant the next cut would be smaller.

On the foreign exchange markets, the euro was in the ascendent yesterday, rising as far as 92.35 cents at one point, nearly 1% up on the day. Forecasts from the International Monetary Fund over the weekend confirming that Eurozone growth should outstrip the US this year sharpened the market's appetite for the single currency.

"People are getting unnerved about the US economy and are still very concerned about the outlook in Japan," said David Bloom, currency strategist at HSBC Markets in London. "Given the ECB seems fairly confident about growth, the euro is benefiting and should continue to go up."

The euro's rally is expected to continue on the back of growing confidence in the strength of the eurozone economies. Such expectations were reinforced after the G7 said on Saturday that growth prospects in the single currency region were favourable due to strong domestic demand, a point repeated yesterday by the head of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet.

webTitle: Allies ready to ease Iraq sanctions

fields.headline: Allies ready to ease Iraq sanctions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Britain and the US have agreed to rethink their policy towards Iraq in the face of mounting hostility from the Arab world inflamed by last Friday's air strikes, Whitehall officials said yesterday.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor  and Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
Britain and the US have agreed to rethink their policy towards Iraq in the face of mounting hostility from the Arab world inflamed by last Friday's air strikes, Whitehall officials said yesterday.

Growing opposition among Nato allies, including France and Germany, to the existing attempts by Washington and London to contain Saddam Hussein has persuaded the British government that a different approach may be needed. Doubts at home have also contributed to a reassessment of the hardline policy

To try to turn foreign and domestic opinion around, ministers are actively considering a dual track strategy.

They are looking at plans for "smart" sanctions combined with a new propaganda drive highlighting the repression carried out by the Iraqi regime and insisting that its people's suffering - including infant deaths - is of the dictatorship's making.

Even so, the government went on yesterday strongly defending last Friday's air strikes against Iraqi radar installations, and the no-fly zones imposed on Iraq by Britain and the US after the 1990-91 Gulf war. These, officials still say, will be abandoned only if President Saddam allows in United Nations weapons inspectors.

Whitehall officials say the issue of the zones could be part of an overall agreement in which Baghdad made concessions on inspections.

The framework of a new sanctions policy was discussed by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, during talks in Washington last week with the US secretary of state, Colin Powell. Yesterday Mr Cook held a special meeting about Iraq with his Foreign Office ministers and their senior advisers.

General Powell is about to embark on a tour of Middle Eastern countries, including Syria, which recently opened a new oil pipeline with Iraq. Sanctions against Iraq are increasingly being flouted, and smuggling of goods and petroleum is rife.

The plans for "smart" sanctions would concentrate on arms control - specifically Saddam Hussein's nuclear, chemical, and biological, weapons programme - and the finances and freedom of movement of leading members of his regime. Imports for rebuilding Iraq's infrastructure and oil industry would be allowed.

Such measures, London and Washington believe, would not be opposed by Iraq's Arab neighbours or by members of the UN security council.

The British government is also planning to "refocus the public debate", as one official put it yesterday, pointing to the executions and other brutal practices used by Baghdad against critics and opponents. This repression, it argues, would be worse without the no-fly zones.

Foreign Office spokesmen yesterday issued a sort of balance sheet yesterday noting that since sanctions were imposed Iraq had not used chemical weapons or invaded its neighbours. Blaming sanctions for the sufferings of the Iraqi people was "not credible", the paper declared. Iraq was exporting food and medicine to other countries.

It said UN weapons inspectors had been unable to account for 4,000 tonnes of chemicals used to make weapons, and some 31,000 chemical weapons munitions.

The air strikes by American and British planes on Iraqi air defence installations were a "proportionate response in self defence", the defence minister, Baroness Symons, told the Lords yesterday. Ministers had "no choice but to act to protect" allied aircrew.

The bombings were in response to increasing attempts by Iraq to shoot down British and US aircraft, she said. Since January 1999, there had been over 1,200 attempts to attack them with surface-to-air missiles and anti-aircraft artillery. Last month had seen more of these than the whole of 2000.

She said the no-fly zones had served a "vital humanitarian purpose" in limiting Saddam Hussein's ability to repress the Shi'ites in the south and the Kurds in the north.

Though the zones and the bombings are not specifically sanctioned by any UN security council resolutions, she described the patrols as "justified in international law as a legitimate response to prevent a grave humanitarian crisis".

The French foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, disagreed, saying there was no basis in international law for the attacks.

France, which has withdrawn from aerial patrols of the no-fly zones, was not consulted before Friday's strikes, Mr Védrine. His strongly worded condemnation said France wanted an end to economic sanctions against Iraq.

Meanwhile, in a stretch of desert in southern Israel, Patriot anti-missile missiles will be launched in the course of a five-day US-Israeli military exercise that began yesterday. But the Israeli army said the exercise was planned more than a year ago and was unrelated to the raids on Iraq.

webTitle: Mandelson gives £10,000 to campaign to bring action over Omagh bombing

fields.headline: Mandelson gives £10,000 to campaign to bring action over Omagh bombing
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson has donated £10,000 to a campaign to sue the alleged perpetrators of the Omagh bombing which killed 29 people in 1998, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson has donated £10,000 to a campaign to sue the alleged perpetrators of the Omagh bombing which killed 29 people in 1998, it emerged yesterday.

Relatives of the victims of the bombing, who are hoping to mount a civil action against the alleged bombers, are to receive the fees Mr Mandelson was paid for newspaper articles he has written about his fall from power last month.

The bulk of the money, which will be given to a fighting fund run by the Daily Mail, is believed to come from a lengthy piece the former Northern Ireland secretary wrote for the Sunday Times four days after his resignation. Mr Mandelson declared at the end of the article, in which he first pledged to clear his name, that he would pay his fee "to the campaign to prosecute the Omagh bombers".

Labour MPs had mixed reactions last night to the announcement that he would be handing over £10,000. One leftwing backbencher dismissed the donation as an attempt by Mr Mandelson to win favour with the rightwing press as he tries to clear his name.

"This is a meretricious gesture," the MP said. "It does not surprise me - that man is appalling."

However, Kevin McNamara, Labour's former Northern Ireland spokesman, thought there was nothing wrong with the donation. "People are entitled to bring civil actions," he said. "If Mr Mandelson wants to use his money in that way, that is fine. If he has access to private information on this matter, then this may be more questionable."

Relatives of the Omagh bombing victims insisted that Mr Mandelson's concern was genuine. They dismissed suggestions that he was getting involved merely to rejuvenate his political career. A total of 29 people died, including a woman pregnant with twins, when Real IRA bombers attacked the County Tyrone town on August 15 1998

"We had a private meeting with Mr Mandelson last autumn, long before there was any hint he would have to resign. He broke down in tears and said he would do anything he could to help," said Michael Gallagher, whose 21-year-old son Adrian died in the blast.

"We were moved to see someone we considered a hard-nosed politician get so emotional, so we don't see this as a cynical ploy.

"Ironically, he probably could not have supported our campaign when he was secretary of state because he could not have been seen to say the RUC was not capable of bring these people to justice."

Another past secretary of state, the Tory Sir Patrick Mayhew, is also backing the campaign. Relatives said they were keen to get support from all parties, at Westminster and in the Republic of Ireland.

Four men were named as suspects in a controversial BBC Panorama programme, shown last October, which claimed the police had strong circumstantial evidence, regarding mobile phones, which linked some of them to the Omagh area when the car bomb was abandoned there.

A man on remand in the Republic in connection with the attack has already cited contempt of court in connection with the programme.

Mr Mandelson last night called for continuing pressure to be brought to bear on the Real IRA, which broke away from the Provisionals after the 1997 ceasefire. "The Real IRA are the last remaining obstacle to a successful peace process in Northern Ireland," he said. "I am convinced that keeping the spotlight on the bombers who are well known to the police, and maintaining the political pressure on that organisation will assist the police and help deter the Real IRA."

Some of the Omagh relatives want a number of people to be forced to account for their movements on the day of the bombing. It is unclear how many suspects could be involved in a civil case, but it requires a lesser burden of proof than a criminal trial. The relatives need to raise £1m by August to beat the three-year time limit on a civil action.

webTitle: Cars cost 'up to double in Britain'

fields.headline: Cars cost 'up to double in Britain'
fields.standfirst:
European commission report on prices undermines claims that vehicles are becoming cheaper
Special report: Britain's car industry
fields.trailText: European commission report on prices undermines claims that vehicles are becoming cheaper.
fields.body:
British car buyers continue to pay up to twice as much as their continental counterparts for the same vehicles despite industry claims to have substantially cut retail prices in the past six months.

In a damning assessment of Britain's retail car market, the European commission found that Britain remains the most expensive country in Europe to buy a new car by a huge margin for almost all the 71 models it examined.

This comes despite a series of high profile campaigns from the government, the Consumers' Association and the competition commission to bring down prices and is certain to pile further pressure on the car industry to fulfill its promises.

The report revealed for example that a new Mazda 323 cost £11,106 before tax last November in Britain compared to a pre-tax price of £5,307 in Denmark or £6,659 in the Netherlands. That means that the pre-tax price in Britain was 99.3% more than in Denmark.

Brussels found gaping price disparities right across the board for a range of popular models.

The Renault Laguna at £11,626 was almost 96% dearer in Britain than in Denmark and could be bought for £8,335 in Spain or for £6,114 in Finland. A Nissan Almera was priced at £5,787 in Spain compared to almost £9,000 in Britain.

Brussels noted that five manufacturers - Citroen, Mercedes-Benz, Vauxhall, Volvo and Volkswagen - have reduced their British prices by between 5% and 7% since last May, but this had made only a small impact on price differences.

"The price level in the United Kingdom, where there is no extra tax on car purchase, remains very high, despite the slight depreciation of the British pound and the fact that prices in euros for 23 models sold in the UK have diminished by more than 10 percentage points," the commission said in a statement.

It noted that many British consumers continue to buy their cars on the continent because of the big price gap but said that it still received "many complaints" from British bargain hunters who ran into all kinds of problems when attempting to purchase cars abroad.

Unreasonable supplements for right hand drive models and long delivery times were the two most common complaints.

The commission said research had shown that right-hand drive supplements were generally lower for Japanese manufacturers but highest for vehicles produced by the VW group which also includes Audi and Seat. Countries where car prices are lowest, it said, are Finland, Spain, the Netherlands and Denmark.

The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders argued yesterday that varying tax regimes throughout the EU were the main reason for price disparities even though the report concentrated on pre-tax prices only.

"The motor industry is actively seeking price harmonisation across the EU," said the chief executive Christopher Macgowan. "Although prices are falling in the UK, widely-varying taxation systems and the high rate of sterling continue to thwart our goal."

 Land Rover yesterday announced that it was cutting the price of all new Range Rovers by £3,000 because customers were importing them more cheaply from continental Europe.

The cheapest Range Rover, the County version, will now cost £36,995 and the top of the range Vogue 4.6 version will be priced at £49,995.
