webTitle: Law: Fertility treatment and the law

fields.headline: Parenthood postponed
fields.standfirst: How can an infertile man can be the legal father of a child yet be prevented from seeing her?  Angelique Chrisafis  reports on the  court ruling that widens the IVF debate
fields.trailText: How can an infertile man can be the legal father of a child yet be prevented from seeing her? Angelique Chrisafis reports on the court ruling that widens the IVF debate.
fields.body:
Tucked inside Jon's wallet is a blurred photograph of a baby girl in a strawberry print dress and a sun hat. She has round cheeks and big eyes. "Look at the likeness," Jon says. "She's got my eyes and my colouring, my smile, my face shape. Everyone says it. She looks just like me."

This is surprising because Jon is infertile. The child carries none of his genes. Although he takes the photograph everywhere, and has a copy framed beside his bed, he has never seen Chloe, now aged one. He wasn't present at the moment of conception, nor at the birth. He is not named on her birth certificate.

Jon is Chloe's legal father because two years ago he signed a consent form for him and his girlfriend at the time to try for a baby using anonymous donor sperm and in-vitro fertilisation. Jon had suffered testicular cancer and his girlfriend, Debbie, needed help to conceive. When several stressful attempts at IVF failed, the couple separated. But the fertilised eggs remained on ice.

Debbie, now with a new partner, went back to the hospital and had them implanted. She did not inform the hospital that her partner was different. She went about having the baby and setting up home with her new partner. She did not want Jon to see the baby or have any details about her.

Under the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act, if a couple are unmarried, the man who signs the consent form for infertility treatment is the father "for all purposes". In the first case of its kind in Britain, Jon went to the high court and the court of appeal in an attempt to gain access to Chloe and to be given parental responsibility for the child he considered his daughter "beyond a shadow of a doubt".

He set a precedent as the first man to be confirmed by the courts as the father of an IVF and donor-sperm baby because of his signature on a form. Last week, the court of appeal refused Jon's application to challenge a high court ruling that he should not meet Chloe face to face for two years, and that his application for a share in parental responsibility should be postponed.

Jon had been granted indirect contact, which meant he could send Chloe a "modest" present at Christmas and birthdays, an Easter egg and card in April and one letter during the summer. In return, he would receive two photographs of Chloe a year. But meeting her face to face was unlikely to be considered before she was three.

The high court ruled, however, that if Jon maintained the commitment he had shown, he was likely to gain parental responsibility in the future. Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss said in the court of appeal last week that "unusual circumstances" surrounded the case; that Debbie had been found "mentally and emotionally fragile", and was unable to cope with any direct contact between her ex-boyfriend and her daughter.

The judge expressed concern that "the child will have to face aspects of her background that most children do not have to face". She and two other judges upheld Judge Mark Hedley's original ruling that "at some stage this child has to come to terms with the fact that she has a biological male progenitor of whom she can know nothing, a legal father with whom she has no contact, and quite likely, a male figure who is acting as her father and is the only one she has known as such. What effect this will all have can only be a matter of speculation."

Judge Hedley hoped it might serve to widen the debate on IVF treatment and parents' rights. Jon, 38, a quiet, smartly dressed man, is now preparing to wait patiently for two years to meet his daughter.

"Chloe is my daughter totally and completely," he says. "As a man, when you choose to have a child by anonymous donor, they check your height, build, blood group, eye colour and appearance to match the donor with the person. So when the child is born it will have the characteristics of both the father and the mother. It will look like both. A child is not a product of one person, but of two.

"I wasn't surprised by the court of appeal's decision. I hoped parental responsibility would be given, but I've learnt to expect nothing and to be patient. That way you don't get disappointed. I am sad that I will miss out on all the firsts - teething and steps. But Chloe is our child for life and I just have to prepare for the input I will have in the future. I never expected media attention from the case, nor did I think I was a champion of father's rights."

Jon considers himself to be a normal father, doing his best to gain contact and provide some input into his daughter's life. "It's a let-down that generally fathers are not as important to the courts as mothers. If I have set a precedent for future fathers I am pleased. But I have never spoken out as part of a legal crusade. I have simply loved Chloe from the moment I heard she had been born. And I save all the press cuttings and record all the television coverage so that when Chloe grows up, she can see how much I love her."

Jon says he did not go to the court of appeal to rush the direct contact, or to cause unnecessary strain on Chloe's mother. "I appealed because I wanted to stop Chloe losing the father she deserves. I wanted parental responsibility so I could ask Chloe's doctor how she is, and so I could ask her playschool how she is doing, just like a normal dad."

Jon's flat is full of baby bangles, jewellery and birth plaques which he cannot properly engrave because he doesn't know the details of Chloe's birth. He cannot ask Chloe's mother for details in case it is construed as harassment, and he does not want to pressure her.

He has made Chloe a photo album, but for now it has only two pictures in it. His friends and extended family all carry her picture in their own wallets. "I am an only child," he says. "My father died before I can remember. I know the importance of having two parents who love you."

Chloe's mother has told Jon her clothes size, so his presents will fit. After his last present, she wrote back a polite letter telling him how Chloe was developing and what television programmes she liked. Jon says: "We can't go on for the next 10 or 15 years without talking. We have to make decisions about Chloe together."

Apart from court appearances, Jon has not seen Chloe's mother for a year and a half. Seven months after their break-up, he had a hunch she was pregnant. She was, and he went round, talked to her, saw the scan photo and felt the bump. It was obvious she had someone else in her life, and they have not spoken at length since. "All through the traumas of IVF, we always said that I would be the father, no matter what."

Jon and Debbie met at Liverpool pier head in 1988. After their first meeting, he felt it was something special. He came away with a host of details about her. They were friends for six months, before going out for dinner one Valentine's Day, which sparked a six-year relationship before they decided to start a family. They were both in their 30s, with their own homes.

"I was diagnosed with cancer and we realised we were unable to have children. It was like fate had brought us together, because without each other we would not have been able to have the treatment. All I want to do now is open up the lines of communication so we can bring up our daughter sensibly. It is not a battle, or a fight. I am very calm about the process."

Even so, he finds himself staring forlornly when he sees a man wheeling a pushchair in the street. At 38, has he thought about starting his own family? "No, I'm over the hill now. But why would I need to? I have Chloe. Sometimes I ask myself how much more can I take, then I think of my daughter and it makes everything a lot easier. I have my family in sight."

webTitle: Aide saved my life, MP in samurai attack tells court

fields.headline: Aide saved my life, MP in samurai attack tells court
fields.trailText: An MP whose aide was killed in a frenzied samurai sword attack yesterday told a court about the assault and said the victim was "the bravest man I have ever known".
fields.body:
An MP whose aide was killed in a frenzied samurai sword attack yesterday told a court about the assault and said the victim was "the bravest man I have ever known".

Nigel Jones, 52, the Liberal Democrat MP for Cheltenham, was injured, and his assistant, the Gloucestershire county councillor Andrew Pennington, was killed in the attack. Mr Jones told the court that Mr Pennington, 39, had saved his life.

Robert Ashman, 50, a father of two from Cheltenham, has been charged with murdering Mr Pennington and attempting to murder Mr Jones during a surgery in their offices in the town. But he will not face trial after a jury found him mentally unfit last week.

The hearing at Bristol crown court yesterday was to determine whether he carried out the alleged assault.

Mr Jones described his battle for life as he wrestled with Ashman to stop him slicing into him with the sword. The MP said: "When the end of the sword got within three inches my reflexes took over and I turned sharply. I grabbed the blade of the sword as he lunged at me. My arm deflected the blade. I managed to catch it and fell on my front on to the sofa with him on top. The sword was under my body with the blade pressed against my hands."

Mr Jones said he felt the breath being squeezed out of him as Ashman pressed on to him wrenching the sword around in his hands. He told how the tendons of his hands were "filleted". He later needed 57 stitches.

The MP said that although he lost sight of the other office staff, he managed to escape when Mr Pennington smashed something on Ashman's head.

He said: "I heard him say: 'Go, Nigel'. I looked up and saw the open door and made for it as quickly as I could. Mr Pennington was alive when I left but he chose to stay to try to get the defendant off me.

"It was the bravest act I have ever experienced and he saved my life. He is the bravest man I have ever known."

Ashman was arrested outside the surgery, the court heard. He was carrying the sword and it was dripping with blood, prosecutor Paul Garlick said.

Mr Jones told the court that Ashman visited his constituency surgeries up to 100 times after he was first elected in 1992. On the day of the attack, Ashman was anxious because the inland revenue was demanding cash he owed.

Mr Jones said Ashman brought in a letter he had drafted for the MP to transfer to headed notepaper. The politician said his constituent refused to sit down throughout the meeting and eventually said: "I am going to do this thing," before launching his assault. The trial continues.

Press Association

webTitle: Grim forecast, warns climate report

fields.headline: Grim forecast, warns climate report
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Impacts of climate change will be far worse than previously thought, 700 scientists say in a report published yesterday.
fields.byline: Paul Brown  and  Peter Capella  in Geneva
fields.body:
Impacts of climate change will be far worse than previously thought and beyond the capacity of mankind to adapt unless greenhouse gas emissions are cut substantially, 700 scientists say in a report published yesterday.

Loss of food crops, disappearance of fisheries, melting of glaciers which provide millions of people with summer water supply, and a rise in sea levels will cause massive economic disruption and migration, it says.

The Arctic, which is already known to be suffering ice loss, could be completely ice-free in summer and the melting giant icecap on Greenland may cause faster sea level rise than previously thought.

Africa will be worst hit, forcing people off the land in ever greater numbers, and creating the possibility of millions of people migrating to survive. Europe, where rainfall will be plentiful - so much so that it will cause regular flooding of the type seen this winter in Britain - will increasingly be seen as the promised land for people in Africa and the Middle East.

The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change report is intended to guide politicians on problems they face as temperatures rise. Yesterday's assessments mean the world is heading for disasters on an unprecedented scale.

"Climate change, amongst other issues, threatens basic human needs of food clean water and a healthy environment," said Robert Watson, co-chairman of the report.

James MacCarthy, the second co-chairman, said some some temperate countries might gain because of increased crops and faster tree growth, but others would lose.

Scientists have documented links between climate change and impacts in over 420 habitats. Already alpine plants in Europe are moving between three and 12ft higher each decade.

Africa was "highly vulnerable", with climate change affecting water resources and food production, expanding deserts and causing more frequent outbreaks of diseases such as cholera. Glaciers in the mountain ranges of tropical regions were also threatened.

Himalayan glaciers, for example, are the main source of water for the Ganges and Indus on which 500m people depend. If they disappear, so does the summer water supply. John Prescott, deputy prime minister, who took part in the failed climate talks at the Hague last November, said every effort must be made to restart the negotiations and begin cutting greenhouse gas emissions.

"The new report shows that we risk major irreversible changes unless we significantly cut emissions of greenhouse gases," he said.

"How much more evidence do we need before governments take real action to tackle climate change?" asked Russell Marsh, WWF climate change campaigner. "The UK government should take a lead at the G8 summit and use its special relationship with the US to secure their participation in solutions to the problem of climate change."

webTitle: Tories promise extra cash for under-fives

fields.headline: Tories promise extra cash for under-fives
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo yesterday took the pre-election battle over tax to Gordon Brown's home turf when he pledged an extra £200 a year for parents of children under the age of five.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo yesterday took the pre-election battle over tax to Gordon Brown's home turf when he pledged an extra £200 a year for parents of children under the age of five.

In a daring attempt to steal the chancellor's thunder, Mr Portillo promised to set aside an extra £400m to boost Labour's cherished children's tax credit which comes into force in April.

Under his plan, families with a child under the age of five will receive an additional tax break of £200 a year, which works out at just under £4 a week. The pledge will stand even if the chancellor increases the credit's starting rate in the Budget from £442 a year to £520, as proposed by the Treasury.

"Gordon Brown has arranged that a couple each earning £30,000 will receive the credit but a couple with a smaller joint income, with one earner receiving just over £40,000 will receive no tax credit," he said.

The announcement by the shadow chancellor was the latest in a series of tax concessions unveiled by the Tories in the past few weeks.

Central office hopes to appeal to floating voters by targeting tax cuts at middle income earners.

Mr Portillo has pledged to introduce £8bn worth of tax cuts in the run-up to the general election, which will be paid for by cuts in public services.

webTitle: Winter gardens and springlike hopes for city's future

fields.headline: Winter gardens and springlike hopes for city's future
fields.trailText: One of the the biggest urban greenhouses to be built in Britain is to span part of the centre of Sheffield by the end of the year, as part of the first winter gardens to be commissioned for more than 100 years.
fields.body:
One of the the biggest urban greenhouses to be built in Britain is to span part of the centre of Sheffield by the end of the year, as part of the first winter gardens to be commissioned for more than 100 years.

Filled with sago palms, bamboo and - the city council hopes - tourists, the heated glass arcades form the heart of a £120m regeneration scheme unveiled yesterday.

"This is an urban renaissance with people at its heart," said the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, launching the Sheffield Masterplan. "It is not just a list of projects. It is about a commitment to regaining Sheffield's status as one of Europe's leading cities."

Buoyed up by the Boeing aircraft company's new research partnership with Sheffield university, and by poaching Alison Nimmo, the woman who led Manchester's post-IRA bomb rebuilding, as the scheme's director, the city is the main pilot for the government's new concept of urban regeneration companies. Headed by Sir Peter Middleton, the Sheffield-born chairman of Barclays bank, a seven-year partnership between the city council and local business is backing the almost complete transformation of the Victorian centre.

New hotels, offices and galleries linked to the Tate and the Victoria and Albert museum form the commercial spine of the scheme. But its heart is an uncomplicated determination to make the once-dirty central streets a pleasant place. Praising the completed first phase, a fountain garden and cultural square bounded by Sheffield's two theatres, Mr Prescott remembered a similar unlikely oasis from his past.

"When I was a boy growing up in Rotherham, we had a place in the town centre known as Sunshine Corner, where people used to go," he said. On the same lines, parts of the new £15m Millennium Galleries in Sheffield, flanking the winter gardens site, will be given over to concerts and events, alongside John Ruskin's personal art collection, donated to the city on the writer's death, and visiting exhibitions.

Ms Nimmo, whose work in Manchester is given much of the credit for triggering the city's recent revival, said that "celebrating the public realm" was crucial to the Sheffield plan.

Although the regeneration company, Sheffield One, is not pinning its hopes on the winter gardens' 70ft high gothic arches, or any other single project, high quality squares, seats, plants and sculpture are common to all its planning proposals.

The architects of the Millennium Galleries worked on Lord's cricket ground's celebrated "spacepod" press stand and the new parliamentary building at Westminster.

The galleries' formal link with the V&A forms the London museum's first regional out-station and the building has also been chosen to host the National Portrait Gallery's BP portrait award exhibition in the autumn.

webTitle: Lord Cranborne gives lukewarm praise to Hague

fields.headline: Sacked peer's lukewarm praise
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague and his shadow cabinet suffered a blow yesterday when the former Conservative leader in the Lords accused them of "lacking gravitas".
fields.body:
William Hague and his shadow cabinet suffered a blow yesterday when the former Conservative leader in the Lords accused them of "lacking gravitas".

In an interview in which he described his own political judgment as being "better than theirs", Lord Cranborne - the Opposition leader in the upper chamber until two years ago - said Mr Hague should remain party leader if the Tories lose the next election as anticipated but offered only him only lukewarm support.

While insisting the Tory leader "would make an infinitely better prime minister than Mr Blair", the hereditary peer admitted he supported Mr Hague because he was the best option.

"I must confess I don't immediately see among the [other] candidates who I would prefer," he said of Mr Hague's shadow cabinet colleagues.

Lord Cranborne, who was sacked in December 1998 after Mr Hague took exception to his unauthorised backstairs dealing with Labour over the abolition of hereditary voting rights, said he did not have "the faintest idea" how the Tories would fare in the election, widely anticipated for May 3.

"The opinion polls aren't very encouraging and everybody's feeling pretty prosperous still, and to a marked degree elections are about economic issues," he said.

He maintained Mr Hague was becoming more popular - despite opinion poll evidence to the contrary - and continued: "Even if William Hague lost by 100 seats I think I'd want to keep him on. I don't think it's a good idea to change your leader all the time and I think you ought to give him a further crack at it."

After admitting to being "disobliging about William Hague" in the past, Lord Cranborne added: "If he does lose next time, I would very much like to see him give the shadow cabinet a bit more to do.

"He has a very buttoned up leadership style which is very difficult to change... perhaps one of the things he should do is to become a little more... forthcoming."

webTitle: UK at bottom of class in foreign languages

fields.headline: UK at bottom of class in foreign languages
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: It's official: Britons' command of languages other than their own is the worst in Europe.
fields.body:
It has long been suspected but now it's official: Britons' command of languages other than their own is the worst in Europe by a considerable margin. In contrast, more than half of continental Europeans can speak at least one foreign language and sometimes even two.

The report, entitled Europeans and Languages, reveals that 66% of the British population have absolutely no knowledge of any language other than English. This was despite the fact that some 74% of Britons polled said that they thought learning a foreign language was useful.

Some 41% of continental Europeans claim to be able to speak English.

Only 2% of those from Luxembourg owned up to being totally ignorant of any other foreign language while the overwhelming majority boasted that they could speak three languages - and sometimes even four.

More than 16,000 people were polled in December last year of whom at least 1,300 were based in the UK. The survey was released yesterday to publicise the launch of the European Year of Languages 2001 - a joint initiative by the European commission and the Council of Europe - to promote language skills.

The fact that Britain, in effect, comes bottom in the survey is likely to embarrass the government which is keen to be seen as the champion of higher educational standards. But the fact remains that applications to study foreign languages at universities in the UK have fallen dramatically in recent years in favour of subjects such as media studies and sports science.

Only slightly better informed than the British were the Portuguese, where 56% of those polled said they knew only their native language. In Spain that figure was 53% and in France it was 51%.

Unsurprisingly, perhaps, the Dutch and the Scandinavians were confirmed as being some of the brightest stars in the class; the report says that almost 80% of Swedish, Danish and Dutch people can speak English.

French is easily the most widely known foreign language among the British with 22% of those polled claiming some knowledge of the language of love. German comes next at almost 10% followed by Spanish at 6% and and then Italian which languishes at just 1.8%.

One reason for Britons' atrocious foreign language skills could be the lack of places to learn another language since only 30% of those polled in the UK said that provision of language courses in their area was good.

Despite their own self-confessed ignorance, almost a quarter of those polled in the UK argued that everyone should have two foreign languages at their disposal. Some 70% of respondents in the UK thought, however, that everyone else in Europe should be able to speak English.

Viviane Reding, the commissioner responsible for education across Europe, said last night: "Every citizen of Europe has the right to set himself up in another member state where he can work and study, but to fully take advantage of this opportunity knowledge of the host country's foreign language is essential."

She added: "On a personal level learning another language opens the mind and teaches tolerance - two essential qualities for living in harmony.

"By learning a language, any language, we come closer to a foreign culture and learn to know and appreciate each other and to accept our differences.

"It is the key to building a European identity far removed from the cliches of intolerance and racism."

webTitle: Healthcare firm with a low profile

fields.headline: Healthcare firm with a low profile
fields.trailText: A senior executive from SSL's Japanese arm recently remarked that the firm's Cheshire head office seemed sleepy for the nerve centre of a multinational company.
fields.body:
A senior executive from SSL's Japanese arm recently remarked that the firm's Cheshire head office seemed sleepy for the nerve centre of a multinational company.

"I go over there for seminars," he said. "You look out of the window and see cows and sheep grazing."

SSL's headquarters is Toft Hall, a stately home which was used as a prison camp during the second world war.

It is easy to overlook the fact that SSL is one of the biggest healthcare companies in the world, with a sprawling portfolio of brands including Scholl footwear, Durex condoms, Marigold gloves and Deep Heat. It employs more than 7,000 people worldwide, with sales of more than £700m.

The business was created through two mergers - a combination of Seton and Scholl in 1998 created a world leader in healthcare for older people. Outgoing chief executive Iain Cater always maintained that this was a growing market.

The company agreed a tie-up in 1999 with London International, the struggling maker of Durex condoms, to form a £1.4bn corporation.

Despite its size, SSL has been resolutely low profile. Mr Cater was rarely seen in the City and resisted the idea of moving to London. He once joked that the firm had the ideal kit for a good night out - a packet of condoms and a hangover cure.

Interest in the firm has tended to concentrate on Durex condoms. Its peripheral businesses include Sondico - Britain's leading maker of goalkeepers' gloves, endorsed by the likes of David James and David Seaman.

Andrew Clark

webTitle: Drug firms 'drag feet' over BSE

fields.headline: Drug firms 'drag feet' over BSE
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Drug manufacturers of nearly a third of the medicines authorised or being considered for sale in Britain have failed to provide the government with proof they are meeting rules designed to cut the risk of patients catching the human form of BSE, two months after a deadline for providing the information.
fields.body:
Drug manufacturers of nearly a third of the medicines authorised or being considered for sale in Britain have failed to provide the government with proof they are meeting rules designed to cut the risk of patients catching the human form of BSE, two months after a deadline for providing the information.

The medicines control agency said that up to the beginning of February, companies had only sent details about the manufacturing processes and ingredients for 12,000 of 17,500 licensed products.

The agency had requested the information by December 1 so that it could make its own checks that manufacturers were obeying all the rules before new European laws take effect next month. It was acutely embarrassed last autumn when it had to order the withdrawal of an oral polio vaccine developed using material from British cows, 14 years after BSE was first discovered in cattle in 1986.

Guidelines have been in place since 1989 to ban use of bovine sources from BSE-infected countries in injected vaccines, and oral medicines were meant to follow in the same spirit, even though the government still says the risk of infection through medicines is incalculably small.

Comprehensive European legislation was drawn up in 1999, and legally drug companies have until March 1 to comply. But the government told companies in July last year of its own December deadline. The inquiry team into the BSE catastrophe led by Lord Phillips of Matravers, now master of the rolls, was worried that civil servants in charge of the safety of medicines had not been sufficiently rigorous in ensuring that they did not represent a danger to humans.

Frances Hall, of the Human BSE Foundation, representing families of the 94 British victims of variant CJD, said: "The companies do seem to be dragging their feet. It has not been proved that some cases (of vCJD) came from injections. I still have my suspicions that some of them did. People have been tardy getting on top of this."

The Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry said: "The industry was way ahead of everyone else in making sure everything was properly in place. We are talking about thousands of medicines, and companies have had to go back years. It was a huge job and was never going to be done overnight. We have worked extremely hard to get the information right, on time."

Under the new measures, the European commission wanted information about all medicines, including those that did not include animal material in their manufacture.

Safety officials are also about to embark on another review of how vaccines were made as far back as the 1970s. They have already checked back to 1980, but the Phillips inquiry suggested that the scale of cattle disease may have been silently growing unnoticed up to 15 years before it was finally recognised in late 1986.

webTitle: '£500,000 payoff' for Birt ally

fields.headline: '£500,000 payoff' for Birt ally
fields.trailText: One of the closest allies of the BBC's former director general Lord Birt is leaving the corporation seven years before she was due to retire, with an estimated £500,000 payoff.
fields.body:
One of the closest allies of the BBC's former director general Lord Birt is leaving the corporation seven years before she was due to retire, with an estimated £500,000 payoff.

Margaret Salmon, 53, the chief executive of the BBC's resources division, has agreed a substantial early retirement package.

Her departure follows the recent exit of two other Birt lieutenants: the head of policy, Patricia Hodgson, who left last year to lead the independent television commission, and the director of news, Tony Hall, who is joining the Royal Opera House as chief executive.

The size of the Ms Salmon's deal has caused ripples, but the BBC refused to discuss the payoff until it is made public in its annual financial statement later this year. However, a source with knowledge of similar BBC deals said it would be worth up to £500,000.

In her previous position as Lord Birt's personnel chief, she was responsible for implementing some of his most unpopular policies, including "producer choice", which forced production staff to pay far closer attention to their budgets.

Her appointment in 1999 to lead the BBC's resources division was widely interpreted as a reward for her loyalty to Lord Birt. But despite her position, she won the support of the unions.

In the role, Ms Salmon took charge of the BBC's production facilities such as studios and outside broadcast units. In the past year, Lord Birt's successor, Greg Dyke, has presided over a shake-up of the division, which included joint ventures with the private sector and is now expected to make a profit.

Mr Dyke said yesterday she had planned to retire in 1999, but had been persuaded to stay at the BBC in her new role for two years. He paid tribute to her work: "She has done a great job in getting the business into a position where we expect it will make its first profits next year.

In a statement, Ms Salmon said she had enjoyed her time at the corporation. Her deputy, David Green, will take over until a permanent replacement is found.

webTitle: Lake fear

fields.headline: Lake fear
fields.standfirst: Order of the boot for Hannibal the piscine cannibal
fields.trailText: Order of the boot for Hannibal the piscine cannibal.
fields.body:
A giant catfish dubbed Hannibal the Cannibal - because it regurgitated 57 fish when it was caught - has been removed to stop it wrecking a West Sussex lake's ecosystem.

Environment agency officials confessed to being extremely surprised by the catch - the 5ft Wels catfish is not a British fish and should not have been there.

Staff had been routinely netting in Shillinglee Lake, near Billingshurst, West Sussex, to assess fish stocks when Hannibal was caught. Europe's largest freshwater species, the Wels catfish does live in the Rhine but is normally from the warmer waters of southern Europe.

It is a fierce predator and can eat ducks and small mammals. Hannibal weighed 15lb but the European record is 62lb.

Officials feared Hannibal would clear the 30-acre lake of fish if it reached its full potential length of 16ft. The 57 roach and bream it had eaten just before it was caught compare with the average four fish found in the stomach of large pike.

It is believed that someone with an unwanted pet, or an angler who relished catching the fish, which is "extremely powerful and puts up a huge fight", had released it in the lake illegally. The environment agency spokesman said the catfish had been "wreaking havoc, chomping through fish stocks and upsetting the natural ecological balance".

Last night Hannibal was in the Sea Life Centre in Brighton, where he or she has been "rehomed". Catfish can only be kept if the owner has a licence.

webTitle: SSL boardroom battle ejects top executives

fields.headline: SSL boardroom battle ejects top executives
fields.standfirst: Behind the calm exterior of this Cheshire mansion a bitter struggle ended with the scalps of both chairman and CEO
fields.trailText: A four-month boardroom battle for control of Durex condoms maker SSL International ended in dramatic fashion with defeat all round yesterday, as the company announced the departure of its top two directors.
fields.byline: Andrew Clark, Neil Hume  and Simon Bowers
fields.body:
A four-month boardroom battle for control of Durex condoms maker SSL International ended in dramatic fashion with defeat all round yesterday, as the company announced the departure of its top two directors.

SSL said chief executive Iain Cater was leaving immediately, having been "invited by the board to step down". Chairman Stuart Wallis is to follow him in July, when his contract will not be renewed.

On a black day for the Cheshire-based firm, the departures were accompanied by a profits warning, which sent the shares plunging 107p to 409p. This revealed that factory closures and staff reorganisation following the firm's merger in 1999 were proving slower and less lucrative than expected.

The changes were agreed at a tense board meeting on Friday afternoon at the group's Cheshire head office, Toft Hall. In a split revealed by the Guardian earlier this month, the firm's executive directors were pitted against non-executives in their views on who should run the business.

Mr Wallis, who was pressing for Mr Cater's departure with support from his fellow non-executives, yesterday said he had been planning to leave all along: "I had already indicated I was likely to step down in July - I'm involved in several other public companies, and some private ones. I've been at SSL for four years and that's almost a record for me."

He said Mr Cater had been asked to leave because of the company's disappointing performance: "Following the profits warning we had in November, and then the one today, the board felt it was probably appropriate for Iain to step down."

Mr Wallis insisted that the changes had been agreed "very democratically", although he admitted that there were disagreements on the board: "You would not expect, in a situation like this, for everybody to have exactly the same views. But the detail of the way a board operates is not something that should be in the public domain."

When contacted yesterday, Mr Cater was tight-lipped about the way his 22-year career at the company had ended. He would only say of his dismissal: "I don't think it's subject to negotiation."

When asked about his plans, Mr Cater said his job prospects were "an open agenda" before adding: "I really shouldn't comment any further."

Mr Cater, the 49-year-old son of an RAF officer from Cheltenham, was the architect of SSL's creation through a combination of healthcare firm Seton, footcare company Scholl and condoms maker London International. However, his ambition of creating a world leader in over-the-counter healthcare products began to fall apart in November. The company warned of a setback in its attempts to use in-house salesmen, rather than third-party distributors - former partners were dumping their remaining stocks of bandages and dressings on the market at knockdown prices.

Analysts cut their forecasts from £130m to £110m. But the real damage was in presentation - analysts complained that SSL had briefed its own broker in advance, and many were furious that Mr Wallis walked out of a meeting early to catch a plane.

Mr Wallis yesterday said he was obliged to hurry away due to urgent commitments in the US, but admitted he regretted his handling of the incident: "Could I have handled it better? I probably could - with hindsight, I should have made it clear from the outset that I would have to leave early."

The incident threw up differences in the way SSL communicated - Mr Wallis felt the firm should have been more forthright about its predicament, while Mr Cater remained relentlessly upbeat.

After a disastrous plunge in the shares, there were calls for change but the board could not agree on who should take the blame. Mr Wallis urged Mr Cater to quit but he faced opposition from executives, many of whom were long standing colleagues of the chief executive from the days of Seton. They, instead, wanted Mr Wallis to go - one document was drawn up detailing "the case against the chairman".

For a time, the board was deadlocked. But this month's arrival of new finance director Garry Watts, a former executive at Celltech, broke the stalemate.

Mr Watts' first act has been a review of the firm's progress in merging its operations with London International. His conclusion was that the promised £25m in annual savings would be very difficult to achieve.

The need for another profits warning sealed Mr Cater's fate. Mr Wallis said: "If there was a mistake, it was over-optimism about the speed with which things could be achieved."

Mr Cater's colleagues got what they wanted too. Mr Wallis surrendered his position, having failed to keep a lid on unrest. He remains chairman of a clutch of other companies, including the biotech firm Protherics.

SSL yesterday indicated that its profits are likely to be £90m this year. Some analysts believe the firm could now be broken up - Michael King of WestLB Panmure said: "The shares are looking very cheap at the moment and there are some very valuable brands among the group. A number of expanding healthcare companies could be interested in brands like Scholl and Durex."

Mr Cater is likely to pick up compensation of more than £700,000 to soften the blow of redundancy. That will do little to calm impatient shareholders, some of whom are already questioning whether SSL can work as an independent business.

webTitle: City diary

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: City Diary: Richard Adams
fields.body:
 Bit of a pickle for Richard Branson the other week, on his way back from a pleasant weekend of skiing in the Swiss Alps. His Virgin airline, of course, doesn't fly to Geneva, so Branson was faced with a choice between an unappealing menu of Swissair, EasyJet or his old courtroom enemy BA. Since Swissair are fighting tooth and nail to hang on to their local duo-poly (thwarting Virgin and others from getting landing rights), and EasyJet doesn't do business class, poor old Beardie was forced to take the least worst option and ride on BA - much to the amusement of the cabin crew, who lined up to ask him if he was enjoying his flight.

 Happy birthday Gordon! The chancellor hits the big 50 today. The dilemma for his friends is what to get him, but the sense of humour and forgiveness DNA strand is not yet on sale. In the meantime, Gordon - careful with any presents from Mandy. If it's making ticking noises, it's probably not an alarm clock.

 Hyperbole is a concept all but unknown to the internet business world. So investors would have been shocked -shocked! - to hear that E-district.net (an entertainment website) has been "substantially overstated". This might have been a surprise to the stock market, but perhaps not to others in the industry. The IT news site, The Register, long ago queried E-district's claims to have such a large number of users that it should have been one of the busiest websites in the UK. Its 3.43m users and 367m page impressions a month would have put it not far behind Microsoft and Yahoo. Yet it somehow never seemed to show up in the industry's independent surveys of web use. How very strange.

 The BBC's Working Lunch programme had the cunning wheeze of asking City economists what their own mortgage rates were, only to discover just what one might expect: that they are no better at managing their personal finances than anyone else. A nice idea, only slightly ruined by the lack of seriousness among the participants, with one telling the BBC his mortgage rate was 10% (the current base rate being 5.75%), "just for a laugh".

 We are used to reading puffs for dodgy dot.com ventures, but the Sunday Telegraph set new standards last weekend by running a bizarre puff for a dot.com that was going out of business. Online drink seller Lastorders closed down after "a disagreement" (according to the Sunday Telegraph's euphemism) with a leading backer. The "disagreement" was that the company wanted more money to keep afloat, and the Royal Bank of Scotland wanted to pull the plug. Yet how extraordinary this dot.com should fail, since it is almost impossible to buy alcohol in this country (apart from pubs, off-licences and supermarkets, so inconveniently located near where people live and work).

webTitle: CBI calls for Budget tax cuts to promote investment

fields.headline: CBI calls for Budget tax cuts to promote investment
fields.trailText: Industry leaders today will warn Gordon Brown to avoid populist tax giveaways in his forthcoming budget and to target any cuts on reducing business costs.
fields.body:
Industry leaders today will warn Gordon Brown to avoid populist tax giveaways in his forthcoming budget and to target any cuts on reducing business costs.

The Confederation of British Industry says Mr Brown could pump an extra £2bn into the economy without increasing inflation and that his top priority should be cutting the business tax burden.

"The chancellor could and should offer companies greater incentives to invest," said Digby Jones, the CBI's director general. "Manufacturing investment is particularly weak and that could hold back improvements in productivity and economic growth."

Although international comparisons show Britain has one of the most favourable tax regimes for business in Europe, the CBI says the government needs to keep taxes low to attract investment and stop firms from relocating in more competitive countries.

"The past year, perhaps more than any other, shows how globally mobile business has become," Mr Jones said. "The government must focus on keeping our tax system internationally competitive."

The CBI wants Mr Brown to introduce a tax credit for research and development for large firms, to reduce stamp duty on commercial property and give small firms a more generous tax write-off on capital investment.

More firms should be allowed to negotiate discounts on the forthcoming climate change levy.

The government should lift the burden of red tape on business, according to a budget submission from the British Chambers of Commerce, by establishing a probationary period for all regulations.

The prime minister or chancellor should spell out the costs and benefits of all new regulations in an annual regulatory budget.

webTitle: City trader uses human rights law to challenge SFA ruling

fields.headline: City trader uses human rights law to challenge SFA ruling
fields.trailText: A City trader convicted of market manipulation has begun a test case in the high court claiming he was denied a fair hearing.
fields.body:
A City trader convicted of market manipulation has begun a test case in the high court claiming he was denied a fair hearing.

Frenchman Bertrand Fleurose, formerly of US investment bank JP Morgan, is the first person to use the new European human rights legislation to challenge City regulators.

In 1999, Mr Fleurose was found guilty of misconduct by a disciplinary hearing of the securities and futures authority, which was told he helped drive the FTSE 100 down 30 points by last-minute share dealing in a string of companies.

The tribunal cleared him of "not being a fit and proper person", however, on the grounds he had been acting on a superior's orders and was under time pressures.

Yesterday his legal team insisted the conviction, which saw him suspended for two years and ordered to pay legal costs of £175,000, is fatally flawed. He is asking for it to be quashed by Mr Justice Morison in a judicial review.

At the start of the three-day review into an independent panel's decision to uphold the charges last December, Anthony Speaight QC argued the right to a fair trial should apply to disciplinary as well as criminal proceedings.

He told the court that Mr Fleurose had been convicted on the basis of statements he felt compelled to make because failure to do so would also be a disciplinary offence.

There was no provision for Mr Fleurose to have legal aid, which meant he was forced to defend himself against a QC retained by the SFA. Although he can speak English, his legal team is arguing it is not of a sufficient standard to cope with legal terms used in the hearing.

Even though his suspension has ended, Mr Fleurose, of Queen's Gate Gardens, South Kensington, has been unable to find employment because of the stigma his conviction carries in the City.

webTitle: Israeli women refused to serve in 'war zone'

fields.headline: Israeli women refused to serve in 'war zone'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A group of female Israeli soldiers have been court-martialled and placed on probation for refusing to carry out duties in the West Bank and Gaza.
fields.body:
A group of female Israeli soldiers have been court-martialled and placed on probation for refusing to carry out duties in the West Bank and Gaza.

They will be jailed if they breach the provisions of the probation order.

The soldiers, members of the educational unit responsible for lecturing troops on issues ranging from Israeli history to human rights, were ordered on Sunday to teach units stationed in the West Bank and Gaza, the army said.

When they refused, they were tried and sentenced the same day.

Their parents were furious that their daughters had been expected to serve in areas at the heart of the Palestinian uprising.

Many of them insisted that female troops, especially those performing a teaching role, should not be sent into "war zones".

"There is a war there, there is shooting, there are roadside bombs," one father told Israel Radio. "There is no reason to send girls into Gaza or the West Bank.

"These girls are not fighters, they are not combat supporters, [they] do not protect civilians and are in the field for entertainment only.

"I don't want, God forbid, someone to tell me, 'Sorry, I made a mistake.'"

Another father told Israel Radio that women had not been sent into Lebanon during the 22 years Israel occupied the south of the country, and called for a similar ruling for the West Bank and Gaza.

An army spokeswoman said the military provided educational activities to troops serving in all sectors.

She said that the schedule of activities for teachers was decided, and sometimes cancelled, in accordance with the situation.

More than 400 people, mostly Palestinians but also 61 Jews and 13 Israeli Arabs, have been killed since the Palestinian uprising began in September.

webTitle: Diary: Matthew Norman

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Turncoat of Turncoats betting takes a dramatic turn after we receive startling linguistic news. As if demotion from the Foreign Office were not humiliation enough, Peter Hain faces further embarrassment as energy minister unless he turns a blind eye to the hydro-electric power implications of the repugnant Ilisu dam project.
fields.body:
 Turncoat of Turncoats betting takes a dramatic turn after we receive startling linguistic news. As if demotion from the Foreign Office were not humiliation enough, Peter Hain faces further embarrassment as energy minister unless he turns a blind eye to the hydro-electric power implications of the repugnant Ilisu dam project.

He would certainly be foolish to travel to the site, or anywhere else in Turkey, since according to John Still's succinct email, "hain is the Turkish word for traitor". Blimey. When we type the letters into a Turkish-English internet dictionary, an agonising half-second delay ensues -and then up it pops: "Hain (n): traitor, treacherous." Amazing.

Peter was already outright Turncoats favourite, but now shortens to 11-10 (one Istanbul bookie is going odds on 8-13), with Bomber Short and Gus MacDonald out to 5-1. Robin Cook is 13-2, while some especially blethering recent interviews about asylum seekers have seen Barbara Roche backed in to 9-1.

 Meanwhile, Philip Howells writes to request "a user friendly guide" - a full-page racing card, with runners, riders and form guide - to the Turncoats field. "Could you persuade the editors to give you a big splash on a monthly basis for this feature? It is absolutely excellent." A nice thought, Philip, but most of these people have wanted me out for five years, so we will be talking to website supremo Oofy Wegg-Prosser, one-time "soup quote" foe turned colleague, about a Turncoats form guide there.

 MI5's sorties into this century gather pace. Following notable breakthroughs such as more open recruitment and a website, the latest incursion is a coordinated attempt to appeal to black and Asian people. Apart from placing adverts in publications such as the Voice, a lunch party was recently held for prominent types in the funf's Thames House HQ, in the hope that this inclusive approach would osmotically filter through to possible recruits. One guest, newscaster Zeinab Badawi, described herself as "awestruck" at the entertainment, and was last seen heading for St James's Park with regulation rolled-up copy of the Times.

 Following last week's item about designer political knickers available from Politico's bookshop, Dave Carter emails with news that he has "already copyrighted the slogan to be printed on knickers etc to go on sale the morning after the election in Hartlepool ... 'l stayed up for Mandy'. If Matthew Norman would like to order the first set of knickers," he concludes, in an insolent reference to my capacious arse, "we will ensure that they are extra-large."

 This gives us an idea, and my colleague Marina Hyde calls Ann Widdecombe's office to tell Ann's assistant Nicole Hughes this: we've basically made up a story that Politicos are bringing out a new range of literary political knickers; and the Ann pair will sport the Dante quote "Abandon Hope All Ye Who Enter Here" on the ... well, you know where. Anyway, we wondered if Ann might concoct another of those destined-to-fall-flat attempts at spontaneous wit we enjoy so much. "I'll call you back," promises the ever-charming Nicole.

webTitle: Manchester buys into No 2 slot behind BAA

fields.headline: Flying high
fields.standfirst: Manchester buys into No 2 slot behind BAA
fields.trailText: Manchester buys into No 2 slot behind BAA.
fields.body:
Manchester airport yesterday bought Bournemouth and East Midlands airports for £241m from National Express, to become the second largest airport owner in Britain.

It also holds an 82% stake in Humberside airport and is now second only to BAA, the listed airports operator, which runs Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted.

More than 2.2m passengers used East Midlands last year while 273,000 travelled through Bournemouth. In 1999, the two made combined operating profits of £12.9m on £33.9m turnover.

Phil White, chief executive of National Express, said he was "delighted" the two aiports were being acquired by an operator with both a high reputation and considerable expertise. "Due to the expansion of the group over the last 18 months, our UK airports have become less core to the group overall."

National Express appears to have made a tidy profit on the deal. It bought the two airports for £34m, acquiring East Midlands in 1993 and Bournemouth two years later. The transport group has invested £80m in the two, including the construction of a new cargo terminal at East Midlands.

National Express has altered its focus in recent years, building up a rail business in the UK, where it now has nine franchises, and expanding its international operation. It now runs bus and coach services in 30 US states and is the third largest yellow bus school operator in America.

The sale depends on clearance by the office of fair trading.

webTitle: Black icon resigns after SA bribes claim

fields.headline: Black icon resigns after SA bribes claim
fields.trailText: One of South Africa's most influential black businessmen resigned from a host of prominent positions after corruption investigators raided his home yesterday.
fields.body:
One of South Africa's most influential black businessmen resigned from a host of prominent positions after corruption investigators raided his home yesterday.

The public prosecutor's office ordered the raid on a warrant which accused Keith Kunene of accepting bribes from High Beam Trading, a consortium which includes the London commodities trader Trafigura.

Mr Kunene, seen as an icon of economic empowerment for victims of apartheid, is accused of accepting $60,000 (about £41,000) in bribes to influence a $200m oil deal while he was chairman of the state-owned Central Energy Fund, which controls South Africa's fuel reserves.

He was allegedly promised a further $2m in exchange for a contract awarded to the consortium, about 10 times the usual handling fee.

The South African energy minister, Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, sacked Mr Kunene from the energy fund in December after an independent audit revealed irregularities in the oil deal.

Among other things, the deal, which effectively privatised the state's oil trading operations, is said to have been done without tendering and without the government being informed.

The government, which is asking for the contract to be nullified, has lodged papers with a Johannesburg court alleging that High Beam paid bribes. It is also trying to recover $3m (£2.1m) already paid to the consortium.

Trafigura is seeking legal arbitration in London, where the contract was signed.

After yesterday's raid Mr Kunene resigned from all his other positions, including the chair of a state gambling board and the University of Zululand, and numerous directorships.

According to papers lodged by the investigators with the high court in Pretoria, two fuel fund directors allege that they were paid $20,000 (£13,800) each by Mr Kunene to favour High Beam.

Black business groups described the accusations as a further blow to the credibility of the policy of economic empowerment, because Mr Kunene was among the best known and most successful businessmen to penetrate areas previously dominated by whites.

Last year a Johannesburg financial newspaper named him businessman of the year.

The government's efforts to promote black-owned business has come under criticism for creating a new class of extremely wealthy black people without bringing much benefit to the rest of the population.

There have also been accusations of nepotism in the awarding of contracts to black empowerment companies linked to South Africa's controversial agreement to buy £4bn-worth of weapons from British and European arms dealers.

A spokesman for the public prosecutor's office said investigators raided Mr Kunene's home and the office of a High Beam director, Moses Molele, who is alleged to have paid the bribe.

Prosecutors say other officials of High Beam International and Trafigura are still under investigation.

Trafigura has strongly denied any knowledge of irregular payments to Mr Kunene.

"We would like to stress that there is no basis whatsoever for any such allegations, with reference to Trafigura or to its South African joint venture company," it said.

"Trafigura deplores bribery in any form and will not tolerate any irregularities from its own employees or those of its business partners."

webTitle: John Redwood: we haven't done enough to reassure US

fields.headline: We haven't done enough
fields.standfirst:
Blair's US links, the view from the left:
Paul Foot: Conjuring up war criminals

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Six British warplanes flying alongside US aircraft are a good backdrop to Tony Blair's first meeting with President Bush. So say the government's spinners, ever ready to use anything for effect, however deadly and serious.
fields.body:
Six British warplanes flying alongside US aircraft are a good backdrop to Tony Blair's first meeting with President Bush. So say the government's spinners, ever ready to use anything for effect, however deadly and serious.

Unleashing weaponry from a great height on Saddam Hussein's defences is a step too far for many traditional Labour supporters. Its cynical exploitation by Labour's press machine is trying to make up for the misjudgment Blair made in thinking Al Gore would win. It is also trying to bridge a growing chasm between European and US attitudes towards Nato, defence and world problems.

When Blair gets to Washington, he will find goodwill for this gesture, but he will still be under pressure privately on a range of issues where the alliance is no longer in good shape. One raid cannot repair all the damage done by the EU defence initiative nor the bad will generated by a series of expensive trade disputes between the EU and the US. Indeed, Blair is playing a very dangerous game, risking our security for the sake of his over-extended European diplomacy.

Robin Cook and Tony Blair have appeared regularly to tell us that the US is our oldest ally, our best friend, we are united by a common language, history and culture. It is difficult to accept their sincerity about the American alliance when at the same time they want to move into a political, economic and monetary union with our continental friends.

The government refuses to see that we are at a crossroads. If we wish to join France and Germany in a Euro force that has a separate command structure from Nato and intervenes where Nato fears to tread, we will be pulled apart slowly but inevitably from the US defence alliance. Why should the US share intelligence with us if we may share it with others she does not trust completely? Why should the US shield protect us, if we have decided for part of the time to go off and do things that the US disagrees with?

If we sign up to the common foreign policy of the EU we have to accept that it will pull us further away from the US position. A common EU foreign policy would be unlikely to support this type of operation against Iraq. EU policy is much more sympathetic to Russia than US policy likes. EU attitudes to the Middle East and eastern Europe are very different from US ones.

If we sign up to the euro and abolish the pound, we are accepting a plan to provide a rival currency to the dollar. The aim is to create a single economic bloc as strong as the US, and to assert that power around the world.

We are already dragged into conflicts with the US over a range of trading issues. There are rows over beef exports, genetically modified foods, rum and bananas. Airbus sets out to topple Boeing, only to find the US calling foul over its launch aid and the EU crying unfair over Boeing's military contracts.

The UK tried but failed to bring the two sides together in the recent environmental summit. John Prescott's shuttle diplomacy ran out of steam when he decided he wanted to go home. He had had enough of squabbling foreigners. His ration of tact and diplomacy had more than given out. It was a fitting epitaph for a policy that cannot last much longer. Britain has been a bridge between the old world and the new. Now the divide is growing wider and the waters rougher it is becoming impossible to be loved by both sides.

What should the UK do? We need to decide where our best interests lie. Some will say they rest with the EU. They want us to agree with our partners who do not like the Iraqi strikes, throw in our lot with EU defence and join the great project for political and monetary union. That entails "standing up" to the US on a wide range of issues, as France has often done.

Most British people believe that we cannot accept political union. We believe Britain needs a strong defence alliance with the US. That means no Euro army, and an independent foreign policy. It means keeping our own currency. It means trying to prevent the trade conflict between the EU and the US from getting out of hand.

When Mr Blair gets to Washington he will find he has not done enough to reassure the US about our intentions. Above all, they will want to know whether he will support their national missile defence system, at a time when Mr Blair wants to bury the issue as another embarrassment to his party.

 John Redwood is the member of parliament for Wokingham and author of Stars and Strife on the EU/US relationship.

webTitle: Jenny Colgan on fashionistas, LA and masturbation

fields.headline: Darling, how simply terrible for you
fields.trailText: I shouldn't, I shouldn't, I shouldn't be frightened of fashion people. They're not big! They're not clever! But they are the nasty people who used to sneer at my vest and braces in secondary school.
fields.body:
I was sitting on the tube the other day. The woman opposite me was dressed entirely in black, her ghostly white skin caked in make-up. She was wearing enormous sunglasses over her whole face, despite the fact that we were, mmm, underground. And she was swigging from a wine miniature at 9.30 in the morning. This was the point where I remembered how frightened I am of London Fashion Week.

I shouldn't, I shouldn't, I shouldn't be frightened of fashion people. They're not big! They're not clever! But they are the nasty people who used to sneer at my vest and braces in secondary school. (OK, you can stop now. They were very chic braces, thank you.)

Well, I guess it's all right to be frightened of Anna Wintour. She looks like she could fly in your window in the middle of the night, perch on the end of your bed and take a bite out of you. But the rest of them? What is making them so snooty, exactly? Sleevage?

Fashion seems so malicious: they're always bitching each other up. It's nasty. What would you do if Naomi Campbell deliberately dropped a garment in front of you and ordered you to pick it up? Or Jodie Kidd called you fat? (As she thinks Anna Kournikova is fat, I guarantee that she thinks you are fat.)

I have never ever wanted to go to a fashion show as, I imagine, someone else would be sitting on my seat, and they'd look me up and down to see how unfashionable I was, then turn away with a sneer to talk to everyone else they knew (ie absolutely everyone), then everyone would run away to a brilliant party and tell me I couldn't come and I'd have to stand in the middle all by myself and pretend I didn't care, blinking back the tears.

Weirdly, I told this to someone, and they immediately produced a spare ticket for a show. I promise you, this is not the kind of thing that ever happens to me. It was my genuine Victoria Hervey moment. Of course, I said yes immediately.

I really have no interest in clothes. I have a pair of winter jeans, a pair of summer jeans, four different colours of Converse and lots of T-shirts with cartoons on the front. Today it was Snoopy as Joe Cool. I realised, belatedly, that wearing a T-shirt that says "cool" on it pretty much guarantees that you are not. Still. Perhaps scruffy is the new fantastic.

The show was in the Natural History Museum. There was a queue trailing out through the door. "I see pinafores and dungarees are making a comeback," I observed to my foxy agent, whom I was accompanying.

"It's half-term. Those are children. They are here to see the dinosaurs," she said. "Please at least attempt to behave yourself."

Alas, once inside the tent it was so disappointing. All the women were really boring. The pretty ones were wearing stripy tops and the ugly ones were wearing Burberry scarves. I do not know why this is. Fortunately the men were all wearing silver mink coats and fluorescent spectacles. I was very disappointed that there were no celebrities there: I had really been looking forward to seeing Meg Mathews in one of her typically inappropriate outfits: bin-bag trousers, two pasties and a top hat or something.

There's a girl who looks so like Gwyneth I wonder if she's been hired as a looky-likey, and a fat woman wearing fishnets, which is always hilarious. But everyone looks so normal. I even see a girl wearing a T-shirt with a cartoon monkey on the front. (I love it.)

And they're playing Van Morrison, who was so cool for so long that he's now officially become uncool again. Even the official runway clothes are pretty. I'm very upset that there's nothing like the big balloon-head thing, or the dresses covered in cash.

The models, though. Yikes! I can only watch them walk forwards, in that weird, mincing-dog way they have, as the frocks are backless and looking at their knobbly spines bursting through their skin makes me feel sick. They are thinner than I was the fantastic year I got glandular fever and couldn't eat for six weeks, thus making me officially Mrs Thinny-Thin, queen of thin. They look grumpy. I'm not surprised.

But! I'm also not frightened! Actually, I'm insanely bored. I'm looking at a stage, there are people on it, but they're not singing or dancing or telling jokes or anything. I could not possibly care less about them. At last! I have cured my phobia. I love my Snoopy T-shirt. And now I can work on getting a brilliantly bitchy and superior look all of my own. (Although, of course, if anyone has a spare ticket to the Versace party...)

All dressed up and nowhere to live

Hubris: I wrote a book last year that I thought would be a good idea for a film. So did a few people. So it went out to the US, and I went round the studios and pitched the book, and they all seemed to like the idea and made appreciative noises.

So there I was, telling everyone at home how much I was looking forward to writing my film. Then I booked a flight to LA. Then, well, then in a defining moment that even Macbeth might have noticed, I sublet my flat.

Of course, as I found out the next day, nobody on God's earth has the slightest interest in making my film. So I am going to be stuck in LA - where I know nobody, literally nobody at all - for three months.

Oh, and by the way, I can't drive a car. Trying to live your life like a Don Henley song is perhaps not to be recommended.

Now next week is here, and I either have to just step on the plane - without, of course, having sorted out anywhere to live when I get back - or hide under my boyfriend's bed for 12 weeks.

Ho hum. Oh well. How bad can it be? It's not like LA is at all dangerous or filled with wacky loons or anything. It'll be an adventure. And as a friend has kindly pointed out, the worse time I'm having, the more fun my postcards will be.

Self-love is in the air

It's almost - almost - too nasty to write down, but apparently up to 80% of women aged under 40 have masturbated at work. I'm sorry. I hope you're not reading this in an open-plan office. And of course, if it's 80% of women, it's just got to be 100% of men, hasn't it?

Disabled toilets, according to the cognoscenti, are the venue of choice, with fire stairs also proving popular. Gosh. I think this might be a nail in the coffin for computer patience.

 Charlotte Raven is away. Jenny Colgan's latest novel, Talking to Addison, is published by Harper Collins, price £5.99.

They are thinner than I was the fantastic year I got glandular fever and couldn't eat for six weeks, thus making me officially Mrs Thinny-Thin, queen of thin. They look grumpy. I'm not surprised. But! I'm also not frightened! Actually, I'm insanely bored. I'm looking at a stage, there are people on it, but they're not singing or dancing or telling jokes or anything. I could not possibly care less about them. At last! I have cured my phobia. I love my Snoopy T-shirt. And now I can work on getting a brilliantly bitchy and superior look all of my own. (Although, of course, if anyone has a spare ticket to the Versace party...) All dressed up and nowhere to live Hubris: I wrote a book last year that I thought would be a good idea for a film. So did a few people. So it went out to the US, and I went round the studios and pitched the book, and they all seemed to like the idea and made appreciative noises. So there I was, telling everyone at home how much I was looking forward to writing my film. Then I booked a flight to LA. Then, well, then in a defining moment that even Macbeth might have noticed, I sublet my flat. Of course, as I found out the next day, nobody on God's earth has the slightest interest in making my film. So I am going to be stuck in LA - where I know nobody, literally nobody at all - for three months. Oh, and by the way, I can't drive a car. Trying to live your life like a Don Henley song is perhaps not to be recommended. Now next week is here, and I either have to just step on the plane - without, of course, having sorted out anywhere to live when I get back - or hide under my boyfriend's bed for 12 weeks. Ho hum. Oh well. How bad can it be? It's not like LA is at all dangerous or filled with wacky loons or anything. It'll be an adventure. And as a friend has kindly pointed out, the worse time I'm having, the more fun my postcards will be. Self-love is in the air It's almost - almost - too nasty to write down, but apparently up to 80% of women aged under 40 have masturbated at work. I'm sorry. I hope you're not reading this in an open-plan office. And of course, if it's 80% of women, it's just got to be 100% of men, hasn't it? Disabled toilets, according to the cognoscenti, are the venue of choice, with fire stairs also proving popular. Gosh. I think this might be a nail in the coffin for computer patience.  Charlotte Raven is away. Jenny Colgan's latest novel, Talking to Addison, is published by Harper Collins, price £5.99.

webTitle: Emma Brockes meets Guy Ritchie's sister

fields.headline: Don't mention the M-word
fields.standfirst: Tabitha Ritchie is into yoga and pilates. She also has a new gym and juice bar to sell. Oh, and she's Guy's sister.  Emma Brockes  drops by
fields.trailText: Tabitha Ritchie is into yoga and pilates. She also has a new gym and juice bar to sell. Oh, and she's Guy's sister. Emma Brockes drops by.
fields.body:
Tabitha Ritchie is explaining the art of "glamouflage", the design theory on which her west London gym and juice bar is being built. She is particularly excited about the flyers. "It's a fig leaf with crazy colours. It's crazy. You lift up the fig leaf and go, ooh, I wonder what's under there." We are standing on a building site two months before launch and I'm struggling to visualise it.

Tabs, as she is known, is Guy Ritchie's elder sister and, as such, suspicious of my motives for interviewing her. This week she launches the juice bar part of Naked Health, the "lifestyle centre" she has built out of an old Royal Mail sorting office in Earls Court. "This isn't going to be all about Guy," she warns, picking her way through the half-finished site.

"There'll be a yoga and pilates studio there - boudoir style with lots of velvets and chintzes. There will be seaweed treatments and mud wraps, all that crazy stuff. You won't have to go to step classes with a leotard up your bum, going left while everyone else goes right. We're getting away from the corporate-style gym of white walls and hardcore exercise. It will be more like a nightclub atmosphere."

Tabs, who is 34, summarises her career pre-glamouflage as "part media, part traveller". Fifteen years ago she trained as a massage therapist ("there'll be a nice sliding ladder there"), worked for a production company, ("aromatherapy, reflexology"), and hung around the US for a couple of years before casting about for something more challenging to occupy her. "Boxing, spinning, a DJ on Friday night ..." she comes to a stop outside the women's changing rooms, stiff-backed and doubtful. "This place will be like a little laugh centre."

She and her brother, says Tabs, have always wanted to make people laugh.

The laughs at Naked Health will cost between £8 for a class, £35 a treatment and there will be no membership fee. Tabs draws a short breath. Didn't you get expelled from school, I ask quickly? "Oh, why do you want to know about that?" she replies, frowning. Then suddenly she brightens. "You know, I was at school with Meg."

Meg? "Meg Mathews." Oh. "Yes." A short pause. "Oh, all right. A load of us got expelled - 16 in all. They were getting a new headmaster at the Quaker school, so they wanted to get rid of all the troublemakers before he arrived. I didn't see much schooling over the age of 15."

For Naked Health, Tabs knuckled down and learned basic accountancy skills, a "real chore" at the outset, but something she now loves. Luckily, the first friend to whom she mentioned the project thought it sounded great and stumped up some cash. Tabs also sold her house and moved to Wandsworth. "Yes, Wandsworth. So it's like, will someone please buy Tabs a house in Kensington!"

She believes that she and Guy get their creativity from their parents. "We're definitely creative rather than academic. My mum's bohemian - she's called Amber. My dad did all the Hamlet cigar ads."

She is also pretty competitive. "If I play a game, I don't mind losing, but I'm in this to win it. I stopped competing with Guy when he got a black belt in karate and could hoof my door open. Now we're pretty close."

The subtext of this skirt around the houses is that Naked Health, whatever the decor, facilities, ethos etc will be packed with celebrities. No, says Tabs firmly, because Earls Court is a catchment area for "Aussies, gay guys and posh ladies" and that's who she's courting.

"I'd rather it was busy than built on celebrity regulars. It just happens that my brother is that way." She refers to Guy as if he had an embarrassing social disease. Nobody mentions the M-word. Tabs can't pull off the celebrity-tired thing quite convincingly, however.

The launch will be in April. Will there be a big party? "Oh yes," she says, coolly. "We're hoping Guy's bride will come and open it."

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Kingfisher may unload Wegert
fields.body:
Kingfisher may unload Wegert

European retail conglomerate Kingfisher could be on the verge of throwing in the towel with its troublesome German electricals business Wegert, industry sources said yesterday.

Wegert, which trades under the ProMarkt brand, posted losses of £13.9m for the six months to August 2000. A recent shakeup brought in new management but if that does not work Kingfisher may decide to dispose of the unit.

Shares in the company, which is expected to make profits of around £600m this year, edged up 4p to 479p following weekend press speculation.

More aid for Cammell Laird

The government yesterday made an improved financial offer aimed at helping a shipyard win a lucrative contract to build two new cruise ships.

The department of trade and industry said it was increasing the amount of money it was offering to help underwrite the contract to assist Cammell Laird's Birkenhead yard win the work.

The DTI had earlier offered a loan guarantee of £207m but said it was now willing to share £67m more risk with the private sector.

Rogues gallery expelled

A rogue trader, two firms through which he operated and the senior managers who let him get away with unauthorised trades were yesterday expelled from the securities and futures authority's register.

The SFA order effectively prohibits John Ho Park from working in the City as a result of £6m of losses he caused to Griffin, the British arm of a US day trading company.

His trading dated back to 1998 and pushed Griffin into liquidation. Mr Park worked for GLH which is no longer operating and has been expelled by the SFA along with Griffin.

The SFA also expelled Scott Szach, a US-based senior executive officer of Griffin, while Griffin's compliance officer, Steven Rose, has been suspended from the SFA's register of managers and expelled as no longer "fit and proper" to be registered as a compliance officer.

11 Britons held in Manila

Philippine prosecutors in Manila are questioning 11 Britons, held by police since Friday on suspicion of illegal trading in US stocks. Police said a foreign investor claims the group has defrauded him of $145,000 (£100,000).

Senior state prosecutor Archimedes Manabat said he had found a prima facie case of violation of the securities regulation code for trading in securities without a licence.

Compass lands deal in US

UK catering company Compass Group said yesterday its Select Service Partner unit has won a 10-year, £65m food service contract at Reno/Tahoe International Airport.
