webTitle: G2: Real-life killer cannibals

fields.headline: Hannibals in the flesh
fields.standfirst: It's not just in the movies that murderers eat their victims.  Katharine English asks two real-life killer cannibals - one imprisoned, one free - about their terrifying desire to eat other humans
fields.trailText: It's not just in the movies that murderers eat their victims. Katharine English asks two real-life killer cannibals - one imprisoned, one free - about their terrifying desire to eat other humans.
fields.body:
On June 11 1981, Issei Sagawa invited Renee Hartevelt, a 25-year-old Dutch woman, back to his Paris flat for a poetry reading session. They were both students at the Sorbonne university and had been friends for a few months. She was teaching him German. He liked her easy smile, her sunny personality. In a letter home to her parents in Holland, she wrote that she found him "friendly and intellectual".

As she sat in his living room, reading aloud, Sagawa stepped behind her and pulled out a carbine rifle that he had hidden in a chest of drawers. He walked towards her, pointed the gun at the back of her neck and pulled the trigger. After having sex with her dead body, Sagawa began to eat her. "I wanted to know the taste of human flesh, the young beautiful girl's flesh," he tells me 20 years later, over iced coffee in a downtown Tokyo cafe. "Just one bite of the hips. When you fall in love, you really want to kiss her. It's just the same, I just wanted to taste her. I'm a cannibal. It's an obsession."

Sagawa ate part of Hartevelt's thigh, buttock, breast, lips, calves - some cooked, some raw. After two days he decided he needed to get rid of the body. He bought two large suitcases, filled them with her remains, and called a taxi. Helping to load the suitcases, the taxi driver remarked on how heavy they were. "What have you got in here? A dead body?"

When he remembers the taxi driver's question, Sagawa bursts out laughing. This is one of the things about Sagawa - he laughs at inappropriate moments. I am interviewing him for a documentary about modern cannibals, and the first thing that strikes me when I meet him is his size; he is at least a foot shorter than me. His hands and feet are tiny, his fingers deformed. His skin is shiny white and pockmarked. He is 51, but could be in his 30s.

Sagawa was an inept criminal. He dumped the two suitcases in the Bois de Boulogne and ran. Two joggers opened them and found Hartevelt's remains. Sagawa was easily traced through the taxi driver, found to be clinically insane and was put in a psychiatric unit in Paris. The French kept him in a maximum security unit for four years, until the authorities decided they couldn't foot the bill for the rest of his life, so he was deported back to his native Japan. There was no clause in the deportation order that said he had to be kept under lock and key, so now he is a free man. He has become a sort of celebrity; he does restaurant reviews and stars in porn films.

The aim of the documentary is to gain some understanding of how seemingly ordinary people can do the unthinkable, the grotesque. Sagawa tries to describe the sexual obsession which drove him to kill - a complex obsession which involved merging completely with a member of the opposite sex. "I'm a very short, ugly, small man so I always admire big, strong and healthy people, especially beautiful girls. In my mind, eat and eaten is the same. So I don't mind being eaten by a young, beautiful girl."

"So you would like me to eat you?" I ask him.

"Yes," he replies.

We travel to the US. Arthur Shawcross conforms more easily to many people's idea of a cannibal serial killer with his explosive rage, choice of victims and use of savage violence. He has 239 years to serve in New York state's maximum security prison. In 1972, he murdered a girl and a boy, and served 15 years in jail.

Within a year of his release, he was killing again. He killed 11 more people, all prostitutes, within 18 months. Caught in 1990, he was tried and sentenced, since when he has undergone much analysis. He claims that he ate the penis and heart of the 11-year-old boy, Jack Blake; he also says he ate the genitalia of three prostitutes.

Inside the Sullivan Correctional Facility, we are taken through a large number of air-locked doors, down a corridor which echoes with the sounds of lots of men behind bars and into a large white room with nothing in it but a table and two chairs. Shawcross comes in with two guards. He is as big as Sagawa is small, weighing about 320lbs. He has a pot belly and long grey hair, scraped back into a pony tail. He looks like someone's uncle gone wrong. There is no glass divide, the guards are not armed. Shawcross is not wearing handcuffs and is obviously checking us out. The crew and I feel very exposed and the atmosphere is tense.

But Shawcross seems to enjoy being filmed, getting off on playing up to the camera. "I used to eat a lot of raw meat in '64 and '65 when I worked as a butcher. I used to butcher 19 cows a day and just liked the taste of raw meat. You know, I'd just cut off a chunk ... I could tell just by the taste of the blood whether we could turn it into steaks or hamburger."

Shawcross tells me that he developed a taste for human flesh when he served in Vietnam. He describes in lurid detail tracking two Vietcong women in the jungle, ambushing them and tying one alive to a tree while he cut up and cooked the other.

I ask him what human flesh tastes like. "When was the last time you had nice roast pork?" he replies.

"A while ago."

"I don't think you're going to eat it again, are you? If you take a fresh ham, a roast pork, and the butt-end where it's a little burnt, that's what you taste like."

"And why did you eat it?"

"I have no idea."

"Were you hungry?"

"No."

We will never know the truth behind Shawcross's claims of cannibalism. The autopsies showed mutilation in the genital areas, but the bodies retrieved were so decomposed that evidence of cannibalism was inconclusive. The women in Vietnam were probably a fantasy.

Shawcross frightens and outrages me, but as a film-maker it is important to seek explanations. In our interviews with professionals working in the areas of mental health and criminal justice, a complex matrix of factors emerges. Brain injury was one of them. Both Sagawa and Shawcross sustained damage to the frontal lobes of the brain before they became murderers. But this can only go a short way towards explaining people like them. Many thousands of people suffer such brain damage without becoming monsters.

The "softer" sciences of psychology and sociology offer potential clues. Is it merely a coincidence that Andrei Chikatilo, who was convicted of 53 murders from all over the former Soviet Union, was traumatised as a child by the story of his elder brother, who was killed and eaten during the Russian famine?

Then there are Sagawa's home movies. I remember how shocked I was the first time I saw the film of a game he and his brother had played with their father and uncle. Dad dressed up as a knight. Their uncle played a giant. The two adults would "fight" over the children. When dad won, everything was OK. When he lost, the giant got to "eat" them.

The scratchy black and white film shows two children, aged four and two, screaming with delight as the giant prepares the cooking pot - a real one on a real stove.

No one is suggesting for a moment that similar, if less gruesome, games are not played innocently and safely every day by millions of families. But is it just coincidence that Sagawa, the four-year-old child, became Issei Sagawa, the 32-year-old cannibal? Perhaps we can find not the full story within those home movies but they may offer some small clue.

In making this film, we wanted to find scientific explanations for cannibalism. But the scientists are struggling. They want experimental populations numbering hundreds or even thousands. They want extensive control groups. They want vast statistical analysis. But cannibals don't come in such numbers. So ultimately, perhaps, we must turn towards less scientific concepts.

I spend four intense days with Sagawa. Knowing that the crew are uncomfortable eating and drinking in his flat, he is always at pains to reassure us that the glass or plate he is handing us is freshly washed. He recognises our fear of "contamination". But then he makes a joke about the disappearance of the British woman, Lucie Blackman. In trying to understand such paradoxes, I suspect that we must turn to writers such as Dostoevsky and the Brontës for insight. The scientific quest for explanation is fascinating and essential, but that journey has barely begun.

On return from Japan, there is a fax waiting from Sagawa. It is a thank-you letter, in which he says: "You treat me like a man, not a monster."

Here is a man who has tragically and brutally ended the life of a young woman and cannibalised her body. The horrific autopsy pictures say it all. Perhaps his letter stems from self-pity. Since then, his faxes have been veiled threats to sue if I misrepresent him. By the seventh fax I start to see how paranoid, inadequate and vulnerable he is. Then I realise that I have taken my first real step towards understanding him.

 Katharine English is the producer/director of Cannibal: The Real Hannibal Lecters, tonight on Channel 4 at 10pm.

Knowing that the crew are uncomfortable eating and drinking in his flat, he is always at pains to reassure us that the glass or plate he is handing us is freshly washed. He recognises our fear of "contamination". But then he makes a joke about the disappearance of the British woman, Lucie Blackman. In trying to understand such paradoxes, I suspect that we must turn to writers such as Dostoevsky and the Brontës for insight. The scientific quest for explanation is fascinating and essential, but that journey has barely begun. On return from Japan, there is a fax waiting from Sagawa. It is a thank-you letter, in which he says: "You treat me like a man, not a monster." Here is a man who has tragically and brutally ended the life of a young woman and cannibalised her body. The horrific autopsy pictures say it all. Perhaps his letter stems from self-pity. Since then, his faxes have been veiled threats to sue if I misrepresent him. By the seventh fax I start to see how paranoid, inadequate and vulnerable he is. Then I realise that I have taken my first real step towards understanding him.  Katharine English is the producer/director of Cannibal: The Real Hannibal Lecters, tonight on Channel 4 at 10pm.

webTitle: Car crash husband cleared of manslaughter

fields.headline: Car crash husband cleared of manslaughter
fields.trailText: A milkman has been cleared of manslaughter after his estranged wife swerved her car into the path of a lorry while they were having a heated argument.
fields.body:
A milkman has been cleared of manslaughter after his estranged wife swerved her car into the path of a lorry while they were having a heated argument.

Kevin Whitlow had allegedly forced his estranged wife Kathryn Whitlow, 33, to veer into the path of the lorry as they argued over custody of their two children, who cannot be named for legal reasons.

A jury found Whitlow, 40, of Chester, not guilty of manslaughter after 2 hours of deliberation at Chester crown court.

He had suffered superficial injuries in the accident, but Mrs Whitlow, who worked as a department manager at a supermarket, was unconscious and trapped in the wreckage of her Toyota Corolla. She died at the scene from multiple injuries.

Whitlow said that they had met for lunch at a pub in Thurstaston, Wirral, last February, to discuss access to their children. As they returned from the pub in her car, they began rowing when she refused to let him accompany her to collect their children from school later in the day.

As they drove towards Chester, Whitlow said, they were shouting at each other just before the crash.

He claimed he had told her to shut up, threatened to hit her, and the car swerved into the path of a lorry as his wife stuck her chin out to him. But he was unaware of the impending crash on the A540 at Woodbank, south Wirral, until it was too late.

The lorry driver, Joseph Robinson, tried to brake but could not avoid a collision, the court heard.

Kathryn Whitlow's brother, Michael Bresnen, later said the family was devastated by the verdict.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Radio picks

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Wood For The Trees | Lockerbie On Trial | Night Waves
fields.body:
Wood For The Trees (Radio 4, 11.0am) visits Bradfield Woods, near Bury St Edmunds, which have been continuously worked since the 13th century. The regular coppicing of the trees not only provides lengths of straight wood for hurdles and thatching, but also allows dormice and oxslips to thrive. As naturalist Jeremy Cherfas picks his away through the fallen leaves, you can hear that despite their great age, these woodlands are a renewed source of economic activity.

After the dramatisation of the Scott Inquiry came a similar recreation of the investigation of Stephen Lawrence's murder; now another ground-breaking case is re-enacted as theatre. The trial of two Libyan agents accused of planting the bomb that brought down Pan Am Flight 103 made legal history with a Netherlands army base temporarily becoming Scottish territory. Lockerbie On Trial (Radio 4, 2.15pm) digests weeks of evidence, examination and cross-examination into just 90 minutes.This ambitious project involves Margaret Renn, the reporter who covered the trial for the BBC, and was written by Jeremy Howe, a former head of drama.

This year Armenians celebrate 1700 years of Christianity; their country became the first officially to recognise the faith in 301. In honour of the anniversary and to mark the opening of an exhibition at the British Library, Night Waves (Radio 3, 9.30pm) looks at Armenian culture.

webTitle: TV and Radio: TV review

fields.headline: That sinking feeling
fields.trailText: In Deep | The Toughest Sheriff In America | Hitler's Women
fields.body:
Along with Keith Chegwin's bits, another series of The Grimleys, and Gail Porter, Stephen Tompkinson covered in baby oil wearing only a towel and a goatee beard - most likely stolen from Jeremy Beadle - is something we need never again see on television. Much like all of the above, it's really not something we should ever have been subjected to in the first place.

As frightening as it was, the lubed-and-ready-for-action Tompkinson was the least disturbing thing about In Deep (BBC1). Nick Berry trying to be all grizzled and troubled was a lot more worrying. As part of the Special Ops team, he had Seen A Lot. Naturally, this meant he had a difficult relationship with his wife and his children and that he walked around as though he had just stood in something unpleasant. Which, in a manner of speaking, he had. Namely, this drama.

Watching Berry and Tompkinson attempting a metamorphosis from housewives' favourites into mini-Ken Stotts was painful enough - like trying to accept that Big Bird is running a crack den on Sesame Street while Oscar the Grouch is pimping for Maria - but the icky feeling that they were doing so in such an unoriginal, lethargic and plain boring show made it worse.

I mean, dead prostitutes? The oldest trick (so to speak) in the police procedural book. And who are these men? Bent coppers, you say? And they're dealing in what? Drugs? What a dazzlingly unique and inventive story! Next you'll be telling me there's going to be a conflict between friends when one suspects the other of being corrupt, that the investigation is going to spill into their private lives and they will never be the same again...

Oh, you are going to tell me that.

There's a moment in In Deep when police psychologist (no series is complete without one) Meera Syal asks Nick, "Have you any idea how distressing this is?" One fears he doesn't. He and Tompkinson are in deep alright. Right up to their eyeballs in the stinky stuff.

In the jurisdiction of The Toughest Sheriff In America (Channel 5), crime pays. Not for the "criminals" of course, but for the sheriff himself, Joe Arpaio. Quite the media whore, Sheriff Joe enjoys sky-high popularity in this Republican stronghold in Arizona, and invites camera crews on drug busts. He prides himself on making chain gangs clear up litter and dig graves for the poor. He smiles while explaining how he houses prisoners in tents and makes them generate their own electricity. He is positively gleeful when explaining how all of this saves the taxpayer money while keeping him in office. Sheriff Joe clearly has a tiny penis.

With his posse of volunteers and prison guards who are allowed to kill inmates, certain to be exonerated by Sheriff Joe's corrupt justice, Arpaio is a shining example of the deluded self-righteousness in which the right-wing cloak themselves to justify their loathing for everyone, including themselves, and their blind ignorance and stupidity.

Widespread gun ownership reduces crime, Sheriff Joe maintained, while jailing someone for the possession of one joint is completely legitimate. Having pursued his policies for nearly a decade, you would think Sheriff Joe's little corner of Arizona would be blissfully crime free. As if. The tale of Sheriff Joe would be funny if it weren't so depressing.

Hitler - as the old song goes - has only got one ball. The other, you may recall, is in the Albert Hall. Casting such sexual aspersions on the Führer wasn't confined to playground chants, as the intriguing Hitler's Women (Channel 4) explained. During the war American intelligence (which sounds like a contradiction in terms after watching Joe Arpaio at work), suggested he liked his lady friends to poo in his mouth.

Whether he did or not is unknown, but what the suggestion revealed - in what was the most interesting part of the documentary - was the need to prove that Hitler was a pervert in private as well as a monster in public. Such a discovery would validate the idea that only those with sexual perversions were capable of sanctioning horrendous acts of torture, murder and destruction. Only judging from the way Hitler treated women (badly), he was simply as intemperate in that respect as in any other. He wasn't abnormal in his misogyny at all. Rather, he was normal in the extreme. And that is the scariest thing of all.

webTitle: TV and Radio: TV picks

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Godzilla | The Trial | Champions' League Football
fields.body:
Films

Godzilla
(Roland Emmerich, 1998)
9.55am, 5.40pm, Sky Premier

Tokyo's favourite monster takes a tour of Manhattan in Emmerich's disappointing follow-up to Independence Day. State-of-the-art computer-generated effects convey the beast's colossal size - provided it's raining, or at night; the story is lame (the military loses the monster? Huh?), and most of the humans - Matthew Broderick's dopey scientist, Maria Pitillo's newshound, Hank Azaria's irksome cameraman - are in urgent need of squashing. But it makes a fine and funny job of trashing New York, and the chase through a stadium full of hatching lizards, with steady Jean Reno leading the way, is thrilling.

Written On The Wind
(Douglas Sirk,1957)
3.15pm,The Studio

Back in the land of Giant, where the private lives of a rich and powerful Texan oil family are laid bare. Lauren Bacall is the secretary who marries handsome boss Robert Stack but soon realises he's not as slick as he should be. Rock Hudson and Oscar-winning Dorothy Malone, as the family slut, keep the drama gushing.

The Trial
(Orson Welles, 1963)
6pm, FilmFour

Welles also wrote and stars in this eerie adaptation of Kafka's novel. He plays the Advocate, an enigmatic presence in the uncertain world of twitchy Anthony Perkins's K, the man arrested, accused of an unspecified crime and left to wrestle, lonely and afraid, with an implacable judicial system. Filmed in the former Yugoslavia and Paris, it's a melancholy, fragmented work, ringing with hollow laughter.

The Trench
(William Boyd, 1999)
10pm, Sky Premier

The novelist Boyd's directorial debut sets a solid stage in a trench on the Western front, two days before the battle of the Somme in 1916. The trench is populated by seemingly stock characters of the British army, from limp officer (Julian Rhind-Tutt) to tough Sarge (Daniel Craig) and green private (Paul Nicholls); but Boyd's eloquent script and the committed performances make it an atmospheric and moving experience.

Poison Ivy
(Katt Shea Ruben, 1992)
10.10pm, FilmFour

Drew Barrymore stars as poison Ivy, a vicious teenager who sneaks into the house of "friend" Cooper (Sara Gilbert), seduces her father, the comfortably drunk Tom Skerritt, and ousts her sad mother (Cheryl Ladd). The tone is a little too Whatever Happened To Baby Jane to take very seriously, and ultimately it's a bit sleazy and dispiriting; but Barrymore plays a girl you'll love to hate.
Paul Howlett

Sport

Champions' League Football
7pm, ONsport2; 7.30pm, ONsport1

Another big European week, and as usual OnDigital are kicking it off with a Tuesday double-header. Last week they were lucky enough to have two English clubs playing on the same night; this week there's just one, Manchester United, whose match against Valencia is on ONsport2 from 7pm. For those of a more continental persuasion, France's under-achieving giants Paris St-Germain host Milan on Onsport1 from 7.30pm.
Simon Burnton

webTitle: Consultants hit at private work plan

fields.headline: Consultants hit at private work plan
fields.trailText: NHS hospital consultants last night accused the government of railroading through a plan to stop them working in the private sector as a cynical pre-election stunt after months of dithering by Alan Milburn, the health secretary.
fields.body:
NHS hospital consultants last night accused the government of railroading through a plan to stop them working in the private sector as a cynical pre-election stunt after months of dithering by Alan Milburn, the health secretary.

The British Medical Association said that ministers were "playing politics with Britain's 25,000 consultants to the detriment of patients and the NHS".

The government is expected tomorrow to publish proposals for a new consultants' contract. They will incorporate an idea floated in the NHS plan in July to make newly-qualified consultants work exclusively for the NHS "for perhaps the first seven years of their career."

The move follows a private meeting between Mr Milburn and the BMA last week at which the doctors' representatives are understood to have harangued the minister over his treatment of them.

It looked last night as if Mr Milburn has decided Labour will lose nothing in the forthcoming election campaign by taking on a profession whose image has been dented by recent scandals.

But Peter Hawker, chairman of the BMAs consultants committee, hinted that doctors would respond by challenging the credibility of Mr Milburn's NHS reforms. "He should not assume consultants will be endlessly cooperative when the call on their goodwill is entirely one-sided," Dr Hawker said.

The row centres on the first comprehensive reform of the national consultants' contract since 1948.

Ministers want to provide better rewards for consultants who are fully committed to NHS work, in return for a stronger system of appraisal and clearer lines of accountability.

Dr Hawker said: "We have been seeking to negotiate privately and in good faith ... (but) the Department of Health has consistently failed to produce any concrete proposals.

"Planned negotiating meetings have been cancelled in the absence of any papers and we now fear there is no realistic prospect of meaningful progress before the general election is called."

The proposals being published tomorrow were no substitute for proper negotiation, he said.

"Consultants will be deeply cynical of the government's motives for doing so. In the rush to engage in megaphone negotiations, the government is making the serious mistake of underestimating the very real anger of consultants," Dr Hawker added.

A spokeswoman for the Department of Health said: "We are slightly surprised by their stance because we had a very cordial meeting with them last week. But in a way we would expect this in the run up to any negotiations."

The NHS Confederation, representing the employers' side in the negotiations, said that the BMA's intervention was "ill-timed and intemperate".

Stephen Thornton, the confederation's chief executive, said: "Shortly before the government publishes its proposals is not the time for damaging megaphone diplomacy ... The new contract must enable NHS management to properly manage its staff, including doctors.

"Recent scandals and reports of failing clinical quality have made this imperative."

webTitle: Law: Marcel Berlins' diary

fields.headline: Marcel Berlins
fields.standfirst: Matrix can hardly complain at the reaction to this apparent breach of its human rights philosophy
fields.trailText: Matrix can hardly complain at the reaction to this apparent breach of its human rights philosophy.
fields.body:
 I'm surprised at the venom generated by the news that one of Matrix Chambers leading QCs: Nick Blake, has gone to Fiji to act on behalf of the (not very human-rights minded) military rulers seeking to confirm their overthrow of the constitution.

I've spoken to a lot of lawyers - by no means all of them sour-grapes competitors - who find it deeply upsetting that a chambers so publicly dedicated to human rights should have one of its stars picking up a hefty fee to oppose, in effect, the downtrodden and discriminated-against races of that island (represented by another English QC, Geoffrey Robertson, for free).

There isn't a cab rank rule obliging barristers to work abroad. Partly it's Matrix's own fault. Its publicity machine is so emphatic at stressing the human rights nature of its work, it can hardly complain at the reaction when such an apparently blatant breach of its philosophy is spotted.

 The thing about 24-hour courts that no one mentioned in last week's stories is their social attraction. I spent a few hours at New York's famous night court, and was struck by the number of spectators wandering in and out, often conversing animatedly as the procession of prostitutes, drunks and thieves passed before the judge. Why are you here? I asked one well-dressed couple. She said: "I think it's very important that people see for themselves how the justice system of our country works." He said: "It's much cheaper than taking a girl to a club." It was ever thus.

 Last week, I informed you of those fundraising letters Lord Irvine was sending top lawyers; and questioned the wisdom of his participation. The issue has now become a top news item everywhere, but does the world scoopster get any credit from those who lifted his story? We get used to such slights.

I once broke an exclusive story for the paper I then worked for. A few evenings later, at nearly midnight, I got a call from an angry news editor. The Other Daily has this important story, why didn't I have it, and could I file 400 words immediately. My protest that the paper had already run the story, and that the other bloke had copied it, didn't pacify him at all. I not only had to write it again, but then listen to the Today programme's morning press round-up giving all the credit to the opposition. All this is by no means unusual in our world. Anyway, should Lord Irvine find himself doing a Mandelson as a result of those begging letters - unlikely, I agree - just remember, you first read about them here.

 There is nothing more enjoyable, and yet more tedious, than another controversy about those absurd curly horse-hair or nylon confections that perch on some lawyers' heads. Wigs, that's the word. This time, wouldn't you know, the Human Rights Act has got into the act. Yup, it's being argued that a denial of the right to wear a wig is a breach of basic human rights. Those threatening legal action are solicitor-advocates - solicitors given the right to argue cases in the higher courts.

The problem is that although they have the same rights of audience as barristers, they don't have the same rights of wig-wearing. And this means, they say, that clients are coming up to them and asking: "Ere, guv, if you're a real brief, why ain't you wearing a wig like the other geezer?" A clear case of discrimination, under Article 376 of the European human rights convention: "Everyone shall be entitled to equality of perukes."

Women lawyers came seventh in the men's wish list (behind headhunters). Their "high" position was explained by the "Ally McBeal phenomenon".

The suggestion that Ally McBeal could make men actually want to date women lawyers, rather than jump out of the nearest high window to avoid them, is not a concept I understand. Anyway, I don't think being seventh or eighth among only two dozen categories is a cause for celebration. Aston Villa came seventh in the premiership and that didn't get them into even the most rubbishy European competition.

webTitle: G2: Country diary

fields.headline: A tale of two herds
fields.standfirst: Somerset
fields.trailText: Somerset.
fields.body:
Last week I met a farmer who claimed that, even though her cattle have to cross a busy road that leads to Weston-super-Mare, motorists held up by them - even families hurrying to the beach - sit patiently watching, and smile contentedly, however long it takes.

The farm has two suckling herds; calves follow their mothers for eight to ten months until they are sensitively weaned, and it is the relatively unusual sight of the natural family groups that casts a spell on motorists. Moorland Farm lies on an ancient drove road which runs across flat land barely above sea level beside medieval Axbridge.

Just to the North, the Mendips stand steeply up from the plain to a height of over 200m, running westwards to where, at Brean Down, they peter out into the Bristol Channel. The two herds of mainly Aberdeen Angus beef cattle are all born and raised on the farm. They grow at their own pace; as a breed, they get plenty of protein from their natural feed, most of it home-grown.

Only in one respect do the two herds differ; one lives down on the moor, where relatively small fields are divided by rivers and ditches, while the other grazes the hills. From below, we could just make out the silhouetted forms of cattle up on the tops. They have immense space to roam, and woods and hollows for shelter. These upland cousins, less confined, are said to be the more contented.

But the animals I saw below, munching luscious hay in the shelter of a warm, dry, open barn and big yard, looked as if they appreciated the regime of a farmer who believes that it is good (for both cattle and customer) to treat each animal with dignity, and to follow natural rhythms and traditional ways.

webTitle: Spanish bishops 'soft on Eta'

fields.headline: Spanish bishops 'soft on Eta'
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: The Spanish deputy prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, accused the Roman Catholic bishops of going soft on terrorism and the Basque separatist group Eta yesterday.
fields.body:
The Spanish deputy prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, accused the Roman Catholic bishops of going soft on terrorism and the Basque separatist group Eta yesterday.

He was responding to their refusal to sign a pact against terrorist agreed by the main political parties.

"There is no room here for ambiguities or half-heartedness," he said.

Mr Rajoy, whose conservative Popular party is normally close to the church, said the vast majority of Catholics in Spain "demand a pronouncement".

The bishops' congress argued that it was unable to sign an essentially political document.

Privately, bishops recognise that the refusal to support the government's stance on terrorism is led by Basque bishops.

There is growing concern that sectors of the Basque church are not only ambiguous about Eta, which killed 23 people last year, but actively sympathised with its aims.

Mr Rajoy's criticism was endorsed by the opposition Socialist party and various newspapers, all of whom accused Basque bishops of being too nice to Eta.

"The Basque bishops try to maintain an impossible balance between those who kill and those who are killed," El Mundo said.

"The church has been practising politics for 2,000 years but, faced with the destruction of the social fabric of the Basque country, it has responded with empty words."

The Basque country is one of Spain's most intensely Catholic regions: the Jesuit order was founded there by St Ignatius of Loyola in the 16th century.

In Franco's time the church was the main defender of the Basque language, Euskara, and of Basque culture.

In the past Basque priests have been jailed for giving refuge to Eta gunmen.

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Cassandra Wilcox

fields.headline: No 1823
fields.standfirst: Cassandra Wilcox
fields.trailText: Cassandra Wilcox.
fields.body:
Age: 42

Appearance: Claws out, back arched.

Status: Aggrieved stepdaughter to a cruel and wicked stepmother.

Wow. A real-life Cinderella. Sort of. Except there doesn't look like there's going to be much of a happy ending.

Hmm. Inter-family disputes. It's good to get these things out in the open. Why don't they talk it out on one of those daytime chat shows, like Esther? Not entirely appropriate.

Why ever not? Esther is the wicked stepmother.

Oh. Still, I'm sure they can sort it out amicably in the privacy of their own homes. Not likely. They've been washing their dirty laundry and hanging it out to dry in the newspapers all week.

Do tell. When Rantzen published an extract of her forthcoming autobiography detailing the circumstances of husband Desmond Wilcox's recent death, there was a teaser promising the next extract would include "why I cannot forget the bitterness of Desmond's ex-wife".

So? Understandably the children of the late Patsy Wilcox were a little bit peeved by the promise of someone publicly dirt-dishing on their mum, so Cassandra fired back an article contesting the version put forward by the once "toothy, overweight brunette" presenter who redecorated the Wilcox family home from "floor to ceiling in chintz and Tiffany lamps".

Mee-ow. Cue extract number two in the weekend papers, adding fuel to the fire, and leading to the return of Cassandra in Monday's papers, condemning the "vituperative attack on my mother in order to gain financially and plug her book".

Jeez. Somebody call a family meeting. I'm afraid it's gone beyond that. Rantzen has now issued a statement saying: "I have no intention of disputing with my stepdaughter Cassie, though her recollections differ very profoundly from mine."

Memory does play the strangest of tricks. Ah well. That's life.

webTitle: Why do French people live longer?

fields.headline: Your very good 'ealth
fields.standfirst: Yesterday it emerged that the French will soon live longer than any other nation. So, asks  James Meek, what's their secret?
fields.trailText: Yesterday it emerged that the French will soon live longer than any other nation. So, asks James Meek, what's their secret?
fields.body:
In 1965, a French lawyer, André-François Raffray, took a gamble on statistics that was to cost him and his descendants dear. He acquired the flat of a 90-year-old woman, Jeanne Calment, agreeing to pay her a lifetime pension of 2,500 francs a month in exchange. It seemed reasonable to think Calment would die before him. After all, he was only 47.

But the decades flew past, and while the pensioner thrived, Raffray went into a sad decline. On Christmas Day 1995, aged 77, the notary died, having paid out three times the market value of the apartment. At her nursing home in Arles that day, Calment, aged 120, dined on chicken liver, roast duck and Yule log.

She would enjoy life for another two years before dying, the longest-lived human being whose age can be confirmed by reliable records. "I took pleasure when I could. I acted clearly and morally and without regret. I'm very lucky," she said.

Was it mere luck? Perhaps something else was at work. Calment was exceptional. But with a glass of red wine in one hand and a French health insurance card in the other, our neighbours appear to be dancing their way towards being the longest-lived nation on earth.

The French already run the Japanese close in terms of average life expectancy. At a conference in San Francisco at the weekend, a joint team of US and French researchers declared that, if recent trends in death rates continue, average life expectancy in France would reach 85 by 2033, two years ahead of Japan, well ahead of Britain and leaving the US one-and-a-half centuries behind.

It was a Bordeaux cardiologist, Serge Renaud, who coined the phrase "the French paradox" - pointing out that, despite eating a diet high in saturated fat, the French tended to live longer and had one of the lowest rates of coronary and cardiovascular disease in the industrialised world.

He put it down to wine. Two or three glasses a day, he said - with some heavy scientific data to back it up - acted as a cure-all, combating not just heart disease but cancer (although more than four glasses has the opposite effect).

It was a great boost to Gallic pride in France's civilised lifestyle, not to mention French wine exports. In the Anglo-Saxon world, burger-guzzlers and diet obsessives alike ground their teeth. McDonald's has so far resisted putting wine on the menu in Britain and the US, perhaps because it can't work out whether to market it as an iced drink or as a dip, but many of the world's most influential public health bodies now accept that a little wine does you good.

In Britain, we shouldn't be too hard on ourselves. No scientist has yet done with beer or whisky what Renaud did with wine - tracked the health of 34,000 middle-aged men, almost three-quarters of them regular wine drinkers, in eastern France over 12 to 15 years.

More to the point, the difference between the life expectancy of French men and men in England and Wales is now tiny. In 1998, it was 74.8 years for both. It is French women who are living longer. In 1998, they had a life expectancy of 82.4, compared to 79.7 for women in England and Wales.

Marjorie Marais, who grew up in Brittany and now works in publishing in London, says that the difference in drinking culture between the two societies is very marked - as much to do with rhythm as quantity. "The French drink a lot more regularly, in smaller quantities. In England, people binge a lot."

But it is not just about lifestyle choice. The French healthcare system, funded by compulsory insurance from individuals and employers, is better.

"Here, you might get a cervical smear once every three years," says Marais. "In France, you're encouraged to get a check-up every six months if you're sexually active. You might have to pay something like three pounds, depending on what cover you have. Any kind of test takes longer here because you have to go through your GP. If you've got a pain in a specific part of your body you can go straight to a specialist. You don't have to see a GP first."

Jacques Vallin, director of research at the Institut National D'Études Démographiques in Paris, is sceptical about some of the claims made for the "French paradox", pointing to statistical discrepancies in, for instance, different ways of recording deaths in different countries.

Statistics appear to show higher death rates from alcohol-related disease in the north of France than the south, he says, despite the fact that surveys showed the south drank more. The reason is that there is a stigma attached to drinking in the north, so people are more likely to lie.

Vallin, too, points at improvements in the French health service as a reason for greater average longevity - such as better training and equipment to deal with cardiac emergencies.

But, at 59, Vallin isn't living up to the image that jealous English office-workers conjure up as they gnaw at their cold, limp tikka wraps. No two-hour, three-course lunch, conversing over a bottle or two of fine Bordeaux with friends. He had a quick lunch of courgettes and a bit of fish in the staff canteen. What, no wine? "No wine ... everything you eat is poison. So the best idea is to eat a very great variety of things. In France, we have quite diverse food, I think. If you go to the US, food is more and more the same for everybody, every day."

Average life expectancy is a blunt statistic. There are many wonders concealed within. It is true, if not immediately obvious, that the longer you live, the greater your chance of exceeding the average - particularly if you reach 65.

Another is the extraordinary rate at which the number of centenarians is increasing, in France and in Britain. In 1950, there were thought to be only about 200 people aged 100 or over in France. In 1998, there were 6,840; and by 2050 there could be 150,000 in France, and only slightly fewer in Britain.

It may be, of course, that today's British twenty- and thirtysomethings are doing enough to overtake France in the latter half of this century. It may be that ecstasy, overwork, binge drinking, video games, evening TV and daytime IT, nightclub dehydration, chips, vodka and cranberry juice, rain and mobile phone radiation is exactly the magic recipe required to push our average lifespan up. But I wouldn't bet my flat on it.

webTitle: Comment: Paul Foot on the Baghdad bombing

fields.headline: Conjuring up war criminals
fields.standfirst:
Blair's US links, the view from the right:
John Redwood: We haven't done enough

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: When is a war criminal to be bombed, and when is he to be subsidised? One answer comes this week as a result of the peculiar genius of President Bush and his lapdog in Downing Street.
fields.body:
When is a war criminal to be bombed, and when is he to be subsidised? One answer comes this week as a result of the peculiar genius of President Bush and his lapdog in Downing Street. Just as a war criminal, still soaked in the blood of Palestinians whose murders he engineered and authorised in Sabra and Shatila refugee camps nearly 20 years ago, gets elected as prime minister of Israel, so Bush turns the international spotlight on Saddam Hussein and subjects still more Iraqi civilians to another round of "routine" aggression.

Saddam, we are reminded, became a war criminal for the gassing of Kurds when US policy in the Middle East was based on unconditional support for him. Such grotesque contradictions pollute all US policy in the Middle East.

When Saddam invaded Kuwait in 1990, a vast array of military force was deployed under the banner of the United Nations to put a stop to such a blatant breach of international law. When Israeli forces invaded the West Bank, the Golan heights and East Jerusalem in 1967, seizing, occupying and exploiting whole tracts of other peoples' territory by force of arms; when the Israeli government refused to give up an acre of that territory as UN resolutions recommended it should; and when this blatant breach of international law was followed up with an equally illegal invasion of Lebanon in 1982, the reaction from the US was to step up aid to Israel, which gets far more money from the US government than any other country in the world.

The guiding moral principle of US policy in the Middle East is that war criminals from Israel should be subsidised by the US taxpayer while Arab war criminals should be punished only if and when they threaten the supply of cheap oil to the US.

A farcical glimpse of these contradictions came last week from the man who skilfully failed to secure peace in the Middle East: Bill Clinton. Clinton was on television angrily rebutting charges of corruption arising from his last-minute presidential pardon for the appropriately named Marc Rich, a "financier" who has been hiding in Switzerland for 17 years to escape federal charges of tax fraud in the US.

Bursting with indignation on the Geraldo Rivera chat show, Clinton made it absolutely clear that the pardon for Rich had nothing whatever to do with the fact that the fugitive's former wife Denise gave a million dollars to the Democratic party; nothing whatever to do with Mrs Rich's handsome donation to Hillary Clinton's campaign to become a New York senator; and absolutely nothing to do with the $450,000 Mrs Rich gave to the Clinton presidential library. None of these things influenced him one jot, said Honest Bill. "Now I'll tell you what did influence me," he added. "Israel influenced me profoundly."

His attitude to Mr Rich, so resolute in defiance of all those contributions to his party and his library, had been profoundly moved by a letter from Shabtai Shavit, the former head of the Israeli intelligence agency Mossad. Mr Shavit described the fugitive financier as "a fine and generous individual" who had "used his extensive network of contacts" all over the world to "produce results" for Mossad. What more persuasive argument could an ex-president with his back to the wall have deployed to sway US public opinion behind him? His party, his wife and his library may have been heavily subsidised by the Rich family, but his real motive in securing a pardon for Mr Rich was to spring to the aid of Mossad and Israel.

Anti-Arab, pro-Israel prejudice in the US is as powerful as ever, but in Britain, I would say, it is on the wane. webTitle: Cell calls put Boesak in jeopardy

fields.headline: Cell calls put Boesak in jeopardy
fields.trailText: The jailed South African cleric and anti-apartheid leader Allan Boesak faces new criminal charges after being caught calling a cabinet minister, a senior aide of President Thabo Mbeki, and his wife from prison, apparently on a stolen cell phone.
fields.body:
The jailed South African cleric and anti-apartheid leader Allan Boesak faces new criminal charges after being caught calling a cabinet minister, a senior aide of President Thabo Mbeki, and his wife from prison, apparently on a stolen cell phone.

He is likely to be charged with perjury for denying he used the phone.

Boesak was jailed last May for defrauding donors of tens of thousands of pounds meant for his Foundation for Peace and Justice, set up to help the victims of apartheid.

The transport minister, Dullah Omah, admitted speaking to him."I have great respect for Dr Boesak ... He is going through a difficult time and his friends must remain his friends," he said.

Records show that Boesak called the offices of the Rev Frank Chikane, director general of the presidency; the Archbishop of Cape Town, Njongonkulu Ndungane; the deputy home affairs minister; and a prominent judge. Mr Chikane's office denied receiving a call.

webTitle: Obituary: Charles Trenet

fields.headline: Charles Trenet
fields.standfirst: France's favourite chanson serenader
fields.trailText: Charles Trenet, who has died aged 87, was the most influential popular French songwriter of the mid-20th century.
fields.body:
Charles Trenet, who has died aged 87, was the most influential popular French songwriter of the mid-20th century. A performer of immense charm, with a light baritone voice of individual, caressing softness, he created - with his near-contemporaries Jean Sablon and Yves Montand - a style veering between wistful nostalgia and exuberant bravado that withstood the bombardment of American pop music for more than 30 years. His most famous song, La Mer (The Sea), sold more than 70m records after its release in 1946.

Trenet was born in Narbonne, where his early schooling took place; after his parents divorced, he was a boarder at the Institution de la Trinité at Béziers. He finished his studies at Perpignan, where his first efforts as a poet and painter were noticed by the poet Albert Bausil, editor of Le coq catalan. He encouraged Trenet to go to Paris, where he studied at the Académie des Arts Décoratives. He later worked as an assistant to the stage designer Jacques de Baroncelli.

At a student haunt, College Inn, in the rue Vavin in Montparnasse, the 20-year-old Trenet met the pianist Johnny Hess. Two years younger than Trenet, Hess came from Switzerland and had studied with Horowitz, but soon turned towards jazz, influenced by the music of Arthur Briggs and Django Reinhardt. The two became co-authors of a series of songs which they performed in cabaret as Charles et Johnny; at first, Trenet wrote the words and Hess the music, but later in his career, Trenet was sole author of all his material.

Charles et Johnny made their first recordings in January 1934 and, although they included some numbers by Cole Porter and Stéphane Grappelli, most of their duets were their own work - witty, cheeky songs that soon caught on, including Maman, ne vends pas la maison, Sous le lit de Lily, and one of Trenet's earliest solo successes, Rendezvous sous la pluie.

Trenet's facility with words and music soon brought commissions from established stage and recording artists. He wrote Y'a de la joie for Maurice Chevalier, and Vous qui passez sans me voir for Jean Sablon, while the as-yet-unkown Yves Montand made his debut in 1937 with Trenet's C'est la vie qui va.

Military service brought the Charles et Johnny duo to an end in 1936. The following year, Trenet began his career as a solo performer, adopting the outfit he wore on stage for the next 50 years or more - light blue, double-breasted suit, dark shirt and pale tie, a narrow-brimmed Fedora perched on the back of his head. Jean Cocteau drew a famous poster showing Trenet in this outfit, but equipped with angels' wings, floating in mid-air. With the songs Boum!, Je chante, La Polka du Roi, and Vous oubliez votre cheval, he established the quick-talk charm of his own tour-de-chant.

More than his light-hearted comedy songs, it was Trenet's romantic, nostalgic numbers that put him at the forefront of the chanson. Cocteau wrote that when Trenet sang, "He was so young, so fresh that the bar yielded to a rustic decor, the projectors became the stiff branches of a cherry tree, the microphone a hollyhock, the piano a cow."

During the Nazi occupation of France, Trenet continued to write and record, but, after performances at the Folies Bergère, refused to socialise with the German officers who made up almost all of his audiences. In 1943, Que reste-t-il de nos amours? - widely regarded as his greatest num ber - became a love song for the French, and for everyone who longed for the return of "ces beaux jours". After the war, even greater success came with La Mer, L'me des poètes, which De Gaulle once quoted in one of his speeches, Coin de rue and Mes jeunes années.

Trenet made several films, including La Route Enchantée and Adieu, Leonard, but he was essentially a man of the stage, with a rapport with the public that never deserted him. He celebrated his 80th birthday with a series of concerts at the Opéra Bastille.

Trenet never officially retired. In his 80s, he could still fill the huge concert hall of the Palais des Congrés in Paris. He outlived virtually all his contemporaries - Piaf, Brel, Ferré and Montand - to become a national monument, the most successful and best-loved chanteur of the age. In 1995, he brought out a CD, Fais ta vie, with 12 new songs on it.

Although he lived in Aix-en-Provence, Colette referred to him as "the provincial genius who gives lessons in happiness to Paris". Trenet's songs about it - Ménilmontant, La Romance de Paris (the title song of Jean Boyer's 1941 film) and Quartier Latin - remain among the best of the thousands of chansons serenading the pavements of that city.

 Peter Lennon writes: When you realise that the early 1940s was the period when Charles Trenet was "an immense star" in Paris, some uncomfortable questions are raised. The Folies Bergère and Gaieté Parisienne, where he starred, were some of the favourite haunts of the Wehrmacht. But, by June 1943, Jews were prohibited from performing on stage and banned from entering a theatre. Meanwhile, Trenet happily warbled Douce France and Stolen Kisses for a privileged audience.

When, in honour of his 80th birthday, Paris staged a three-day marathon, with 70 singers performing 200 of his songs, no one wanted to be reminded of the past of their favourite fou chantant (crazy singer). His wartime collaboration was dismissed as innocent and minor.

In fact, following the fall of France, the 26-year-old Trenet got himself demobbed on the grounds of being a "Farmer: Has to return to his land to plant potatoes" - a crucial occupation for Vichy France - and clandestinely headed straight back to recoup his fame in occupied Paris.

His biographer, Richard Cannavo, claimed that he "never compromised himself in any way". But, while Trenet never lent himself to blatant propaganda by appearing at fascist rallies, his behaviour was not so innocent. When Paris newspapers reported he was a Jew and the son of a rabbi, he produced four generations of his parish records to prove he had no Jewish blood. Later, his agent was said to carry Trenet's birth certificate when negotiating contracts.

Trenet was forgiven partly because of his psychological make-up and partly because show business could be regarded as the kindergarten of French politics, whose naughty inhabitants were to be indulged.

webTitle: Obituary: Monty Woodhouse

fields.headline: Monty Woodhouse
fields.standfirst: Classical scholar whose involvement with Greece embraced ancient and modern wars
fields.trailText: Classical scholar whose involvement with Greece embraced ancient and modern wars.
fields.body:
Lord Terrington of Huddersfield, better known as "Monty" Woodhouse, who has died aged 83, was a scholar, soldier and politician of unusual distinction. His intimate connection with wartime resistance forces in Greece, and with that country's later history and politics, spanned 60 years, and he was Conservative MP for Oxford for many years.

The second son of the Liberal peer Lord Terrington, Woodhouse was educated at Winchester and New College, Oxford, where one of his tutors was Isaiah Berlin. In 1939 he gained a double first in classics and a clutch of the most prestigious university prizes. He seemed destined for an academic career, and, on graduation, left for Greece to prepare for the All Souls fellowship examination. Unlike so many of those immersed from an early age in the study of classical Greek, he was intrigued rather than affronted by the fact that modern Athens bore little resemblance to the city of Pericles.

On the outbreak of the second world war, Woodhouse enlisted in the Royal Artillery, a choice determined by his prowess in mathematics. His knowledge of the modern Greek language made him an obvious candidate for attachment to the British military mission sent to Greece early in 1941 in the forlorn hope of stemming the threatened German invasion of the country.

After the withdrawal of British forces to Egypt, he was recruited into the Special Operations Executive (SOE) and spent a dispiriting few months in Crete in the winter of 1941-42, assisting in the evacuation of Commonwealth troops left behind in June 1941, in gathering intelligence and in assessing the prospects for resistance.

In the autumn of 1942, he was parachuted by SOE into mainland Greece as second-in-command of the Harling party, whose task was to disrupt the Thessaloniki-Athens railway line, an important supply route for Rommel's Afrika Korps. After a confused landing, the Harling commander, Brigadier Eddie Myers, ordered Woodhouse to make contact with Nap- oleon Zervas, the commander of the EDES resistance group in Epirus.

This Woodhouse accomplished after a prodigious feat of high-speed walking, sometimes for 15 hours at a stretch across rugged mountains. The Harling party, with the cooperation of units of the communist and non-communist resistance, blew up the Gorgopotamos railway viaduct on the night of November 24-25; it was one of the most spectacular wartime acts of resistance in occupied Europe.

From the outset, Myers and Woodhouse found themselves embroiled in the fraught politics of occupied Greece, and the tall and conspicuously un-Greek-looking Woodhouse, his gingerish hair and eyebrows dyed black, was infiltrated into Athens early in 1943 on an extremely hazardous mission to attempt to fathom these complexities.

When Myers was withdrawn from Greece in the summer of 1943, Woodhouse, promoted to the rank of full colonel at the age of 26, became commander of the allied military mission to the Greek resistance. In this ca pacity, he played a key role in negotiating a truce in the civil war that broke out between the communist and non-communist resistance groups in the winter of 1943-44.

On the liberation of the country in October 1944, Woodhouse, appalled that no room could be found for representatives of the resistance organisations, characteristically declined to take part in the victory parade organised by the British military authorities. For his service in Greece he received British (DSO and OBE), American (Legion of Merit) and Greek decorations, while the official historian of SOE described the team of Myers and Woodhouse as one of the most effective in the troubled, brief existence of that organisation. Soon after the war, Woodhouse wrote The Apple Of Discord, a profound analysis of this critical period in Greek history, in which his own central involvement is scarcely hinted at.

In the early 1950s, he briefly served in SIS (MI6). In this capacity he masterminded the critical initial stages of Operation Boot, the unimaginative codename for the overthrow of Mohammed Mossadeq, the Iranian politician bent on nationalising the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company. One of the more remarkable disclosures in Woodhouse's entertaining, self-deprecating autobiography, Something Ventured (1982), was the use of the BBC Persian Service to send coded messages to the Shah.

A not altogether happy four-year stint (1955-1959) as director-general of Chatham House followed. Woodhouse was also, for a time, chief editor of Penguin Books. In 1959 he was elected Conservative MP for Oxford, holding the seat until 1966, and again from 1970-1974. During his first term, he held junior ministerial office, latterly in the Home Office.

His second term coincided with the colonels' dictatorship in Greece. Whereas a good number of his parliamentary colleagues, from all parties, were only too eager to accept the junta's hospitality in the form of freebies dressed up as fact-finding missions, Woodhouse was always steadfast and outspoken in his opposition - a rare voice on the Conservative benches prepared to speak out against the idiocies of military dictatorship.

This was in part out of loyalty to his old resistance com rades and politician friends, many of whom were the victims of the colonels' brutal excesses. In part, too, it reflected that profound commitment to freedom and parliamentary democracy that had made Woodhouse such a formidable obstacle to the ambitions of the communist-controlled resistance in wartime Greece.

The loss of his parliamentary seat in 1974 meant more time for scholarship. In addition to studies of British foreign policy, and lives of Rhodes (with JG Lockhart) and Dostoevsky, he published a dozen books on different aspects of Greek history. This prodigious output ranged widely over the history of the Greek people from the fall of Constantinople to the present day.

Woodhouse's books included a study of the 15th-century philosopher Georgios Genistos Plethon; a number of works on the struggle for Greek independence in the early 19th century, including a monumental life of Count Ioannis Capodistrias, the first president of independent Greece; two major books on the troubled decade of the 1940s; a study of Greece under the colonels; and a life of Constantinos Karamanlis, the conservative Greek politician whom he so greatly admired. His last book, published in 1995, was a life of Rigas Velestiatis, the proto-martyr of Greek independence.

Shortly before his death, Woodhouse completed the formidable task of translating into English the 10-volume History Of The European Spirit, by his friend Panayiotis Kanellopoulos, a man who, like Woodhouse, combined the life of the mind with the world of politics.

It gave him particular pleasure that his study of Plethon, originally published by Oxford University Press, was republished last year by Sandpiper Books, prompting an invitation to Mistra, in the Peloponnese, where, in the dying days of the Byzantine empire, Plethon had called for a return to the pagan philosophies of the ancient world.

In 1945, Woodhouse married Davina, the widow of the 5th Earl of Erne. She died in 1995. He is survived by the two sons, Christopher and Nicholas, and the daughter, Emma, of the marriage, by one stepson and two stepdaughters. He became the 5th Lord Terrington on the death of his brother in 1998.

On the liberation of the country in October 1944, Woodhouse, appalled that no room could be found for representatives of the resistance organisations, characteristically declined to take part in the victory parade organised by the British military authorities. For his service in Greece he received British (DSO and OBE), American (Legion of Merit) and Greek decorations, while the official historian of SOE described the team of Myers and Woodhouse as one of the most effective in the troubled, brief existence of that organisation. Soon after the war, Woodhouse wrote The Apple Of Discord, a profound analysis of this critical period in Greek history, in which his own central involvement is scarcely hinted at. In the early 1950s, he briefly served in SIS (MI6). In this capacity he masterminded the critical initial stages of Operation Boot, the unimaginative codename for the overthrow of Mohammed Mossadeq, the Iranian politician bent on nationalising the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company. One of the more remarkable disclosures in Woodhouse's entertaining, self-deprecating autobiography, Something Ventured (1982), was the use of the BBC Persian Service to send coded messages to the Shah. A not altogether happy four-year stint (1955-1959) as director-general of Chatham House followed. Woodhouse was also, for a time, chief editor of Penguin Books. In 1959 he was elected Conservative MP for Oxford, holding the seat until 1966, and again from 1970-1974. During his first term, he held junior ministerial office, latterly in the Home Office. His second term coincided with the colonels' dictatorship in Greece. Whereas a good number of his parliamentary colleagues, from all parties, were only too eager to accept the junta's hospitality in the form of freebies dressed up as fact-finding missions, Woodhouse was always steadfast and outspoken in his opposition - a rare voice on the Conservative benches prepared to speak out against the idiocies of military dictatorship. This was in part out of loyalty to his old resistance com rades and politician friends, many of whom were the victims of the colonels' brutal excesses. In part, too, it reflected that profound commitment to freedom and parliamentary democracy that had made Woodhouse such a formidable obstacle to the ambitions of the communist-controlled resistance in wartime Greece. The loss of his parliamentary seat in 1974 meant more time for scholarship. In addition to studies of British foreign policy, and lives of Rhodes (with JG Lockhart) and Dostoevsky, he published a dozen books on different aspects of Greek history. This prodigious output ranged widely over the history of the Greek people from the fall of Constantinople to the present day. Woodhouse's books included a study of the 15th-century philosopher Georgios Genistos Plethon; a number of works on the struggle for Greek independence in the early 19th century, including a monumental life of Count Ioannis Capodistrias, the first president of independent Greece; two major books on the troubled decade of the 1940s; a study of Greece under the colonels; and a life of Constantinos Karamanlis, the conservative Greek politician whom he so greatly admired. His last book, published in 1995, was a life of Rigas Velestiatis, the proto-martyr of Greek independence. Shortly before his death, Woodhouse completed the formidable task of translating into English the 10-volume History Of The European Spirit, by his friend Panayiotis Kanellopoulos, a man who, like Woodhouse, combined the life of the mind with the world of politics. It gave him particular pleasure that his study of Plethon, originally published by Oxford University Press, was republished last year by Sandpiper Books, prompting an invitation to Mistra, in the Peloponnese, where, in the dying days of the Byzantine empire, Plethon had called for a return to the pagan philosophies of the ancient world. In 1945, Woodhouse married Davina, the widow of the 5th Earl of Erne. She died in 1995. He is survived by the two sons, Christopher and Nicholas, and the daughter, Emma, of the marriage, by one stepson and two stepdaughters. He became the 5th Lord Terrington on the death of his brother in 1998.  Christopher Montague 'Monty' Woodhouse, Lord Terrington of Huddersfield, scholar, soldier and politician, born May 11 1917; died February 13 2001.

webTitle: Fischer inquiry 'political' murder trial judge says

fields.headline: Fischer inquiry 'political' murder trial judge says
fields.trailText: The hard-pressed German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, received a big boost to his struggle for political survival yesterday when the Frankfurt regional chief justice suggested that the prosecutors investigating him were politically motivated and said their formal inquiry was "totally irregular".
fields.body:
The hard-pressed German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, received a big boost to his struggle for political survival yesterday when the Frankfurt regional chief justice suggested that the prosecutors investigating him were politically motivated and said their formal inquiry was "totally irregular".

"Whoever understands politics can see what is what," Judge Heinrich Gehrke said in a newspaper interview.

The formal investigation of complaints that Mr Fischer gave false testimony to a murder trial was opened as the minister prepared to meet the US secretary of state, Colin Powell, in Washington today.

At the same time the conservative daily Die Welt moved the affair into new territory by claiming that Mr Fischer could soon become dispensable in the eyes of the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder.

Mr Fischer's political fate is a key issue not just for Mr Schröder's coalition government but also for the debate on Europe's future, which Mr Fischer has helped to shape in recent months.

Last month Mr Fischer gave evidence in Judge Gehrke's court as a character witness in the trial of a friend from his radical youth, Hans-Joachim Klein.

Klein, who took part in the 1975 raid on an Opec meeting in Vienna in which three people were killed, was jailed for nine years last week for murder, attempted murder and hostage-taking.

Among the questions Mr Fischer was asked by the counsel prosecuting Klein was whether he had ever harboured a terrorist.

Judge Gehrke cut in to say that he was under no obligation to answer the question since it had no bearing on the case. But the foreign minister replied that he would happily do so, and dismissed the notion with a quip.

It later emerged that a member of the Red Army Faction, Margit Schiller, who was not wanted by police at the time, had stayed in the same house as Mr Fischer - a communal squat in Frankfurt divided into several flats.

Mr Fischer did not testify under oath, but in German law it is an offence to give intentionally unsworn evidence that is wrong or incomplete.

In an interview with the Financial Times Deutschland, Judge Gehrke said: "Fischer's testimony may perhaps have been wrong, but it would be hard to prove intention."

The occupant of the flat next door to Mr Fischer's, Barbara Köster, came forward yesterday to say, in another interview, with the leftwing Berlin daily Tageszeitung, that it was she who had put Ms Schiller up.

"I came home late and found Schiller sleeping in my bed," she said.

Mr Fischer has never tried to disown his radical past, but he has always insisted that he opposed the resort of some on the left in the 1970s to guerrilla methods. His version has been backed consistently by former terrorists.

Mr Fischer, a Green, has always been seen as crucial to the architecture of Germany's coalition government - an alliance between the Greens and Mr Schröder's Social Democrats.

But Die Welt argued that the performance of another Green, Renate Künast, who took over responsibility for the BSE crisis last month as agriculture minister, had provided Mr Schröder with a possible replacement as the cabinet's highest-ranking Green.

Poll results released yesterday suggested that most Germans do not believe that Mr Fischer should be under investigation.

Another survey published at the weekend by the news magazine Focus found that, while Mr Fischer's popularity and credibility had been dented by the affair, he remained the best-liked politician in Germany after the president, Johannes Rau.

webTitle: France mourns singer-songwriter, Trenet, dead at 87

fields.headline: Immortal Trenet finally bows out
fields.standfirst: France mourns singer-songwriter, dead at 87
fields.trailText: France was plunged into something like national mourning yesterday by the death of the singer-songwriter Charles Trenet, among the greatest of Gallic chansonnier
fields.body:
France was plunged into something like national mourning yesterday by the death of the singer-songwriter Charles Trenet, among the greatest of Gallic chansonnier

Radio stations tore up their schedules to celebrate the life and music of the man affectionately known as "the singing fool", who died peacefully early yesterday, aged 87.

The television news was devoted to him, and even the normally reserved Le Monde made his death its main story and published an eight-page supplement.

Politicians, writers, actors and musicians queued to pay homage to a man described by President Jacques Chirac as "a magician with words, and inventor of rhythms, one of those rare poets who give to an entire era its colour, its tunes, its atmosphere, and who nourishes its dreams".

The prime minister, Lionel Jospin, praised Trenet as someone who "led us to another world, to that secret garden where emotions are born".

The culture minister, Catherine Tasca, said Trenet "engraved in our hearts some of France's most unforgettable melodies".

Trenet's secretary, Georges El Assidi, said he died "quietly and gently", having decided to end the pain by refusing treatment after his second stroke in a week.

Among Trenet's best-known songs were the haunting classic La Mer (the Sea), which captured the sadness of France's defeat in 1940, and Douce France (Gentle France), a heart-wrenching tribute to his country written in 1943.

Born in Narbonne, southern France, the son of a public notary and amateur violinist, Trenet wrote his first song when he was 10 and gave his first public performance, in Paris, in 1933. His last album was released just two years ago, and his final stage shows were in November 1999.

Trenet was a flamboyant homosexual. Added to his penchant for swing and jazz and a large circle of Jewish friends, that ensured him a difficult war.

After the war, a mixture of classic Gallic charm and a genuine and highly original talent as a wordsmith assured him an extraordinary popularity. In the 1960s he returned to writing novels (he published six, the first in 1939), but his music was rediscovered in the 80s and 90s.

Singers such as Jacques Higelin and Alain Souchon, and even some of France's rap artists, have praised what the music historian Daniel Nevers called "the simplicity of his melodies, the well-chiselled lyrics of his songs, the utter timelessness of his talent."

fields.headline: US thanks
fields.trailText: Just a note to let you know that I much appreciate your articles on the US election (Inquiry into new claims of poll abuses, February 17). Our press seems to be intent upon acting as if our system worked, when most Americans know that it did not.
fields.body:
Just a note to let you know that I much appreciate your articles on the US election (Inquiry into new claims of poll abuses, February 17). Our press seems to be intent upon acting as if our system worked, when most Americans know that it did not. Please keep telling the truth about what happened here.
Jane Whitley
Charlotte, USA gogirl42@msn.com

 As an American and a Florida voter you have my thanks for publishing the real story behind election 2000. We feel betrayed and victims of a coup. Please continue to investigate and let the world know the truth.
Debra Scott Hierlmeier
Land O'Lakes, Florida
