webTitle: Women: Foreign prostitutes in Soho

fields.headline: Foreign bodies
fields.standfirst:
Was last week's swoop on prostitutes in Soho a mercy mission to free sex slaves - or was there another reason for the raids? Diane Taylor investigates

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Was last week's swoop on prostitutes in Soho a mercy mission to free sex slaves - or was there another reason for the raids? Diane Taylor investigates.
fields.body:
The flat in Soho's Frith Street has been empty for a few hours, since police and immigration officers marched in and pulled out Irina, a prostitute from Kosovo, while she was servicing a client. At the same time last Thursday, nearby flats were raided and another 32 immigrant sex workers arrested. None has been charged with any criminal offence but three Albanian women and one Thai woman have already been deported. The rest have all made asylum claims.

Judy, Irina's maid and an ex-Soho prostitute herself, witnessed her forced departure, handcuffed and in tears, and is upset at the way the raid was carried out. "It was police from the Clubs and Vice Unit who came and they are usually very good round here. They know all the girls and they leave us alone unless there's anyone underage working or a girl is being held against her will," she says.

Twenty-two of the women removed are Kosovan, the rest are Albanian, Moldovan, Iraqi, Thai, Russian and Belarussian. Police say the swoop - the biggest ever in the sex industry's internationally famous square mile - was the culmination of months of intelligence gathering, but Judy laughs at that. "They have known some of these girls for years because they visit us regularly to check that everything is OK. I don't think this raid was down to them, it's not their style. This was an immigration job."

Soho has always been about sex - reports of copulation for sale here date back to the 17th century - but it is only in the past four years that women from overseas have begun to appear on the scene in significant numbers. Now between 50 and 75% of sex workers in the area are from abroad and Judy is angry about the media spin that paints them as sex slaves trafficked into the UK kicking and screaming - "slave trade in vice girls" as London's Evening Standard newspaper put it.

"Yes, there have been one or two who were here against their will," Judy admits, "but by and large we got rid of the pimps for them, threatened we'd shop them to the police if they didn't clear off."

She will miss the women who have gone, she says. "Soho is quite small and everyone knows everyone. We all used to meet for breakfast and talk through our problems. It's not a perfect lifestyle here and I don't mean to make it sound cosier than it really is but we did all support each other. It was a bit like a little union really."

Judy says a lot of the women were asylum seekers, some with babies and young children. "They were starving while they waited for their vouchers to come through and, like Irina, they ended up here because they didn't know any other way to make money to feed themselves and their kids. They didn't have drug problems like some of the English girls - they didn't even drink - and they sent hundreds of pounds home to their families."

While there is evidence that hard-core traffickers who force refugee women into prostitution have gained a foothold in other European countries such as Germany, the women who were raided in Soho support Judy's assertion that they were not coerced. Yes, many of them paid a trafficker to smuggle them into the UK and, yes, most started to sell sex reluctantly because there were few other options open to them, but there is no hard evidence to support the sex slaves banner headlines. Nor is there much sign of their alleged slave masters - only women were seized in the raids.

It is unlikely a true picture will ever emerge of just how much or how little coercion was involved in bringing these women to Soho and the raids have put the police in a difficult position. The low-key approach previously adopted by the Metropolitan Police's Clubs and Vice Unit allowed its officers to gather intelligence about the circumstances of the foreign women in the Soho flats, and the women and their maids viewed the police with a degree of trust.

Scotland Yard admits this raid was not the usual "softly, softly" style of the Clubs and Vice Unit. But according to chief inspector Chris Bradford: "Any other predators out there realise that they [the prostitutes] haven't gone to the police, they've been deported by the police, so it gives them a cover story, a little bit of protection."

Carrie Mitchell of the English Collective of Prostitutes has little time for this explanation of the raids. "If the women are victims, then they need support and resources, not deportation," she says. "But the women are not working for pimps or traffickers; they have found a safer, more independent way of working. This crackdown will force many women out on to the streets, where evidence shows it's ten times as dangerous to work."

Michelle Farley of Sexual Health On Call, an agency that encourages prostitutes to look after their health and practise safe sex, is concerned that the women will now go further underground. "It has taken a long time for us to build up trust with some of these women, particularly the eastern European ones," she points out, "but in the past year they have been coming to the clinics. If they stop accessing healthcare, they put at risk not only themselves but also the men who use their services and the men's partners."

Julie Bindel is an academic from North London University who is researching trafficking. "These women are some of the most disenfranchised you're ever likely to meet," she says. "The occupational hazards of their job are rape, murder and HIV, and with no documents, they're not likely to walk into a police station and report any problems.

"I don't think the dramatic language about a modern-day slave trade is helpful. It obscures the real issues about why so many men are choosing to use foreign women for sex. We hear stories of women being trafficked from Romania to Cambodia because the men there want white women, and from Cambodia to Thailand because the men there want black women. These men want a woman who couldn't be their sister, daughter or mother because it dehumanises them."

Judy is changing the sheets on Irina's bed, ready for a new tenant. After the initial shock of the raids, it's business as usual and other prostitutes, keen to leave the street beat, have already clinched deals on every single one of the flats vacated by the women the police and immigration officers pulled out. "These flats have been used to sell sex for more than 50 years," Judy says, "and however many times the police raid them, there will always be new girls waiting to take their place."

Although business is still booming for her, she says she can't get out of her mind the women who have been removed. "I know a few of them have been released and have had to sign something to say that they won't come back to Soho, so they have gone to work at King's Cross. But it's horrible down there. Everything's crack and they'll have to find a dingy hotel room full of drug-users. I'm going to go down there and look for them and bring them back here, whatever piece of paper they've signed. I hope all those girls they have taken aren't suffering now. What I really want to know is just who this is going to help."

webTitle: Letters: More questions on Iraq

fields.headline: More questions on Iraq - and why MPs can't ask them
fields.trailText: My long-held belief that the Guardian readership is largely composed of intelligent, not sentimental, liberals will be challenged if yesterday's letters (February 19) on Iraq are representative.
fields.body:
My long-held belief that the Guardian readership is largely composed of intelligent, not sentimental, liberals will be challenged if yesterday's letters (February 19) on Iraq are representative. The situation on the ground is indisputably hideous and the reformulation of policies is long overdue. Nevertheless, Saddam Hussein remains a calculating and unscrupulous dictator to whom normal diplomatic representations would be utterly futile.

While civilian casualties are a ghastly cost of allied operations, perhaps the alternative costs - which would also be borne by civilians - should be given due consideration before we erupt in a lather of righteous indignation. I suspect that these are the same voices who despair about the plight of other oppressed peoples (in East Timor, Chechnya and Tibet, for example) while countries like Britain stand idly by.
Morgan Thomas
Wembley, Middx mpthomas@tinyworld.co.uk

 What about some concern for the 180,000 Iraqi Kurds killed by Saddam's men in 1987-88, or the 250,000 Iraqis who still suffer from the result of chemical attacks on civilians by the regime; or the 50,000 (some estimates suggest 250,000) Iraqis killed by the Iraqi military when they crushed the uprising against Saddam in 1991 (the Iraqi intifada)?
Clive Furness
London

 The no-fly zone in the south of Iraq is to protect the Shiite minority from the "aggression of the Iraqi government". The so-called Shiite, constitute 60% of Iraq and live in Baghdad, the centre and the south of that country.

From my frequent visits to Iraq and to the south, where I was born, I can safely say the people of Iraq, including those in the south, look to their government to provide them with law and order, food rations, medical and other services. You can ask anybody in the south or north of the country (barring the Kurdish area) what are their main concerns, and they will tell you: sanctions and the dropping of bombs from British and US warplanes.
Ali Al Mosawi
Henley-on-Thames, Oxon

If 50 or more MPs contact your paper requesting such action, maybe the "Guardian Amendment" will be taken seriously by the government.

Derek Wyatt MP
wyattd@parliament.uk

fields.bodyText: My long-held belief that the Guardian readership is largely composed of intelligent, not sentimental, liberals will be challenged if yesterday's letters (February 19) on Iraq are representative. The situation on the ground is indisputably hideous and the reformulation of policies is long overdue. Nevertheless, Saddam Hussein remains a calculating and unscrupulous dictator to whom normal diplomatic representations would be utterly futile. While civilian casualties are a ghastly cost of allied operations, perhaps the alternative costs - which would also be borne by civilians - should be given due consideration before we erupt in a lather of righteous indignation. I suspect that these are the same voices who despair about the plight of other oppressed peoples (in East Timor, Chechnya and Tibet, for example) while countries like Britain stand idly by. webTitle: Letters: In praise of togs and toffs

fields.headline: In praise of togs and toffs
fields.trailText: What is happening to your fashion coverage? First the Paris reports include pictures of couture garments reminiscent of Vogue in the 50s, now the Style section (The almost famous five, February 19) prints drawings which show the designers' intentions.
fields.body:
What is happening to your fashion coverage? First the Paris reports include pictures of couture garments reminiscent of Vogue in the 50s, now the Style section (The almost famous five, February 19) prints drawings which show the designers' intentions.

If you carry on like this, young photographers will be driven to despair. How can they distinguish themselves from those who work for the mail-order catalogues unless they are allowed to photograph young women folded up into bizarre positions in lighting which conceals every detail except the model's profile or décolleté?

This must stop or one reader at least will be seized with a cardiac condition known as "lifting of the heart", a delight in fashion unsuited to her age and figure but very welcome.
Margaret Baker
Brentwood, Essex

 The Lady Victoria Hervey interview (Toff at the top, February 19) should have been run with an anti-monarchy poll - see it ping off the swingometer! No long, drawn-out debates about tradition; you have your answer in that interview. You can just imagine the nobility packing their bags saying "its a fair cop guv'!"

Got anymore toff interviews lined up? Hope so, it means I won't have to creep out after dark for a copy of Class War to quench my thirst for laughing at inbred parasites.
Lizzie O'Grady
London ogrady@barclays.net

webTitle: Harsh winter threatens rare Russian leopard

fields.headline: Harsh winter threatens rare Russian leopard
fields.standfirst: Frozen out
fields.trailText: Russian wildlife experts are concerned that the tiny surviving population of the Amur leopard - one of the world's most endangered species - may be devastated by the harshest winter to hit the country's far east for 70 years.
fields.body:
Russian wildlife experts are concerned that the tiny surviving population of the Amur leopard - one of the world's most endangered species - may be devastated by the harshest winter to hit the country's far east for 70 years.

They fear that there are no more than 25 or 30 of the subspecies left, most of them in the forests around Vladivostok.

Local protection groups say it is in immediate danger of extinction.

The leopard has evolved to cope with the Russian winter: it has long legs to help it walk through the snow and a reddish-yellow coat which grows 7cm thick towards the end of autumn. But experts are afraid that the surviving few may starve because huge numbers of deer, hares and badgers, on which it feeds, died when the temperature dropped to minus 60C.

Intense poverty on Russia's eastern flank has hampered protection efforts. Despite anti-poaching campaigns local hunters persist in killing both the leopard and the threatened Amur tiger.

The Amur skin, with its distinctive colour and unusually large spots, is coveted by international fur traders. The skeleton is smuggled across the Chinese border for use in traditional medicines.

Although the law prescribes strict penalties for killing leopards, prosecutions are rare. Local judges appear to sympathise with the hunters, who see the leopard as an expensive threat to the livestock on which they depend.

The region is also becoming popular with rich Russians as a venue for licensed hunting. Even killing permitted animals like boar threatens the leopard by reducing its food supplies.

A UN Development Programme project to cultivate the nearby Tymangan basin as a commercial centre has caused alarm, because it would further diminish the dwindling strip of land where the surviving leopards live.

"This is the biggest and most beautiful of all leopards, but the situation it is in at the moment is catastrophic," said Maria Vorontsova, of the International Fund for Animal Welfare, which sponsors an anti-poaching project.

webTitle: Letters: Shopping for bodies

fields.headline: Shopping for bodies
fields.trailText: Having only just returned from Nicaragua, where I met with workers from the giant maquilla or clothing assembly companies operating in Managua's free trade zone, I read your article on worldwide labour standards (Cheap labour, ruined lives, February 16) with particular interest.
fields.body:
Having only just returned from Nicaragua, where I met with workers from the giant maquilla or clothing assembly companies operating in Managua's free trade zone, I read your article on worldwide labour standards (Cheap labour, ruined lives, February 16) with particular interest.

It's true that neither they nor I want to see those companies closed down completely or precious jobs lost in a country with near 60% unemployment. What we do want is that the tens of thousands of workers who pour into the free trade zone each morning receive a decent, living wage and have their rights as human beings and employees respected.

The alleged picket "in favour of free trade" was not a voluntary protest but a carefully orchestrated piece of propaganda by the maquilla company owners. Workers were ordered to go on the march - if they didn't they were threatened with docked wages and attendance bonuses, and even the sack.

Independent experts calculate that a basic living wage in Nicaragua would be about $190 a month. Workers in the giant clothing sweatshops are lucky to make $140 a month. I've seen the homes they live in - mud-floored shacks with no sanitation or direct access to running water. Paid less than 20 cents for every pair of jeans exported (and sold in the US for $30 or more) Nicaraguan workers are exploited as little more than slave labour. When union reps sought to negotiate an 8-cent increase, they and hundreds of other workers were sacked.

Consumers in the north must look behind the label and demand that retailers pay decent living wages to the many hands that they ultimately profit from. It would be naive and an insult to the brave trade unionists that I met to believe that companies operating in the free trade zone will reform without media and public pressure.
Anita Roddick
Founder, The Body Shop

 Charlotte Denny's argument that imposing labour standards can backfire on the people they are meant to help ignores basic facts. Through their membership of the International Labour Organisation, developing countries commit themselves to its core principles. However, many do not enforce these very basic labour standards and are discouraged from doing so by the World Bank, supported by western governments.

Trade unionists in developing countries are fighting for better labour standards for all workers, whether in the formal or informal sectors. Finding a job does provide a route away from poverty for many. However, this does not mean that people want to work in dangerous conditions. All workers want a fair wage in return for their labour.

Charlotte Denny asks how minimum standards can be enforced. The answer is for all governments to adopt a "zero tolerance" policy towards employers who break the law, exploit poor workers and prevent them organising themselves into unions.
Annie Watson
Director, Commonwealth Trade Union Council
anniewatson@supanet.com

 Paul Collier, research director of the World Bank's development economics department, expresses his concern that OECD governments reduced official aid to Africa during the 90s (Cuts in OECD aid condemn African poor, February 16). His concern for official aid is accompanied by neoliberal convictions on foreign direct investment.

At a conference in Bradford in 1997 he claimed that "African governments must do the unthinkable, the politically and socially unacceptable, in order to attract foreign direct investment" and that "foreign direct investment in Africa must wait until the labour market tightens in China".
David Alexander
Anstruther, Fife
david@djalexander.fsnet.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Safety must come first

fields.headline: Safety must come first
fields.trailText: Your story (Safety team vetoes leading air traffic bid, February 15) gives a stark warning of the dangers of selling a controlling shareholding in national air traffic services to the highest bidder.
fields.body:
Your story (Safety team vetoes leading air traffic bid, February 15) gives a stark warning of the dangers of selling a controlling shareholding in national air traffic services to the highest bidder.

The new Transport Act commits the secretary of state to "exercise his functions so as to maintain a high standard of safety in the provision of air traffic services", over all other considerations. Ministers assured both houses that air safety was paramount.

Your report that the Nimbus/Serco consortium, the highest bidder, may make 1,200 maintenance staff redundant and use sub-contractors, illustrates the conflicts in putting a vital public service up for auction: to pay more, bidders have to cut more.

When the transport minister reports back to the House of Lords next month, Liberal Democrats will insist that he accepts the safest, not the highest, bid. And is it too late for the government to see the risks of its unnecessary Airtrack in the sky?
Matthew Oakeshott, Susan Thomas
House of Lords

 The internal Labour politics over privatising London's tube system are a little complicated (Leader, February 17), however, the big picture is very clear. Labour is still determined to force through privatisation of our tube system, despite all the warnings from the disastrous Tory privatisation of our railways.

In doing this, Labour is ignoring warnings from the national audit office that its sums are too complicated and the heath and safety executive over the safety risks of privatisation.
Lynne Featherstone
Lib Dem GLA transport spokesperson
l_featherstone@cix.compulink.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Some things to come

fields.headline: Some things to come
fields.trailText: Clare McManus is wrong (Letters, February 16). She is not a "bog standard mum". I know. I am married to her.
fields.body:
Clare McManus is wrong (Letters, February 16). She is not a "bog standard mum". I know. I am married to her. Like Trevor Phillips (Comment, February 17), we knew all about outside toilets. And we were the only kids on our respective streets to pass the 11-plus. Selection into different schools by whatever means and by whatever percentages is divisive, isolating and wasteful.
Paul Nicholas
Worksop, Notts

 Is it fair to assume that if my school decides to specialise in the study of language and syntax Messrs Blair and Blunkett will allow it to be known as a grammar school?
George Steel
Liverpool

 Lyons Corner Houses may be no more, but Hywel Williams (Comment, February 16) is wrong to suggest the music of Sir Arthur Bliss is "defunct". New recordings of his music, which retains a startling vibrancy and freshness, appear frequently and his score for the film Things to Come is widely acknowledged as one of the finest of that genre. How sad that concert promoters do so little to celebrate such important British composers.
Christopher Ellicott
Trinity College of Music

 Until reading Friday's Review (February 16) I had never heard of the song Strange Fruit. By bedtime I had - in the soundtrack to the BBC2 Timewatch programme on the German invasion of Crete in 1941. An astonishing coincidence?
David Nelson
Dunfermline

 Presumably, those Tories calling for an 80mph limit on motorways because the present limit is "widely discredited and ignored" (Politics, February 16) will also be supporting the legalisation of cannabis on the same basis.
Anthony Purcell
Chelmsford, Essex

webTitle: Leader: nobody knows what to do about Mugabe

fields.headline: Making a mockery
fields.standfirst:
Nobody knows what to do about Mugabe

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The expulsion orders issued against two foreign correspondents working in Zimbabwe and expected moves to force all others to leave the country are just the latest in a long string of depredations wrought by Robert Mugabe.
fields.body:
The expulsion orders issued against two foreign correspondents working in Zimbabwe and expected moves to force all others to leave the country are just the latest in a long string of depredations wrought by Robert Mugabe.

After terrorising the farming community, intimidating the opposition and fiddling last summer's general election, Mr Mugabe is now focusing on his own presidential re-election bid. His "campaign" to date has included attempts to trump up criminal charges against Morgan Tsvangirai, the Movement for Democratic Change's leader and his main rival, thereby disbarring his candidacy; the forced resignation of senior judges who challenged his diktats; renewed rampages by thugs given free rein by Zanu-PF; and efforts to muzzle the domestic media.

Somebody blew up the printing presses of the Harare Daily News last month. Perhaps Mr Mugabe might care to say what progress has been made in identifying the person who ordered this attack?

Perhaps not. Mr Mugabe believes himself to be above the law. He is no more interested in impartial justice than he is in bringing peace to Congo or reversing the calamitous fall in living standards that has made paupers of his people. He appears concerned only with personal power and to that end will do all he can, including calling a snap election to perpetuate his Lear-like misrule.

What is to be done? Comradely persuasion, the preferred approach of South Africa's Thabo Mbeki, has failed. Some people believe Mr Mugabe is mad and thus beyond the reach of reasoned argument; others that obsessed with his founding father status, he has forgotten that leadership is a responsibility, not a right. The freezing of IMF-World Bank support and other such sanctions has not modified his behaviour; tougher measures, like cutting South Africa's electricity supply subsidies, would hurt ordinary Zimbabweans most.

There is no safe prospect of a "people's power" revolt while the army and police remain firmly in Mr Mugabe's pocket. Outside military intervention is not an option. In London, the government expresses "extreme concern"; the UN woefully wrings its hands. Last May, Commonwealth ministers demanded Mr Mugabe uphold democratic rights. He ignored them then and he will again now. Big bad Bob, aged 77 this week and still going strong, scorns such impotence and through his unchecked excesses makes all the world his victim.

fields.headline: US threat to punish Zimbabwe as Mugabe steps up repression
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The United States says it is looking for new ways to punish Robert Mugabe following government threats to the lives of Zimbabwe's leading judges and the expulsion of two foreign journalists, including a BBC correspondent.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  in Harare  and Chris McGreal
fields.body:
The United States says it is looking for new ways to punish Robert Mugabe following government threats to the lives of Zimbabwe's leading judges and the expulsion of two foreign journalists, including a BBC correspondent.

Washington said it was consulting key allies, including Britain, to coordinate measures to get the government to halt its increasingly violent campaign against opponents and what appear to be the first steps toward barring the opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, from running for president on trumped up charges of inciting revolution.

The US has already cut a large proportion of its aid since Mr Mugabe encouraged supporters to occupy white-owned farms and ignored his supreme court's ruling that the land invasions were illegal.

Britain joined in the international condemnation of the expulsion orders issued against a BBC reporter, Joseph Winter, and Mercedes Sayagues, a reporter for the Guardian's sister paper in South Africa, the Mail and Guardian. Zimbabwe's high commissioner, Simbarashe Mumbengegwi, was called to the Foreign Office to hear a minister, Brian Wilson, protest at the expulsions, the harassment of judges, and the recent bombing that wrecked the presses of Harare's Daily News.

"A free press and independent judiciary are essential parts of any democratic society," Mr Wilson said." Expelling journalists cannot prevent the world from seeing what is happening in Zimbabwe or anywhere else."

President Mugabe's reaction to such protests came in an address to foreign diplomats assembled at State House in Harare: "We are still the subject of malicious propaganda by external forces opposed to the land reform programme," he told them. "This is affecting our image abroad."

Mr Winter flew to Johannesburg yesterday after a raid on his home late Sunday night by men presumed to be government supporters forced him and his family to seek shelter at the British high commission.

He and Ms Sayagues had won a high court order letting them stay until the end of the week to settle their affairs, but the BBC correspondent said he had decided to leave quickly, fearing for his wife and two-year-old daughter: "There is just too much pressure and harassment, and it's not fair for them to go through it."

The information minister, Jonathan Moyo, who ordered the reporters out, refused to accept the extension and said he did not recognise the court's authority.

He has hinted that all foreign journalists will have to leave before long. But confusingly, a senior BBC TV reporter and camera team from Johannesburg were allowed into Zimbabwe yesterday and given accreditation "until new regulations come into force".

The information minister faces problems of his own: the Ford Foundation filed a lawsuit in Nairobi yesterday accusing him of embezzling $80,000 (then worth £51,600) when he worked for the charity for four years up to 1997.

Mr Moyo, who described the charges as "scurrilous accusations", says he in turn is suing the Ford Foundation, accusing it of "misrepresenting a research project" in which he participated.

In a further move to intimidate or drive out white Zimbabweans, the government says it will tighten laws barring dual citizenship. About 20,000 people in Zimbabwe are believed to hold British passports. Many also hold Zimbabwean citizenship without revealing their British status to the Harare administration.

The current law technically bars dual citizenship, but the supreme court has ruled this impractical because no provision was made for renunciation of citizenship.

The new laws are also going to strip anyone who remains out of the country for five years of their Zimbabwean nationality. "There are concerns that those with dual citizenship are behind efforts to discredit the government," an official said.

webTitle: Glaciers melting because of global warming

fields.headline: Glaciers melting because of global warming
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The glaciers of Mount Kilimanjaro in east Africa and the Andes of Peru are melting so fast that they could disappear within 10 to 20 years.
fields.body:
The glaciers of Mount Kilimanjaro in east Africa and the Andes of Peru are melting so fast that they could disappear within 10 to 20 years.

The news follows other warnings that the Arctic ice field is both shrinking in area and thinning in depth. A glacier in Antarctica has also retreated dramatically in the past decade.

Now, according to Lonnie Thompson of Ohio State University, the Quelccaya glacier in Peru has retreated 32 times faster in the past two years than in the 20 years from 1963 to 1983. Kilimanjaro's ice fields have retreated by at least 80% since 1912. The icecap of Mount Kenya has shrunk by 40% since 1963. In 1972, in Venezuela, there were six glaciers; now there are only two. They too will melt within a decade.

"As a result of global warming, many tropical glaciers around the globe may disappear completely by 2020," Professor Thompson told the American Association. "Apart from the dramatic impact on local communities it is also a potent sign that the Earth is undergoing enormous changes."

Prof Thompson and his colleagues spent two decades studying ice cores in South America, China, Africa and Tibet, analysing the air trapped in the ice to build a history of climate change.

"These glaciers are very much like the canaries once used in coal mines," he said. "They are an indicator of massive changes taking place and a response to the changes in climate in the tropics."

webTitle: 'Reign of terror' vicar escapes jail

fields.headline: 'Reign of terror' vicar escapes jail
fields.trailText: A vicar who bullied, kicked and even used a fork to stab his two teenage daughters yesterday received a nine-month prison sentence, suspended for two years, after a court heard that his short temper and misery at the death of his wife had left him ill-equipped to be a single parent.
fields.body:
A vicar who bullied, kicked and even used a fork to stab his two teenage daughters yesterday received a nine-month prison sentence, suspended for two years, after a court heard that his short temper and misery at the death of his wife had left him ill-equipped to be a single parent.

Sidney Riley, 57, former priest in charge of St Paul's church at Morley, West Yorkshire, apologised and expressed his shame to Leeds crown court after listening from the dock to a three-year catalogue of abuse.

He admitted slapping and punching his two daughters Elizabeth and Pauline, listening to their phone calls, reading their post, and making them beg him for pocket money.

Neither daughter has contacted him since formal complaints were made in 1999, it was stated. But Elizabeth, now 21 and a nursery nurse, was in court to hear how he had hit her over the head with a plate for telling a joke and flung her across the room when she interrupted him.

David Gordon, prosecuting, said Riley had challenged her and Pauline, now a 20-year-old student, to phone Childline, telling them no one would believe their word against a vicar's and that he would say "they were just naughty girls".

He had stamped on their bare feet, kicked their shins with metal-capped boots and hit them with a cheeseboard, as well as a table knife and a home-made cosh.

"The defendant had a purse that he would keep loose change in for housekeeping," said Mr Gordon. "Both girls complained that he used this to strike them on their heads when he was annoyed."

Riley sat with head bowed for sentencing after pleading guilty at an earlier hearing to two charges of actual bodily harm and nine of common assault.

The court heard he had first lost control when his daughters were 11 and 12, but the "reign of terror" had taken place between 1991 and 1994, when the girls were in their mid-teens. He was described as having old-fashioned views on childcare, including the Victorian belief that children should be seen and not heard.

Derek Duffy, in mitigation, appealed for a non-custodial sentence to avoid further distress to the vicar's family. He said: "Mr Riley is ashamed and apologetic for what has taken place. It was not his intention to cause emotional and physical harm to his daughters."

Passing sentence, Judge Norman Jones QC said that the vicar had lacked the skill and temperament to deal with two teenage girls at a time when he also had to come to terms with the loss of his wife.

webTitle: Women: Sidelines

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: These becalmed nether days of early spring afford essential moments of reflection on life's great imponderables. Yorkshirewoman Ms J Blake has written to the New Scientist to pose the topical question: what happens to breasts in space?
fields.body:
 These becalmed nether days of early spring afford essential moments of reflection on life's great imponderables. Fresh from lengthy cogitations on the contemporary relevance of the Frankfurt School, historical materialism versus the hierarchy of needs, and whether it's ever right to tread on a cat, Sidelines is pleased to see that others are following suit.

Yorkshirewoman Ms J Blake has written to the New Scientist to pose the topical question: what happens to breasts in space? Fans of the Alien series will already be furnished with the answer: they look really good in a tight white vest, so long as you're Sigourney Weaver. However, space science adviser to the Royal Astronomical Society Peter Bond responds rather more scientifically: "Breasts would float up and rest horizontally at right angles to the chest." Which puts a whole new complexion on the benefits of space travel. We await with interest a suitably pneumatic, and right-angled, "Hello Martians" Gossard campaign.

 Another dilemma of brain-bleeding proportions has been tackled by the Royal Marines. Senior officers have banned training instructors from swearing when women recruits undertake the corps' commando course for the first time next month. This is mighty fortunate, since we all know that ladies' ears actually drop off whenever they hear rude words. Did you think those dangly earrings were just for decoration? They perform an essential function, secretly hingeing lady-ears to the head, lest a stray expletive cause an embarrassing public moult.

 Billie Piper was reportedly seen otherwise than upright over the weekend, having drunk a few half-pints with close friend Chris Evans. Piper is said to have laughed it off, saying she tripped over her handbag. The poor wee soul clearly has yet to learn that little glasses don't automatically mean little effect. It's the same sort of false consciousness that leads to the mistaken belief that coconut-based cocktails make you more attractive to koalas or that drinking Bailey's makes you better at pool. Remember: this sort of thing only happens in adverts.

webTitle: Illegal immigrants disrupting Channel tunnel services

fields.headline: Human tide 'holds up our trains'
fields.standfirst:
Eurotunnel demands help from British and French governments

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Eurotunnel demands help from British and French governments.
fields.body:
Eurotunnel called on the British and French governments yesterday to take action to stem the flow of illegal immigrants into Britain through the Channel tunnel, claiming that the numbers were disrupting journeys.

The company said that a "daily flow" of 150 asylum seekers from the French side was causing considerable delays and inconvenience to scheduled services. Numbers have been escalating since the beginning of the year.

Patrick Ponsolle, the outgoing chairman, said that after making "multiple and repeated efforts to prevent or limit the consequences of these intrusions," Eurotunnel had no option but to turn to the authorities in London and Paris.

Mr Ponsolle said: "We very much hope that the British and French authorities will themselves take the necessary measures to curtail this phenomenon as a matter of urgency."

In January, the Guardian disclosed that Eurotunnel was discreetly lobbying the government to change the system under which fines are imposed on transport companies found to be carrying asylum seekers.

The company has made approaches to immigration minister Barbara Roche as well as south coast MPs including the Conservative former home secretary, Michael Howard.

Yesterday a Eurotunnel spokesman said security measures had been tightened and £2m had been spent on improved inspection methods. Last year an estimated 5,500 people attempted to stow away on freight trains.

The refugees, many from Iraq, Iran and Afghanistan, wait at the Calais terminal for lorries to park. When detected, they are sent to a Red Cross holding centre at Sangatte, not far from the entrance to the Channel tunnel. Eurotunnel claims that they are "back again the next day".

Isnardo Gheza, Eurotunnel's customer services officer, said that security was so bad on the Brussels service that delays were frequent. "Sometimes the 'immigrants' do not leave the train and make a fuss so the service is stopped," he said.

He said that there were many problems on the Paris-Lille service because passenger numbers were always checked.

The French have agreed to a request from Tony Blair to allow more British immigration officials to operate on Eurostar trains from Paris to London Waterloo.

Mr Ponsolle, who has been chairman of the debt-laden company since 1994, will be leaving in April for a job in an unrelated sector. He will be succeeded by Charles Mackay, deputy chairman, while Philip Lazare will take day-to-day control as chief executive.

Full year operating losses have been reduced from £139m to £124m, mainly due to lower costs and a greater number of lorries using the shuttle. Higher prices and strong freight traffic growth helped fill the revenue vacuum left by the abolition of duty free sales.

Operating revenues in the year up to December 31 slipped 5% to £580m. Before interest charges, operating profits rose 2% to £208m, al though they fell by 2% after foreign exchange fluctuations.

Mr Ponsolle said that the results showed that within 18 months, the company had succeeded in compensating for the substantial loss of duty free sales. During the second half of the year, Eurotunnel also achieved more than 100% interest cover for the first time.

"For the first time, the tunnel is paying for the tunnel," Mr Ponsolle said. "Overall, our 2000 performance gives us confidence in our ability to meet the objective we set a year ago: to cover by 2002 not only our financial charges but also the capital investment costs from our operating cashflow."

Long term, he said, completion of the first stage of a Folkestone to London high-speed rail link, planned for 2003, should lift revenues.

"Growth in our shuttle revenues of 7% to 8%, together with stable operating costs, would be enough to generate double digit growth of operating profit."

webTitle: Nomura slaps damning 'sell' verdict on Autonomy

fields.headline: Nomura slaps damning 'sell' verdict on Autonomy
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Autonomy, the Cambridge-based software group, was yesterday uncharacteristically silent in the face of yet another damning verdict on its valuation from technology analysts.
fields.body:
Autonomy, the Cambridge-based software group, was yesterday uncharacteristically silent in the face of yet another damning verdict on its valuation from technology analysts.

Japanese investment bank Nomura has dropped its "hold" rating on the stock to "sell" - the latest in a string of attacks, which have left the City divided over the company's value.

Keith Woolcock, a senior analyst at Nomura, has issued a note outlining concerns that not only cast doubt on Autonomy's ambitions to achieve market dominance but go on to suggest the stock could be overvalued by as much as 20-30%.

To support a market capitalisation of £1.97bn, Mr Woolcock said Nomura "would need to feel confident that Autonomy's strategy of embedding its software in other developers' products could lead to market dominance". "We feel there is little chance of this happening."

Yesterday shares in Autonomy fell 11p to £15.15 as news of the critical note fed through to the market. Autonomy's usually outspoken chief executive Mike Lynch, who has launched a number of aggressive counter-attacks on critical research, declined to comment yesterday. A spokesman for the firm said: "Mike does not comment on opinion. Keith knows the company well and is entitled to his opinion."

The spokesman also pointed out that a number of other institutions, including UBS Warburg, Credit Suisse First Boston and SG Cowen, believe Auton omy to be well, or under-priced. Central to Mr Woolcock's doubts is the number and quality of the manufacturers signed up to incorporate Autonomy software in their products. He is sceptical as to whether such deals would even represent as much as 10% of Autonomy sales by the end of the year.

The company has 40 such arrangements with firms of varying size. However several of Autonomy's partners have issued profits warnings in recent months or are small, privately-owned businesses. Mr Woolcock said Autonomy needed to strike deals with the premier players in all its targeted sectors.

He also warned that, despite posting impressive pre-tax profits of $20.69m(£14.3m) this month, an over-valued Auton omy share price could suffer if major shareholders pull out as their "lock-up" agreements come to an end.

Criticism from Nomura comes on the heels of two well-publicised disputes between Autonomy and ABN Amro and Merrill Lynch after they criticised the FTSE-100 company. Autonomy's chief executive, Mike Lynch, issued a defensive trading statement last month dismissing ABN Amro claims that the company could be compared with Inktomi, a US software firm.

This month, Mr Lynch claimed a leaked internal document from Merrill Lynch, suggesting that a number of Autonomy staff had moved to Microsoft to develop rival products, were "completely untrue".

webTitle: Phrases that cloy the palate

fields.headline: Phrases that cloy the palate
fields.trailText: It is a cheeky little thesis for academic research but I think you will be amused by its presumption - wine critics have to go on pouring out new phrases to describe the contents of the same old bottles.
fields.body:
It is a cheeky little thesis for academic research but I think you will be amused by its presumption - wine critics have to go on pouring out new phrases to describe the contents of the same old bottles.

Adrienne Lehrer, who researched linguistics at the University of Arizona at Tucson, got interested in the words decanted about wine 20 years ago. Recently she went back to take a new look at how the language of the cellar and bodega had changed.

In 1983, she sipped from a vat of words that included attenuated and austere, clean and cloying, gassy and gay, meagre and mealy, piquant and plump, and even transcendental and twiggy.

When she returned, she told the American Association, she found she had to roll around in her mouth terms such as in-your-face, approachable, diplomatic and hedonistic, the meanings of which were not entirely obvious.

She also had to savour such adjectives as barnyard, reticent and intellectual, and words that described texture: among them, dense and coarse. Terms such as closed and open, backward and forward and even dumb and precocious, described a wine's age.

She also had to daintily spit out a suite of words to describe vinous structure. These included loose-knit, harmonious, gossamer-like and intense.

Ann Noble, professor of viticulture at the University of California Davis, thought such words unpalatable. "How offputting when people use words like blithe to describe wine. It is meaningless," she said.

But Dr Lehrer defended the pundits who quaff and then spill the purple prose. "They are pushing the language, they are making up metaphors."

Adrienne Lehrer, who researched linguistics at the University of Arizona at Tucson, got interested in the words decanted about wine 20 years ago. Recently she went back to take a new look at how the language of the cellar and bodega had changed. In 1983, she sipped from a vat of words that included attenuated and austere, clean and cloying, gassy and gay, meagre and mealy, piquant and plump, and even transcendental and twiggy. When she returned, she told the American Association, she found she had to roll around in her mouth terms such as in-your-face, approachable, diplomatic and hedonistic, the meanings of which were not entirely obvious. webTitle: High wind keeps shuttle Atlantis in orbit

fields.headline: High wind keeps shuttle Atlantis in orbit
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: For the second day in a row, gusts of nearly 25 mph forced space shuttle Atlantis and its astronauts to keep circling Earth yesterday instead of coming home.
fields.body:
For the second day in a row, gusts of nearly 25 mph forced space shuttle Atlantis and its astronauts to keep circling Earth yesterday instead of coming home.

The weather was no better at the backup landing site in southern California, so Mission Control ordered the crew to spend a 13th day in orbit and aim for a Tuesday afternoon touchdown.

"Bottom line is we're waving off for today," Mission Control told commander Kenneth Cockrell. "We do have three sites for tomorrow, all of them have a 'go' forecast at this time."

Atlantis and its crew of five undocked from the international space station on Friday, after delivering and installing the $1.4 billion Destiny laboratory, and should have returned to Earth on Sunday.

But the crosswind at the landing strip was well above the 17-mph safety limit, a situation that recurred on Monday. Not only that, thick clouds began moving in on Monday and Nasa worried they might bring rain.

The last time Cockrell flew in space, the mission dragged on for almost 18 days because of landing delays and turned out to be the longest shuttle flight ever. Atlantis astronaut Thomas Jones was also on that mission.

"The rest of the crew wanted me to pass on that I already have the endurance record," Cockrell joked to Mission Control as the weather deteriorated. "So there's no need to try for that this time."

Mission Control replied: "We'll do our best to get you back as well before you exceed that 18-day record you've already set."

Meteorologists expected good weather, finally, at the Kennedy Space Center on Tuesday. The other two options were Edwards Air Force Base in California and White Sands, New Mexico, as a last resort. A space shuttle has landed only once at White Sands, way back in 1982.

Atlantis has enough fuel and supplies to remain aloft until Wednesday and possibly even Thursday, according to Mission Control.

Until all the landing delays, the mission had gone off without a hitch to the pleasant surprise of both the astronauts and ground controllers.

The spectacular sunset launch on February 7 was followed by a flawless linkup with the space station two days later and the eventual installation of the Destiny laboratory. It took three spacewalks and the assistance of the both the shuttle and station crews to install the lab module.

webTitle: Kurds despair under west's leaky umbrella

fields.headline: Kurds despair under west's leaky umbrella
fields.standfirst:
The desperate flight of refugees from northern Iraq raises questions about the scope of US-British air patrols

Special report: the Kurds
Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: The 900 refugees whose ship was beached on the French Riviera at the weekend are the visible tip of a much larger exodus fleeing harassment by Saddam Hussein, Kurdish sources said yesterday.
fields.byline: Brian Whitaker and Jon Henley  in Paris
fields.body:
The 900 refugees whose ship was beached on the French Riviera at the weekend are the visible tip of a much larger exodus fleeing harassment by Saddam Hussein, Kurdish sources said yesterday.

"People are continuously fleeing," Mahmoud Osman, a Kurdish leader based in London said. "The arrival of the refugees in France should send a very strong message to Europe that as long as Saddam is there people will leave.

He added: "Every Kurd I know wants the no-fly zone in northern Iraq to stay, though at present it doesn't give adequate protection."

The 250 men, 180 women and 480 children who arrived in Fréjus on Saturday claim to come from the Mosul area of Iraq where they were protected, in theory, by British and American air patrols north of the 36th parallel.

The area, however, is just south and west of the territories controlled by two rival - and effectively autonomous - Kurdish factions, the Kurdish Democratic party (KDP) and the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK).

Salih Azad, a Kurdish speaker who was called in by the French government to interview the refugees, said they had fled because their village had been devastated.

"Many of them are house-owners and had had their property seized by Saddam because they are Kurds and Yazidites - in other words, not Muslim. They all thought they were heading for Italy.

"Some told me of throat-slittings and torture. They all say there is not enough to eat there. Even the babies are deprived of food. They could no longer live where they were."

Mr Azad, who himself came to France as a refugee, said they paid $300 (£210) to get to the Turkish border, and then $2,000 to $3,000 (£1,400 to £2,100) to be ferried out to the ship moored off a beach in eastern Turkey.

"This shows once more the desperate state of the Kurdish people. In northern Iraq, some 4,000 of their villages have been destroyed or are completely cut off from the rest of the country," he said.

The Kurdish areas of northern Iraq have long been in conflict with the Baghdad regime. In 1988 Saddam Hussein used chemical weapons to attack the Kurdish town of Halabjah, killing thousands of people.

In 1991, following the Gulf war, rebellions broke out in both northern and southern Iraq and many Kurds fled their homes in the north as Iraqi forces sought to reassert control.

UN security council resolution 688, passed in April 1991, called on Iraq to end repression of its civilian population, and the US declared a no-fly zone north of the 36th parallel to protect the KDP and PUK areas. Ground forces also gave temporary assistance to the Kurds under Operation Provide Comfort.

The no-fly zone covers only about two-thirds of the Kurdish areas, leaving large parts - such as Kirkuk - under Iraqi control on the ground. After 1991, the Baghdad government held on to the main oil fields around Kirkuk and Mosul and since then has pursued a policy of moving in Arab families from further south, displacing the resident, and unprotected, Kurds. Iraqi influence also penetrates the Kurdish areas which have autonomy.

"Iraqi spies come in and go out," Mr Osman said. "Relations between the Kurdish parties also allow infiltration, so the Iraqis are still active here and there. There are some skirmishes, but Saddam can't bring in his army or shell people with artillery as he did before."

Yesterday, the KDP said that gunmen with automatic weapons had killed Francois Hariri, a former governor of Irbil. Hariri, who was the KDP's governor until last year, was attacked in his car in the Kurdish-controlled city on Sunday, the party said. It was not clear if Iraqi forces were to blame.

If western air patrols provide incomplete protection they do, in the eyes of many Kurds, fulfil a useful role.

Last December, according to the Foreign Office, Iraqi troops surrounded the Kurdish village of Ba'edra, near Dohuk, but were driven back by the combined efforts of KDP fighters on the ground and US-British patrols in the air.

Many of the Kurdish refugees who make their way to Europe come, originally, from outside the protected area.

"Some are ousted from Kirkuk and the Arabised areas under Iraqi control," Mr Osman said. "But when they come to the so-called liberated areas they can't find homes or jobs. There is 85% unemployment in Kurdistan. These people, when they come out, want to stay in Europe and help their families."

The northern no-fly zone, officially known as Operation Northern Watch, is enforced from Incirlik air base in Turkey with about 45 US and British aircraft and more than 1,400 support personnel.

In the most recent incident, on February 12, Iraq fired at patrolling aircraft from sites north of Mosul. The western aircraft responded by attacking Iraq's air defence system. Amid international criticism of the no-fly zones following Friday's US-British attacks on radar stations around Baghdad, the arrival of so many Kurdish refugees has highlighted the other side of the argument.

A history of persecution

1988 Iraq conducts "Anfal" campaign against rebel Kurdish areas, culminating in a chemical weapon attack on town of Halabjah, killing at least 5,000

March-April 1991 Iraqi forces suppress rebellions in Kurdish north and Shi'ite south

April 1991 UN safe haven for Kurds created in northern Iraq, with no-fly zone established north of 36 degrees north

1996 Iraqi forces temporarily allowed into city of Irbil by KDP during fighting between rival Kurdish factions. Scores of anti-Saddam activists executed

1997 Operation Provide Comfort replaced by Operation Northern Watch

2000 Iraq resumes domestic passenger flights from Baghdad to Mosul

Foreign office Iraq briefings
Pentagon's no-fly zones operation
Voices in the Wilderness: UK anti-sanctions group
UN resolution establishing monitoring commission for Iraq, December 1999

webTitle: Sarah suspect in court

fields.headline: Sarah suspect in court
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The parents of Sarah Payne came face to face with the man accused of murdering their daughter for the first time yesterday.
fields.body:
The parents of Sarah Payne came face to face with the man accused of murdering their daughter for the first time yesterday.

Sara and Michael Payne sat just feet away from Roy William Whiting, 42, formerly of Littlehampton, who appeared for the second time at Lewes crown court charged with kidnapping and murdering Sarah last year. Judge Richard Brown adjourned the case until May 18.

Earlier Sarah's parents and grandparents, Terry and Lesley Payne, arrived at the East Sussex court. Inside the packed courtroom Sara Payne stared at Mr Whiting throughout the hearing.

Sue Lumbard, for the prosecution, said that due to the "nature and complexity of the case" it would take several weeks to serve papers on the defence.

The court was packed with family and friends of Sarah, many of whom were wearing badges bearing her picture and the words "For Sarah". Sarah, from Hersham, Surrey, disappeared near her grandparents' home in Kingston Gorse, West Sussex, on July 1 last year. Her body was found 16 days later.

webTitle: E-district suspends chief

fields.headline: E-district suspends chief
fields.standfirst:
Entertainment group admits user figures were overstated

More net news
fields.trailText: Entertainment group admits user figures were overstated.
fields.body:
Online entertainment group E-district.net suspended its founder and chief executive Steven Laitman yesterday after the discovery of "significantly" overstated revenues and user numbers.

The company, which raised £30m from an institutional placing on the stock market in March last year, admitted the alleged overstatements could pre-date the flotation. If the prospectus is found to have contained erroneous information, company auditor PricewaterhouseCoopers and sponsor West LB Panmure could both face legal action from investors.

The discovery of anomalies between advertising revenues and the company's stated figures was made by finance director Eddie Abrahams at the end of last week. Mr Laitman, who owns 44% of the company, was suspended on Sunday and the company's shares were frozen yesterday at 107.5p. They were offered at 195p at flotation.

The board is conducting an investigation with PWC and its lawyers, Osborne Clarke, and has not yet contacted any outside authorities. In a statement it said: "The board has reason to believe that the reported numbers for registered users, page impressions and revenues have been substantially overstated. It is not clear over what period of time this overstatement has occured but it could include all of 2000." The board was not aware of any misappropriation of funds.

The company's main business was LeisureDistrict, a network of websites that includes e-commerce, games and chat rooms. It claimed to have 3.4m registered users at the end of last year and 367m page impressions but the company said it now believes both figures had been inflated.

LeisureDistrict is also available as an interactive service on Telewest, Cable & Wireless and Bush internet TVs.

A spokesman said the future of the group was dependent upon the outcome of the investigation. It still has £12m in the bank and employs 40 staff.

webTitle: UK finally complies with rights convention

fields.headline: UK finally complies with rights convention
fields.standfirst:
The new Terrorism Act may conform to the European code and unify British legislation, but critics fear it could stifle legitimate protest

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: The new Terrorism Act may conform to the European code and unify British legislation, but critics fear it could stifle legitimate protest.
fields.body:
The government yesterday abandoned its 12-year-long refusal to comply with a European convention on human rights ban on holding terrorist suspects for days for interrogation without bringing them before a judge.

The government's controversial "derogation" from its obligations followed a ruling by the European court of human rights in Strasbourg that holding four suspected terrorists in Northern Ireland for terms ranging between four and nearly seven days without bringing them to court breached the convention. This was the only occasion on which the governement refused to comply with the convention.

The convention's rarely used article 15 allows countries bound by it to take measures derogating from their obligations "in time of war or other public emergency threatening the life of the nation". The measures must be only those "strictly required by the exigencies of the situation". Only a handful of countries bound by the convention have ever invoked article 15.

The withdrawal of the derogation coincides with the implementation yesterday of the Terrorism Act. This includes new measures under which a judge must be asked to authorise the detention of a terrorist suspect after 48 hours. It amounts to an acknowledgment by the government that the Troubles in Northern Ireland no longer count as a public emergency threatening the life of the nation.

Andrew Carter, Britain's ambassador to the Council of Europe which enforces the convention, yesterday presented papers formally withdrawing the derogation at the council's headquarters in Strasbourg.

The Terrorism Act will operate throughout the UK, replacing separate temporary anti-terrorist legislation for Britain and for Northern Ireland which had to be renewed each year.

For the first time the law will target groups using Britain as a base for terrorist acts abroad. Radical Islamic groups such as Hamas and Hezbollah could be outlawed. Cyber-terrorists who hack into computers to undermine governments or threaten lives are also targeted.

The act allows ministers to add groups to a list of proscribed organisations, which currently includes Irish groups such as the IRA and the Ulster Volunteer Force.

Groups which could be banned include the Tamil Tigers, Kurdistan People's Party (PKK) and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad. Once an organisation is on the list, it will be illegal to be a member, support it financially, display its emblems or share a platform with a member at a meeting of three or more people.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, said the new legislation strengthened civil liberties as well as increasing police powers to clamp down on terrorism.

"This act strengthens the powers of the police and other enforcement agencies in the fight against terrorism, and is fully consistent with our obligations under the Human Rights Act," he said.

The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, said his party had serious reservations about some parts of the legislation. Most worrying was the wide definition of terrorism, which he believed could easily be used to stifle legitimate protest.

"If you are a trade union leader calling for a strike at a hospital you would effectively be caught by the legislation," he said.

The leader of the Muslim parliament, Ghayasauddin Siddiqui, said many British Asians would feel intimidated by the new laws.

There had to be a distinction drawn between freedom fighters and terrorists so that people could feel sure they would not be intimidated for acting to end human rights abuses, he said.

The new laws were welcomed by Conservative MP Nigel Waterson, who said his anti-terrorism bill had been blocked by Labour when in opposition.

He said his private member's bill contained some of the same measures which become law today.

webTitle: Inside world's most bizarre prison

fields.headline: Inside world's most bizarre prison
fields.standfirst: Freedom for thousands of hostages seized by inmates at jail where you can 'marry' a transvestite cellmate, appear on TV or make a record
fields.trailText: Armed police last night ended the largest uprising in Brazilian penal history when they persuaded inmates at Carandiru prison, one of the most bizarre and unruly jails in the world, to release thousands of hostages, including hundreds of children.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Armed police last night ended the largest uprising in Brazilian penal history when they persuaded inmates at Carandiru prison, one of the most bizarre and unruly jails in the world, to release thousands of hostages, including hundreds of children.

The officers negotiated entry to the pavilions at the notorious Sao Paulo jail, the most crowded in Latin America, where last night they were supervising cell-to-cell searches carried out by independent prison staff. The tense stand-off that developed during visiting day on Sunday and spread rapidly to other prisons throughout the country - resulting in the death of 12 inmates, including three at Carandiru - underlined the chaotic state of Brazil's prison system.

Yesterday, as politicians debated the scale of the uprisings and the speed with which they spread, questions were being asked about whether the degree of independence given to prisoners had reached disturbing new levels.

The events have underlined the absolute lack of authority within the prison system, where even at the best of times the prisoners run the show.

"Brazil differs from other countries in that here there is a very significant degree of control by the prisoners themselves," said James Cavallaro, of the human rights monitor Global Justice. "The only way to guarantee security is to let the prisoners make their own rules."

Prisoners took several thousand hostages on Sunday to protest about the transfer of five prisoners last week. Receiving messages on mobile phones, inmates at 28 other prisons started simultaneous uprisings throughout Sao Paulo state. In addition to the deaths, four police officers received bullet wounds. There was relief that the death toll was so low. In 1992, riot police stormed a rebellion at Carandiru and killed 111 people.

In Carandiru, where 7,200 men live in space designed for a third that amount, there is only one guard for every 100 prisoners. The result has been the emergence of an alternative society based on privileges and staff corruption.

As soon as they arrive, prisoners are made to "rent" the cells they live in and must bargain favours to improve their living conditions. Sometimes prisoners who have done their time must continue paying "rent arrears" from outside the jail.

There is a strict hierarchy and violent code of discipline for those who are seen to break it. Deaths and punishment beatings are common.

Mobile phones

Light was first shed on life within the prison in Carandiru Station, written by the Aids doctor Drauzio Varella. The book became an unexpected hit in 1999, selling 165,000 copies. Dr Varella explained how it is sociably acceptable for a macho prisoner to "marry" a transvestite prisoner and keep "her" domesticated in his cell, if he can afford to keep "her" well.

During the day, all prisoners can circulate more or less freely within each pavilion provided they are not part of the 10% imprisoned in the prisoners' own prison (called the Yellow, the colour of these inmates' skin since they rarely see sunlight).

Certain privileges can get you almost whatever you want in Carandiru: drugs, mobile phones, fridges, TVs, stereos, cigarettes and alcohol. Armando Tambelli, of the Sao Paulo prison chaplaincy, estimates that 80% of prisoners take drugs and that there are at least 200 mobile phones, probably many more.

The advent of mobile phones in prisons has meant that prisoners can communicate with those in other jails. It is believed that this made possible the simultaneous protests that spread throughout Sao Paulo state's prisons on Sunday.

The blame for the rebellions has been given to the Capital's First Command, one of the many networks of prisoners linked to drug gangs. They were allegedly angry that five of their leaders were transferred from Carandiru last week.

Authorities did not agree to any of the prisoners' demands to have certain inmates returned. However, Mt Tambelli said the prisoners said they felt their show of force and solidarity had been a success.

Despite Carandiru's squalor and overcrowding it has many liberal policies. Women are allowed to visit and have sexual relations with prisoners. In rooms shared by up to 15 people, they implement rota systems and divide the tiny cells up by hanging sheets. The conjugal visits have greatly reduced violence within the jail and virtually eliminated sexual violence bewteen prisoners, of whom about 15% are HIV-positive.

Rap bands

When I visited the prison last year I met Eduardo Fonseca, a convicted drug dealer, who after six years in jail had a four-year-old and a one-year-old child. Last July 114 Carandiru inmates married their girlfriends in a mass wedding ceremony organised by an evangelical church.

Another phenomenon of Carandiru is how it has turned into a "factory" for young rap bands. Many inmates have turned to rap since it needs no instruments and is useful in channelling aggression. Of the dozens of groups within the jail, at least two - the Rap Prisoners and 509-E - have record contracts. The bands are allowed out of the prison to appear on TV chatshows, perform gigs and do promotional work - provided they are accompanied in handcuffs by police and return to their cells by 10pm.

James Cavallaro said the stakes appeared to be rising in the prisoners' conflict with the authorities. "The one thing that is sacred is the family visits. To show that there was a massive riot during the family visit shows that something is very wrong. The conditions of chaos, violence, little or no medical help or legal care and overcrowding has created a powder keg looking for a spark. This time the spark was the Capital's First Command."

World's penal dustbins

Kresty, St Petersburg

Built in 1892 and meant to hold about 2,000 inmates, this prison now houses more than 10,000. Up to 14 share cells designed for one and the daily food budget is just 14p per inmate. Trotsky was once held here after the 1917 Bolshevik revolution. The prison is now open to the public who pay for a ghoulish tour of the cells and their inmates

Bang Kwang, Bangkok

Built in 1931 and known, in irony, as the "Bangkok Hilton". Currently has 6,700 inmates, more than twice the number it was designed for. With only 16 guards per 1,000 inmates on any shift, problems are many. Prisoners have been known to supplement their meagre diets by eating the big rats that live in the sewage system

Vinarice, Prague

A high security prison known as the "Czech Alcatraz". By law, inmates have to pay up to £8 a day for their stay, but get only 76p a day as food allowance. Riots that spread through the Czech jail system began here last year, as 1,500 prisoners protested at poor sanitation and crowding

Red Onion State Prison, Virginia

Opened in 1998 to house dangerous prisoners in 23-hour-a-day solitary confinement. Constantly criticised by human rights groups, the jail is under investigation by the US justice department after allegations of prisoner abuse and degradation. Controversially, some guards wear stun belts that deliver an eight-second shock of 50,000 volts to stun an unruly inmate

La Planta, Caracas

Severely overcrowded and with poor sanitation (418 people to each lavatory and shower, though prisoners often prefer to urinate in plastic bags that are then thrown from the window). In 1996, 25 prisoners died in a fire believed to have been started by guards
Ian Bucknell

webTitle: Will the real George Bush please stand up?

fields.headline: Will the real George Bush please stand up?
fields.standfirst:
Presidential charm offensive masks hardline goals of new administration

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: George Bush completes his first month in office today, having pulled off the seemingly impossible - cloaking his lack of a mandate under the banner of bipartisanship while pursuing the most radically conservative agenda since the Reagan era.
fields.body:
George Bush completes his first month in office today, having pulled off the seemingly impossible - cloaking his lack of a mandate under the banner of bipartisanship while pursuing the most radically conservative agenda since the Reagan era.

"Bipartisan" has been the most widely-used buzz word of his administration, along with "civility" and "humility". When he was finally handed the presidency on December 13 by the supreme court's unprecedented intervention in the closest election in living memory, he promised to govern with "humility". After the bitterness and controversy of the manual recounts, he promised to "begin the work of healing the nation".

Commentators interpreted the rhetoric as a clear signal that he would modify his conservative platform to allow for the fact that more people had voted against it than for it.

But exactly one month into his presidency, has he been as bipartisan as billed? Or has his enthusiasm for the key elements of a rightwing Republican agenda started to shine through?

There is no debate about the efforts he has made to flatten the usual social barriers separating the parties in Washington. He has made unexpected overtures to his most powerful liberal critics, inviting Senator Ted Kennedy and his family to a White House screening of a film about the Cuban missile crisis, Thirteen Days.

He even addressed a policy retreat held by congressional Democrat leaders, where by all accounts the grizzled veterans turned soft and giggly when the commander-in-chief awarded them all nicknames, although one or two soubriquets apparently fell flat. He called Barbara Mikulski, the 1.5-metre (4ft 11in) senator for Maryland, "Mini-Me".

He even disarmed some of his fiercest critics, black American leaders, by going out of his way to meet the congressional black caucus, and being photographed attending black churches and black schools. He went as far as taking time out early in his presidency to meet the Rev Jesse Jackson, who had accused him of stealing the election.

"In the realm of gestures and imagery, Mr Bush is a bipartisan love machine," the Washington Post journalist Frank Bruni said.

The Bush charm offensive has been singularly successful in blunting Democratic opposition in the vital first month, and in this endeavour he has been aided enormously by his predecessor, Bill Clinton, whose scandal-ridden final days have demoralised his party.

Many US liberals, however, have begun to warn that President Bush, under cover of smiles, handshakes and nicknames, is assembling the most conservative policy agenda Washington has seen for 20 years.

"The tone on all sides remains much improved, and that is no small matter, but the reality remains rough," the columnist Tom Oliphant wrote in the Boston Globe.

The critics point to the appointment of the former Missouri senator John Ashcroft to the position of attorney general. Mr Aschroft is arguably the most ideologically committed politician to hold the post for a generation. He has supported moves to ban abortions even in cases of rape or incest, and is a staunch opponent of affirmative action for minorities. He is even on record as praising the work of a neo-Confederate journal Southern Partisan, which regularly publishes articles by apologists for the slave-owning southern forces in the civil war.

He appointed hardliners to other key posts. Donald Rumsfeld, the defence secretary under President Ford and an opponent of almost all the major arms-control treaties of the past 30 years, got his old job back. And Gale Norton, a nemesis of the environmental lobby and a supporter of ranchers' property rights in the battle over national parks, was made interior secretary.

On the other hand, Mr Bush clearly made an effort to assemble the most diverse cabinet of any Republican president in history, including two blacks, four women, two Asian-Americans (one a Democrat), a Cuban-American and an Arab-American. Colin Powell, as secretary of state, became the most powerful African American in US history, alongside the most powerful black woman ever, Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser.

Characteristically of the new president, outward appearances belied the policy substance beneath. His cabinet may reflect the country's ethnic diversity, but they are almost all conservative on the issues closest to the collective heart of the American right.

Mr Bush is choosing his battles in line with a pared-down but still aggressively partisan strategy. The keystone of that strategy was presented earlier this month, in the form of a $1,600bn (£1,100bn) tax-cut which will disproportionately benefit the wealthiest members of US society.

Mr Bush also proposes to abolish inheritance tax, which affects only the top 2% of people with estates worth more than $675,000.

If approved by Congress the measures will reverse the redistributive steps taken by the Clinton administration and further widen the already huge gap between haves and have-nots.

His tax policy represents a policy of making no concessions to the Democrats, as do Mr Bush's and Mr Rumsfeld's plans to pursue a scaled-up national missile defence system in the face of grave doubts about its affordability and feasibility in Congress and among US allies.

The NMD is an article of faith among military conservatives.

The exception to the rule has been Mr Bush's policy in education, a field in which there is already a high degree of consensus on the need for new thinking and greater accountability.

Mr Bush won support from Democrats with his concern about the progress of schools in the poorest areas.

Furthermore he signalled that he was ready to compromise on his controversial conservative advocacy of a voucher-based education scheme.

It was a compromise in an argument Mr Bush knew he was likely to lose.

It also won him room for manoeuvre on issues which are more central to his agenda, and in particular the redistribution of income towards the nation's wealthiest citizens.

Long after the charm has faded, that redistribution may prove to be this presidency's most abiding legacy.
