webTitle: Market forces: Vodafone falls off top rung

fields.headline: Vodafone falls off top rung
fields.trailText: How the mighty fall. Vodafone was stripped of the title of Europe's biggest company yesterday as investors started to worry about its debt position.
fields.body:
How the mighty fall. Vodafone was stripped of the title of Europe's biggest company yesterday as investors started to worry about its debt position.

Vodafone, which saw it shares price slip below 200p for the first time in two years, saw the title taken by BP, up 13p to 580p. At the height of the dot.com boom last year, Vodafone shares were changing hands for 400p.

The unprecedented concern about Vodafone's debt centres on the sale of Infostrada, its fixed-line Italian telecoms subsidiary, to electricity firm Enel. The deal was supposed to bring £7bn into Vodafone coffers, leave it with debt of about £10bn at its fiscal year-end in March and confirm it as the company with the strongest balance sheet in the industry.

All that now hangs in the balance. On Friday, Vodafone warned that demands by Italy's competition authorities could derail the deal. It seems they want Enel to cut its electricity production by 25% as a condition for allowing the sale to progress.

If the deal is pulled, Vodafone's debt will total £17bn at the fiscal year-end. Although Vodafone would not lose its cherished single-A credit rating, it would still be a blow.

"It is clearly possible that the Infostrada developments will slow the pace of Vodafone's M&A drive in the short term ... or push the company to use equity rather than cash for future acquisitions, which would not be well received by investors," analysts at Deutsche Bank said.

The deal could be renegotiated but the prospect of a 25-40% reduction in the asking price failed to support Vodafone, which settled 6.5p lower at 198p.

Investors were also given a clear illustration of why the London market is dependent on Wall Street for its direction.

With US markets closed for the President's Day holiday, the FTSE 100 drifted aimlessly, trading in a range of just 37 points. Turnover, which normally reaches 1.7bn on a Monday, struggled to 1.5bn, with trading in Vodafone accounting for about 23% of that.

Up to the closing bell it was unclear whether the blue chip index would end higher or lower as falling telecom shares ( Energis lost 21.5p to 454.5p and Spirent 17p to 428p) were offset by gains in the oil and drug sectors.

In the end solid performances from GlaxoSmithKline, up 37p to £19.20 ahead of tomorrow's full-year figures, and BP were just enough to push the FTSE 5.7 points higher to 6094.

The FTSE Techmark 100, slipped 14.60 points to 2505.39 and the FTSE 250 eased 2.4 to 6716.80.

AB Foods, maker of Twinings tea and Ryvita, topped the blue chip leaderboard, benefiting from its defensive qualities and a big push from its broker, WestLB Panmure.

Following a meeting with the company, which goes into its quiet season soon, the German broker repeated its "outperform" rating and said it was happy with its full-year pre-tax profits forecast of £402m. AB Foods closed 18.5p up at 503.5p.

Buyers were also in good supply for Tesco (up 7.5p to 268.5p) after the grocer said it expected full-year figures to match market expectations.

In a mixed tech sector, Anglo-Dutch IT group CMG ended 19p lower at 886p, undermined by rumours first heard on Friday that it is experiencing a slowdown in sales. CMG is due to report full-year figures next Monday.

Holders of Persimmon shares (18.5p stronger at 292p) were left in no doubt about whether they should vote in favour of the housebuilder's acquisition of Beazer on Wednesday. UBS Warburg, which repeated its "strong buy" rating, reckons the deal will enhance Persimmon's 2002 earnings per share by 20%. Beazer shares rose 7p to 197.5p, reflecting the equity content of Persimmon's offer.

Rival George Wimpey saw good gains, up 12.5p to 177p ahead of tomorrow's full-year figures.

Software billing outfit Intec Telecom was marked 41.5p lower at 374.5p after disappointing first-quarter results: losses were wider than expected.

webTitle: Matalan knockback

fields.headline: Matalan knockback
fields.trailText: Matalan's stock price may have picked itself off the floor in the past few weeks but not everybody is happy with the performance of the Lancashire-based discount retailer.
fields.body:
Matalan's stock price may have picked itself off the floor in the past few weeks but not everybody is happy with the performance of the Lancashire-based discount retailer.

SG Securities is understood to have lowered its rating to "hold" from "buy", following a visit to the company on Friday and has made further revisions to its earnings forecasts. Apparently SG is now looking for pre-tax profits of £82m this year, back from £84m previously. Market gossip says SG's profit downgrades reflect lower sales and weaker margins due to stock writedowns. SG is also said to be advising clients that although Matalan is likely to see strong sales growth this year, gross margins are unlikely to recover due to competition from the likes of Asda.

Shares in Matalan, once a contender for a place in the FTSE 100, ended 9p better at 540p yesterday, valuing the company at £2.2bn.

webTitle: At this price?  St James's Place

fields.headline: At this price?  St James's Place
fields.trailText: Sir Mark Weinberg, chairman of St James's Place Capital, is all too aware that the major high street banks are after his wealthy customers. Chasing the "mass affluent" is now a common pursuit.
fields.body:
Sir Mark Weinberg, chairman of St James's Place Capital, is all too aware that the major high street banks are after his wealthy customers. Chasing the "mass affluent" is now a common pursuit.

Yet Sir Mark and his "partners" have been at it for years. This might explain why, in yesterday's profits statement, Sir Mark insisted that none of the initiatives by the likes of HSBC and Lloyds TSB are a serious threat. This is because he believes St James's Place customers have a strong trust in their adviser and do not need to be charmed into a "personal relationship".

Halifax believes him. It bought 60% of the company last year and is now able to tout it as its bank for the rich. Through a link with Halifax's telephone-cum-internet bank Intelligent Finance, St James's Place is also getting into banking for the better-off.

St James's Place, which J Rothschild Assurance Group reversed into a few years ago, is careful to boast that it is not just about servicing the mega-rich. While one of its "partners" - or sales agents - sold 20 mortgages of £1m last year, it also has customers with basic salaries of around £40,000.

These partners, who are locked into the company through options, increased by 8% last year to 1,050, and will need to keep growing at a rate of around 10% a year if St James's Place is to achieve its goal of 15% growth in its business each year.

Last year its pretax profits fell from £174.8m to £82.7m but this included more than £70m from the sale of its asset management arm. Before exceptionals profits were up 33% to £79.5m. One of the exceptionals includes a £2.1m income tax bill which St James's Place picked up for partners and management after the Halifax deal.

While St James's Place fell 20.5p yesterday to 424p, this was more about profit-taking after a sharp run than City alarm. With only 33 % or so of the shares free floating - around 7% are owned by management and partners - these are shares which should hold their value.

webTitle: ENIC unlocked

fields.headline: ENIC unlocked
fields.trailText: ENIC, the sports and media group, has said it is seeking approval from shareholders to sell some or all of its 2.8% stake in Autonomy after being released from a "lock-up" period at the end of January.
fields.body:
ENIC, the sports and media group, has said it is seeking approval from shareholders to sell some or all of its 2.8% stake in Autonomy after being released from a "lock-up" period at the end of January.

Apax Partners, a venture capital group that holds an 8.12% stake, was released at the same time, but was only free to sell after the issue of its own results. It has said it has "no immediate intention to sell any shares".

Four board members, including two Apax directors, also hold stakes. Directors are subject to an extended "lock-up" period which expires at the end of April.

webTitle: City derides Cantab deal

fields.headline: City derides Cantab deal
fields.trailText: Biotech company Xenova Group last night rejected City criticism of its £62m takeover of Cantab Pharmaceuticals, which created one of Europe's largest drug development portfolios.
fields.body:
Biotech company Xenova Group last night rejected City criticism of its £62m takeover of Cantab Pharmaceuticals, which created one of Europe's largest drug development portfolios.

The surprise announcement ended speculation over Cantab's future since it put itself up for sale after the failure of an advanced treatment for genital warts depressed its share price.

The all-share deal received a lukewarm reaction in the City, with analysts saying it was "nothing exciting". Others questioned whether Cantab, previously linked with suitors such as Powderject, would fit Slough-based Xenova's product range.

One analyst said he was "completely underwhelmed" by the news.

The deal came on the day both companies reported full-year losses for 2000. Vaccine specialist Cantab was in the red to the tune of £3.9m compared to an £8.7m loss last year while Xenova showed an unchanged loss of £9.4m.

Xenova's chief executive, David Oxlade, who will be chief executive officer of the new group, insisted the tie-up would produce a strong company focusing on treatments for cancer, infectious diseases and addiction.

The enlarged group would boast one of Europe's biggest clinical pipelines and there would be more muscle in its partnerships with big drugs companies such as Celltech, GlaxoSmithKline and Pfizer.

Defying the waves of criticism whenever a drug or compound fails, he predicted the new group would be loss-making for several years until the portfolio is developed.

"Companies with a narrow portfolio are more of a risk," he said. "In a sense, difficulties are to be expected as these are complex areas."

Mr Oxlade said some redundancies were likely, principally in duplicated operations such as payroll, but numbers would be relatively small. Cantab has 130 staff while Xenova has about 60.

The proposed deal, which will see Xenova exchange 11 new shares for every seven Cantab units, will value the enlarged group at £123.7m. The merger offer represents a premium of 16.5% on Cantab's closing price of 120p on February 16.

webTitle: Unilever lands £1.2bn for food group

fields.headline: Unilever lands £1.2bn for food group
fields.trailText: Unilever yesterday sold its Bestfood Baking subsidiary for $1.76bn (£1.2bn) to George Weston, a Canadian food and supermarkets group run by the younger brother of Garry Weston, the former executive chairman of Britain's Associated British Food.
fields.body:
Unilever yesterday sold its Bestfood Baking subsidiary for $1.76bn (£1.2bn) to George Weston, a Canadian food and supermarkets group run by the younger brother of Garry Weston, the former executive chairman of Britain's Associated British Food.

Galen Weston, the chairman of the Canadian company, is also a non-executive director of ABF and is a director of Wittington Investments, the family company which owns a controlling stake in ABF.

Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch group, said that Bestfood Baking, a US-based business, no longer fitted its strategy of operating in fewer sectors with fewer brands.

Patrick Cescau, the group's foods director said that Bestfood Baking was "a very strong business that happens to fall outside of our foods strategy to focus on leading brands in core categories, such as Lipton, Knorr, Slim-Fast and Hellmann's".

Bestfood Baking, best known for its Entermann's sweet baked goods and Thomas' English muffins, has been up for sale ever since Unilever bought its parent company, Bestfoods, for £16.8bn in October last year.

Since that deal, Unilever has raised about €4bn (£2.5bn) through a series of disposals including its European baking supplies business, the Elizabeth Arden cosmetics company, and a number of European soup and sauce operations.

The price which Unilever got for Bestfood Baking was at the top end of analysts' expectations, reflecting interest from rivals bidders thought to include Sara Lee and Grupo Bimbo de Mexico.

Bestfood Baking, which employs about 12,000 people at 19 plants in the US, last year made a profit before tax and interest of £97m on sales of £1.2bn. The acquisition of the company will double George Weston's US sales. The Canadian company already operates 23 bakery plants in the US and Canada and controls Canada's largest chain of supermarkets.

Unilever yesterday played down reports that the company was interested in Clairol, the US hair products maker, which Bristol Myers Squibb has put up for sale with an estimated price tag of £3.1bn.

A spokesman said the company had already told analysts not to expect much in the way of acquisitions this year.

webTitle: Bid in Sweden completes 3i tour of Europe

fields.headline: Bid in Sweden completes 3i tour of Europe
fields.trailText: British venture capital group 3i continued its European expansion yesterday with a £590m bid for Swedish private equity investment firm Atle.
fields.body:
British venture capital group 3i continued its European expansion yesterday with a £590m bid for Swedish private equity investment firm Atle.

If the offer succeeds it will be 3i's fourth purchase in continental Europe in little more than a year.

The bid for Atle is being made through Woodrose Investments, a Swedish company jointly owned by 3i and another Swedish company, Ratos. The two companies have already decided on the division of Atle's portfolio of investments if the deal goes through.

3i's share of the purchase price will be £363m for which it will get a share portfolio worth £343m plus Atle's business, management and staff.

"This [acquisition] is the last key element in our European strategy," said finance director Michael Queen. "Sweden was the last big market that we needed to get into. Other countries like Denmark and Portugal have very much smaller venture capital markets so we can develop organically."

Over the next five years 3i is aiming to develop its investment portfolio so that more than 30% will be in continental Europe, more than 10% in the US and more than 5% in Asia. "What was a 100% UK business is by 2006 going to have less than 50% of its assets in the UK," Mr Queen said.

3i believes the ability to operate on an international basis is crucial in the venture capital business. "If you can show you have a network of established connections that sends out a very powerful message," Mr Queen said.

Although Britain has traditionally been seen as a much more highly developed venture capital market than continental Europe, 3i has detected a significant shift in attitudes.

The Atle deal is conditional on the Swedish firm divesting its stake in Studsvik, which provides products and services to the nuclear power industry. Atle plans to give the Studsvik shares to existing Atle shareholders.

webTitle: Three-way fusion of steelmakers will lead to further job cuts

fields.headline: Three-way fusion of steelmakers will lead to further job cuts
fields.trailText: Three European steel groups - France's Usinor, Luxembourg's Arbed and Spain's Aceralia - heralded a new wave of plant closures and job losses yesterday after announcing a £3.7bn merger to create the world's biggest producer.
fields.body:
Three European steel groups - France's Usinor, Luxembourg's Arbed and Spain's Aceralia - heralded a new wave of plant closures and job losses yesterday after announcing a £3.7bn merger to create the world's biggest producer.

Market hopes that cuts in over capacity presaged by the three would trigger a long-awaited recovery in prices boosted the stock of Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steel group in the throes of a painful restructuring that involves 6,000 UK job losses. Corus shares were up more than 5% on the day.

The European merger, effectively a takeover by Usinor of its two rivals, will create a group producing more than 46m tonnes of steel a year and catapult it beyond the world's two leaders, Japan's Nippon and Korea's Posco, which produce some 26m tonnes each. It will have sales of around 30bn euros (19bn) a year.

The new group, initially dubbed NewCo, will control 40% of the European market for flat carbon steel products where prices have fallen to their lowest levels for almost three years and earlier efforts at profitability through small-scale cuts in output failed.

Commerzbank analyst Peter Dupont was cautious about the extent to which prices could be pushed higher. "Even if they did achieve higher prices that would just suck in imports."

The deal is to be examined by the European commission's competition directorate but Francis Mer, Usinor's chief executive, said the enlarged group was ready to make disposals to gain approval and could embark on closures and job losses.

"We think we might have to make a few concessions in the distribution sector and in flat steel products where the commission might not be entirely satisfied."

The three companies estimate the merger will generate savings of some 300m euros by the end of 2003 and 700m euros by 2006. That suggests the restructuring might not be as radical as some observers hope. Even at the peak, the savings would amount to little more than 2% of annual sales.

Corus, which was formed from the 1999 fusion of British Steel and Hoogovens and has just begun formal talks with unions at local level on its own plans, cautiously welcomed the rival merger. Corus will become the world's fourth largest producer with output of just over 20m tonnes a year.

The Anglo-Dutch group, which is cutting its steelmaking capacity by a fifth, hopes the European rationalisation will boost prices significantly. The strong pound, a dramatic fall in UK demand and substantial losses on export sales to mainland Europe have cost it more than £1bn in the 16 months since its merger.

Industry sources said the continental deal would not alter Corus' plans to shut plants in Wales, end steelmaking in Llanwern, near Newport, Gwent, and trim operations on Teesside and in Scunthorpe.

The plans have caused outrage among politicians and unions, which have drafted counter-proposals to keep plants open. The continental merger could provoke similar resistance, with the Luxembourg government, which holds 29.7% of Arbed, said to be hostile.

webTitle: LA mayoral candidates tainted by Clinton pardon

fields.headline: LA mayoral candidates tainted by Clinton pardon
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton's controversial granting of pardons has engulfed the mayoral election in Los Angeles, where two leading candidates lobbied the White House on behalf of a freed cocaine smuggler whose father contributed to their campaigns.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton's controversial granting of pardons has engulfed the mayoral election in Los Angeles, where two leading candidates lobbied the White House on behalf of a freed cocaine smuggler whose father contributed to their campaigns.

Voting is not until April 10, but it is already assumed that there will be a run-off between the two leading candidates in the field of 24.

Only six candidates are seen to have a real chance, and two of them, Antonio Villaraigosa and Xavier Becerra, lobbied on behalf of the cocaine smuggler Carlos Vignali, who was pardoned by Mr Clinton.

It now transpires that Mr Vignali's father Horacio, a businessman, donated about $160,000 (£110,000) to politicians seeking office, including Mr Villaraigosa and Mr Becera, although the sums they received were relatively small, about $3,000.

Mr Villaraigosa has apologised for acting without knowing the full details of the case, and Mr Becerra has defended his own role in the affair but the issue is unlikely to go away in such a close-run race.

For the first time Los Angeles could have an openly gay mayor in Joel Wachs, 61, who has attracted support and funds from the large West Hollywood gay community. He also hopes to win support from conservatives who admired his fiscal management skills during his long career in local government.

Mr Villaraigosa, 48, hopes to become the city's first Latino mayor since the 1870s. He has a background in the union movement and has the backing of the LA county federation of labour.

"I believe this city is looking for a bridge; this city where we speak more than 144 languages, but oftentimes don't speak with a common vision," he said in a recent speech.

He is challenged for the Latino vote, which accounts for about 20% of the electorate, by his fellow Democrat and congressman Xavier Becerra, who has resisted attempts by Latino powerbrokers to get the two to agree that only the likeliest winner should stand.

webTitle: Boys held for Ivy League couple's murder

fields.headline: Boys held for Ivy League couple's murder
fields.trailText: A pair of fugitive schoolboys accused of killing two Ivy League university professors were arrested at a lorry drivers' cafe yesterday while apparently trying to flee to the other side of the US.
fields.body:
A pair of fugitive schoolboys accused of killing two Ivy League university professors were arrested at a lorry drivers' cafe yesterday while apparently trying to flee to the other side of the US.

Robert Tulloch, 17, and James Parker, 16, said to be all-American boys with a shared interest in theatre and rock climbing, were thought to have discussed the killing at school before going on the run.

They were picked up after police listened to a citizens' band radio conversation between two truck drivers. One said he was giving a ride to two hitchhikers who said they were trying to get to California.

Their arrest in New Castle, Indiana, nearly 2,000 miles short of their destination, ended a hunt which began after the murder three weeks ago of Half and Susanne Zantop, stabbed to death in their home in the town of Etna, five miles east of Hanover, New Hampshire.

The couple had a reputation for keeping open house for students and colleagues. The police have not suggested a motive for the attack, and it is understood that the boys were linked to the crime by fingerprints and a knife bought on the internet.

Mr Zantop, 62, was a professor of earth studies at Dartmouth College and Susanne, 55, the head of its German studies department.

The accused boys had no connection with the University and had visited Hanover, 25 miles south of their home in Chelsea, Vermont, only to go to the cinema.

The driver who picked them up after they abandoned the car in which they had been travelling had no idea that they were murder suspects.

"The truck driver had felt sorry for them because they were close in age to one of his own," Sergeant Bill Ward said in Indiana.

Robert Sherman, a neighbour of the boys in Chelsea,which has a population of 1,300, said: "I've known them most of their lives. My children went to high school with them and played sports with them. The whole community is in shock.

"They are very important members of this community. No one's invisible in this community. Everyone is part of a great big family.

"I imagine their families are going through hell.

"No one in America can explain why two good boys would do something horrible," he said.

Kevin Ellis, a friend of the Parker family, said: "James is a very bright kid and his father's an ace carpenter who built my house. I trust him with my life."

Robert Tulloch was president of Chelsea high school student council last year. He intended to study overseas.

"He was supposed to go abroad, but he didn't go," Marilyn Childs, a speech coach at the school, said.

"I will tell you, this boy is brilliant. I deal with a lot of students and this boy was gifted."

"He was supposed to go abroad, but he didn't go," Marilyn Childs, a speech coach at the school, said. "I will tell you, this boy is brilliant. I deal with a lot of students and this boy was gifted."

webTitle: Republicans take office on their own terms

fields.headline: Republicans take office on their own terms
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Just how even-handed has Bush been in his first month in office? Here we grade his decisions, giving 5 to the most cosily bipartisan moves, -5 to those most closely adhering to the Bush agenda.
fields.body:
Just how even-handed has Bush been in his first month in office? Here we grade his decisions, giving 5 to the most cosily bipartisan moves, -5 to those most closely adhering to the Bush agenda:

Bipartisan decisions

 Appoints Colin Powell secretary of state

An easy score. Powell is popular across almost the entire political spectrum. The appointment of black Americans and Hispanics makes his cabinet as diverse as Clinton's. It also includes one Asian-American Democrat, Norman Mineta
Rating: 4

 Proposes educational reforms

His first major initiative, with suggestions on teacher accountability and extra funding, gained bipartisan support. Also includes a controversial voucher scheme, but Bush signalled that vouchers were negotiable
Rating: 3

 Meets black and Democrat caucuses

Bush broke down social barriers in Washington which normally separate the parties. No policy content, but big points for schmoozing
Rating: 3

 Bombing Iraq

Did not rouse much press comment or complaint from Democrats, who support containment of Iraq
Rating: 1

Partisan decisions

 Appoints John Ashcroft attorney general

Ashcroft has a track record of opposing abortion rights and affirmative action. He also has a soft-spot for the neo-confederates, apologists for the slave-owning South in the American civil war
Rating: -5

 Makes Donald Rumsfeld his defence secretary

Rumsfeld is a cold warrior who was opposed to the nuclear test-ban treaty, the anti-ballistic missile treaty, and the ban on chemical weapons
Rating: -5

 Halts foreign aid spending on abortions

In one of his first acts, Bush reverted to the Reagan policy of barring federal funding of international family planning organisations which promote or facilitate abortions
Rating: -4

 Plans to explore Alaskan reserve for oil

Bush plans to open up the Alaskan National Wildlife Refuge to prospectors. He has also signalled that he will relax environmental controls on old power plants
Rating: -4

 Promotes "faith-based" social services

Churches would receive federal funding for their work on social welfare, raising questions about whether it will siphon funds from secular social care, and blur the separation of church and state
Rating -2

 Tax cuts

Despite losing the popular vote, Bush does not give an inch over his proposed $1.6 trillion tax cut. He also proposes elimination of estate tax, which affects only the wealthiest 2% with assets of over $675,000
Rating: -5

 Opposed patients' bill of rights

The bill of rights is a bipartisan measure, but Bush has signalled that he would oppose any move to strip legal immunity from the private healthcare organisations (HMOs)
Rating: -4

Overall rating: -18

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Pilot trials on saliva drug test
fields.body:
Pilot trials on saliva drug test

A drug test which uses a saliva swab rather than a urine sample is to be piloted in Stafford, Nottingham and Hackney, east London. The electronic kits, which check for heroin, cocaine and crack use, will help police assess whether a crime was fuelled by the use of drugs.

Blood imports 'caused Aids'

Peter Jones, member of the World Federation of Haemophilia, has called for a public inquiry into the use of imported blood products used to treat haemophiliacs, which he fears claimed the lives of 77 of his patients who became infected with HIV and hepatitis C. Dr Jones worked with haemophiliacs on Tyneside in the early 1970s.

Quest for the perfect face
A man is appealing for sponsors via the internet to fund plastic surgery to transform his features into the perfect face. Tim Whitfield-Lyne, 32, from Stoke-on-Trent, estimates he will need £20,000 and has offered sponsors a say in the way his features are rearranged. He is willing to have his transformation filmed for a documentary.

Ratings edge for News at Ten

Unofficial ratings show ITV's relaunched News at Ten as an early winner over BBC's 10pm bulletin. On the three or four nights a week they went head-to-head, ITV reached an average audience of 6.1m compared with the BBC's 4.9m.

Aid for knee implant victims

Arthritis sufferers fitted with faulty knee implants, including one whose leg was amputated, have been granted legal aid to pursue claims. A government watchdog, warned hospitals not to implant the knees.

PC on attempted rape charge

A policeman will appear before magistrates in Hendon, north west London on Thursday accused of indecent assault and attempted rape during a street attack while he was off duty on Saturday night. Pc Paul Miller, 35, was granted bail.

Town fans top bootleg league

Fans of Ipswich Town are the biggest buyers of bootleg cigarettes, according to analysis of discarded packets outside Premiership grounds. Research for the Tobacco Manufacturers' Association found 41% of packs outside Town's Portman Road ground avoided duty.

Museum 'fraud' inquiry begins

Fraud squad officers have begun an inquiry into the rebuilding of the British Museum's south portico. It emerged in 1999 that a contractor supplied cheap French limestone for the building rather than the Portland stone the museum had wanted. The investigation will centre on the alleged non-fulfilment of a contract.

Church wins libel battle

Bishop Michael Reid and five trustees of the Peniel Pentecostal Church, in Pilgrim's Hatch, Essex, yesterday accepted a five figure libel sum at the high court in London from Anthony Galbraith, an Independent Conservative on Brentwood council, whosaid they were part of a dangerous cult in a press release in 1999.

Killer cut up victim's body

William Wharton, 57, was jailed for life yesterday for the murder of Lincoln restaurateur Rumel Bakar, 25, whose body was cut up and buried across the midlands. Mr Bakar was killed in December 1999 after a row with Wharton, Nottingham crown court heard.

Keeper killed by elephant

Richard Hughes, 34, a keeper at Chester Zoo has died in hospital after suffering brain damage when he was butted by a four tonne elephant earlier this month.

webTitle: Plan for network of drugs courts to prevent addicts returning to crime

fields.headline: Plan for network of drugs courts to prevent addicts returning to crime
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is to step up the war against drugs by setting up a nationwide network of courts to prevent addicts returning to a life of crime.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is to step up the war against drugs by setting up a nationwide network of courts to prevent addicts returning to a life of crime.

In an attempt to woo Tory voters ahead of the election, the government is to increase the testing of all drug suspects. Specially trained magistrates will also be given powers to force anyone convicted of drugs-related offences to undergo treatment to help them kick the habit.

The initiative, which follows the prime minister's weekend pledge to establish a national register of drug offenders, comes amid mounting concern at the rising cost of drugs-related crimes, which is thought to amount to £2.5bn a year.

Almost two-thirds of criminals (61%) test positive for one or more drugs. Home Office figures also show that 12,250 suspects arrested each week have taken heroin, crack or cocaine in the previous two days.

Under the proposals, drugs offenders would be dealt with by specially trained magistrates who would regularly monitor offenders as they serve their sentence.

The plans draw on a pilot scheme in Wakefield where around 40% of criminals involved in such a scheme have come off drugs, leading to a sharp fall in property crimes. Less than a quarter of those sentenced under a similar scheme in the US reportedly re-offend.

Downing Street confirmed the proposal is likely to be included in Labour's election manifesto. A spokesman said last night: "We are looking at a number of ways of dealing with these problems more effectively and this is one of them."

Jack Straw, the home secretary, underlined the government's determination to tackle drug abuse. "Crime is falling but Class A drugs continue to fuel a significant amount of property crime. We are determined to break the vicious circle of drugs and crime at all levels. Identifying drug misusing offenders at each stage of the criminal justice system is a key objective of the government's crime reduction strategy."

He was speaking at the launch of a scheme to use saliva, rather than urine, to test for drugs. The two-year scheme will be used by police and probation officers in Hackney, Stafford and Nottingham.

Mr Straw said: "The extension of drug testing across the criminal justice system will provide for continued and repeated oversight and treatment of drug misusers to reverse deep-seated hard drug habits and the crime that is committed to feed them.

"It will complement measures such as the drug treatment and testing orders and drug-arrest referral schemes which are already helping to tackle this serious issue."

Downing Street's latest initiative to break the link between drugs and crime reflects increasing government concern at the mounting threat posed by drugs. However, ministers will hope that proposing tough measures prior to the election will impress floating voters on the centre ground who may be tempted to return to the Tories in the light of William Hague's hardline stance on crime.

The prime minister showed his determination to place the fight against the crime at the forefront of his election campaign when he used Labour's spring conference at the weekend to announce the setting up of a drugs register similar to the paedophile register.

webTitle: Meacher in new row over homes secrecy

fields.headline: Meacher in new row over homes secrecy
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Michael Meacher was last night embroiled in a new dispute over his ownership of up to 12 homes after he invoked a secrecy clause in the "open government" code to avoid answering a parliamentary question on the issue.
fields.body:
Michael Meacher was last night embroiled in a new dispute over his ownership of up to 12 homes after he invoked a secrecy clause in the "open government" code to avoid answering a parliamentary question on the issue.

Andrew Lansley, the shadow Cabinet Office spokesman, wrote to Tony Blair last night after the environment minister refused to tell parliament how he ensured there was no conflict of interest over his home purchases and his government policy role.

Mr Meacher, while saying he believed there was no conflict of interest, insisted that he was not obliged to explain how he had resolved the issue with his permanent secretary, Sir Richard Mottram.

The minister invoked part of John Major's access to government information code, and said that "the handling of my personal interests" was covered by a ban on the release of internal Whitehall documents.

Mr Lansley has asked the prime minister to insist that Mr Meacher gives a detailed reply to parliament and has quoted the ministerial code which, he says, obliges the environment minister to give a full explanation. The code states: "It will be for individual ministers to judge how best to act in order to uphold the highest standards. They are responsible for justifying their conduct to parliament."

The question of a possible conflict of interest was first raised when Channel 4 and the Guardian revealed that Mr Meacher and his wife, Lucianne, were buying through property companies flats to rent out as investments, as well as owning three homes.

In the 1980s Mr Meacher in a book attacked the use of property as a "status symbol and an object of conspicuous consumption". At a Labour conference meeting two years ago he condemned second home owners for "robbing people of a home which is a basic right".

Yesterday the Department of the Environment defended Mr Meacher's decision not to reveal the information.

A spokeswoman said that "Sir Richard Mottram has been following the issue closely and is content that Mr Meacher has no conflict of interest".

The department also said the minister had been scrupulous in trying to get the best advice on how to deal with the situation.

webTitle: Aitken's house in Westminster sold for £2.4m

fields.headline: Aitken's house in Westminster sold for £2.4m
fields.trailText: Jonathan Aitken's Georgian house in Westminster has been sold for £2.4m three weeks after it was put on the market by the former cabinet minister's trustee in bankruptcy.
fields.body:
Jonathan Aitken's Georgian house in Westminster has been sold for £2.4m three weeks after it was put on the market by the former cabinet minister's trustee in bankruptcy.

The double-fronted five-storey house in Lord North Street, a five-minute walk from the Houses of Parliament, was bought by a neighbour in the street at a price higher than the estate agents, Strutt & Parker, expected. Contracts were exchanged at the end of last week.

The sale brings to a close the realisation of Mr Aitken's assets by the trustee, accountants Baker Tilley, who were appointed after his failed libel action against the Guardian and Granada Television's World in Action in 1997. He then faced costs of £2.2m and after a trial at the Old Bailey he was sentenced to 18 months in prison for perjury.

Attempts to sell the house had to be put on hold for a year as it was deemed to be the family home of his son, William, who was at that time a minor.

There was also the complication that Mr Aitken's wife, Lolicia, who divorced him, claimed an interest in the property. She is now living abroad and an arrest warrant against her for conspiring to pervert the course of justice is still outstanding.

The issue of any family interest has yet to be resolved. The money will be deposited in an account held by Baker Tilley and the trustee is now likely to go to court to seek permission to distribute the cash to Mr Aitken's creditors. Apart from the Guardian and Granada, they include the Inland Revenue, which is seeking £300,000.

It will be open to Mr Aitken's family to make representations to the court.

Strutt & Parker distributed 400 glossy brochures last month to a list of high-value clients and suggested offers over £2m. It is understood that the neighbour, with a mere single frontage, wanted a larger home.

The Aitken home, described in the brochure as having a "fascinating history owing to its close association with the political establishment of this country", has a 37ft drawing room, once the venue for celebrated Tory parties and the home of the Conservative Philosophy Group.

webTitle: Stem cells may repair brain injuries damage

fields.headline: Stem cells may repair brain injuries damage
fields.trailText: Umbilical cord blood injected into the veins within 24 hours could restore the damaged brains of stroke victims. The discovery - so far demonstrated only in laboratory rats - could lead to tests in humans within two years.
fields.body:
Umbilical cord blood injected into the veins within 24 hours could restore the damaged brains of stroke victims. The discovery - so far demonstrated only in laboratory rats - could lead to tests in humans within two years.

The technique might one day also help sufferers from spinal injuries, Parkinson's, Huntington's, motor neurone disease and other brain injuries.

It could also re-awaken the controversy over the use of embryo stem cells as a treatment for disease. Embryo stem cells can change into any of the 300 types of tissue in a human being. Britain last month led the world when parliament changed the rules and permitted the use of embryo cells for research into disease as well as fertility, in the hope that this would open up a new kind of transplant treatment.

Opponents argued that adult stem cells and umbilical cord blood could be altered to provide transplant tissue without raising any kind of ethical problems. There are also other difficulties: one of them is a shortage of donated embryos.

Paul Sandberg, of the University of South Florida, told the American Association for the Advancement of Science meeting in San Francisco that more than 4m children were born in the US each year, bringing with them the bonus of umbilical cord blood. There were also 700,000 strokes a year. Stem cells from cord blood had been used in the treatment of children's blood diseases such as leukaemia. This suggested that the cord blood stem cells could change into something else.

But it was the first hint that they could also change into the neurons and glial cells that make up the brain. Working with a commercial company that preserves cord blood from hospitals, Dr Sandberg's group separated the stem cells and treated them to trigger changes in the precursors of nerve cells. They injected the cells into the veins of rats that had suffered induced strokes. The earlier the injection, the faster they seemed to recover.

When the scientists examined the rats they found that although the stem cells were to be found in many parts of the body, significantly more had migrated to the damaged areas of the brain. The new cells did more than replace damaged tissue, they seemed to stimulate a repair process.

"The animals that had the umbilical cord blood cells showed recovery fairly close to normal levels. The animals that didn't, did not show that kind of recovery," he said. "Most of our studies have involved directly injecting into the brain around the stroke. This is the first time our group is reporting doing an intravenous approach."

Dr Sandberg has already worked with bone marrow stem cells for brain repair, and Sertoli cells, taken from testicles, to trigger new growth in damaged or failing brains. Umbilical cord cells are already being stored at birth to help children in treatment for certain cancers. As the cord stem cells are very young, he said, rejection might be less likely and it might be possible to use cells from one individual to help another.

Because these stem cells are already used in medical treatments, researchers could progress to clinical trials with humans within two years.

"This finding suggests that umbilical cord blood is a noncontroversial, readily available source of stem cells and could provide an alternative to embryonic cells," he said.

webTitle: Labour's £6m libraries scheme to aid poorer children

fields.headline: Labour's £6m libraries scheme to aid poorer children
fields.trailText: Christmas came 10 months early for Britain's most impoverished children yesterday when the government promised to spend £6m on providing them with toys.
fields.body:
Christmas came 10 months early for Britain's most impoverished children yesterday when the government promised to spend £6m on providing them with toys.

A total of 150 toy libraries are to be set up in deprived areas as part of a commitment to helping 3m children still living in poverty. The announcement, which will see each library receive £40,000, follows government-funded research which shows that children who are given educational toys, work with their parents on the alphabet, are taught nursery rhymes, or pay visits to libraries, do better than their peers by the time they are three.

Launching the scheme at a toy library in Pimlico, central London, the education and employment minister, Margaret Hodge, said: "Every parent knows toys and play equipment can be expensive. As a result, many young children from deprived areas are going without essential early play that is crucial to child development. We are determined to change that."

Parents will be able to borrow toys and play equipment for their children, and many libraries will offer onsite play facilities and care support for young children, including those with special needs. Some of the libraries will be mobile, others will be based in schools and community centres.

The pledge follows the chancellor, Gordon Brown's description of child poverty as "a scar on the soul of Britain", at Labour's spring conference, and his determination to end this as one of "five radical economic goals for our generation".

One million children have been lifted out of poverty since the government came to power, but yesterday the Child Poverty Action Group stressed that more needed to be done. "This (toy scheme) would not be necessary if impoverished families had adequate incomes," said its director, Martin Barnes.

webTitle: Comment: Irvine's political fundraising undermines his office

fields.headline: The discredited model of a modern lord chancellor
fields.standfirst:
Derry Irvine's political fundraising seriously undermines his office

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: February 20 2001, Hugo Young: Derry Irvine's political fundraising seriously undermines his office.
fields.body:
It's shocking, but should not be surprising, that the lord chancellor has become a fundraiser for the Labour party. The revelation is a salutary delight. It cuts through pretences, explodes illusions and destroys the exquisite British paradox that has permitted the holder of the office to be a judge, an executive and a legislator all at once, without any one of these jobs being seen as in conflict with the others. Derry Irvine's £200-a-plate dinner - with a more "significant contribution" strongly advised on top - should be the beginning of the end for an office that cannot now be defended.

This is more important than whether Lord Irvine himself stays in post, which he surely will until after the election. His lordship has done service to a truth he long denied. His deed illuminates what his words invariably bury. We learn definitively that the lord chancellorship is, above all, a political job. The politics comes first. Any danger that judicial impartiality might be compromised by the spectacle of him touting for political funds was plainly swept aside when the dinner was arranged. It wasn't even worth considering. That's where Irvine stands. It is a clarifying moment.

He's not the first modern lord chancellor whose conduct raised a question about his multi-hatted role. Lord Hailsham was just as politically identified as Irvine, with an experience of elective politics that gave him more right to intervene in general controversy. Occasionally he used it. Irvine's predecessor, Lord Mackay of Clashfern, presided over years of tension between the judiciary and the government, owing to his resolve to defend cabinet policy on public spending. In the minds of some judges, Mackay ranked among the most hated leaders his profession has ever had.

Nonetheless, Hailsham and Mackay respected the paradox of their office. They did their best to avoid rubbing their political allegiance in. They understood that the appearance of impartiality was worth preserving. They didn't abuse the cardinal feature of the job, which is the way its judicial aspect confers unique authority on its political functions. That's where the chancellor's special magic comes from. They didn't purloin this to give more heft to party work, let alone to cadging for funds.

Lord Irvine has been different. From the start, he operated not merely as lord chancellor but as general counsel to the prime minister: very close, available, trusted, and powerful across the field. He deserves credit for muscling through the Human Rights Act and imposing professional reform, though less for his sabotage of legal aid and his complicity in the curbing of jury trial.

But the main thing wrong with Irvine has been his refusal to contemplate reform of his own job. Like any good advocate, when challenged he went straight on the attack. Far from all his jobs being in conflict, he claimed that each supported the integrity of the others. Far from being a threat to judicial independence, he, Derry Irvine, was its very embodiment and protector.

Well before he became lord chancellor, agreement on this was less than universal. The great British paradox was fraying for want of credibility. Lord Steyn, a law lord, said the chancellor should cease to be head of the judiciary. Steyn and some other law lords withdrew from their own conflict of interest by declining any longer to take part in legislative work.

Irvine himself was prevailed on not to sit as a judge in any case that involved the government, which cuts out human rights cases, devolution cases and much judicial review. In effect, he has ceased to be a functioning judge, while still claiming the highest salary both in the cabinet and the judiciary on the grounds that, as senior judge, he must maintain a proper differential over the lord chief justice.

Despite this, he insists on being untouchable. While withdrawing from the judicial function, he demands that he must keep it. While becoming the most political lord chancellor in living memory, he insists he must be leader of the judiciary. While purporting to defend judicial impartiality, he puts the party political arm on lawyers whose careers he holds in his hands. While occupying a post that requires at least the appearance of standing aside from the government, he's proud of his role as executive minister, intimate political adviser and, now, money-raiser in chief from the richest profession in Britain.

Of these conflicts, the most specific concerns his power of appointment. Single-handedly he can shuffle the senior judges, promote the appellate judges, appoint the lower judges and make or break every lawyer whose ambition stops at the circuit bench. What barrister, hoping to advance his claims, might not have been impressed by the desirability of responding positively to Derry's appeal for Labour funds? Who could fail to be struck by the redefinition of the judicial climate his begging letter appeared to authorise?

This specific concern has a simple answer, which is to revert to the commitment Labour once made to hand judicial appointment to an independent commission, free of control by a member of the cabinet. Irvine, who supported this in opposition and rejected it in government, has now driven it far up the agenda for the next parliament. How else can the standing of the judiciary be maintained, after the present sole appointer has shown himself so indifferent to the impartiality that's the key to judicial standing in the first place?

The general message is more telling. For the indifference is not particular but pervasive. The entire system of government finds it hard to grasp the meaning of impartiality. It simply cannot see the point. Revealing his constitutional illiteracy, Alastair Campbell said there was no difference between Irvine raising party money and Tony Blair doing the same thing. Where New Labour is concerned, normal proprieties are not meant to apply, not because they've ceased to be proper but because this inclusive government somehow transcends them. The new norm is New Labour by definition. Much the same rubric applied when Greg Dyke, despite having made a huge donation to the Labour party, was put in charge of that other bastion of impartiality, the BBC.

Someone called lord chancellor could still survive. The law lords, after all, are overworked and undermanned. They need him as a judge. But he should not be head of the judiciary, so long as he's a minister. His political work should be handed to a ministry of justice, accountable in the Commons not the Lords, with the appointments commission as guardian of the judges. For centuries the paradox the office embodied, its sublime non-separation of powers, may have been sustainable. It falls to Lord Irvine to show with welcome crudity that this is no longer so.

The new culture has no time for the old rules. It reminds me of what the US supreme court did to itself to get George Bush declared president. But unlike America, where the tainted court soldiers on, we have a remedy. The office, being putrefied, can be buried, with the incumbent in all his finery as first gravedigger.

webTitle: David Lacey marks Eriksson's England card

fields.headline: Pick of the crop
fields.standfirst: David Lacey marks Eriksson's England card
fields.trailText: David Lacey marks Eriksson's England card.
fields.body:
GOALKEEPERS

Old favourites

David Seaman (Arsenal)

A good England career but should have taken Tony Adams' hint and retired

Wild cards

Nigel Martyn (Leeds)

He will hope Romania in Euro 2000 was an isolated blip; so will England

Young guns

Paul Robinson (Leeds)

Excelled as Nigel Martyn's deputy and will be capped sooner rather than later

Richard Wright (Ipswich)

Tord Grip likes his powers of anticipation,making spectacular saves unnecessary

Lost his Grip?

David James (Aston Villa)

Much improved but still an accident waiting to happen,and too much of a risk

DEFENDERS

Old favourites

Gary Neville (Man Utd)

He is very experienced but now an international risk at right-back

Sol Campbell (Tottenham)

Still limited going forward but a class centre-back all the same

Wild cards

Michael Gray (Sunderland)

Not a success under Keegan but he may be worth another look now

Danny Mills (Leeds)

Lacking international quality but his versatility gives him a chance

Phil Neville (Man Utd)

Not in the United side lately but Eriksson will have him filed in his mental index

Young guns

Rio Ferdinand (Leeds)

Good going forward but has yet to prove himself an England defender

Wes Brown (Man Utd)

A favourite with Eriksson and Grip and may come in now at right-back

Gareth Barry (Aston Villa)

Best on the left of the three-man defence Eriksson is hardly,if ever, going to field

John Terry (Chelsea)

Impressive but needs another season before he can think about England

Titus Bramble (Ipswich)

Outstanding for Ipswich this season but probably needs more time

Ashley Cole (Arsenal)

Has remarkable composure for his age but needs more experience

Lost his Grip?

Stuart Pearce (West Ham)

Still one of the Premiership's best defenders but England must look ahead

Lee Dixon (Arsenal)

Ten years younger and he'd walk in at right-back - but not now

MIDFIELDERS

Old favourites

David Beckham (Man Utd)

A world-class crosser but ordinary in central midfield

Paul Scholes (Man Utd)

Should now have the chance to play off a striker,probably Emile Heskey

Steve McManaman (Real Madrid)

Real talent for Madrid but wasted wide on the left for England

Nick Barmby (Liverpool)

Nimble of foot and thought,his industry may appeal to Eriksson

Paul Ince (Middlesbrough)

Forgettable Euro 2000 but has revived since Venables took over at Boro

Wild cards

Paul Merson (Aston Villa)

The England man who never was but his good form for Villa is worth a mention

Frank Lampard (West Ham)

Floundered under Keegan but still has good vision and delivery, plus a strong shot

Gavin McCann (Sunderland)

Long-odds but, in an ingenuous Sunderland midfield, shows imagination

Young guns

Kieron Dyer (Newcastle)

Exceptional pace could see him on the right although best position is central

Jamie Carragher (Liverpool)

Option at back of midfield in absence of Gerrard

Michael Carrick (West Ham)

Long-shot but his willingness to go box-to-box makes him a great prospect

Joe Cole (West Ham)

Wunderkind has added impressive body strength to his skills and an England chance will come soon

Lost his Grip?

Darren Anderton (Tottenham)

Surely gone and forgotten where England are concerned

Dennis Wise (Chelsea)

Indian summer for England saw few bright periods amid many a scattered shower

STRIKERS

Old favourites

Robbie Fowler (Liverpool)

Could yet be England's best chance of World Cup qualification, if he stays fit

Andy Cole (Man Utd)

Still hard to ignore but has probably blown it in terms of an England career

Teddy Sheringham (Man Utd)

Nudging 35 but is still difficult to ignore on his form and goals this season

Wild cards

Kevin Phillips (Sunderland)

Would have had an international career had Niall Quinn been English.

Young guns

Michael Owen (Liverpool)

Those two goals in Rome last week could not have come at a better time

Emile Heskey (Liverpool)

Anfield academy has added better technique to his speed and strength, and goals have followed

Lost his Grip?

Stan Collymore (Oviedo)

Maybe Stan thinks he should be in Eriksson's first squad. No harm in thinking

 Not considered (Injured)

Steven Gerrard

Gareth Southgate

Martin Keown
