webTitle: Egg shelves current account

fields.headline: Egg shelves current account
fields.standfirst:
Online bank vows to break even despite widening losses

More net news
Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Online bank vows to break even despite widening losses.
fields.body:
Egg, the internet bank, announced yesterday that it had delayed indefinitely its plans to launch a current account and reported a widening of its losses.

The company, majority owned by Prudential, insisted it would break even later this year for the first time despite losses worsening by £6m to £155m in 2000.

Customer "inertia" in the current account market, where more than 70% of the business is controlled by Lloyds TSB, NatWest, HSBC and Barclays, deterred Egg from launching a new account. "We've built the capability for a current account. If new entrants are able to smash the inertia we'll launch it. I don't think any of them have yet," Paul Gratton, the chief executive, said.

He said Egg wanted to be a "fast follower" and capitalise upon any success achieved by the Halifax in trying to shake-up the current market where only 500,000 customers a year out of 30m move their account.

"We smashed the savings and credit card markets," Mr Gratton said. But the current account market appears too tough for Egg to crack. He said advertising for current account customers "seemed an expensive way to blow a lot of money".

Last year Egg, which has "global ambitions", spent £50m developing its brand through another series of quirky adverts. According to Nielsen/NetRatings, Egg's website - egg.com - was busier than any other financial services site in January, reaching almost 6% of active users.

Egg will only start to make profits once it has sold more than one product to each of its 1.3m customers and is expected to start concentrating on achieving that this year.

Last year Egg's "cross-sales" were 1.29 products per customer last year. To reach breakeven, that figure needs to rise to 1.5 by the end of the year - a target Mr Gratton said Egg could achieve.

Analysts at Fox-Pitt, Kelton said they remained sceptical about Egg's plans. "The critical issue is can Egg cross-sell and the fourth quarter is frankly very disappointing," the analysts said, predicting Egg would fail to achieve its aim of breaking even this year.

Egg, which was swamped by new business when it was launched two years ago, claimed January was its busiest month ever when 100,000 customers took out new products, particularly its credit card. This rate of new customers was another reason why Egg had decided not to advertise for current account business. "You don't kill a campaign when it's going well," said Mr Gratton.

He also pointed to the prospects of breaking even by highlighting the quadrupling in revenues to £93.2m and the fact that Egg would be spending less than the £34m it spent last year on developing new products and facilities.

Egg's first product, its saving account, suffered a £850m outflow of money as customers chased better rates although the outflow slowed between the third and fourth quarters.

The company said it had plans to be global and is talking to a number of companies in Europe, in particular, about forming partnerships similar to the one it has with Boots for its credit card. It also has a loans and mortgages business as well "supermarket" sites for investment and insurance products and will launch one for mortgages later this month.

The company's shares ended the day at 132.5p, down 1p - still below the 160p at which they made their debut in May last year.

webTitle: Peter Preston on the legal retirement age

fields.headline: Old enough to know better
fields.standfirst:
The government is to abolish the age of compulsory retirement. Great news, says Peter Preston, but the British are still too ready to write people off as past it

Work site
fields.trailText: The government is to abolish the age of compulsory retirement. Great news, but the British are still too ready to write people off as past it.
fields.body:
Consider the dislocation. Baroness (Margaret) Jay will be retiring from the cabinet and politics this spring. The leader of the House of Lords is 61, way past her bus pass birthday. She is, it was solemnly explained the other day, the second-oldest member of Tony Blair's top team and wishes to spend more time with her grandchildren. Maybe, when she does, she'll jet out of Heathrow as President Bush's newly appointed secretary for defence jets in and give him a glance. Donald Rumsfeld is 68. George W has just given him a post he first held (for Gerald Ford) in 1976.

Nothing about age - even as it relates to those who make our laws and order our lives - makes any sense. Is William Hague, at 39, more widely revered than Ken Clarke at 60? When pundits look at the next Tory leadership stakes, they tend to dismiss Malcolm Rifkind (54) as a blast from the past. But George Bush the younger is 54. All we have here is assumptions and attitudes. Praise be that, at last, they are under the microscope.

Grinding into line with Europe, our government has just decided to outlaw any benchmark for involuntary retirement. Farewell to the rigid absurdities of 60, 65 - or even the big 50 (which so many employers still think signals the onset of senility). Welcome to the chance to work and earn on, to life beyond the finality of a pensions' slip.

There is, of course, no altruism here. Britain, like the rest of Europe, is ageing fast. People are healthier and living longer - but birth rates are plummeting. Italy and Spain are crucially short of babies, nations shrinking inexorably, failing to replace themselves. And, for all the angst over teenage mums, we are contracting and wizening, too. In actuarial terms, that is hopeless. An ever-smaller working population cannot support the swelling ranks of the retired.

But it is also a terrible waste. When you read that one-third of men and women aged between 50 and 65 (a cool 2.8m people) have chosen or are condemned to an "economic inactivity" which costs £26bn a year, you see the essential challenge: expand that working population by expanding the age span of work. Back to attitudes and assumptions.

Some jobs, of course, have a finite physical stretch. There will be no £3m a season for David Beckham at 35. City dealers under constant pressure notoriously burn themselves out ("I want to make enough now for when I'm 40 and a postman," one said to me recently). But particular problems lack general application.

Whatever happened to your friendly local bank manager? I can tell you what happened to mine. He looked in gloom as the branches were closed and merged around him, as his fortysomething brothers were put out to grass, and he worried himself sick about what would happen when he was 50. Inevitably, the axe fell. He got a lump sum and a topped-up pension. And where, three years later, is he today? Working as many days a week for the same bank, bringing experience to bear: paid on contract and, with pension, enjoying the toil of "early retirement".

Whichever way you cut it, that must be economic rubbish. Yet, through the 80s and 90s, it has been the underlying assumption of so much business hiring and firing. Young is beautiful; grey is ghastly. There's a symbolic virility to spitting out a generation ahead of its time. Hand-in-hand with that, moreover, has gone another equally dodgy assumption - which is that retirement is a lustrous, easeful era full of rest from labours and enjoyment of wider pastures.

Trade unions, remember, embraced ever earlier retirement as a benefit, not a penalty. They negotiated better terms, not first principles, and they tended to see extra years with your feet up as just as desirable as a salary rise, a suitable case for settlement. Strangely, almost symbiotically, psychological wear and tear seemed to increase as the retirement age came down. Because policemen, say, were supposed to be past it in their 40s, that decade of their life became prey to sickness, depression and chronic absenteeism. Another self-fulfilling prophecy.

Now, perhaps, this whole mindset is out of time and out of fashion. Ministries plead with the nurses of the 70s, who have raised their families, to come back to the wards - and to dedicated teachers to stay in the classroom. A civil service that lowers the boom at 60 looks increasingly stupid. Why pay a cabinet secretary to depart at the height of his powers to run an Oxford college or sit on a dozen lucrative boards? Why arbitrarily strip away at the talent you have, and find damned difficult to replace?

Slowly, too slowly, we are beginning to see this issue in the round. People are people, which means people are different. Some will, indeed, embrace the chance to escape and vegetate or do fresh things with the rest of their lives; but some, very definitely, will not - will feel, instead, that they have much to contribute and that continued contributing is one definition of their existence.

They will not, necessarily, want to plough exactly the same furrow, but they will want to keep working. And society, as we see, needs them to keep working: an obligation as much as an imposition.

I'm not, for heaven's sake, arguing for another kind of inflexibility. Fresh generations always need their turn and there's nothing more disheartening than to go back to a nation and government you knew 30 years ago and find (as I did last year) exactly the same master politician, now 82, still in charge and surrounded by exactly the same acolytes.

That isn't progress, in the sense that seeing Shimon Peres (77) back in charge of Israeli foreign affairs, or Ariel Sharon (72) finally running the whole shooting match, isn't progress. Yet individual cases, individually chosen, shed a quite separate light.

Picture a movie industry without the inexhaustible Robert Altman (76 today), or even Britain's secondhand chance of an Oscar from the Gladiator, Ridley Scott (63). Hannibal Hopkins is 63 and may soon need his dentures. Picture a theatre without Michael Frayn (67), Tom Stoppard (63), Peter Hall (70) or the 70-year-old Harold Pinter. Picture such an empire as News International without Rupert Murdoch (69) or the wise man he keeps close by, Edward Pickering (88). Who wants a Daily Telegraph without Bill Deedes (87), a Tate exhibition without Peter Blake (67), or a Newcastle United without Bobby Robson (68)?

While the BBC witters about relegating newsreaders when they turn 50, the American networks are still fronted by Dan Rather's 60s generation. India's rulers go into politics after they retire from whatever they were doing before. Nelson Mandela is 82.

Our government, at last, is asking the questions and pondering the answers, consulting while Help the Aged applauds. But this, I think, isn't simply a pressure group issue - and seeing it that way constrains too narrowly.

webTitle: Dance review: La Fille Mal Gardée

fields.headline: La Fille Mal Gardée
fields.standfirst:
Alhambra Theatre
Bradford
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Alhambra Theatre
Bradford
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Birmingham Royal Ballet's production of Frederick Ashton's bucolic classic is a dream for wannabe ballerinas of any age - I and the five-year-old in front of me were transfixed. The farmyard capers, colourful folk dances and intricate choreography for Lise and her sweetheart, Colas, are enchanting. Osbert Lancaster's cartoon set, with dreamy water-meadows and a wacky farmhouse kitchen, is as fresh as it was in 1960, when this version was premiered. The whole thing looks like an Old Master recently cleaned, the costumes full of Watteau blues and pastels. Artistic director David Bintley has sharpened up the action and his corps looked as if they were having a ball. No bored yokels here.

American principal Molly Smolen gave us a pert and teasing Lise, strong on comic expression, especially when she is discovered dreaming of marriage and motherhood. She's also a gifted technician and flitted impressively through the bravura allegro passages. She was cheerfully partnered by Tiit Helimets, with dashing elevation and powerful, centred spins. (Both danced for the Estonian National Ballet before joining BRB.) She taps across the stage on pointes with machine-gun rapidity, while he gets airborne or hoists her into spectacular one-handed lifts.

Young farmers might do it in their wellies, but Colas gets his girl with haberdashery. Yards of pink ribbon tie the knot of love and he entwines her in an elaborate cat's cradle. We get even more ribbons in the maypole dance, but the zenith is the cartwheel created by the country girls, with Smolen as the hub.

That character gem, Widow Simone, the original mother from hell, was in the masterful hands of veteran David Morse. With more than a hint of Hilda Ogden, he gave us a bird-like dame, beady eyes missing nothing. He ripped through the clog dance with glee, tweaking at his cardi and hoofing up a storm. Fille has other wonderful grotesques: the vineyard owner Thomas, a suitably lecherous Alain Dubreuil; and Alain, his nice-but-dim son, danced by Timothy Cross - fleet of foot and strong on pathos. When, jilted, he offers his giant diamond ring to us in desperation, you almost wish he'd got the girl.

 At the Empire, Sunderland (0191-514 2517), on March 16 and 17.

webTitle: Pop review: EAR

fields.headline: Spitz invaded by geese from outer space
fields.standfirst:
EAR
Spitz
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
EAR
Spitz
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
EAR is short for Experimental Audio Research, a name that neatly describes what you get, visually: one man on stage, his back to the audience, hunched over five primitive-looking gadgets, all chunky knobs and flashing lights, like something out of the BBC Radiophonic Workshop. The fact that it's Pete Kember up there makes it significant: not for nothing have people travelled from as far as Poland to hear this.

For most of the 1980s, Kember was known as Sonic Boom; he was one half of Spacemen 3, whose other mainstay was Jason Pierce, later of Spiritualized. Although the group fell apart in 1990 (their last album, Recurring, saw the pair record their own compositions in separate studios), their psychedelic drone-rock anticipated much of the best music of the next decade, from the Verve to Labradford. Since then, Sonic Boom has released a dozen albums as Spectrum or as EAR, the latter a loose collective whose revolving-door policy has seen contributions from Kevin Shields of My Bloody Valentine and Eddie Prevost of AMM.

For this show, however, Kember is solo, and creating one long piece of untitled music. Because he's in DIY mode tonight, he's also got his own CD stall by the door, from behind which he explains his methods to a steady stream of awestruck autograph-hunters before the show. The piece will be a one-off and entirely improvised, he says. The modular synthesizers comprise hundreds of components that can be configured in many ways. The performance requires deep concentration; he compares it to spinning plates. For him it is "a religious experience".

This composition ebbs and flows, rises and falls, builds to a climax before dissolving into silence. At the 10-minute mark, Sonic Boom's transmissions include rocket whooshes, lunar static and sonar bleeps; at 20 minutes, what could be a swarm of geese in outer space pans across the stereo range; at 30 minutes, the menacing hum of a 23rd-century tank; at 45 minutes, we seem to have picked up a cloudburst on Venus. By the end, some people are apparently attempting to unravel the complex, structureless nature of what they've just heard, while others have nodded out completely.

webTitle: Jazz review: John Etheridge

fields.headline: John Etheridge
fields.standfirst:
College Grove Sports Club
Wakefield
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
College Grove Sports Club
Wakefield
Rating: ****
fields.body:
For guitarist John Etheridge, this gig must have been like slipping on a comfortable old pair of shoes. Having spent his formative years touring and recording with the late Stéphane Grappelli, he has elected to take this affectionate tribute show on the road. The ace up his sleeve, however, is the up-and-coming violin superstar Christian Garrick. Garrick was last seen in these parts with the Gary Potter quartet, a gig that had him playing second fiddle to a technically accomplished show-off. Here, his playing was allowed to flower peacefully in a garden of musical colour, fertilised and nurtured by Etheridge's maturity and sense of restraint. Rhythm guitarist Dave Kelbie and bassist Malcolm Creese provided a strong, swinging foundation, and the group whipped through a toe-tapping assortment of Grappelli tunes, as well as tracks from Etheridge's new Sweet Chorus album and the odd Django Reinhardt song.

Etheridge gleefully showed off Garrick at every opportunity. Garrick uses his violin to evoke a permanent sense of surprise, often sounding like an excited child opening presents on Christmas morning. When he solos, he seems to go beyond the jazz idiom, entering the hallowed realm of the classical cadenza and leaving his fellow musicians staring in wonder. Wonderful though they are, Garrick's effervescent flights of fancy lack the darker, bluesier undertones that characterise Etheridge's playing. The guitarist's facial expressions suggest that every note is being torn from his soul, but the overall effect was effortlessly transporting. It is music that demands that you close your eyes and listen, for only then can the ethereal nature of what is being played stand separate from the physical reality of darting fingers and blurred plectrums.

The concert was given in a spirit of good- humour. Later on, Garrick threw in a few bars of the theme from Parkinson, a self-deprecating reference to his recent appearance on the show. But the biggest laughs were inspired by Etheridge's glorious Grappelli anecdotes, which convey his admiration for the man.

webTitle: Working lives: Learning at work

fields.headline: Richard Reeves
fields.standfirst:
The only skill we really need is the ability to learn. And we do that best on the job, not in class

Work site
fields.trailText: The only skill we really need is the ability to learn. And we do that best on the job, not in class.
fields.body:
"I love to learn," said Oscar Wilde, "I just can't bear to be taught." Today, though, we cannot move for teachers of one sort or another - personal trainers, mentors, gurus, consultants. Companies are striving to become "learning organisations". Even Who Wants to be a Millionaire? puts a new premium on learnedness. The market for imparting information is booming, with "webucation" the latest vehicle.

Yet real learning remains a deeply personal experience, and an everyday activity. While schools, colleges and courses are seen as the principal sites of learning, it is at work that the steepest learning curves are conquered. We used to learn, then earn. Now we learn as we earn.

Helen Handfield-Jones, who has just polled 6,000 senior US executives for McKinsey concludes that "the kind of training that really makes a difference has nothing to do with programs and everything to do with the informal training that goes on within companies".

We learn best from doing, rather than listening. Some of the best-paid computer programmers in the business are school drop-outs; they learned from hours voluntarily spent glued to a screen. The government has announced that some employees are to get a day off a week for "training", which is commendable. But it would be better if they were learning on the other four days.

We spend most of our waking hours at work - it is what engages our minds and energies. Once you can do a job without too much difficulty, it gets boring, and satisfaction leads inexorably to dissatisfaction.

Handfield-Jones recommends that "people with high potential should move through a series of challenging jobs, for after two or three years the learning curve in any position tends to flatten out, and capable people start to chafe". Research from the Institute of Personnel Directors confirms that job satisfaction declines over time. Talent has to be kept on its toes.

Jobs are, in any case, changing too rapidly to let us stop learning. What really counts is not the possession of a chunk of knowledge, but the ability to rejuvenate and update skills. Javier Bajer, who heads The Talent Foundation, a charity that works to improve learning skills, says our preoccupation with courses and technical skills is misplaced. "What matters most of all is having the emotional capacity and desire to learn," he says. "Technical skills are disposable - we have to be ready to drop them and pick up new ones."

Many years ago I dropped a law degree course in favour of geography, causing mild parental consternation: "What will you do with a geography degree?" I could never answer that question. But the point was that I experienced the thrill of pursuing ideas that interested me. And work can continue to provide those opportunities - I have certainly learned more from my work than from any course in anything.

But learning at work requires a new mindset from workers and firms. It means we as individuals have to have the courage to admit ignorance: remember the Chinese proverb that someone who asks the question is a fool for a day, while the one who never asks is a fool for ever. It also requires companies to reform cultures and performance systems that currently force people to maintain a knowing facade, so that asking "stupid" questions is seen for what it really is - as a sign of intelligence and intellectual curiosity.

The paramount skill required in the new economy - the capacity to learn - means that the best course to take is ancient history, if ancient history is what turns you on. Paradoxically, the old-fashioned idea of "learning for learning's sake" is precisely what the new world of work requires.

The Orwellian rhetoric of the modern corporation can hinder effective communication. One large chocolate retailer, for example, bans the use of the word "problem". Every problem, executives intone, is an opportunity in disguise. One new recruit, on his second day in the job, rang his boss and said: "I've got a problem." Boss: "No you haven't. Weren't you listening to the induction course? Ring me back in five minutes with an opportunity." Recruit (five minutes later): "I've got an opportunity." Boss: "That's better. What is it?" Recruit: "I have the opportunity to get a new company car." Boss: "How so?" Recruit: "I've just written off the one you gave me."

 Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society.

Weren't you listening to the induction course? Ring me back in five minutes with an opportunity." Recruit (five minutes later): "I've got an opportunity." Boss: "That's better. What is it?" Recruit: "I have the opportunity to get a new company car." Boss: "How so?" Recruit: "I've just written off the one you gave me."  Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. rreeves@indsoc.co.uk work@theguardian.com

webTitle: Phoney mortgage wars

fields.headline: Phoney mortgage wars
fields.standfirst: Marianne Curphey on the reasoning behind the Nationwide's decision to cut mortgage rates
fields.trailText: Marianne Curphey on the reasoning behind the Nationwide's decision to cut mortgage rates.
fields.body:
The decision by Nationwide, the country's biggest building society, to cut its mortgage rates for existing customers is being portrayed as the start of a mortgage war. Don't be fooled. Your bank or building society is not about to suffer as a result of its generosity to you.

If you've got savings you'll know that the best rate you can get on your cash in an average instant access account is just under 5% - with a few accounts around 5.3%.

In general, mortgage lenders routinely keep a healthy gap between savings rates and mortgage rates. They have in the past been swifter to cut savings rates after a cut in the base rate by the Bank of England than they have to cut mortgage rates. This delay in reducing the mortgage rates helps keep their margins - and their profits - healthy.

In addition, the best mortgage rates are available to new, rather than existing customers. This is one of the reasons behind the recent boom in remortgaging. As customers become more financially astute, they recognise that by staying loyal to their bank or building society they are actually getting a worse deal than if they switched lenders every couple of years and shopped around for the best rates.

This is why Nationwide's announcement is good news for its existing customers, and why it is also commercially a smart move. Loyal borrowers will be able to benefit from the same special deals on standard variable mortgage rates as new customers. Nationwide has identified that people are becoming much keener to chase the best mortgage rates. It has already seized the savings initiative on the internet by offering one of the best bank accounts on the web.

As more and more people become accustomed to using the internet as a search tool, they will be able to shop around more quickly and more easily for remortgage deals. This will put more pressure on lenders to extend their best deals to existing, rather than new customers. The mortgage war started long ago - not on the high street, but on the internet.

Marianne Curphey is editor of Guardian Unlimited's Money website at www.theguardian.com/money. She is the author of E-Cash, a complete guide to managing your money, bank account, mortgage and investments online.

webTitle: Knives are out on mortgage rates

fields.headline: At last the big lenders advance
fields.standfirst:
Knives are out on mortgage rates

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Notebook: Knives are out on mortgage rates.
fields.body:
Believe it or not, we have some real competition kicking off in the business of financing homes. The moves by the Nationwide - and Halifax this morning - are a new twist in the battle among financial services providers struggling to retain customers in a mortgage market where one in three "remortgages" every seven years.

For years the big lenders have complained about fierce competition in the mortgage market; only two years ago Standard Life Bank was causing havoc with its low rates. But now we have evidence that it is beginning to hurt. Perhaps they have learned that winning customers back is harder than losing them.

The cost of cutting mortgage rates so substantially will be particularly painful for Halifax, which warned six months ago that it expected its margin on mortgages to shrink by 10% during 2001. Now the City knows precisely why.

It is possible that the stock market will punish Halifax this morning. It is important to remember, however, that it does not spell the end of profitability for Halifax or any other of the leading lenders which still have a big gap to close if they are to make their headline rates competitive with small, nimble rivals.

A generalised margin squeeze across financial products of all flavours has been factored in for some time now.

It is nonetheless bewildering that such an aggressive move by two of the industry's major players has taken so long to arrive.

Browne study

There was an unusual display of peevishness from the venerable Sir John Browne at the weekend, with the BP chief executive seemingly upset that last week, when the former oil firm delivered the biggest annual profit ever produced by a British company, his share price dropped and everyone starting demonising Big Oil for earning too much money.

Well, the executive had reason to cheer up yesterday as a 3% drop in the market capitalisation of Vodafone and a 2% gain in BP's share price left Sir John's baby at the top of the European corporate tree. Valued at £13bn, it is the biggest company in Europe.

BP, in its current form, is very much Sir John's creation. It is leanly managed, global, (relatively) well diversified; it is throwing heavy money at new energy sources, such as solar power; and it is ultra-conscious of its social and environmental responsibilities. All in all, BP is something of a model modern multi-national, which also happens to be British.

Sir John's moment of opportunity proved to be three years ago when, as the oil price spiralled lower, BP responded by leading the wave of consolidation which has since transformed the industry. In its wake, the company left a trail of empty office suites across America as bloated executives were ordered to go and spend their obscene share option packages on a beach somewhere.

As trading conditions improved (in the form of a higher oil price), profitability skipped ahead. Simple as that.

On occasions, merger and takeovers work spectacularly well. BP's example will be studied for years to come.

Red alert

As will Vodafone, that other British corporate heavyweight, which has established itself as Europe's finest in the field of telephony by being fastest off the starting blocks in the race to grab new mobile markets.

It has been warned here and elsewhere over recent months to stop doing deals and to work on integration and the delivery of the technology instead. But, markets being markets, the mood has already turned, leaving Vodafone little time in which to heed any advice.

Yesterday, analysts were making the fair observation that, if BT can be forced towards radical dismemberment by its own lack of financial foresight, then Vodafone must surely have problems of its own.

The company managed a huge back-door rights issue by buying Mannesmann complete with Orange and then selling Orange on to France Télécom. Its gearing problem is nothing like that faced by BT.

But it does have around £17bn of debt, which it plans to shrink by £7bn through the sale of its Italian fixed-line business, Infostrada, to the local electricity firm Enel. That deal is now in doubt, due to regulatory problems surrounding Enel.

Throw in the fact that someone kicked off a rumour yesterday that a radical cost-cutting plan was being hatched at the company's Newbury headquarters, amid worries that year-end profits might not meet the City's best expectations, and ... Well, it would be rash to suggest chief executive Chris Gent does not know exactly what he is doing.

webTitle: Rate cut sparks mortgage war

fields.headline: Rate cut sparks mortgage war
fields.standfirst:
Halifax poised to cut cost of borrowing after Nationwide lays down challenge

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Halifax, Britain's biggest mortgage lender, is expected to cut the cost of borrowing today - escalating a mortgage war among high street lenders.
fields.body:
Halifax, Britain's biggest mortgage lender, is expected to cut the cost of borrowing today - escalating a mortgage war among high street lenders.

The first shot was fired yesterday by the Nationwide, the country's biggest building society, which unveiled a new basic mortgage rate of 6.49% - about 1% lower than the standard variable rate of its rivals - and accused the high street banks of overcharging by £1bn.

For a homeowner paying a £60,000 interest-only mortgage the rate cut would mean average savings of about £30 a month.

The move provoked a swift response. Today the Halifax, which has 2.5m customers, will announce a cut in its borrowing rate from 7.5% to 6.75% from March 1.

By cutting their rates, the two lenders are substantially widening the gap on their rivals which are offering standard variable rates, paid by around half of all homeowners, as much as one percentage point higher at 7.5%. They might also fuel house price rises by making it cheaper to borrow.

Nationwide said about 3m borrowers, with mortgages totalling £100bn, were on standard mortgage rates.

The moves reflect the increasingly competitive nature of the mortgage market. One in three new home loans is merely a customer moving their mortgage to a bank or building society with a more attractive rate than their current lender.

Both the Halifax and Nationwide are desperately trying to keep their customers and deter them from being lured to rivals.

Many high street names are offering cheap deals for new customers while keeping current borrowers on high rates. The Nationwide and Halifax intend to make their rates available to all customers to banish this discrepancy.

Brian Davis, Nationwide's chief executive, tried to up the ante in the mortgage market, saying: "If the banks don't look after their borrowers they will lose them. Nobody should be paying 7.5% on their mortgage and now nobody needs to. Get a better deal from your lender or come to Nationwide."

Rivals mocked the building society's move. Abbey National, the second largest lender, said of Nationwide's package: "It is extremely complicated."

The Woolwich, now owned by Barclays, said Nationwide was "undercutting" the market. It added that customers were free to remortgage to a better deal if they wanted.

At mortgage broker Charcol, Siobhan Hotten said that while the Nationwide's move was "great news" for many of its customers it was unlikely to win it much new business.

Rivals are also certain to point out that while Nationwide and Halifax are focusing their attention on standard variable rates, an increasing number of homeowners are on specialised deals, such as fixed or discounted rates.

Even with its mortgage rate cut, City analysts calculated that the Nationwide's rate was still profitable. They said the lenders' rate is still above the Bank of England's base rate of 5.75% and none have improved the rates on savings.

As a building society, the Nationwide's members will carry the cost of the reduction, while Halifax's shareholders will be expected to take the hit.

The former building society, which became a bank four years ago, is due to publish its profits figures today. It has already warned the City that it expects its profits margins to be damaged by a battle for customers.

Halifax's existing 2.5m customers who want to take advantage of the new rate will not automatically be transferred but have to apply. The company refused to comment.
